'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2012/07/10/is-florida-headed-for-a-sellers-market/'), ('pubDate', 'Tue, 10 Jul 2012 14:41:00 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=4')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', '<span class="submit">Original Post date: July 10, 2012\nArticle by: Anonymous</span>\n<div class="content">\n\nThe subtitle of a recent Miami Herald Business Monday (6/18/2012) article read: “South Florida\'s real estate market suffers from depressed prices and low inventory [emphasis added].” With an average decrease of 49% in real estate values from the housing peak in 2006, perhaps suffering is an appropriate term –unless you are looking to buy. With prices so low, demand has increased; however, some homeowners, including those who borrowed too much during the Housing Bubble at peak prices, seem unwilling to sell unless the need arises. As the supply of available houses constricts, real estate values have increased. Miami’s 4% increase from prices six months ago is the second largest rebound in the nation, following Phoenix, suggesting the Florida housing market has bottomed out from the Great Recession (Miami Herald, 6/21/2012).\n\nStill, not everyone is optimistic. Some within the real-estate market are still skeptical that the rebound is permanent. With the Florida housing market representing almost 30% of all foreclosures in the U.S. (towards the end of 2011), perhaps the case for skepticism against reaching the price bottom should be taken seriously. Banks have yet to flood the market with previously foreclosed homes but, with the nearly 1.1 million distressed sales in Florida, the potential for a significant increase in available homes for resale is still there to offset the rising effects of demand on home prices.\n\nWhat does this all mean for new home construction? Well, currently the confidence level among U.S builders has reached a five-year high according to the National Association of Home Builders/Wells Fargo builder sentiment index. Nevertheless, builder confidence is still nowhere near the level it was during the housing boom. Florida home construction is likely to remain well below pre-bubble peaks for quite a while.\n\n</div>'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '4'), ('wp:post_date', '2012-07-10 14:41:00'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2012-07-10 14:41:00'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'is-florida-headed-for-a-sellers-market'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', [OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'florida'), ('#text', 'Florida')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'housing'), ('#text', 'Housing')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'housing'), ('#text', OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_path'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', 'For Whom the Road Rolls (Me or Thee?)'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2012/09/05/for-whom-the-road-rolls-me-or-thee/'), ('pubDate', 'Wed, 05 Sep 2012 14:59:00 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=6')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', '<span class="submit">Original post date: September 05, 2012\nArticle by: Sam Staley</span>\n<div class="content">\n\nA catchy little tune is making its way around the Internet, lambasting the tolls levied by <a href="http://dullesgreenway.com/">the Dulles Greenway</a>. \xa0 The Greenway is a privately developed, owned, and financed extension of the Dulles Tollroad (which is publicly owned and operated). The song, “<a href="http://www.wtop.com/41/3021414/Song-calls-Dulles-Greenway-tolls-highway-robbery-VIDEO">Highway Robbery</a>,” laments the toll rates drives have to pay to use the facility:\n\n“They built a road in the countryside\nRolling green hills for miles and miles\nThe farms and the fields no factory\nBut don\'t you dare think you can drive for free\nBecause it\'s highway robbery”\n\nBut, a little cognitive dissonance is embedded in these populist lyrics, since the songwriters also observe:\n\n“Fourteen miles and it\'s nice and smooth\nFrom Leesburg to Dulles you can really move\nDrive everyday but you cry at night\nCause of the price of the toll is out of sight”\n\nSo, the road is a good facility—“nice and smooth” and “you can really move”—but you “cry at night” because the “toll is out of sight.” In essence, the songwriters are complaining because they aren’t getting something for nothing. (Later on, they argue for eliminating the tolls or rolling them back significantly.)\n\nThe Dulles airport corridor is a highly congested part of Northern Virginia, where traffic on “free” roads (really taxpayer funded) slows to a crawl, even during shoulder and sometimes off peak periods. The tolls on the Greenway are essential to not only generate the revenues necessary to fund the facility but also to prioritize access based on willingness to pay.\n\nBut another perhaps even more important issue beyond pure financial management and economics is implicit in the song’s lyrics: Users of the Dulles Greenway should be subsidized by non users. Many roads like the Dulles Greenway serve very specific transportation needs\xa0for targeted travelers. Perhaps the more equitable solution is, in fact, to have the users finance these roads rather than redistribute funds through taxes from those that don’t benefit.\n\nIn the real world, nothing is free, not even roads. We probably need more user fees, not fewer, if we want to sustainably support our transportation network for efficiency and equity reasons.\n\n</div>'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '6'), ('wp:post_date', '2012-09-05 14:59:00'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2012-09-05 14:59:00'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'for-whom-the-road-rolls-me-or-thee'), Forcing Florida Over a Fiscal Cliff'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2012/10/05/municiple-pension-forcing-florida-over-a-fiscal-cliff/'), ('pubDate', 'Fri, 05 Oct 2012 15:22:00 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=8')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'Original post date: October 05, 2012\nArticle by: Anonymous\n\nFlorida public pension programs have become a cause for concern in recent years, and the debate just ramped up with the <a href="http://collinsinstitute.fsu.edu/sites/collinsinstitute.fsu.edu/files/SEP%202012%20Years%20In%20The%20Making%20report.pdf">publication </a><a href="http://collinsinstitute.fsu.edu/sites/collinsinstitute.fsu.edu/files/SEP%202012%20Years%20In%20The%20Making%20report.pdf">of </a><a href="http://collinsinstitute.fsu.edu/sites/collinsinstitute.fsu.edu/files/SEP%202012%20Years%20In%20The%20Making%20report.pdf">a </a><a href="http://collinsinstitute.fsu.edu/sites/collinsinstitute.fsu.edu/files/SEP%202012%20Years%20In%20The%20Making%20report.pdf">new </a><a href="http://collinsinstitute.fsu.edu/sites/collinsinstitute.fsu.edu/files/SEP%202012%20Years%20In%20The%20Making%20report.pdf">report</a> by Florida State University’s Leroy Collins Institute. Florida cities are facing a fiscal cliff on municipal pension funding, and much of it appears to be of their own doing.\n\nThe <a href="http://watchdog.org/57385/fl-report-municipal-public-sector-pension-shortfalls-long-term-and-worsening/">Service </a><a href="http://watchdog.org/57385/fl-report-municipal-public-sector-pension-shortfalls-long-term-and-worsening/">Employees </a><a href="http://watchdog.org/57385/fl-report-municipal-public-sector-pension-shortfalls-long-term-and-worsening/">International </a><a href="http://watchdog.org/57385/fl-report-municipal-public-sector-pension-shortfalls-long-term-and-worsening/">Union</a> claims that the stock market crash in 2008 and the subsequent economic crisis were the events that sent municipal pension funds over the edge. But, the Collins Institute report begs to differ. In <a href="http://collinsinstitute.fsu.edu/sites/collinsinstitute.fsu.edu/files/SEP%202012%20Years%20In%20The%20Making%20report.pdf"><em>Years </em></a><a href="http://collinsinstitute.fsu.edu/sites/collinsinstitute.fsu.edu/files/SEP%202012%20Years%20In%20The%20Making%20report.pdf"><em>in </em></a><a href="http://collinsinstitute.fsu.edu/sites/collinsinstitute.fsu.edu/files/SEP%202012%20Years%20In%20The%20Making%20report.pdf"><em>the </em></a><a href="http://collinsinstitute.fsu.edu/sites/collinsinstitute.fsu.edu/files/SEP%202012%20Years%20In%20The%20Making%20report.pdf"><em>Making</em></a><a href="http://collinsinstitute.fsu.edu/sites/collinsinstitute.fsu.edu/files/SEP%202012%20Years%20In%20The%20Making%20report.pdf"><em>: </em></a><a href="http://collinsinstitute.fsu.edu/sites/collinsinstitute.fsu.edu/files/SEP%202012%20Years%20In%20The%20Making%20report.pdf"><em>Florida</em></a><a href="http://collinsinstitute.fsu.edu/sites/collinsinstitute.fsu.edu/files/SEP%202012%20Years%20In%20The%20Making%20report.pdf"><em>’</em></a><a href="http://collinsinstitute.fsu.edu/sites/collinsinstitute.fsu.edu/files/SEP%202012%20Years%20In%20The%20Making%20report.pdf"><em>s </em></a><a href="http://collinsinstitute.fsu.edu/sites/collinsinstitute.fsu.edu/files/SEP%202012%20Years%20In%20The%20Making%20report.pdf"><em>Underfunded </em></a><a href="http://collinsinstitute.fsu.edu/sites/collinsinstitute.fsu.edu/files/SEP%202012%20Years%20In%20The%20Making%20report.pdf"><em>Municipal</em></a><a href="http://collinsinstitute.fsu.edu/sites/collinsinstitute.fsu.edu/files/SEP%202012%20Years%20In%20The%20Making%20report.pdf"><em>Pension </em></a><a href="http://collinsinstitute.fsu.edu/sites/collinsinstitute.fsu.edu/files/SEP%202012%20Years%20In%20The%20Making%20report.pdf"><em>Plans</em></a>, the Institute points out that Florida pensions were underfunded <em>before</em> the stock market fell and the recent decline only exacerbated an existing problem. The main issue facing Florida’s public pension programs is not a decline in assets, which fund the pensions, but an increase in liabilities—the promised increases in benefits to retirees.\n\nSince the pension programs in Florida operate like a “pay as you go” system in which current contributions fund outgoing benefit payments, incoming pension contributions must be of greater or equal value to the current retiree benefits paid out. Over the last two decades, the amount paid out to retirees has increased, and the age at which they may begin collecting benefits has been lowered. This has led to an overall increase in the amount of funds necessary to cover the municipal pension programs. Unfortunately by 2010, for the first time, total contributions were lower than the total amount paid to retirees.\n\nFlorida has been until recently one of the few states that <a href="http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/2012-09-07/news/fl-high-court-considers-pension-issue-20120906_1_retirement-benefits-retirement-age-public-employees">did </a><a href="http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/2012-09-07/news/fl-high-court-considers-pension-issue-20120906_1_retirement-benefits-retirement-age-public-employees">not </a><a href="http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/2012-09-07/news/fl-high-court-considers-pension-issue-20120906_1_retirement-benefits-retirement-age-public-employees">require </a><a href="http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/2012-09-07/news/fl-high-court-considers-pension-issue-20120906_1_retirement-benefits-retirement-age-public-employees">public </a><a href="http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/2012-09-07/news/fl-high-court-considers-pension-issue-20120906_1_retirement-benefits-retirement-age-public-employees">employees</a> to contribute to their pension plans.\xa0 So, Florida Governor Rick Scott presented a plan to fill the gap by requiring public employees to begin paying 3% of their paychecks towards their pensions (in addition to lowered benefits and a higher retirement age requirement). The news was met with clamorous opposition, especially by unions which filed a legal challenge to stop the governor’s plan, arguing that changing the terms of their contracts was unconstitutional. <a href="http://www.ocala.com/article/20120907/WIRE/120909814">A </a><a href="http://www.ocala.com/article/20120907/WIRE/120909814">final </a><a href="http://www.ocala.com/article/20120907/WIRE/120909814">decision </a><a href="http://www.ocala.com/article/20120907/WIRE/120909814">has </a><a href="http://www.ocala.com/article/20120907/WIRE/120909814">not </a><a href="http://www.ocala.com/article/20120907/WIRE/120909814">yet </a><a href="http://www.ocala.com/article/20120907/WIRE/120909814">been </a><a href="http://www.ocala.com/article/20120907/WIRE/120909814">reached</a><a href="http://www.ocala.com/article/20120907/WIRE/120909814">,</a>but these judicial delays are not helping to alleviate the state’s financial woes.\n\nThe bottom line? The major determinants of the efficiency of Florida’s public pension programs are controllable variables, and this is the point of the Collins Institute study. One can conclude from this information that regardless of the performance of the stock market, the basic funding equation must be balanced for the pension system to work efficiently, and the income from investments is only part of that equation.\xa0 Ultimately, liabilities (the\xa0 promises made to retired public employees) also have to be addressed. In essence, the solution will come down to a trade-off between higher taxes to fund the pension promises, lower benefits to bring spending in line with revenues, or some combination of the two.'), ('#text', 'Florida')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'leroy-collins'), ('#text', 'Leroy Collins')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'pensions'), ('#text', OrderedDict([('title', 'Controversy Over Pension Liabilities May Leave Taxpayers in the Hole'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2012/11/13/controversy-over-pension-liabilities-may-leave-taxpayers-in-the-hole/'), ('pubDate', 'Tue, 13 Nov 2012 15:28:00 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=10')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'Post date: November 13, 2012\nArticle by: Anonymous\n\nA <a href="http://collinsinstitute.fsu.edu/content/lci-releases-latest-report-years-making-floridas-underfunded-municipal-pension-plans">recent report published by the Leroy Collins Institute</a> at Florida State University regarding Florida’s increasingly unfunded public pension plans received some controversial feedback, largely in response to the accounting methods used. <a href="http://robertdklausner.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/12/Response-to-Collins-Study-1900631.pdf">Critiques of the study were published by actuaries</a> who claim that cities’ plans were inaccurately represented by the calculations performed by the Institute. The Governmental Accounting Standards Board (GASB) provides the methods and accounting standards for government agencies, but the Collins Institute argues that the resulting figures are not an accurate portrayal of the relative health of public pension plans.\n\nThe method of accounting used by the Collins Institute is referred to as the <em>market valuation of assets</em>, in which assets are calculated using current market values-the amount for which assets could be sold at the time of measurement. This method reveals the actual value of pension plan investment funds at any given time. Due to market volatility, the resulting figures are not as optimistic as other methods such as the <em>actuarial valuation of assets</em> (see below) but they provide a more accurate representation of the value of assets a pension plan is holding at the time of the valuation. Using these values to make other calculations, such as the funding ratio for promised benefits or the value of unfunded liabilities, produces a good indicator of how a pension plan is doing for policy making purposes, according to the Collins Institute.\n\nRather than using the market value, the actuarial valuation of assets involves forecasting future asset values and the future value of investments is then used to derive an interest rate according to which the assets are discounted. This process is <a href="http://coss.fsu.edu/d6/dmc/content/2.%09http:/www.aei.org/article/economics/retirement/the-market-value-of-public-sector-pension-deficits/">similar to compounding</a> but in reverse. \xa0One problem with this method is that it is difficult to accurately predict what the value of or return on assets will be in the future. Although the actuarial valuation seems like a logical method of calculating, it does leave room for error. Both the estimated benefit and liability figures have been off historically and underestimating the pensionable-salary figure and/or overestimating investment returns can end up costing municipalities and taxpayers a great deal of money.\n\nThe other problem is that the GASB methods encourage riskier investments; higher risk yields higher (expected) returns, and “shifting to a riskier portfolio allows public pensions to use a higher discount rate, instantly improving their funding status,” <a href="http://coss.fsu.edu/d6/dmc/content/1.%09http:/www.aei.org/print/the-accounting-trick-that-will-haunt-public-pensions">according to Andrew Biggs at the American Enterprise Institute</a>. Some may argue that future projections on assets have enough uncertainty already without the assets being high-risk in nature. \xa0Ultimately, retirees may get the benefits they have been promised, but at a higher cost to local governments and taxpayers than is necessary.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '10'), ('wp:post_date', '2012-11-13 15:28:00'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2012-11-13 15:28:00'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'controversy-over-pension-liabilities-may-leave-taxpayers-in-the-hole'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', [OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'fiscal-policy'), ('#text', 'Fiscal Policy')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'florida'), ('#text', 'Florida')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'gasb'), ('#text', 'GASB')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'government-spending'), ('#text', 'Government Spending')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'market-valuation'), ('#text', 'market valuation')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'pensions'), ('#text', 'pensions')])]), ('wp:postmeta', [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_publicize_pending'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_published'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_client_id'), ('wp:meta_value', '-1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_facebook'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_google_plus'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_twitter'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_linkedin'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_tumblr'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_path'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', "Florida's Public Pension Funding #1"), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2012/11/29/floridas-public-pension-funding-1/'), ('pubDate', 'Thu, 29 Nov 2012 15:33:00 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=12')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'Original post date: November 29, 2012 Article by: Anonymous Despite all of the controversy surrounding the soundness of Florida’s public pension programs, a\xa0<a href="http://www.cato.org/pubs/wtpapers/Gokhale-WP-State-and-Local-Pension-Plans.pdf">report by Jagadeesh Gokhale at the Cato Institute</a> recognizes Florida as the number one state in terms of public pension plan health. This may be surprising due to all of the scrutiny Florida’s municipalities have endured over pension funding lately, but comparatively speaking they’re still better off than their counterparts in other states.\n\nWhat has Florida been doing to attain the highest rating? The answer lies in the funding ratio of assets to liabilities. Although retiree benefits (pension liabilities) have increased in recent years, smart investors have secured and managed a stable asset portfolio.\n\nThroughout the recent economic downturn, Florida has managed to maintain adequate funding for its public pension program, according to the Cato Institute. This is in part due to the soundness of the plan before the downturn. (Readers should note not everyone agrees with the Cato Institute, and we have previously commented on the controversy <a href="http://coss.fsu.edu/d6/content/controversy-over-pension-valuations-may-leave-taxpayers-hole">here</a>.) Prior to 2001, Florida had an actuarial surplus of assets to liabilities.\n\nThe Cato Institute named Florida number one after taking into consideration “initial funding conditions with the change in its funding status during the first decade of the twenty-first century.” Although Florida’s public pension plans were hit by the market crash and subsequent economic recession, they were in good health to begin with and the relative decrease in value was not as significant or deleterious as that experienced by other states.\n\nThis is positive news for Floridians, but the concerns of the <a href="http://collinsinstitute.fsu.edu/">Leroy Collins Institute</a> discussed earlier on this blog are not invalid. According to actuarial calculations, Florida’s public pension plan is viable.\n\nHowever, market valuation of pension assets reveals that no state, including Florida, has a fully funded pension program. Even so, Florida’s financial woes have not yet severely affected the level and quality of public services provides to its citizens.\n\nDue to wise investment decisions and an adequate source of funding to cover benefit promises, Florida remains a strong state financially and is coming out of this recession with its head held high. Maintaining this standing will require current pension plan managers to exercise the same prudence as past administrators, while coping with the current state of the market.'), ('excerpt:encoded', '1')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', 'Do Left-Leaning Cities Oppose New Housing?'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2013/02/25/do-left-leaning-cities-oppose-new-housing/'), ('pubDate', 'Mon, 25 Feb 2013 15:35:00 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=14')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'Original post date: February 25, 2013\nArticle by: Anonymous\n\nMatthew E. Kahn of UCLA’s Institute of Environment <a href="http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0094119010000720">concludes in a study published in the <em>Journal of Urban Economics</em></a>that cities with a majority of citizens registered in political parties with liberal tendencies—the Democratic Party, Green Party, and Peach and Freedom Party—issued fewer new housing permits than other cities. Drawing on data from 317 California cities containing nearly three-quarters of the state\'s population, Kahn also found that these cities purchased more hybrid vehicles and were less likely to vote for George W. Bush in the 2000 election. Overall, a 10 percent increase in a city\'s share of liberal voters was associated with a 30% decline in housing permits.\n\nKahn used regression analysis to control for other variables such as per capita income, commuting distance to the central business district, proportion of African-American citizens, and topological features such as mountains. Even when these variables were taken into account, the overwhelming evidence was that liberal cities issued fewer permits.\n\nKahn also found some evidence of a spillover effect in adjacent cities, suggesting the permitting policies of liberal cities may deflect growth to their neighbors. This might be the case, for example, in Berkley\'s neighboring city Emeryville, which has enjoyed sharp growth in commercial and residential real estate.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2013/03/20/the-pope-entrepreneurship-and-human-dignity/'), ('pubDate', 'Wed, 20 Mar 2013 15:39:00 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=16')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'Original post date: March 20, 2013\nArticle by: Sam Staley\n\nThe new Pope may be more sympathetic to entrepreneurship as a way to alleviate poverty than previous pontiffs. He seems to understand that individual freedom and liberty are essential to creating wealth, and entrepreneurship is a crucial element that elevates the poor to become full participants in society. Michael Matheson Miller has a lot more to say on this over at <a href="http://spectator.org/archives/2013/03/18/street-smarts">The American Spectator</a>. A more complete statement by Pope Francis when he was a Cardinal in Argentina can be found <a href="http://www.aicaold.com.ar/index2.php?pag=bergoglio090930">here</a>.\n\nMany people may not realize it, but FSU has a unique, active and extensive student-run program,<a href="http://globalpeaceexchange.org/">Global Peace Exchange</a>, that sponsors and implements economic development programs in low-income countries. Ruth Krug, a fifth-year senior and former co-director of Global Peace Exchange, thinks the Pope doesn’t go far enough. Ruth has worked on entrepreneurship, microfinance, and empowerment projects in India and Uganda and managed projects in Rwanda and Guatemala while traveling even more extensively around the globe. While she is not Catholic or involved in faith-based initiatives (GPE is strictly secular), Ruth said the following after reading comments by the Pope on economic development based on her experiences designing and implementing these programs:\n\n<em>“At one point the Pope said that social activity ‘must be grounded in morality that puts the human person, and not profit or economic growth, at the center.’ And while I agree with this, it\'s about including the poor in the economic growth and profit world that I feel is going to really liberate them. We can\'t run away from economics--it\'s kind of how our world currently operates; so let’s work within the system to make some changes together. Get the poor in the work force, invest in them as entrepreneurs so they can show the world that being ‘poor’ does not mean they are any less capable of supporting a family and living a life of dignity. In the end I feel people need to do it for themselves to really sustain it. God can be a reason you want to pursue the journey, but in the end you need to empower yourself through your own personal strength and believe in yourself to succeed.”</em>\n\nPerhaps we are near a tipping point at understanding the true nature of economic development, and, ultimately, how it relates to social development. Entrepreneurship is about creating social value, validated through the marketplace, and ultimately wealth. But true entrepreneurship can \xa0only be achieved when individuals are free to pursue their own goals and objectives, not those of someone else. Entrepreneurship and human dignity are inevitably intertwined concepts in a thriving and prosperous economy.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '16'), ('wp:post_date', '2013-03-20 15:39:00'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2013-03-20 15:39:00'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'the-pope-entrepreneurship-and-human-dignity'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', [OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'catholicism'), ('#text', 'catholicism')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'economic-development'), ('#text', 'economic development')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'entrepreneurship'), ('#text', 'Entrepreneurship')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'entrepreneurship-2'), ('#text', 'entrepreneurship')]), '1')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', "Buildings Don't Create Permanent Jobs"), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2013/03/22/buildings-dont-create-permanent-jobs/'), ('pubDate', 'Fri, 22 Mar 2013 15:45:00 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=18')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', '<span class="submit">Original post date: March 22, 2013\nArticle by: Sam Staley</span>\n<div class="content">\n\nGaines Street is the "it" place for Tallahassee\'s economic redevelopment initiatives, <a href="http://www.talgov.com/Uploads/Public/Documents/ecd/economic/pdf/fscra_map.pdf">skirting the northern edge </a>of the sourthern border of the Frenchtown/Southside Community Redevelopment Area. With large new projects going up along the corridor--the <a href="http://www.talgov.com/Uploads/Public/Documents/ecd/economic/pdf/fy11_cra_annualrpt.pdf">College Town mixed use project</a> alone is expected to add 72 new residential units, 44,000 square feet of retail, and $18.2 million in "new" real estate value to the district--it\'s easy to get caught up in the excitment of new construction and new buildings and believe that the activity itself is economic development. It\'s not. The construction activity is a byproduct of economic growth, not it\'s cause.\n\nI was reminded of this point when I read an article on another mixed use develoment project in the same corridor. The Deck and the Block are p<a href="http://www.tallahassee.com/article/20130322/BUSINESS/303220008/Gaines-Street-District-mixed-use-development-projects-launched">rojects expected to generate $114 million</a> in new value along the Gaines Street corridor. Here\'s how the <a href="http://www.tallahassee.com/">Tallahassee Democrat</a> described (March 22, 2013, p. 6A) the recent groundbreaking for the Block, the second phase in the development:\n\n<em>Dan Schimberg, president and CEO of Uptown Rental Properties in Cincinnati, Ohio, [and the developer] told the gathering that the projects will generate more than 850 construction jobs and have a permanent economic impact of $17 million. They will produce 157 permanent jobs.</em>\n\nAfter studying economic development for more than 25 years, and teaching classes in urban development for 20, I\'m at a loss to see how a building creates 157 permanent jobs. Buildings don\'t create jobs. The construction of the building will employ many laborers, craftsmen, and professoionals. But these jobs will disappear once the construction is finished. Similarly, how can the construction of a building create a permanent economic impact of $17 million? It can\'t. And it won\'t. We simply need to see the collapse in real estate values in the wake of the Great Recession to see the fallacy of that argument. Value is created by the market, which depends as much on demand as it does suppply.\n\nEconomic development, and the increase in value for the land and buildings in this area to $17 million, will come from the income earned by workers hired to fill positions in industries and businesses other than those used to construct these buildings. Moreover, that income will have to be channeled into this area of Gaines Street for these values to materialize. If these projects simply attract people, households, and businesses from other parts of the city--say students and young professionals from Midtown or Downtown--net job creation and income growth may be zero. (This is not purely hypothetical. Some studies of the impact of sports stadiums have found negative economic effects for precisely this reason.)\n\nSo, where did Mr. Schimberg get this information about permanent job growth and impact? Most likely, his firm, or the Community Redevelopment Agency (CRA), hired a consultant to examine the <em>potential</em> impacts of a development their size using input-output studies. <a href="http://www.planetizen.com/node/43417">I\'ve critiqued these studies eleswhere</a>, but the basic methodology behind this tool assumes that all new spending is net new spending, not money redistributed from other parts of the regional economy. These studies also routinely ignore the potential productivity impacts of taking funds out of one sector of the economy and putting them in another perhaps less productive sector. This becomes problematic when local governments, like Tallahassee and Leon County, subsidize new development because the very nature of the subsidy implies the market has determined the investment in this area is less productive than other parts of the region. So, in essence, these studies assume that dollars are parchuted into the local economy and automatically generate new income, even when the dollars have really just been redistributed from somewhere else and probably redirected from more productive uses.\n\nDoes that mean these projects are destined to fail? Not necessarily. But their success depends crucially on the income generated from new employment created in the non-real estate sectors of the economy. In short, as long as Florida State and Florida A&amp;M, are growing, these projects will do fine.\n\nConstruction is not the source of sustainable, long-term economic development. Improved productivity and innovation are the drivers of Tallahassee\'s economic future.\nThe real-estate industry is the beneficiary of that growth, not the driver.\n\n</div>'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '18'), ('wp:post_date', '2013-03-22 15:45:00'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2013-03-22 15:45:00'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', Medicaid Expansion?'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2013/03/25/do-floridians-oppose-medicaid-expansion/'), ('pubDate', 'Mon, 25 Mar 2013 15:47:00 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=20')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'Original post date: March 25, 2013\nArticle by: Anonymous\n\nThe <a href="http://www.jamesmadison.org/">James Madison Institute</a> in Tallahassee published a poll inquiring about Floridians’ support of the recently endorsed Medicaid expansion. The <a href="http://www.jamesmadison.org/wp-content/uploads/Florida-Statewide-Medicaid-Poll.pdf">poll revealed that 59% of respondents</a> oppose the expansion, but these conclusions elicited some <a href="http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-02-22/the-real-conservative-echo-chamber.html">criticism from Josh Barro at Bloomberg View</a>.\n\nThe poll started off with a few general questions about the state of Florida’s economy, and the increasing National Debt, and then segued into Medicaid. According to Barro, the poll’s initial questions were priming respondents by giving them a negative sense of the economy and future spending, in order to procure a majority against the expansion. Barro also takes issue with the phrasing of the question asking whether or not the respondent is in favor of the expansion, because it adds the clause “even if it results in tax hikes and spending cuts.”\n\nMichael Cannon, the Director of Health Policy Studies at Cato Institute, insists that this is not the case, and that <a href="http://www.cato.org/blog/yes-florida-voters-oppose-obamacares-medicaid-expansion">the questions are far less insidious than Barro implies</a>. Cannon argues that this isn’t “priming,” or a “push poll,” or subliminally coercive in any way- it’s just asking about benefits and including cost information.\n\nMany polls ask about the benefits of the Medicaid expansion without even mentioning costs which, as Canon points out, is more contrived than providing a balanced poll that addresses both. The poll resulted in a majority opposed to the expansion, and perhaps this is because respondents in Florida really don’t think an expansion is worth the price.\n\nReferences:\n\nMichael Cannon Article on Cato:\n\n<a href="http://www.cato.org/blog/yes-florida-voters-oppose-obamacares-medicaid-expansion">http://www.cato.org/blog/yes-florida-voters-oppose-obamacares-medicaid-expansion</a>\n\nJMI Poll:\n\n<a href="http://www.jamesmadison.org/wp-content/uploads/Florida-Statewide-Medicaid-Poll.pdf">http://www.jamesmadison.org/wp-content/uploads/Florida-Statewide-Medicaid-Poll.pdf</a>\n\nBarro Article on Bloomberg:\n\n<a href="http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-02-22/the-real-conservative-echo-chamber.html">http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-02-22/the-real-conservative-echo-chamber.html</a>'), '1')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', 'Florida Does Not Need More Corporate Welfare'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2013/03/27/florida-does-not-need-moore-corporate-welfare/'), ('pubDate', 'Wed, 27 Mar 2013 16:07:00 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=23')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', '<span class="submit">Original post date: March 27, 2013\nArticle by: Anonymous</span>\n<div class="content">\n<p class="Normal1">Even amongst fiscal conservatives, the argument is often made that the public funding of sports stadiums is justified because of the economic benefits they bring to their communities. \xa0<a href="http://tbo.com/news/politics//Florida-considers--million-subsidy-to-build-MLS-soccer-stadiums-B82454553Z.1">According to TBO</a>, the state senate has passed a measure that would give $60 million over 30 years to VisionPro Sports Institute Holdings, a British company aiming to build a Major League Soccer (MLS) stadium in downtown Tampa. Proponents argue that current stadiums are insufficient and that better ones are needed before the MLS can expand into the Southeast. But would this help Florida’s economy?</p>\n<p class="Normal1">Unfortunately, stadiums and arenas typically have very little impact on local economic growth. University of Maryland economists Dennis Coates and John Humphries <a href="http://www.rebelavenger.com/sports/8.pdf">argue</a> that “household spending on sports ... is highly substitutable for other forms of entertainment,” and that “[r]esidents maintain their levels of entertainment spending but alter the allocation of this spending toward sport related spending.” Complicating matters further is the fact that much of the sport-related spending goes to pay the salaries of athletes, coaches, and owners who (unlike the staff at, say, a movie theater or restaurant) often do not live in their host cities full time. This means lower spending multipliers compared to other forms of entertainment. In short, <a href="http://www.uwlax.edu/faculty/anderson/micro-principles/stadiums.pdf">new sports facilities and teams do not raise per capita income or total employment</a>.</p>\n<p class="Normal1">Will this time bedifferent? Maybe attracting Major League Soccer to Florida <em>would </em>be a boon for the economy. But should taxpayers have to shoulder that risk? After all, the proposal would allocate a total of $60 million in public funds to constructing the new soccer stadium. If a major profit opportunity exists, then private investors should be capable of funding the project. Columbus Crew Stadium, an MLS stadium in Ohio and the first stadium built exclusively for professional soccer, was entirely funded with private money. So was the much larger Gillette Stadium in Foxboro, Massachusetts, which is home to both the New England Patriots and the New England Revolution, an MLS team.</p>\n<p class="Normal1">What the issue boils down to isn’t economic growth, but corporate welfare. Those who stand to benefit from a new soccer stadium aren’t local economies, but well connected political and business interests. What Florida needs is more private investment in projects that grow the economy. Soccer stadiums don’t fit that bill.</p>\n<p class="Normal1">References:</p>\n<p class="Normal1">Tampa Tribune Article</p>\n<p class="Normal1"><a href="http://tbo.com/news/politics//Florida-considers--million-subsidy-to-build-MLS-soccer-stadiums-B82454553Z.1">http://tbo.com/news/politics//Florida-considers--million-subsidy-to-build-MLS-soccer-stadiums-B82454553Z.1</a></p>\n<p class="Normal1">Coates &amp; Humphreys on Sports and Urban Economic Development</p>\n<p class="Normal1"><a href="http://www.rebelavenger.com/sports/8.pdf">http://www.rebelavenger.com/sports/8.pdf</a></p>\n<p class="Normal1">Siegfried and Zimbalist on Sports Facilities and their Communities</p>\n<p class="Normal1"><a href="http://www.uwlax.edu/faculty/anderson/micro-principles/stadiums.pdf">http://www.uwlax.edu/faculty/anderson/micro-principles/stadiums.pdf</a></p>\n\n</div>'), ('wp:post_name', 'florida-does-not-need-moore-corporate-welfare'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', [OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'columbus-crew'), ('#text', 'Columbus Crew')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'corporate-welfare'), ('#text', 'corporate welfare')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'economic-development'), ('#text', 'economic development')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'fiscal-policy'), ('#text', 'Fiscal Policy')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'gillette-stadium'), ('#text', 'Gillette Stadium')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'job-creation'), ('#text', 'job creation')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'major-league-soccer'), ('#text', 'major league soccer')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'mls'), ('#text', 'MLS')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'public-spending'), ('#text', 'public spending')])]), ('wp:postmeta', [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_publicize_pending'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_published'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_client_id'), ('wp:meta_value', '-1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_facebook'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_oembed_2989a2b34ddc01bf501e415b427a3489'), ('wp:meta_value', '{{unknown}}')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', 'Path Dependence, Entrenched Interests, and the Future of Transit'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2013/04/09/path-dependence-entrenched-interests-and-the-future-of-transit/'), ('pubDate', 'Tue, 09 Apr 2013 16:18:00 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=25')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'Original post date: April 09, 2013\nArticle by: Anonymous\n\n<strong>Path dependence: </strong>The\xa0tendency of a past or traditional\xa0practice\xa0or preference to continue even if better alternatives are available.<strong>\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0</strong>\n\nMortimer L. Downey has worked in New York\'s Metropolitan Transit Authority (MTA) and the Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority (MATA), and was one of several presenters at a May 2012 <a href="http://www.coss.fsu.edu/dmc/content/market-oriented-transit-reform">symposium at Florida State University on market-oriented transit reform</a>. At the forum, he suggested that managers think of transit services as having two customers: the users who pay a fare, and the government which expresses its preferences through the political system. Transit was once a private sector service but did not have a sustainable business model; ridership eroded through the rise of automobiles and suburbanization, and government intervened to ensure its continuation. Due to its near extinction, the transit industry does not embrace the risk inherent change and prefers the status quo.\n\nThe transit system is both labor intensive and capital intensive, <a href="http://www.coss.fsu.edu/dmc/sites/coss.fsu.edu.dmc/files/DowneyFSUTransitSymposium.pdf">Downey noted</a>. It has to deal with several factors: its labor practices, its definition of services, its choice of markets, its choice of equipment, its investment decisions, and the way the system perceives its relationship to customers. In transit systems, employees are represented by unions, and change will only come about if labor leaders and transit managers can work out solutions to their mutual benefits. Old work rules tend to stay in place unless a strong incentive exists to remove them. Usually, changes in work rules come from a new bargaining framework that shows those changes to be the only way to provide a reasonable wage settlement. Expensive benefits are hard to take away from current and former employees, but redefining benefit packages for new employees is possible.\n\nGiven the public sector nature of transit services, the system typically operates within a no-strike framework. However, this is not always the case. Transit workers can strike in certain cities, even when they are public employees and certainly when they are employees of a private company.\n\nThe outcomes of third party arbitration are often disappointing, said Downey, and result in both sides of labor disputes having less incentive to seek "win-win" solutions when both sides know what is likely to be the outcome. However, one of the areas where management and labor interests do coincide is safety.\n\nIn publicly operated systems, elected officials are more often motivated to sustain the status quo rather than to take the opportunity to make systems more efficient or effective. For instance, elected officials in Washington allowed metro fares to rise without altering services, in a recent cycle of fare and service changes. \xa0Services should be reformed from time to time, even if it is only to reallocate resources to areas where they will be more effectively applied.\n\nWithin the areas of fares and services, the perceived equity arguments for specific groups of users and beneficiaries are a sensitive one. For example, many advocates are trying to elevate mobility for seniors and the disabled to a civil right. However, the way this mobility is currently provided to these groups creates a burden on transit providers and payers. For example in Washington, the current cost of a ride is in the neighborhood of $40 while the maximum fare that can be collected is two time the regular fare. Even more troublesome, New York’s paratransit budget is more than five times the amount of Washington’s.\n\nTransit system managers tend to stick with the equipment they are comfortable with. Being the first to transition to new technology is risky, Downey says, but so is staying with old technology past the time suppliers are able to support it. Risk aversion by conservative transit agencies has led to such anomalies as rail lines that take advantage of abandoned rail right-of-way rather than running routes more suited to serve ridership. Change may be coming, such as in the case of public-private partnerships (P3s) in transit projects, e.g. the RTD in Denver.\n\nToday, technological advances allow for a computer app to tell users the best route to their destination, their real time of arrival and the necessary fare. The money transaction will also change for the better as customers will be able to use whatever is in their wallets, such as credit cards or personal IDs, to pay.\n\nTwo factors help to explain what transit systems can and do move in new directions, concluded Downey. First, the areas being changed are new opportunities not within the previous scope of the agency operation that bring about beneficial changes. Second, these changes are what customers are demanding.\n\nReferences:\n\nLink to presentation by Mortimer Downey:\n\n<a href="http://www.coss.fsu.edu/dmc/sites/coss.fsu.edu.dmc/files/DowneyFSUTransitSymposium.pdf">http://www.coss.fsu.edu/dmc/sites/coss.fsu.edu.dmc/files/DowneyFSUTransitSymposium.pdf</a>\n\nLink to presentation at Market-Oriented Transit Critical Issues Symposium:\n\n<a href="http://www.coss.fsu.edu/dmc/content/market-oriented-transit-reform">http://www.coss.fsu.edu/dmc/content/market-oriented-transit-reform</a>'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '25'), '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_path'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', 'Ohio Pedicab Operator Regulatory Goal? Limit Competition'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2013/06/04/ohio-pedicab-operator-regulatory-goal-limit-competition/'), ('pubDate', 'Tue, 04 Jun 2013 16:23:00 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=29')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', '<span class="submit">Original post date: June 04, 2013\nArticle by: Sam Staley</span>\n<div class="content">\n\nAt least pedicab operators in Columbus, Ohio are honest about what they expect out of the city\'s licensing process: Purging the city of competition. The city is about to adopt regulations that, among other things, limit the number of legally operated pedicabs to 40. Pedicabs are three wheeled, pedal-powered vehicles, and they are popular in downtown areas and entertainment districts. Columbus officials estimate that between 25 and 30 currently operate in their city (and Tallahassee recently had <a href="http://capitalcitypedicabs.com/CCPedicabs/home.html">its first entry into its local downtown travel market</a>).\n\nThe primary advocates for these caps are not customers--how many customers want their options to be limited? Rather, it\'s the current pedicab operators in Ohio complaing about "out of town" companies and drivers swooping in during major events to take customers to their destinations.<a href="http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/local/2013/06/04/pedicab-licenses-soon-city-says.html"> According to the Columbus Dispatch </a>(June 4, 2013),\n\n"Pedicab operators say the licenses will help legitimize an industry that has grown in the past five years and, they hope, ward off out-of-town operators who swoop in during large events such as Ohio State University football games. The code would limit the number of licenses it issues to restrict outside companies from coming into Columbus."\n\nOf course, these large scale events are exactly when large number of pedicabs (and taxis) are needed. Part-time operators are crucial to smooth functioning cab markets, whether conventional taxis or pedicabs. Without them, customers are literally left on the curb. Ironically, this hamstrings the ability of cities and downtowns to promote a vibrant, walkable street life because it limits the services available to visitors.\n\nUnderstandably, pedicab operators are worried about their revenues. What makes the taxi (and now pedicab) market different is the degree to which local regulators are willing to tilt the market in favor of existing operators and against consumers and entrepreneurial start ups. In too many cities, the experience of taxicab licensing shows that <a href="http://www.fee.org/the_freeman/detail/taxi-regulation-and-the-failures-of-progressivism#axzz2VHS1ns31">the effects of caps and other regulations limiting entry</a> has been to concentrate ownership in a few large companies and limit the availability and diversity of services available to customers.\n\nUnfortunately, if Columbus pedicab operators get their way, city officials will do their part to ensure the traveling public is likely to get the short end of the stick.\n\n</div>'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_path'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')])]), ('wp:comment', OrderedDict([('wp:comment_id', '91'), ('wp:comment_author', 'Phil Driver'), ('wp:comment_author_email', 'pedicab@britecom.co'), ('wp:comment_author_url', None), ('wp:comment_author_IP', '98.234.139.64'), ('wp:comment_date', '2016-01-01 00:27:39'), ('wp:comment_date_gmt', '2016-01-01 00:27:39'), ('wp:comment_content', 'This would not help the public at all ! The story, <a href="http://www.wtsp.com/news/local/story.aspx?storyid=316418">broken by 10 News in Tampa</a>, has drawn national attention in large part because of how small changes in light duration can lead to large increases in revenue from red light cameras, estimated in the news report to be in the neighborhood of $50 million. The ticket revenue generated by the red light cameras is shared between state and local governments, making the situation a win-win for everyone involved. Unless, of course, you count Florida’s drivers.\n\nMaking the story particularly interesting is the fact that the change was allowed by simply deleting three words from the state rules governing yellow light duration. According to 10 News:\n\n<em>“When the Florida legislature approved 2010\'s Mark Wandell Act, regulating red light cameras across the state, FDOT had a long-standing rule that mandated yellow light calculations factor in either the posted speed limit or 85<sup>th</sup> percentile of drivers\' actual speed --whichever was greater.\xa0 The point of the law was to calculate safe stopping times for the majority of drivers on any given roadway.</em>\n\n<em>But in 2011, FDOT struck the "whichever is greater" language from its Traffic Engineering Manual(TEM), reducing minimum yellow light lengths and allowing communities to re-time their signals at RLC intersections.”</em>\n\nThis case highlights two points familiar to political economists, particularly public choice theorists: 1.) the view that government actors can be fully trusted to act in the public interest is faulty; and 2.) that such agents, acting in pursuit of profit, can exploit subtle changes in policy in order secure benefits for themselves at the public’s expense.\n\nStories like this serve to remind us why we should be wary of government; despite our wishes, it often acts in ways that cater to the interests of a few while shirking its responsibility to the public. For more on bureaucratic corruption, take a look at the <a href="http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cnn.com%2F2013%2F05%2F15%2Fpolitics%2Firs-conservative-targeting%2Findex.html&amp;sa=D&amp;sntz=1&amp;usg=AFQjCNFalCcmv5-XJCYfzbGtprY_z2oNjw">recent IRS scandal</a>.\xa0 Over at Marginal Revolution, <a href="http://marginalrevolution.com/marginalrevolution/2013/05/red-lights-for-profit.html">Alex Tabarrok highlights</a> the connection between this case and the Drug War analysis of Florida State’s very own<a href="http://mailer.fsu.edu/~bbenson/PC1995.pdf">Bruce Benson and David Rasmussen</a>.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '31'), ('wp:post_date', '2013-06-05 16:28:00'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2013-06-05 16:28:00'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'yellow-light-corruption'), OrderedDict([('title', 'Public Debt: How Does Florida Stack Up?'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2013/06/20/public-debt-how-does-florida-stack-up/'), ('pubDate', 'Thu, 20 Jun 2013 16:35:00 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=33')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'Original post date: June 20, 2013\nArticle by: Anonymous\n\nOver at the Tax Foundation, a recent <a href="http://taxfoundation.org/blog/monday-map-state-debt-capita">Monday Map</a> highlights the debt per capita of each state. The good news is that Florida ranks fairly low on the list, coming in at #40; I’ll leave it to you to decide whether $2,294 is an acceptable figure. Rounding out the top ten are (from highest to lowest): Massachusetts, Alaska, Rhode Island, Connecticut, New Jersey, New York, Delaware, New Hampshire, Hawaii, and Vermont. Tennessee takes the coveted bottom spot with $925 of debt per capita, while Massachusetts residents are each saddled with over $11,000 of debt.\xa0 Compared to much of the Northeast, Florida’s $2,294 makes it look stingy.\n\nFor a more local perspective on how public liabilities are being borne by residents, <a href="http://floridaopengov.org/local-spending-and-revenue/">Florida Open Government </a>has annual data on local debt service payments. For 2010, Collier ($346), Palm Beach ($140), and Alachua ($110) counties are the top three in per capita payments. At the city level, Palm Beach ($623), Sanibel ($555), and Kissimmee ($511) top the list.\n\nMy own home county, Pasco, comes in at $30 of debt per resident for 2010.\xa0 If you’re interested in how your town stacks up, Florida Open Government has the complete list of debt payments (and many other items) for each Florida city and county. In addition to annual rankings, you can also view trends in local government debt service payments going back to 1993.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '33'), ('wp:post_date', '2013-06-20 '1')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', 'Housing Formation in a Recession'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2013/06/27/housing-formation-in-a-recession/'), ('pubDate', 'Thu, 27 Jun 2013 16:45:00 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=35')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'Post date: June 27, 2013\nArticle by: Gary Chong-Qui\n\nIn past years, a stigma seems to have followed people moving back in with their parents after college. Most undergrads think they’ll have their lives sorted out by the time graduation day comes, or at the very least have some direction for moving on. The statistics typically show that many college grads take jobs and start their own households. Unfortunately, many young adults have delayed their entry to the housing market due to the economic recession of 2007-2009 <a href="http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0094119013000284">according to recent research.</a>\n\nKwan Ok Lee of National University of Singapore and Gary Painter of USC Sol Price School of Public Policy found that the option of moving home with Mom and Dad is gaining favor. When potential households (those with the potential to buy houses for the first time) are assessing their options, the economic climate is a big factor in the decision-making process. Recessions and high unemployment rates make living with parents a more attractive alternative to recent grads and other young adults facing the job market, which explains why the “rate of young adult men living at home has grown rapidly from 14% to 19% from the beginning of the recession until 2011.”\n\nThere is some ambiguity around the data concerning parental wealth. Parental wealth appears to generate an incentive for young adults to remain at home since their parents are capable of providing for them, while further data shows that parents with more wealth assist their children in forming separate households.\xa0 Among this latter group, the data also suggests that those whose parents have wealth in the form of assets, like real estate (other than the home they inhabit), equities in business, vehicles, etc., are more likely to buy a house than rent. Children whose parents own their own home are also more likely to buy.\n\nFor those who move back home, this declining rate of entry into the housing market is unfortunate, especially since the economic downturn has been accompanied by a buyer’s market. Interest rates and housing prices are historically low right now, making it an opportune time to start a new household. Hopefully, the future will bring a more accommodating job market for recent graduates and young adults, and they will choose to invest in their own homes.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', 16:47:00 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=37')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'Original post date: July 30, 2013\nArticle by: Anonymous\n\n<a href="http://www.tampabay.com/blogs/the-buzz-florida-politics/latvala-asks-scott-for-fdle-probe-of-lawmakers-residencies/2131114">The Tampa Bay Times reported </a>that Governor Scott has assigned his top lawyer to look into claims that six state legislators do not actually reside in the districts they represent. The accusations come courtesy of Sen. Jack Latvala, R-Clearwater and chair of the Ethics and Elections Committee, who called for a criminal investigation in a <a href="https://docs.google.com/file/d/1jTRNHsOZ-Lyh8m5srq0s8G1Vamah0xNVelcbBnPyRPgrcouv9KM_q6GQ63dI/edit">letter</a> sent to the governor and several top lawmakers. Florida’s constitution requires that representatives be elected from within their districts. Though the letter was also sent to leaders in the House and Senate, it is up to the governor to decide whether or not to investigate.\n\nThe accusations were brought on by an <a href="http://www.local10.com/news/criminal-investigation-wanted-for-elected-officials-living-outside-districts/-/1717324/20920552/-/vlbctmz/-/index.html">investigative news report from WPLG-TV</a> in Miami that claimed that several state and local lawmakers owned homes outside of their districts. Reporters uncovered photos of lawmakers leaving large luxury homes they own in other areas, which wouldn\'t have been so alarming if not for <a href="http://www.local10.com/news/investigation-finds-elected-officials-with-houses-outside-their-districts/-/1717324/20516720/-/bwp40jz/-/index.html">photos of the far more modest homes they claimed as their actual residences</a>. This issue is not new to Florida; in 2009, Congressman Robert Wexler (who is <a href="http://www.colbertnation.com/the-colbert-report-videos/72021/july-20-2006/better-know-a-district---florida-s-19th---robert-wexler">no stranger</a> to media debacles) became embroiled in a similar controversy centered on his claim that his mother-in-law’s house was his in-district residence.\n\nNotable is the fact that each of the lawmakers accused by Latvala is a South Florida Democrat. It is hard to believe Latvala is unaware of the potential political gains state Republicans could make if six Democrats were unseated. Even if they aren’t ultimately unseated, a criminal investigation would be sure to stir up a lot of negative media attention for Democrats. Regardless of the motivation behind the charges, a decision by Governor Scott to go forward with the investigation would have a large impact on Florida politics.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '37'), ('wp:post_date', '2013-07-30 16:47:00'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2013-07-30 16:47:00'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'legislator-residency-called-into-question'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', [OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'criminal-investigations'), ('#text', 'criminal investigations')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'florida'), [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_publicize_pending'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_published'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_client_id'), ('wp:meta_value', '-1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_facebook'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_google_plus'),
