'a:4:{s:4:"time";d:1419017613.8288800716400146484375;s:7:"message";s:55:"devoemoorecenter changed the comment status to approved";s:5:"event";s:15:"status-approved";s:4:"user";s:16:"devoemoorecenter";}')])])]))]), OrderedDict([('title', 'Transit Reform in Santiago'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2013/10/18/transit-reform-in-santiago/'), ('pubDate', 'Fri, 18 Oct 2013 19:20:00 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=54')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'Original post date: October 18, 2013\nArticle by: Ben Douglas\n\nIn 2007, Chile’s center-left ruling government coalition eliminated most private provision of transit, citing the need to eliminate profit and reduce the diversity of services offered to the traveling public in the capital city of Santiago. Additional concerns included the pollution, accidents, and traffic congestion caused by the three thousand bus companies that serviced the city. At the same time, however, these companies were doing something remarkable: privately providing timely and reliable public transit in a dense, metropolitan city.\n\nThis is the situation described to us by Duke economist Michael Munger in <a href="http://www.econlib.org/library/Columns/y2008/Mungerbus.html">his work</a> on Santiago’s transit woes prior to the institution of a World Bank-funded <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bus_rapid_transit">Bus Rapid Transit</a> (BRT) system, which shall be addressed shortly. The reasons for pollution are fairly straightforward. Santiago occupies a basin between two mountain ranges that, due to the <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inversion_(meteorology)">inversion effect</a>, leaves a hue of smog covering the city; this problem was not helped by the sheer quantity of internal combustion engines within this confined area. Moreover, buses were old and dirty due to lack of licensure, enforcement of tort law, or other formal or informal institutions that promote compliance with emission standards.\n\nThe accident problem stemmed from the structure of incentives. “Drivers were paid based on the number of passengers, rather than on time or distance driven,” Munger explains. “But a moment\'s thought reveals the problem: Take one bus stop with a crowd of passengers, and then add two buses with a lot of empty seats. The result is a 40-mile-per-hour bus race on streets full of cars and pedestrians. The drivers were taking tickets, making change, watching traffic, and reenacting the chariot race scene from the movie <em>Ben-Hur</em>\xa0all at the same time.” The result of all this commotion was a nearly 50% increase in the number of motor vehicle accidents between 1990 and 2005 and an average of 700 pedestrians killed by car or bus annually. Both of these rates rose during this fifteen year period in Santiago despite having declined in many other Latin American cities.\n\nFollowing precedents set by numerous other Latin American nations, the Chilean government responded to these problems by establishing <em>Transantiago</em>—Santiago’s very own BRT. Operation commenced on February 10, 2007. The <a href="http://www.globalmasstransit.net/archive.php?id=6461">new fleet</a>, comprised of 1,200 new low-floor articulated trunk buses, 1,500 conventional trunk buses and 2,300 feeder buses, completely replaced the innumerable private buses that had previously serviced the city. In contrast to Lima, the subject of <a href="http://www.coss.fsu.edu/dmc/content/limas-transit-woes">my previous blog</a> , Santiago’s BRT system is publicly owned and operated. The regulations imposed by Lima’s municipal authorities are exchanged for a ban on private buses, with the exception of ten companies licensed by the city and granted a monopoly on certain routes. In my next blog, I will discuss the implementation and results of these policy changes.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '54'), ('wp:post_date', '2013-10-18 19:20:00'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2013-10-18 19:20:00'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'transit-reform-in-santiago'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', [OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'bus-rapid-transit'), ('#text', 'Bus rapid transit')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'chile'), ('#text', 'Chile')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'santiago'), ('#text', 'Santiago')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'socialism'), ('#text', 'socialism')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'transit'), ('#text', 'transit')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'transportation'), ('#text', 'Transportation')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'transportation-2'), ('#text', 'transportation')])]), ('wp:postmeta', [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_publicize_pending'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_published'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_client_id'), ('wp:meta_value', '-1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_facebook'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_google_plus'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_twitter'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_linkedin'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_tumblr'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_path'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', 'Transit Reform in Santiago: Part II'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2013/10/22/transit-reform-in-santiago-part-ii/'), ('pubDate', 'Tue, 22 Oct 2013 19:24:00 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=56')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'Original post date: October 22, 2013\nArticle by: Ben Douglas\n\nThe success of any endeavor is dependent upon the metric being used. If the goal of transit reform in Santiago, Chile was the elimination of profit from transit and the homogenization of bus services, the new Bus Rapid Transit (BRT) system, <em>Transantiago</em>, was a wild success. Prior to reform, Santiago’s bus system operated entirely without public subsidy—an astonishing feat for the densely populated city—generating $60 million in profit per year. In contrast, the system lost $600 million per year as of 2008 under the new system. Subsidies cost every citizen of Santiago $100 just to have a bus system. Initial estimated capital costs of $250 million proved to be entirely too modest.\n\nTaking into account extensive expansions on the original BRT project, the final bill for Santiago’s transit consolidation and reform amounted to <a href="http://www.globalmasstransit.net/archive.php?id=6461">$2.5 billion</a>. Moreover, the product differentiation offered by private bus companies was replaced with a one-size-fits-all monopoly in an attempt to eliminate “inequalities” in quality of transport. More soberingly, if the success of a public transit system is to be measured by occupancy and ridership, <em>Transantiago</em> has been a failure. A failure, in fact, deemed worthy of <a href="http://m.npr.org/story/15100976">presidential apology</a> by the Chilean administration. Ridership has gone down slightly, although it is difficult to tell for certain because commuters began sneaking in the rear doors of the <a href="http://www.globalmasstransit.net/archive.php?id=6461">1,200</a> massive new articulated buses (colloquially referred to as “bendy buses”) purchased by the government. A cornerstone of BRT systems around the world, these buses are intended to pick up large numbers of passengers for efficiency’s sake.\n\nHowever, perverse incentives under the new system resulted in many buses driving around almost empty much of the time. The reasons were as follows: Average commute times rose from 40 minutes to 1 hour 40 minutes following the opening of <em>Transantiago</em>. This resulted in widespread substitution of private car and taxi usage for transit, further increasing the congestion problem. Bus drivers were now paid for being on time rather than the number of passengers they transport. Thus, late drivers caught in traffic often decided to forgo a bus stop along their route entirely, leaving commuters high and dry, in order to meet their on-time performance benchmark.\n\nWhen they actually stopped to pick up passengers, drivers sometimes declined to make them pay at all. The new bendy buses have a rear entrance (meant for hopping off) that unscrupulous commuters often used to sneak on for free. Compounding the problem, the bendy buses were 6-8 inches wider than the lanes and prone to causing accidents. For all of their flaws, the small, nimble buses of the old competitive system were much better suited to operating Santiago’s narrow lanes and mountain foothills.\n\nAnother cornerstone of the new system was the elimination of bus routes that ran parallel to the metro rail routes. This decision stemmed from planners’ desire that commuters should ride feeder buses to the metro and then use that as their primary long-distance method of transportation, rather than buses. Duke University political scientist Michael Munger explains the failure of this plan by pointing out that if this is what people wanted, this is what transit providers would have done. Economists refer to this concept as demonstrated preference—people indicate preferences by their actions, not by what they say or what an expert seems to think is the most efficient course of action. If buses were faster and cheaper, people would use them to commute.\n\nChilean planners failed to use the information given to them by the previous system, and instead designed a new one from the top down. They tried to implement the perfect system in a vacuum, rather than serve the demands of commuters. “Instead of looking at what people wanted,” Munger <a href="http://www.econtalk.org/archives/2008/07/munger_on_the_p.html">explains</a>, “say as evidenced by what the map had evolved to look like, they drew it as what they thought it should look like from a planning perspective.”\n\nPrivatization-friendly Chile is not a corrupt country. Nor is it authoritarian. According to the Frasier Institute’s Economic Freedom Index, its economy is one of the <a href="http://www.freetheworld.com/2012/EFW2012-map-hi-res.pdf">freest in the world</a>. In spite of this, it has provided us with a case study in how not to reform transit. <em>Transantiago</em> demonstrates the importance of information as conveyed by prices in competitive markets. The number and size of buses, where bus routes should run and at what times is information that can only be conveyed through the grassroots, bottom up market process. <em>Transantiago’s</em> failures are the result of what happens when experts make the choices instead of leaving them to consumers.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '56'), ('wp:post_date', '2013-10-22 19:24:00'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2013-10-22 19:24:00'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'transit-reform-in-santiago-part-ii'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', [OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'chile'), ('#text', 'Chile')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'latin-america'), ('#text', 'latin america')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'pricing'), ('#text', 'pricing')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'santiago'), ('#text', 'Santiago')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'socialism'), ('#text', 'socialism')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'transit'), ('#text', 'transit')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'transit-reform'), ('#text', 'transit reform')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'transportation'), ('#text', 'Transportation')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'user-fees'), ('#text', 'user fees')])]), ('wp:postmeta', [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_publicize_pending'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_published'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_client_id'), ('wp:meta_value', '-1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_facebook'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_google_plus'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_twitter'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_linkedin'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_tumblr'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_path'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', 'Preliminary Prices on Obamacare Exchanges Exceeds Estimates'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2013/10/30/preliminary-prices-on-obamacare-exchanges-exceeds-estimates/'), ('pubDate', 'Wed, 30 Oct 2013 19:26:00 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=59')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'Original post date: October 30, 2013\nArticle by: Anonymous\n\nNow that October 1 has passed, the online marketplaces for health insurance under Obamacare are open for business. Individuals are free to <a href="https://www.healthcare.gov/">browse the site</a> and choose any policy available to them after answering some questions and being guided through their options. So far, site traffic has been causing some technical difficulties, and enrollment is less than predicted.\n\nThe high cost of the new premiums could be scaring some consumers away.\xa0 According to a study by <a href="http://www.forbes.com/sites/theapothecary/2013/09/25/double-down-obamacare-will-increase-avg-individual-market-insurance-premiums-by-99-for-men-62-for-women/">The Manhattan Institute</a>, average individuals will face a cost increase of 62% if they’re female, and 99% if they’re male. (Although low-income families will be eligible for subsidies, this study does not consider them since they will only be available to select individuals and families.)\n\nThe Manhattan Institute study was conducted by finding the five cheapest plans offered in each state before the exchanges, and comparing them to the five cheapest plans offered on the exchanges. They looked at rates for 27, 40, and 64 year-olds, and men and women. In the majority of states, 27 year-olds will face steep increases. Men and women will both see increasing premiums, but men will face a higher increase. In the previous system, men typically paid less than women, but now their rates are more similar.\n\nSixteen of the states and D.C. decided to set up their own exchanges, while the remaining 34 left the work up to the federal government. According to the Manhattan Institute study (which looked at 13 of the 16, and D.C.), the states that were eager to set up the exchanges will see premiums increase by <a href="http://www.forbes.com/sites/theapothecary/2013/09/04/interactive-map-in-13-states-plus-d-c-individual-health-premiums-will-increase-by-an-average-of-24/">an average of 24%.</a> Five of the states see decreasing averages, but nine will face increasing rates. Although many people will receive subsidies, plenty of families fall in the range just above the subsidy cutoffs, but below the income level that would make many of the available healthcare plans “affordable.” Since the subsidies only help very low-income families, higher premiums will penalize the middle class the most.\n\nPeople in states like Ohio, New York, and Colorado are some of the few seeing lower premiums and health insurance costs since the exchanges opened. <a href="http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/10/02/obamacare-enrollment_n_4032678.html">A family of four in Denver</a> will be able to pay lower out of pocket costs than before, even with children who have pre-existing conditions. Unfortunately, aside from these states, the majority of people, especially young, healthy individuals, are seeing higher health insurance costs.\n\nGovernment officials are not alarmed by the low number of people buying insurance plans. The final date to purchase a plan for the 2014 year is March 31, 2014, so people have time to weigh their decisions carefully. Many people are still confused about how to use the new system, so it’s possible that enrollment will pick up in the next few months, especially as people learn about subsidies for which they may qualify.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '59'), ('wp:post_date', '2013-10-30 19:26:00'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2013-10-30 19:26:00'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'preliminary-prices-on-obamacare-exchanges-exceeds-estimates'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', [OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'adverse-selection'), ('#text', 'adverse selection')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'healthcare'), ('#text', 'Healthcare')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'healthcare'), ('#text', 'Healthcare')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'healthcare-policy'), ('#text', 'healthcare policy')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'insurance'), ('#text', 'insurance')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'obamacare'), ('#text', 'obamacare')])]), ('wp:postmeta', [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_publicize_pending'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_published'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_client_id'), ('wp:meta_value', '-1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_facebook'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_google_plus'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_twitter'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_linkedin'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_tumblr'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_path'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', "Go Green, Don't Expand Transit"), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2013/11/04/go-green-dont-expand-transit/'), ('pubDate', 'Mon, 04 Nov 2013 19:31:00 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=61')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'Original post date: November 04, 2013\nArticle by: Ben Douglas\n\nThe careful application of economics to policy reveals a host of ironies. Minimum wages <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Price_floor">create unemployment</a> among the very unskilled laborers policymakers intend to help. Rent control <a href="http://www.econlib.org/library/Enc/RentControl.html#lfHendersonCEE2-145_footnote_nt389">destroys</a>\xa0housing in the very cities it is intended to save. Adam Smith’s entire concept of an “invisible hand,” by which self-interested buyers and sellers come together in the market to make mutually beneficial exchanges, is steeped in irony. These examples are well known to economists. A lesser known irony can be found in transit—a sector of the economy dominated by central planning.\n\nTransit is often touted as the advanced, cost-effective, environmentally friendly way to do urban transportation. On the surface, this makes sense. If you take one commuter out of his car and put him on a bus that is going to be operating anyway, efficiency within the existing system goes up. More people on existing buses, <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ceteris_paribus"><em>ceteris paribus</em></a>, increase the number of passengers per trip and therefore reduces <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_thermal_unit">BTUs</a> (or energy used) per passenger mile. Transit, it would seem, is the environmentally friendly way to commute.\n\n<a href="http://freakonomics.com/2012/11/07/can-mass-transit-save-the-environment-right-wing-or-left-wing-heres-a-post-everybody-can-hate/">Not so fast</a>, says Eric Morris, an urban planning professor writing for the <em>Freakonomics</em> blog. Frequently, studies on the energy efficiency of transit vs. private automobile travel assume a bus filled to capacity and one rider per car. In the real world, this assumption doesn’t hold water. The average car has about 1.6 riders, whereas the average bus has around 10. By the government’s very own statistics, transporting each passenger one mile takes more energy by bus than by car.\xa0 “It is not clear,” says Morris, “that moving around large and largely empty vehicles is much of an improvement over moving around smaller ones. In fact, it may be worse.” (See also this analysis by Randal O’Toole <a href="http://www.cato.org/publications/policy-analysis/does-rail-transit-save-energy-or-reduce-greenhouse-gas-emissions">here</a>.)\n\nMorris recommends policymakers cease to expand transit, and instead seek to expand ridership on existing transit systems. The above figures alone show there is plenty of room for a few additional passengers per bus, and the marginal cost is almost nothing. Morris’ proposal for increasing ridership includes “pull” strategies designed to incentivize the use of public transport (e.g., fare cuts), and “push” strategies designed to disincentivize the use of private cars (e.g., taxes and fees for driving).\n\nUnfortunately, these goals may be difficult to accomplish. As the satirical news organization The Onion <a href="http://www.theonion.com/articles/report-98-percent-of-us-commuters-favor-public-tra,1434/">pointed out</a>, 98% of US commuters support public transportation for others. Transit thus seems to be a <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prisoner%27s_dillema">prisoner’s dilemma</a>. Collectively, it is in our interest as commuters, taxpayers, and environmentalists to see more people in Greyhounds instead of Cadillacs. At the individual level, however, it is in our interest to drive privately. The marginal increase in pollution and traffic congestion from one car on the road is very small. Our private gain from the freedom private car usage provides, however, tends to be enormous. Perhaps this is why <a href="http://www.census.gov/newsroom/releases/archives/american_community_survey_acs/cb11-158.html">76.6% of Americans and 83% of Floridians</a> chose to commute alone in 2010.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '61'), ('wp:post_date', '2013-11-04 19:31:00'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2013-11-04 19:31:00'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'go-green-dont-expand-transit'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', [OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'central-planning'), ('#text', 'central planning')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'environmentalism'), ('#text', 'environmentalism')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'green-energy'), ('#text', 'Green energy')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'prisoners-dilema'), ('#text', 'prisoners dilema')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'private-transit'), ('#text', 'private transit')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'transit-reform'), ('#text', 'transit reform')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'transportation'), ('#text', 'Transportation')])]), ('wp:postmeta', [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_publicize_pending'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_published'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_client_id'), ('wp:meta_value', '-1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_facebook'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_google_plus'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_twitter'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_linkedin'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_tumblr'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_path'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', 'Equal Access to Transportation, a Right?'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2013/11/06/equal-access-to-transportation-a-right/'), ('pubDate', 'Wed, 06 Nov 2013 19:34:00 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=63')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'Original post date: November 06, 2013\nArticle by: Anonymous\n\n<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ray_LaHood">Ray LaHood</a>, the recently retired secretary of the Department of Transportation, said that equal access to transportation is “<a href="http://www.whitehouse.gov/blog/2011/06/01/equal-access-transportation-right-all-americans">one of the most fundamental of American rights.</a>” Mobility is a crucial aspect of life for many people today, and there is a large transportation need. Many people are unable to afford private transportation methods, creating a market for public transit.\n\nProviding transportation within the immediate vicinity of one’s home seems simple, but the farther one needs to travel, the higher the cost of providing transportation becomes. As infrastructure grows, so do the costs that must be passed along to the consumer, or else subsidized.\n\nAccording to the American Public Transportation Association, buses, trolleys subways, ferries, commuter trains, monorails and streetcars provide a number of benefits to society. <a href="http://www.apta.com/mediacenter/ptbenefits/Pages/default.aspx">These benefits</a> include reducing gasoline consumption, providing personal freedom for people from every walk of life, and returning $4 for every dollar invested.\n\nThere are two ways of looking at the problem of providing mobility. The first view looks for a solution to the problem of transporting people by subsidizing it with public funds that will provide quality transportation to all those who need it.\n\nThe other option is to allow the market to determine prices and what types of transportation services will be provided.\xa0 Proponents of this view claim that the market will be better at gathering the knowledge necessary to understand the tradeoffs involved with any transportation project. When viewed as a right, however, anything that may prevent access to transportation—even particular modes such as busses or trains—can be viewed as a deprivation of a right.\n\nThose in charge of public transportation programs recognize that for every action there is a cost. Public transportation programs implement fees to help offset this cost. When prices must rise due to increased costs, those who view transportation as a right would rather disperse the cost through subsidization, than to raise the cost to consumer by increasing fares. This is what happened in Sao Paulo, Brazil, the largest city in Latin America.\n\nPublic transportation in Sao Paulo is crowded and commute times are long. Sao Paulo transportation officials recently increased fares for the metro and bus from 3 reais (about $1.40) to 3.20 reais (about $1.50).<a href="http://www.reuters.com/article/2013/09/30/brazil-economy-survey-idUSEMS06001120130930">Annual inflation</a> around 6% was one of the factors that caused this raise in fares, though the cost from inflation was larger than the fare increase.\n\nThis increase in fare, combined with the subpar service provided, sparked a protest by a group called the<a href="http://farefreebrazil.blogspot.com/">Free Fare Movement</a>. Protests became riots and a simple fare raise led to a national cry for revolution and a new approach to society. The riots, where cars were burned and buildings vandalized, were <a href="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m58R19SEeh8">well</a><a href="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bssMiHhqJ-Y">documented</a> and publicized. The violent response of police in riot gear <a href="http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2013/06/18/rage-in-brazil.html">raised sympathy</a> for the protesters.\n\nUnder the pressure of the protests, vandalism and the media, Governor Geraldo Alckmin <a href="http://espnfc.com/news/story/_/id/1480780/pele-calls-end-protests-brazil?cc=5901">announced the reduction</a> of fares to their previous levels. The protestors <a href="http://www.reuters.com/article/2013/06/20/us-brazil-protests-idUSBRE95I1H820130620">were not satisfied</a> by this reduction though. Due to the vague demands of the protest and a lack of an official structure, the unrest continued.\n\nThe riots seem to be less about the actual price increase, but rather a symptom of deeper discontent with the way the government is run.\xa0 A question to ponder is whether these protests would have happened had buses, trolleys, subways and trams been provided by private companies.\n\nCustomers expect private companies to respond to new costs and market forces by changing service levels or fares. They also expect that companies will compete to provide the best service, for the best price. When a business provides a service it is seen as a tradeoff between inputs and outputs designed to maximize profit and provide utility to consumers. On the other hand, when a government provides services, people expect a low fixed rate, or even no cost at all.\n\nTransit is a service like any other, and requires inputs of capital and labor in order to produce output (transportation to citizens). If fares were nonexistent, the only capital input would come from taxpayer money, even though public\xa0 transit is used by a small portion of the population. Fares and fees charged enable those who use the services to contribute to them, while those with private transportation are not held financially obligated.\n\nThe right to equal access to transit does not imply the same entitlement as the Free Fare Movement protestors felt. Citizens are not entitled to be transported free of charge to their chosen destinations, but they ought to be <em>physically capable</em> of taking a bus, train, plane etc., should they choose to. LaHood would like to see disabled individuals using common forms of transportation with as much ease as nondisabled citizens. Anyone who has a need and the appropriate bus fare should be able to use the service.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '63'), ('wp:post_date', '2013-11-06 19:34:00'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2013-11-06 19:34:00'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'equal-access-to-transportation-a-right'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', [OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'department-of-transportation'), ('#text', 'Department of Transportation')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'dot'), ('#text', 'DOT')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'mobility'), ('#text', 'mobility')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'ray-lahood'), ('#text', 'Ray LaHood')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'rights'), ('#text', 'rights')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'sao-paulo'), ('#text', 'Sao Paulo')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'transit'), ('#text', 'transit')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'transportation'), ('#text', 'Transportation')])]), ('wp:postmeta', [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_publicize_pending'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_path'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', 'Entrenched Interests Fight Innovation in Taxi Industry'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2013/11/19/entrenched-interests-fight-innovation-in-taxi-industry/'), ('pubDate', 'Tue, 19 Nov 2013 19:37:00 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=65')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'Original post date: November 19, 2013\nArticle by: Ben Douglas\n\nA revolutionary new smartphone app is changing the nature of the taxicab business, but stiff opposition from entrenched taxi companies risks keeping their innovations from benefiting customers.\n\nUber is a venture-capital funded startup company that provides on-demand taxi and limousine services using cellphones to connect passengers with nearby drivers. Billing is automatic and handled exclusively through the app, while a reputation system holds drivers (who are independent contractors and not Uber employees) accountable. The convenience used to cost a premium, with prices exceeding typical cab fares by <a href="http://news.cnet.com/8301-30685_3-57338236-264/car-service-uber-raises-$32-million-launches-in-paris/">50-75%</a>. This is no longer the case with UberX, marketed as “<a href="http://blog.uber.com/2013/06/11/uberx-cheaper-than-a-taxi/">the low cost Uber</a>,” which promises to undercut local cab rates by at least 10%. UberX’s rates beat the competition by <a href="http://blog.uber.com/uberx-dc-new-prices?utm_source=feedly">18%</a> in D.C., <a href="http://blog.uber.com/uberXLA">30%</a> in Los Angeles, and <a href="http://blog.uber.com/uberXSD">37%</a> in San Diego.\n\nCurrently available in <a href="https://www.uber.com/cities">33 cities across the Americas and 57 around the world</a>, Uber has expanded rapidly since its 2010 debut in San Francisco. The ride has not been entirely smooth, however. Numerous legal potholes have arisen along the way. City and state governments across the US have had to reevaluate their ridesharing and common carrier laws. Additionally, existing taxicab companies have objected to Uber slipping through regulatory loopholes and gaining an unfair advantage.\n\nDallas Yellow Cab is one such firm. An <a href="http://www.dallasnews.com/news/transportation/20130914-dallas-officials-yellow-cab-worked-together-to-thwart-uber-transportation-app.ece?nclick_check=1">investigative report</a> by <em>the Dallas Morning News</em> uncovered deep ties between the established cab company, a “longtime political and financial benefactor to council members,” and city government officials. Working in conjunction, the two organizations arranged a multi-pronged assault on Uber, chiefly engineered by Yellow Cab’s attorney, John Barr.\n\nAn ordinance put before the City Council in late August that would make it difficult for Uber to operate in Dallas used Barr’s draft as the <a href="http://cityhallblog.dallasnews.com/2013/10/uber-investigation-part-1.html/">primary guide</a>, according to an ensuing investigation by City Hall. A vote was delayed due to this investigation and several council members’ objections.\n\nCouncil member Phillip Kingston <a href="http://cityhallblog.dallasnews.com/2013/08/dallas-to-rewrite-limo-regulations-in-effort-to-calm-cabbies-unhappy-with-app-summoned-uber.html/">raised the following objection</a>: “[S]taff has slipped the issue onto the agenda for next week at the last possible moment and put it on the consent agenda, meaning not scheduled for individual consideration or debate. It hasn\'t been briefed to Council or even to the Transportation committee, and it\'s a policy change, entirely in favor of the taxi lobby, that comes with a not insignificant risk of getting the city sued.”\n\nMeanwhile, according to the <em>Morning News </em>report, Barr contracted former FBI agent and private investigator Debbie Burns to conduct an undercover investigation into Uber in an attempt to find incriminating behavior. Subsequent police investigations failed to detect insurance and licensing violations. Regardless, the city issued citations to 31 drivers for, among other charges, “lacking authority to operate in the city.”\n\nCharges against all 31 drivers were dismissed just as City Hall released its investigation into the City Council’s handling of the Uber matter. The report acknowledged “<a href="http://www.dallasnews.com/opinion/editorials/20131024-editorial-uber-probe-finds-much-wrong-at-dallas-city-hall.ece">several wrong decisions and bad judgments</a>” and laid blame at the feet of interim City Manager A.C. Gonzalez, who <a href="http://www.dallasnews.com/news/metro/20131021-gonzalez-apologizes-to-mayor-and-council-members-for-bypassing-them-on-uber-issue.ece">apologized</a> to the mayor and City Council for bypassing them. Mayor Rawlings characterized Gonzalez’s handling of the situation as “<a href="http://cityhallblog.dallasnews.com/2013/10/uber-investigation-part-1.html/?nclick_check=1">highly disappointing</a>,” but said that no “<a href="http://www.dallasnews.com/opinion/editorials/20131024-editorial-uber-probe-finds-much-wrong-at-dallas-city-hall.ece">potential illegal or unethical activity or behavior</a>” was found.\n\nFor Uber, the battle may have been won, but the war is far from over. Across the United States, Uber faces legal opposition from entrenched taxicab cartels and the regulatory agencies fighting on their behalf.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '65'), OrderedDict([('title', 'Customers Rise Up to Support Taxi Innovator'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2013/11/19/customers-rise-up-to-support-taxi-innovator/'), ('pubDate', 'Tue, 19 Nov 2013 19:39:00 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=67')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'Original post date: November 19, 2013\nArticle by: Ben Douglas\n\nFinding a more textbook example of <a href="http://mercatus.org/expert_commentary/regulatory-capture-what-experts-have-found">regulatory capture</a> than the taxicab industry is difficult, as the case of the innovative on-demand taxi service Uber clearly demonstrates.\n\nDespite the highly regulated nature of the American taxicab industry, newcomer Uber continues to grow, due partly to its politically active clientele.\xa0 A recent attempt by the D.C. taxi commission to establish a $15 “minimum fare” (i.e., price floor) was met <a href="http://reason.com/reasontv/2013/10/22/the-uber-wars-how-dc-tried-to-smother-a">with tens of thousands of emails</a> protesting the measure.\n\nUber’s victories in <a href="http://coss.fsu.edu/d6/dmc/content/entrenched-interests-fight-innovation-taxi-industry">Dallas</a> and D.C. are accompanied with a mixed ruling from the California Public Utilities Commission, which regulates taxis for the state of California. <a href="http://www.dailynews.com/business/20131013/ride-sharing-companies-dodge-restrictions-at-airports">The ruling</a> “created a new class of regulated transportation companies,” and thereby “rendered moot a cease-and-desist notice — which no one actually followed — sent by the Los Angeles taxicab administrator, who had warned the companies they were not licensed to operate in the city.”\n\nBoth Uber and entrenched taxi interests <a href="http://www.bizjournals.com/sanfrancisco/blog/2013/10/uber-lyft-sidecar-taxicab-puc.html?page=all">are fighting the ruling</a>, from opposite perspectives. “Uber … reiterated its earlier claim that it is not subject to regulation by the Public Utilities Commission because it is a technology company that does not provide transportation services.” Indeed, Uber has managed to avoid the numerous regulations and licensing fees facing taxicab companies because it is not, in point of fact, a taxicab company, as its website makes <a href="https://www.uber.com/legal">very clear</a>:\xa0 “Uber itself does\xa0<strong>not\xa0</strong>provide transportation services, and Uber is not a transportation carrier. It is up to the Transportation Provider to offer transportation services, which may be requested through the use of the Application and/or the Service. Uber only acts as intermediary between you and the Transportation Provider."\n\nThe ruling did not affect airport ridesharing policies, however. “According to [Los Angeles International Airport] rules and regulations, casual ride-sharing drivers <a href="http://www.dailynews.com/business/20131013/ride-sharing-companies-dodge-restrictions-at-airports">may not pick up passengers in the Central Terminal Area</a>.” Not to be deterred, Uber drivers and passengers have found creative and covert ways to subvert LAX policies. Whether it’s arranging a surreptitious pickup, loading their own luggage, or sitting in the front seat, users of the tech-savvy car service have far from given up.\n\nThe Uber wars continue to wage on with no indication of relenting. The established firms and the public agencies that regulate them are powerful, but Uber’s management and clientele have proven themselves remarkably persistent. Regardless of who wins, one thing is clear: The taxi industry is evolving. The regulatory framework surrounding it must evolve with it or risk obsolescence.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '67'), ('wp:post_date', '2013-11-19 19:39:00'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2013-11-19 19:39:00'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'customers-rise-up-to-support-taxi-innovator'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', [OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'entrenched-interests'), ('#text', 'entrenched interests')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'licensing'), ('#text', 'licensing')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'lyft'), ('#text', 'lyft')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'public-choice'), ('#text', 'public choice')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'taxi'), ('#text', 'taxi')]), ('wp:postmeta', [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_publicize_pending'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_published'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_client_id'), ('wp:meta_value', '-1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_facebook'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', OrderedDict([('title', 'Transit as an Inferior Good'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2013/11/25/transit-as-an-inferior-good/'), ('pubDate', 'Mon, 25 Nov 2013 19:41:00 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=69')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'Original post date: November 25, 2013\nArticle by: Ben Douglas\n\nMass transit is frequently accompanied by mass-subsidization, cartelization, and monopolies. This chronic need for artificial support might be an indication of its inherent inferiority as an economically valued good or service. If consumers preferred the bus or metro over other transportation alternatives, and if it was cost-effective, users would pay for the service and it could operate on its own merits.\n\nThis is not to say that transit cannot and does not operate without subsidization. In some places, such as<a href="http://www.coss.fsu.edu/dmc/content/limas-transit-woes">Lima, Peru</a>, it can and it does. Thousands of private bus companies, many of them illegal, compete over commuters—completely without subsidy. This, however, is the exception, not the rule.\n\nAs the DMC’s very own Dr. Sam Staley points out, <a href="http://www.planetizen.com/node/33371">transit</a> is an inferior good. “The term is not intended to be pejorative,” says Staley, “it\'s a technical one and characterizes an important economic relationship between income and the demand for a specific product or service. As our income increases, we consume less transit, opting for alternatives, most notably the automobile.”\n\nCuriously, most nations or cities that institute a transit system seem to do so as part of a plan to modernize and improve transportation. In the minds of municipal planners, transit seems to go along with advances in technology, increases in wealth, and the evolution of urban civilization. This runs contrary to what we know about inferior goods. If anything, we should see a decline in transit as people become wealthier.\n\nThis is because demand for inferior goods is inversely correlated to wealth. Thus, as society becomes wealthier, a government can only maintain transit artificially, either through ever-increasing subsidies or by limiting alternatives preferred by consumers, such as the automobile.\n\nIf public transit is the way of the future, then it also should not require such extraordinary artificial support. If a business cannot acquire a sufficient amount of <em>private</em> investment to open, but instead depended upon a multimillion dollar World Bank loan, it is reasonable to assume that the model is not sound.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '69'), ('wp:post_date', '2013-11-25 19:41:00'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2013-11-25 19:41:00'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'transit-as-an-inferior-good'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', [OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'lima'), ('#text', 'Lima')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'subsidies'), ('#text', 'subsidies')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'sustainability'), ('#text', 'sustainability')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'transit'), ('#text', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2013/12/03/obamacare-opens-up-new-opportunities-for-profit/'), ('pubDate', 'Tue, 03 Dec 2013 19:43:00 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=71')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'Original post date: December 03, 2013\nArticle by: Anonymous\n\nThe Affordable Care Act has many flaws and critics, but entrepreneurial individuals have found a way to profit from the law, and investors are eager to take advantage of these openings. With new online exchanges, new policies and regulations, and millions of individuals affected, several service markets are opening up.\n\n<a href="http://www.businessinsider.com/obamacare-is-the-chance-of-a-lifetime-for-venture-capitalists-2013-10">Venture capitalists are looking for opportunities to invest</a> in companies that help health providers adjust to new billing methods, design technology for the online marketplaces, or are otherwise involved in the remodeled healthcare system. Since so many people will be joining an already crowded system, medical practices will be looking toward technological advances to increase efficiency.\n\nThe premiere of the exchanges revealed a host of technological glitches, indicating a need for investment into some more advanced technology and expertise in the online marketplaces’ designs. Additionally, many people remain in the dark about their options in the exchanges, so consumer education and marketing likely will become a profitable enterprise.\n\nAnother service opportunity exists for data collection, management, and analysis. Doctors need data on their patients for a myriad of reasons, the least of which is for proof to insurers for compensation. Doctors will also need to know which insurance plans provide the most compensation and whether the coverage on plans meets their standards. Comprehensive documentation and analysis of data in the healthcare industry is both immensely important and cumbersome to collect and manage, so innovators who can make it more efficient will be rewarded.\n\nBilling is another area within healthcare that could benefit from some entrepreneurial attention. The new third-party payer system and other massive changes that are occurring will also make waves in the billing departments of hospitals and doctor offices across the country.\n\nWhile many of its effects have been less than favorable, the Affordable Care Act has succeeded in at least one thing: providing new opportunities for employment and creating new investment opportunities for those with capital.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '71'), ('wp:post_date', '2013-12-03 19:43:00'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2013-12-03 19:43:00'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'obamacare-opens-up-new-opportunities-for-profit'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', ('pubDate', 'Tue, 10 Dec 2013 19:45:00 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=73')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'Original post date: December 10, 2013\nArticle by: Ben Douglas\n\nIn my <a href="http://www.coss.fsu.edu/dmc/content/entrenched-interests-fight-innovation-taxi-industry">previous</a> <a href="http://www.coss.fsu.edu/dmc/content/customers-rise-support-taxi-innovator">blogs</a>, I discussed some of the legal and regulatory hurdles encountered by Uber, a Transportation Network Company (TNC) that provides on-demand taxi and limousine services using a smartphone app to connect passengers with nearby drivers. \xa0In this blog, I will analyze the regulatory framework encountered by the venture-funded startup company from several different perspectives.\n\nBroadly speaking, the regulatory situation can be seen in two different ways. From Uber’s perspective, taxi companies such as Yellow Cab are jealously guarding their monopoly rents. The established taxi interests are anti-competitive, and regulators who carry out their wishes to quash new firms are unjust. (See <a href="http://www.fee.org/the_freeman/detail/taxi-regulation-and-the-failures-of-progressivism#axzz2 kxlUeqTv">this analysis</a> by Sam Staley.) By bringing Uber into the regulatory fold, agencies such as the <a href="http://reason.com/reasontv/2013/10/22/the-uber-wars-how-dc-tried-to-smother-a">D.C. Taxi Commission</a> are attempting to fix something that is not broken. Indeed, Uber is not even a transportation carrier; it’s a middleman not even in the same industry.\n\nFrom the perspective of existing firms, however, Uber is subverting the rules, regulations, and fees that everyone else in the industry is forced to abide by. Far from jealously guarding their monopoly privilege, existing firms’ attempts to use government to sabotage Uber and other TNCs stem from the righteous pursuit of legal equality. In fairness, these upstarts should be subjected to the same rules, the same minimum fare statutes and the same licensing requirements that established firms are forced to comply with. Regulatory compliance is costly, and a market in which some firms’ costs are greater than others can hardly be deemed free, open, or just.\n\nThe other two parties in the “Uber wars” are consumers and regulators. Regulators theoretically exist to serve the needs of consumers, but analyzing their function through the lens of <a href="http://www.econlib.org/library/Enc/PublicChoice.html">public choice</a> can provide us with a few insights. In his seminal 1971 article “The Theory of Economic Regulation,” Nobel laureate George Stigler argues that regulators are sometimes “captured” by the firms they are supposed to be regulating. When this happens, they cease to serve the needs of consumers and begin serving the needs of the industry.\n\nMy <a href="http://www.coss.fsu.edu/dmc/content/entrenched-interests-fight-innovation-taxi-industry">previous</a> <a href="http://www.coss.fsu.edu/dmc/content/customers-rise-support-taxi-innovator">blogs</a> described real life examples of regulatory capture the Dallas, D.C., and L.A. taxi industries. These are by no means isolated incidents. Taxi regulations across the United States overwhelmingly protect established companies and drivers from competition. Local regulators harm potential new firms by erecting barriers to entry in the transportation services market, making it difficult to enter into business and compete with the establishment.\n\nPotential new firms are not the only losers, however. Consumers suffer from the artificially constricted supply, higher prices, and worse service. Established taxi companies and TNCs are thus not the only conflicting parties in the Uber Wars. Consumers’ and regulators’ interests can be at odds as well.\n\nRectifying these regulatory ills will be the taxi industry’s greatest challenge in coming years. When casting your bets on who will win the Uber Wars, it is important to remember that lawmaking is a political process. If history is any indication, the victor will likely be the party with the greatest political clout.\n\nWhile taxi franchises tend to have significant influence with municipal governments, Uber has shown remarkable strength and versatility. Who will emerge on top—or whether a compromise will be reached that leaves both parties unsatisfied, <a href="http://www.bizjournals.com/sanfrancisco/blog/2013/10/uber-lyft-sidecar-taxicab-puc.html?page=all">as was the case in California</a>—is anyone’s guess.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:postmeta', [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_publicize_pending'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_published'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('title', 'Selling Land to Buy Land'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2014/01/22/selling-land-to-buy-land/'), ('pubDate', 'Wed, 22 Jan 2014 19:46:00 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=75')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'Original post date: January 22, 2014\nArticle by: Anonymous\n\nFlorida has more than 3 million acres of state lands protected from development by the Department of Environmental Protection (DEP). Almost 5,000 acres of this conservation land could soon be up for sale. The sales are intended to raise $50 million to buy more conservation land.\n\nThe Preservation 2000 program, which expanded on earlier land acquisition programs, began in the early 1990s. Conservation advocates were concerned about the rapid growth of Florida cities and sugar plantations, so, with state funds they purchased large amounts of property. In doing so they saved environmentally sensitive land, crucial for water preservation and quality as well as providing a habitat <a href="http://www.dep.state.fl.us/lands/fl_forever.htm">to over 285 rare species</a>, including the alligator and the Florida panther. In the early 1990s Florida had the largest land acquisition program for environmental protection efforts in the US. Much of the land acquired was private property, raising some questions in the minds of skeptics about violation of basic property rights. Benjamin G. Parks of the National Inholders Association protested the acquisition, insisting that the solution to “an alleged wildlife problem” would create “<a href="http://www.evergladesplan.org/docs/river_interest/031512_river_interests_2012_chap_10.pdf">a very real problem to the people</a>” (p.165). Support for the program was widespread throughout the scientific community, which listed Florida as one of the “most-endangered ecosystems” <a href="http://www.gator-woman.com/statusreport.html">in a 1995 status report on endangered ecosystems.</a>\n\nDespite a few concerns with property rights of citizens, the program was applauded and led to Florida Forever, through which large amounts of property were acquired. Now, 20 years later, the Florida Forever program has seen a reduction in annual funding from $300 million to $20 million in the 2013 legislature.\xa0The legislature authorized <a href="http://www.dep.state.fl.us/lands/assessment/">an additional $50 million in spending</a>, provided the funds were obtained by selling lands no longer needed for conservation purposes. The money is to be used to acquire lands with a greater need for conservation. <a href="http://www.dep.state.fl.us/lands/assessment/Maps.htm">The list</a>of properties was assembled rapidly and originally included over 10,000 acres. The Trust for Public Land warned that the total revenue from the sales would not come up to $50 million, and recommended that the DEP <a href="http://www.tampabay.com/news/environment/list-of-surplus-state-park-land-raises-questions-outrage/2139676">reset their criteria. </a>The list has since been adjusted to include around 5,000 acres worth of property, with around half the acreage of the original list it is unlikely the sale will achieve the target $50 million.\n\nThe proposed lands to sell include 5.4 acres from the <a href="http://www.floridastateparks.org/catfishcreek/"><strong>Allen David Broussard Catfish Creek Preserve State Park</strong></a> in Polk County. This has infuriated William and Margaret Broussard, who donated a large amount of money towards the purchase of this state park in memorial of their son. They are resisting the sale of this property with the help of attorney Clay Henderson. In a <a href="http://static-lobbytools.s3.amazonaws.com/press/60348_clay_henderson_letter_to_dep.pdf">letter</a> to the DEP, Henderson said he is “ deeply troubled by this very rushed effort to sell off portions of the legacy of Florida\'s irreplaceable conservation lands.” Henderson’s concerns are shared by non-profits and conservationists such as the<a href="http://www.northfloridalandtrust.org/">North Florida Land Trust</a> (NFLT). Marc Hudson, the NFLT land protection director says the “<a href="http://news.wjct.org/post/proposed-sale-florida-conservation-lands-causes-concern">process is being rushed before it can be assessed properly.” </a>\n\nLand acquisition can be costly and complicated, and the process often leaves individuals feeling out of the loop. Even when they attempt to cooperate with state agencies to preserve land, as was the case with William and Margaret Broussard, the results are only guaranteed as long as the land remains valuable to the ecological goals of whatever agency is in charge. There are several options, to provide better funding and staffing to agencies dedicated to environmental protection, or to investigate private initiatives. Private initiatives have higher incentives to respond to performance metrics and market forces. Government agencies are required to deal with a large amount of bureaucracy and often suffer from a lack of any “substantial performance review.” <a href="http://reason.org/news/show/conservation-through-private-i">As Michael De Alessi from the Reason Foundation says</a>, “Using performance indicators to measure and acknowledge conservation success, especially in the context of using the land is the next logical step.”'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '75'), ('wp:post_date', '2014-01-22 19:46:00'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2014-01-22 19:46:00'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'selling-land-to-buy-land'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', 'land-conservation'), ('#text', 'land conservation')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'land-use'), ('#text', 'Land Use')])]), ('wp:postmeta', [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_publicize_pending'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_published'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_client_id'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_path'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', 'Why do Workers Support The Minimum Wage?'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2014/02/03/why-do-workers-support-the-minimum-wage/'), ('pubDate', 'Mon, 03 Feb 2014 10:12:00 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=77')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'Original post date: February 03, 2014\nArticle by: Ben Douglas\n\nOne of the more peculiar political phenomena of our time is the widespread support of <a href="http://www.usatoday.com/story/money/business/2013/12/05/fast-food-strike-wages/3877023/">minimum wage laws</a>among unskilled labor, particularly service workers in low-wage industries such as hotels, restaurants, and retail shops. This is likely to increase with <a href="http://www.cbsnews.com/news/obamas-2014-state-of-the-union-address-full-text/">President Obama’s push to increase the minimum wage to over $10 per hour</a>.\n\n<a href="http://coss.fsu.edu/d6/dmc/content/walmart-minimum-wages-and-economic-development">Economists largely agree</a> that an effective minimum wage is likely to increase unemployment. Wages are generally set based on the perceived productivity of workers. Pushing wages higher than their productive level will result in fewer jobs, pushing low productivity workers into unemployment lines.\n\nYet, from an economist’s perspective, unskilled workers seem to provide broad-based support for increasing the minimum wage. Why?\n\nThree possible reasons exist for their insistence upon pricing themselves out of the labor market. The first is they believe demand curves don’t slope downward. In other words, the higher cost of labor will not reduce quantity demanded for the labor among employers. If this is the case, the discipline of economics as a whole is being questioned and minimum wage debates are of the least concern.\n\nThe second is that they are masochists yearning for institutional unemployment. If this is the case, the ethical choice would be to quit their own jobs and refrain from subjecting their colleagues to such disparaging treatment.\n\nThe third possibility—and the most likely—is that they have been deceived by political agents with an agenda.\n\nOne factor that should make unskilled workers think twice about attempting to raise wages by legislative fiat is the wily support proffered by skilled labor—their competitors.\xa0 Unions, which overwhelmingly represent skilled workers, have historically lobbied for minimum wage laws.\n\nThe <a href="http://www.aflcio.org/Issues/Jobs-and-Economy/Wages-and-Income/Minimum-Wage">AFL-CIO</a> claims this is because they are a “critical and simple way to help repair the underlying weakness in our economy” and “would boost consumer spending and increase the purchasing power of millions of low-wage workers, especially in states with the highest percentages of low-wage workers[.]”\n\nWhile this makes for excellent political propaganda, <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Price_floor">price floors</a> in the labor market represent nothing short of inter-industry protectionism. Relatively wealthy, skilled, and white union laborers have a vested interest in minimum wages because they price their competition out of the labor market.\n\nIf the economic value of an hour of an individual’s labor is $5, and the minimum wage is $7.25, he will not be hired because his productivity doesn’t compensate for the cost of employing him. Because skilled and unskilled labor are <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Substitute_good">substitutes</a>, employers often turn to more productive—and expensive—skilled workers, even though it would be less efficient in a free labor market.\n\nUnions support immigration control for similar reasons. Labor tends to flow to where capital is abundant, just as capital flows to where labor is abundant. Because the United States is a relatively capital-abundant country, workers migrate here in search of higher-paying jobs. These workers tend to be unskilled and thus represent a threat to union labor.\n\nThe iconic phrase “They took our jobs!”—made so by <em>South Park’s</em> <a href="http://www.southparkstudios.com/full-episodes/s08e06-goobacks">brilliant satire of protectionism in the labor market</a>—encapsulates the rage felt by American workers who are out-competed by migratory labor. (For a critique of this, see <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Z9csCerjfdE">this video</a> on the economic effects of the North American Free Trade Agreement, or NAFTA, on labor by ReasonTV).\n\nCircumstances such as these illustrate the importance of economic understanding in policymaking. As economist Murray Rothbard <a href="http://mises.org/daily/2197">noted</a>, “It is no crime to be ignorant of economics, which is, after all, a specialized discipline and one that most people consider to be a ‘dismal science.’ But it is totally irresponsible to have a loud and vociferous opinion on economic subjects while remaining in this state of ignorance.”'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '77'), ('wp:post_date', '2014-02-03 10:12:00'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2014-02-03 10:12:00'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'why-do-workers-support-the-minimum-wage'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', [OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'afl-cio'), ('#text', 'AFL-CIO')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'economics'), ('#text', 'economics')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'immigration'), ('#text', 'immigration')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'labor'), ('#text', 'labor')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'labor-economics'), ('#text', 'Labor Economics')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'minimum-wage'), ('#text', 'minimum wage')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'price-floors'), ('#text', 'price floors')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'productivity'), ('#text', 'productivity')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'south-park'), ('#text', 'south park')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'unemployment'), ('#text', 'unemployment')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'unions'), ('#text', 'unions')])]), ('wp:postmeta', [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_publicize_pending'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_published'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_client_id'), ('wp:meta_value', '-1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_facebook'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_google_plus'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_twitter'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_linkedin'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_tumblr'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_path'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', 'Solar Energy Users Left in the Dark by Utilities'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2014/02/06/solar-energy-users-left-in-the-dark-by-utilities/'), ('pubDate', 'Thu, 06 Feb 2014 10:16:00 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=79')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'Original post date: February 06, 2014\nArticle by: Anonymous\n\nSolar powered homes are becoming increasingly ubiquitous as US citizens move toward more environmentally sustainable ways of using energy. In 2013 rooftop solar systems were being installed at a rate of <a href="http://www.seia.org/research-resources/solar-market-insight-report-2013-q2">one new installation every 4 minutes</a>. Although the Obama Administration is pushing for public and private investment into solar energy, one institution seems less than pleased with the transition: utilities.\n\nCurrently, homes in the US are connected to power grids by area and county utility offices receive large revenues from their constituents’ power usage. Solar panels present a threat to this setup, as they allow people to generate their own energy independently, reducing costs for the homeowner as well as decreasing the revenue of utilities. Many cities have enabled solar paneled homes to connect to the grid and decrease their monthly bills by the amount of energy they produced themselves (a process called net metering), though other utility institutions are being less than acquiescent.\n\nHawaii is one state where, despite a boom in rooftop solar panel installations, solar energy is not providing citizens much respite from high energy costs. In a state with very little shade and a lot of sun, most people run their air conditioning constantly and the costs become astronomical. The opportunity to install a fixture that will permanently cut down high electric costs was one that many Hawaiians jumped on. It’s especially popular given the subsidies available to those who want to install solar panels. Unfortunately, the promise of lower energy costs has not been made fruitful yet in the state of Hawaii.\n\nThis is because Hawaiian Electric Industries, Inc. (HECO), a company that provides nearly all of the energy to Hawaiian citizens, is refusing to connect the solar systems to the energy grid. This means that although citizens are producing their own energy, it isn’t hooked up to the electrical system that powers their homes, so the energy being used is still coming from the utility. The virtual moratorium has left consumers paying their normally high electric bills, in addition to new monthly payments on rooftop solar systems. HECO insists that their resistance is an issue of both safety and timing, noting concerns that with an influx of solar energy “<a href="http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-12-26/utilities-feeling-rooftop-solar-heat-start-fighting-back.html">circuits may become oversaturated, causing voltage spikes, damaging appliances, electronics, and even the utility’s equipment</a>.” HECO needs more time to study the systems before allowing them to be amalgamated with the current grid.\n\nNeither HECO nor Hawaiians with solar systems are alone in their plights; many other states are experiencing similar issues. Some utilities have proposed assessing taxes or fees on solar efficient homes, to offset their lack of financial contribution to the electric grids. Others are charging fees to hook up solar systems to the grid, or monthly fees for said connection.\n\nFew citizens are in support of these measures, and many no longer wish to support utilities. If utilities fail to adapt to a changing market, it is possible that they will lose not only revenue but customers as well. One alternative to net metering is using solar power and batteries. Hawaii, for instance, has plenty of year-round sun for solar panel users to power their homes on sunny days, and store up excess energy for rainy ones.\n\nUtility companies sit in a very precarious position. There are costs involved with the upkeep and maintenance of power grids, and they have legitimate concerns regarding how these costs will be covered if people begin to power their own home energy usage. If utility companies refuse to adapt their business model to the growing demand for energy alternatives, they may soon notice that demand for the services they provide is diminishing. High costs spur cost-saving innovations, and unless utilities get on board they will face the ugly side of creative destruction.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '79'), ('wp:post_date', '2014-02-06 10:16:00'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2014-02-06 10:16:00'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'solar-energy-users-left-in-the-dark-by-utilities'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', [OrderedDict([('@domain', ('wp:postmeta', [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_publicize_pending'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_published'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('title', 'The Two Kinds of Capitalism'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2014/02/12/the-two-kinds-of-capitalism/'), ('pubDate', 'Wed, 12 Feb 2014 10:20:00 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=81')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'Original post date: February 12, 2014\nArticle by: Ben Douglas\n\nThe term “capitalism” is often thrown around in American political discourse without a specified or coherent meaning. Frequently in a debate, opposing parties will attack or defend their own perceived ideas of what capitalism is, without realizing that their opponent has in mind a completely different system. In the spirit of clearing up this widespread miscommunication, a clear delineation should be maintained at all times between two competing economic systems, both of which are frequently referred to as “capitalism.” These two systems, I will argue, are different not just in degree, but in kind.\n\nThe first type of capitalism is “free-market” or <em>“laissez-faire”</em> capitalism. This is the capitalism of Enlightenment Philosophers Adam Smith and David Hume, economist Ludwig von Mises, and Nobel prize winners Friedrich Hayek and Milton Friedman as well as their many acolytes. Proponents have historically self-identified as liberals (in the classical sense) and supported property rights and small government. Rarely, if ever, do they support monopoly.\n\nIndeed, a vast body of literature in the free-market capitalist tradition is stringently anti-monopoly. An exception is typically made for the provision of law, courts, protection, roads, and some minimalist regulatory institutions, although a number of <em>laissez-faire</em> capitalists have proposed that the market could produce these services better than the state, notably Bruce Benson, David Friedman, and Murray Rothbard.\n\nThe second type of capitalism is “crony” capitalism. Florida State University economist Randall G. <a href="http://mercatus.org/sites/default/files/Crony-Capitalsim-Holcombe-v1-0.pdf">Holcombe</a>describes it as “an economic system in which the profitability of firms in a market economy is dependent on political connections.” In addition to politicians and businessmen who stand to benefit from crony capitalist policies, proponents include well-intentioned neoconservatives and New Deal or left-liberals, whose support is often inadvertent.\n\nNeither kind of capitalism is intrinsically pro-business. Each proposes a different method of doing business. Under both systems, businesses are profit maximizing. Under free market capitalism, however, profits can only be made by producing goods or services that satisfy the wants of consumers. Under crony capitalism, businesses attempt to have laws passed protecting one’s business from competition and imposing costs on the competition. Tariffs protect domestic manufacturers from foreign competition. Subsidies give their recipients a leg up on the competition. Patents grant their holders flat-out monopolies. Regulations impose costs on doing business, thereby creating barriers to entry. The process by which businesses attempt to be at the receiving end of these privileges is known as rent-seeking.\n\nIn a crony-capitalist economy, businessmen cannot simply opt out of rent-seeking. Failure to hire lawyers and lobbyists can be a fatal move— deciding to play nice does not mean the other guy will. The practices of “<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Defensive_medicine">defensive medicine</a>” and “<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Defensive_patent_aggregation">defensive patent aggregation</a>” are two examples of this. Very successful companies are often the target of antitrust lawsuits brought on at the behest of jealous competitors. The extreme malleability of antitrust law enables any company to be arguably found in violation, if its industry is interpreted narrowly enough\n\nFor these reasons, the two kinds of capitalism—free-market and crony capitalism—are different in kind. Under the former, profits are made solely by serving consumer demand. Under the latter, profits can also be made by using the political system to manipulate the market to reward some businesses at the expense of others. This point is further supported by the fact that each system is instituted using entirely opposite means. This will be the subject of my next blog.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '81'), ('wp:post_date', '2014-02-12 10:20:00'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2014-02-12 10:20:00'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'the-two-kinds-of-capitalism'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', [OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'bruce-benson'), ('#text', 'Bruce Benson')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'business'), ('#text', 'business')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'crony-capitalism'), ('#text', 'crony capitalism')]), OrderedDict([('@domain',
