'randall-holcombe'), ('#text', 'Randall Holcombe')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'rent-seeking'), ('#text', 'rent seeking')])]), ('wp:postmeta', [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_publicize_pending'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_published'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_client_id'), ('wp:meta_value', '-1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_facebook'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_google_plus'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_twitter'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_linkedin'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_tumblr'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_path'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', 'A March for Charity Reform is Afoot'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2014/08/28/a-march-for-charity-reform-is-afoot/'), ('pubDate', 'Thu, 28 Aug 2014 17:07:00 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=105')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'Original post date: August, 28, 2014\n\nPosted by: Matt Kelly\n\nBy June of next year, hundreds, perhaps thousands will be marching 60 miles through New England to Salem, Massachusetts, the site where the Pilgrims first landed at Plymouth Rock. For three days, these passionate activists will trudge a path to change the world. They will come from many diverse backgrounds, but they will all be marching for a common cause:<strong>causes</strong>.\n\nCauses? Sounds paradoxical, doesn’t it? Broad at the very least. Many reading this have probably participated in a 5K walk for breast cancer or autism, but marching for causes themselves? <strong>Just why is there a need for this meta-march?</strong>\n\nMembers of <a href="http://charitydefensecouncil.org/" target="_blank">The Charity Defense Council</a> say the need is dire. They claim that charities in America are beholden to an unrealistic ideal that’s kept them locked in the dark ages. They argue that <strong>without a change in public policy and public perception, we will never be able to change the world for the better.</strong>\n\nCharities are uniquely handicapped in their ability to take risks and spend revenues. Like a business, a charity must take risks to innovate and receive rewards, yet donors discourage such behavior. Could Apple have created the iPhone with costs below 20% of revenues? Not a chance! Could Netflix have brought itscustomers the unprecedented access to entertainment they now enjoy without first taking the risk that it might not work? No way! Charities with high staffing and marketing costs can be done for if they get a bad rap from watchdog groups. Yet for-profit businesses take such risks on a daily basis, reaping the rewards for their customers. The Charity Defense Council suggests the social sector must do likewise if they are to solve the world’s monumental social problems and help those in need.\n\nThe Charity Defense Council is headed by its charismatic leader, Dan Pallotta. In previous blogs (<a href="http://www.socialenterprisecompetition.com/competition-blog/june-26th-2014" target="_blank">read here</a>) I’ve discussed Pallotta’s for-profit charity fundraising model, which raised over half a billion dollars to fights AIDS and breast cancer during the 1990s. Pallotta has been a champion of the social sector, pointing out this flawed double standardand its detrimental effect on those in need. Governments and private donors tend to emphasize the percentage of revenues that charities spends on overhead costs, while ignoring their actual impact. Further exacerbating this problem are the onerous government grant conditions that can keep nonprofits’ administrative costs high. This is a recipe for stagnation in the social sector, Pallotta says.\n\nYet many donors are still wary to give their money to an organization that spends too much on overhead. At first glance this can make sense. If your donation to a charity simply enriches its CEO, then you might reasonably consider that a waste. However, charities, like businesses, must attract talent if they wish to be effective in solving social problems. <strong>Dan Pallotta and the Charity Defense Council are forcing people to ask tough questions, challenging our long held beliefs about charity.</strong> With a stated mission to “change the way people think about changing the world,” they certainly have their work cut out for them.\n\nThe Charity Defense Council hopes to raise $1 million with this march so they can act as an anti-defamation organization. Already, many nonprofit employees are registering in a show of\xa0support from the social sector. Though the Charity Defense Council’s mission is of national relevance, its efforts give Floridians reason to reexamine our state’s policies with regard to nonprofit regulation and charitable giving. In future blogs, I’ll be talking about just that.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '105'), ('wp:post_date', '2014-08-28 17:07:00'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2014-08-28 17:07:00'), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'charity'), ('#text', 'charity')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'charity-defense-council'), ('#text', 'charity defense Party Lines'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2014/09/08/uber-wars-transcend-party-lines/'), ('pubDate', 'Mon, 08 Sep 2014 10:22:00 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=83')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'Original post date: September 08, 2014\nArticle by: Ben Douglas\n\nHigh-ranking Republican officials have recently come out in support of Uber, the innovative but legally-troubled ridesharing app that connects drivers and passengers. Republican National Committee Chairman Reince Priebus penned an op-ed in the Chicago Tribune <a href="http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/opinion/commentary/ct-uber-innovation-republican-perspec-0807-20140807-story.html">lambasting Democratic leadership</a> for being “less than hospitable to Uber.” The RNC has even <a href="http://www.gop.com/act/support-uber-petition">posted a petition</a> in favor of the service on its website. In an email calling for signatures and donations, RNC Finance Director Katie Walsh condemns “government officials” for “trying to block Uber from providing services simply because it’s cutting into the taxi unions\' profits.”\n\nThere are two factual problems with this narrative and a political one. First, opposition to the interests of Uber, Lyft, and Sidecar come overwhelmingly from the taxi, limousine, and insurance industries, not drivers or their unions. Second, many of the “government officials trying to block Uber from providing services” are Republicans, which conflicts with the partisan narrative. Finally, framing the taxi innovation cause as anti-union risks alienating taxi drivers who could be some of its greatest supporters.\n\nWhile the dichotomy of “taxi unions and liberal government bureaucrats” vs. “free market principles, entrepreneurial spirit, and economic freedom” may help rally the troops in one camp, a comprehensive assessment of the Uber Wars reveals transcendence of party lines. Complicated networks of political alliances based on economic incentives and concerns regarding <a href="http://coss.fsu.edu/d6/dmc/content/uber-wars">legal equality</a> and <a href="http://www.fastcompany.com/3032165/most-innovative-companies/why-the-insurance-industry-is-taking-aim-at-uber-and-lyft">insurance coverage</a> have put many Republican officials at odds with the GOP’s position on Uber.\n\nGeorgia’s <a href="http://www.legis.ga.gov/legislation/en-US/display/20132014/HB/907">pro-taxi monopoly bill</a> was sponsored by five Republicans and only one Democrat. Arizona Governor Jan Brewer, a Republican, vetoed HB 2262 in April—a measure <a href="http://blog.uber.com/keepazmovingforward">supported </a><a href="https://www.facebook.com/uber/posts/745296585510629">by Uber</a>. New Jersey’s Christie Administration <a href="http://www.northjersey.com/news/car-service-network-uber-gains-clients-critics-in-north-jersey-1.1043198?page=all">co-issued a consumer alert</a> with the Department of Banking and Insurance against using ridesharing services.\n\nGOP opposition becomes somewhat more understandable when you follow the money. Taxicab trade associations—Uber’s primary opponents—donate generously to Republicans. The Virginia Taxicab Association has given <a href="http://www.vpap.org/committees/profile/money_out_recipients/709?start_year=2000&amp;end_year=2014&amp;lookup_type=year&amp;filing_period=all">$427,150 to the state’s politicians since 2000</a>, of which 59% went to Republicans. \xa0A recently-formed Illinois Taxi PAC with a $1 million annual budget <a href="http://www.huffingtonpost.com/david-ormsby/new-illinois-taxi-industr_b_5621881.html">sent its first check to the state’s House GOP leader</a>.\n\nOn the other hand, many prominent Democrats support Uber. Maryland Governor Martin O’Malley <a href="http://www.governor.maryland.gov/blog/?p=10685">protested the decision</a> by the state’s Public Service Commission to regulate Uber, arguing<em>, </em>"We shouldn\'t try to limit a 21st century marketplace with 20th century regulations." Chicago Mayor Rahm Emmanuel <a href="http://www.nbcchicago.com/blogs/ward-room/chicago-city-council-rideshare-uberx-lyft--260974811.html">endorsed an ordinance </a><a href="http://blog.uber.com/ChiOrdinance">favored by Uber</a>.\n\nA more politically astute narrative can be constructed in terms of benefits accrued to drivers by Uber and the costs imposed on them by regulation. For example, the strict taxi company permitting requirements—vigorously defended by the companies themselves—serve to increase market concentration. Our ongoing research on taxi regulations in more than 40 U.S. cities, has shown a <a href="http://coss.fsu.edu/dmc/sites/coss.fsu.edu.dmc/files/Staley_Douglas_APEETaxiConcentration_Ver2.pdf">significant negative relationship between market concentration and taxi driver wages</a>. Uber also provides an avenue for luxury sedan drivers to make a little money on the side through fulfilling the unmet demand created by market entry restrictions.\n\nOpposition to taxi cartelism is hardly limited to one side of the aisle. A big-tent philosophy is advantageous to transportation innovation by incorporating all potential allies, including Democrats and drivers, as well as providing long-term benefits to consumers of these services.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '83'), ('wp:post_date', '2014-09-08 10:22:00'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2014-09-08 10:22:00'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'uber-wars-transcend-party-lines'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', [OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'democrat'), ('#text', 'democrat')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'taxi-licensing'), ('#text', 'Taxi licensing')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'taxis'), ('#text', 'taxis')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'tnc'), ('#text', 'tnc')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'transit'), ('#text', 'transit')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'transportation'), ('#text', 'Transportation')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'transportation-2'), ('#text', 'transportation')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'uber'), ('#text', 'uber')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'uber-x'), ('#text', 'uber x')])]), ('wp:postmeta', [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_publicize_pending'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_published'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_client_id'), ('wp:meta_value', '-1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_facebook'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_google_plus'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_twitter'), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_path'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', 'Florida Workers Would Suffer from Minimum Wage Increase'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2014/09/10/florida-workers-would-suffer-from-minimum-wage-increase/'), ('pubDate', 'Wed, 10 Sep 2014 10:26:00 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=85')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', '<span class="submit">Original post date: September 10, 2014\nArticle by: Matt Kelly</span>\n<div class="content">\n<p dir="ltr">As Floridians nurse their Labor Day sunburns, it’s worth remembering the twentieth century labor movement’s legacies. Chief among them is the<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fair_Labor_Standards_Act"> Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938,</a> a federal law that established the minimum wage. From its original hourly level of $0.25, the federal minimum wage has risen to $7.25 today. In Florida, the minimum wage is $7.93 and determined by a cost of living formula. Recently, President Obama has <a href="http://www.whitehouse.gov/raise-the-wage">called for an increase to $10.10</a>. Despite mountains of research, the minimum wage’s effects on employment remain controversial. A paper from Texas A&amp;M University revisits this long-standing debate. Its results are especially relevant to Florida’s workers.</p>\n<p dir="ltr"><a href="http://www.nber.org/papers/w19262">The 2013 paper from Jeremy</a> <a href="http://www.nber.org/papers/w19262">West and Jonathan Meer</a> reassesses the statistical methods commonly used in labor economics. The authors contend the minimum wage’s effect will be most acute in job growth, rather than aggregate employment levels. This emphasis on growth makes some sense. A business may be loath to terminate workers already on their payrolls, but hiring fewer new employees is an easier way to adjust to higher labor costs. The authors ultimately find that increases in the minimum wage reduce job growth.</p>\n<p dir="ltr">This negative effect is strongest in the retail and food service sectors, making the authors’ findings especially pertinent to Floridians. Florida’s housing market underperformed the national average during the recent recession, and the resulting shift of labor from construction to the service industry has made the minimum wage all the more impactful. Nationally, only about 1% of workers receive a minimum wage, but those who do are more likely to be young and less educated. The Sunshine State is second only to Texas in the number of workers earning the minimum wage, making our state particularly vulnerable to increases.</p>\n<p dir="ltr">Proponents of the minimum wage often point out that theoretical models used by economists have ambiguous implications. Meer and West note that, “although it reduces demand for labor by raising the marginal cost of employing a new worker,” a higher minimum wage might incentivize workers to search for jobs. These countervailing forces will have differing effects in different communities, however. The effect of a minimum wage increase in Orlando would be very different from a city like <a href="http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2014/06/11/seattle-minimum-wage-15-challenge/10344443/">Seattle, Washington, where it was just increased to $15 an hour</a>. In states with large service sectors like Florida, increases in the minimum wage could be more detrimental than in areas where manufacturing or finance are primary industries</p>\n<p dir="ltr">Controversy will continue to dog this issue, especially with President Obama’s calls for an increase to $10.10 an hour, equivalent to a full-time compensation of $20,000 a year. Gubernatorial candidate Charlie Crist has even made raising the minimum wage a part his <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=a8rLScdk66M&amp;feature=youtu.be">campaign\'s platform</a>. However, Meer and West’s work suggests such an increase would mean fewer new jobs for Florida. <a href="http://www.cbo.gov/publication/44995">The Congressional Budget Office’s estimates</a> say 500,000 jobs nationwide could be lost if the minimum wage rose to $10.10. That may be a price Charlie Crist and President Obama are willing to pay, but Florida’s would-be workers could find it too costly.</p>\n\n</div>'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '85'), ('wp:post_date', '2014-09-10 10:26:00'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2014-09-10 10:26:00'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'florida-workers-would-suffer-from-minimum-wage-increase'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), OrderedDict([('title', 'Do UberX Driveres Really Earn Three Times More than Taxi Drivers?'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2014/09/16/do-uberx-driveres-really-earn-three-times-more-than-taxi-drivers/'), ('pubDate', 'Tue, 16 Sep 2014 10:28:00 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=87')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', '<span class="submit">Original post date: September 16, 2014\nArticle by: Ben Douglas</span>\n<div class="content">\n\nIn May, Uber revealed annual median incomes for UberX drivers in New York and San Francisco of $90,766 and $74,191, respectively. In contrast, 2013 median annual taxi driver incomes in New York and San Francisco are $29,910 and $28,060 <a href="http://www.bls.gov/oes/tables.htm">according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics</a> (BLS). This translates into UberX driver annual incomes exceeding taxi incomes by 303% in New York City and 264% in San Francisco. In other words, Uber pays its drivers three times as well!\n\nOnline magazines such as <a href="http://time.com/119587/do-uberx-drivers-really-take-home-90k-a-year-on-average-not-exactly/">Time </a>and <a href="http://pando.com/2014/05/29/fact-checking-ubers-claims-about-driver-income-shockingly-theyre-not-true/">Pando </a>were quick to criticize Uber for using gross and not net figures (i.e., for excluding fuel, insurance, wear and tear). <a href="http://valleywag.gawker.com/beautiful-illusions-the-economics-of-uberx-1589509520/all">ValleyWag</a>, <a href="http://www.businessinsider.com/how-much-you-earn-as-an-uber-driver-2014-6">Business Insider</a>, and <a href="http://www.dailydot.com/business/uber-driver-actual-salary-earnings-wage-90000/">The Daily Dot</a> followed suit. Uber followed up by sending Fusion’s Felix Salmon <a href="https://medium.com/@felixsalmon/the-economics-of-everyones-private-driver-464bfd730b38">good-faith driver cost estimates</a>: “If we go with these figures, we end up with net income for a New York uberX driver of $75,686, and net income for a San Francisco uberX driver of $60,014. Both of which are still significantly higher than the kind of money cab drivers make in NYC and SF respectively.” While we don’t have good estimates for net taxi income for comparison, the fact that UberX’s net incomes are still greater than gross taxi incomes in New York and San Francisco by 240% and 210%, respectively, is revealing.\n\nThere are several factors which, when taken into account, diminish the difference between taxi and UberX incomes. First, Uber’s figures come from <a href="http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/innovations/wp/2014/05/27/ubers-remarkable-growth-could-end-the-era-of-poorly-paid-cab-drivers/">drivers putting in at least 40 hours/week,</a> whereas the BLS figures likely understate the incomes by assuming an exact 40-hour work week. Second, the BLS calculates incomes for the entire Metropolitan Statistical Area. As a result, the income estimates may be understated due to lower population density outside the city limits and higher demand for cabs in the city. Finally, Uber likely used <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Median">median </a>instead of <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mean">mean</a> incomes for their best-paid cities in order to show the highest value possible. BLS mean taxi incomes are also somewhat higher than median, thus the switch would decrease the difference even if it wouldn’t affect UberX incomes.\n\nWhile adjusting for these factors likely would decrease the difference between UberX and taxi incomes, the basic conclusion probably doesn’t change: UberX drivers are much better compensated than taxi drivers in San Francisco and New York. This is supported by the fact that BLS taxi [gross] incomes include tips, and incorporate data from limousine drivers, who tend to have higher incomes than cab drivers. Finally, taxi drivers often face even more costs of operation than rideshare drivers i<a href="http://coss.fsu.edu/dmc/content/restrictive-taxi-licensing-hurts-economic-opportunity">n the form of permit-related fees</a> and car lease expenses.\n\nThe fact of the matter is we don’t have enough data to draw strong nationwide, or Florida specific, conclusions on driver incomes. Nonetheless, these impressive figures indicate the magnitude of ridesharing’s\xa0 potential to transform transportation markets. The initial evidence is promising. Uber is not just good for consumers; Uber is great for its drivers as well.\n\n</div>'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '87'), ('wp:post_date', '2014-09-16 10:28:00'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_path'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', 'Taxes, Inequality, and Business Climate'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2014/09/19/taxes-inequality-and-business-climate/'), ('pubDate', 'Fri, 19 Sep 2014 10:31:00 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=89')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', '<span class="submit">Original post date: September 19, 2014\nArticle by: Dan Davy</span>\n<div class="content">\n\nToday, states are left with a difficult choice between maintaining revenue growth and providing a competitive business climate. Taxes that promote the most competitive business climates tend to be less progressive and have lower growth rates.\n\nStandard and Poor’s (S&amp;P) \xa0released\xa0<a href="http://images.politico.com/global/2014/09/14/sp_state_inequality_report_draft_final.html">a new report</a>\xa0finding that states that are the most reliant on income taxes—typically more progressive in tax rates—experience higher average growth rates. But these states experience more volatility in their revenues, leaving lawmakers in the lurch as they scramble to cut programs or raise taxes to balance the budget.\n\nS&amp;P also found an inverse relationship between inequality and revenue growth rates. \xa0The tradeoff has grown over the last several decades as income inequality has increased and states which have no, or a low income tax are left with a larger and larger share of untaxable income. \xa0This is amplified by the fact that as income is concentrated in the wealthy, consumption as a share of income decreases and a smaller share of income is taxable through sales taxes.\n\nState and local revenue growth nationwide has fallen to nearly 4% since 2009 from rates between 1950 and 1979 of around 10%.\n\nFlorida, in contrast to most states, has no personal income tax and is one of the most sales tax-dependent states. Florida has experienced annual revenue growth rates of a modest 1.9% since 2009— below the national average and in part because of significant tax cuts—after seeing 11.8% annual growth between 1950 and 1979.\n\nMeanwhile,<a href="http://wallethub.com/edu/most-least-fair-tax-systems/6598/">\xa0a recent report\xa0</a>by Wallethub.com, an on-line financial analysis aggregator, found Florida’s taxes to be the 5th least “fair” in the country. The researchers based their results on a survey showing Americans believed a fair tax system should be progressive, ranging from 2.5% for households making $5,000 a year upwards to 7.3% for households making $50,000 and a 16.36% tax for the $2.5 million tax bracket. Since Florida does not have a state income tax, it starts at the lower end of their criteria.\n\nOn the other hand, Florida’s tax climate is considered the 5th most competitive in terms of promoting economic activity according to\xa0<a href="http://taxfoundation.org/article/2014-state-business-tax-climate-index">a study by the non-partisan Tax Foundation</a>.\n\nAmericans have noticed and have voted with their feet, making\xa0<a href="http://www.alec.org/wp-content/uploads/RSPS-FL-14.pdf">Florida second only to Texas</a>—also having no personal income tax—in terms of net domestic migration gains. \xa0This infusion of human capital and new consumers has helped fuel the state’s economic recovery.\n\nFlorida’s tax structure also benefits the public sector. Despite low revenue growth, the S&amp;P study found that Florida has had much less volatility in its revenue growth. As a result, Florida has not been forced to take measures as drastic as some states \xa0to balance its budget. This is a very important feature of Florida’s tax system because it provides more consistency and predictability for the public sector, helping to ensure service levels are maintained.\n\nIncome inequality has been growing and Florida’s tax revenue growth has been modest. However, we should be very cautious to reform our tax structure to address these issues. Progressive tax reforms could sacrifice the strength of our business climate and the jobs and incomes it provides for the 99% who need them most.\n\n</div>'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '89'), ('wp:post_date', '2014-09-19 10:31:00'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2014-09-19 10:31:00'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'taxes-inequality-and-business-climate'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', [OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'business'), ('#text', 'business')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'business-climate'), ('#text', 'business climate')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'economic-development'), ('#text', 'economic development')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'fiscal-policy'), ('#text', 'Fiscal Policy')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'florida'), ('#text', 'Florida')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'income-inequality'), ('#text', 'income inequality')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'public-finance'), ('#text', 'public finance')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'taxes'), ('#text', 'taxes')])]), ('wp:postmeta', [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_publicize_pending'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_published'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_client_id'), ('wp:meta_value', '-1')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', 'B-Corps: A New Kind of Company'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2014/09/23/b-corps-a-new-kind-of-company/'), ('pubDate', 'Tue, 23 Sep 2014 15:32:00 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=91')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', '<span class="submit">Original post date: September 23, 2014\nArticle by: Matt Kelly</span>\n<div class="content">\n<p dir="ltr">On July 20th, 2014,\xa0<a href="http://www.consciouscapitalismfl.org/new-benefit-corporation-lets-companies-focus-on-triple-bottom-line/">Rick Scott signed SB 654 into law,</a>\xa0creating two new types of business entities. These\xa0<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benefit_corporation">benefit corporations</a>\xa0or\xa0“B-Corps” are designed to encourage corporations to pursue charitable purposes,\xa0attempting to combine the strengths of both for-profits and nonprofits, while discarding each’s weaknesses. Such hybrid businesses could allow social entrepreneurs in Florida to\xa0harness the power of a market economy to solve pressing social problems.</p>\n<p dir="ltr">In\xa0<a href="http://coss.fsu.edu/dmc/content/march-charity-reform-afoot-0">previous blog posts on The Charity Defense Council</a>, we discussed the challenges faced by nonprofit charities. For-profit companies can also face disincentives when trying to “do good.” While nonprofit donors often withhold gifts if a charity is incurring risk, shareholders of a for-profit company can similarly divest their holdings if they perceive it as shirking profit maximization. In fact,\xa0if a corporation is\xa0<a href="http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/eleemosynary">eleemosynary</a>\xa0at the expense of profits, shareholders have a right to file lawsuits.\xa0These countervailing preferences can make it difficult for social entrepreneurs in either sector to create innovative solutions to social problems such as homelessness or debilitating diseases. SB 654 could change all that.</p>\n<p dir="ltr">Florida is the<a href="http://www.benefitcorp.net/state-by-state-legislative-status">\xa025th state to enact such legislation</a>. Though half the country now has some form of B-Corp legislation, Florida is one of just three states to create two distinct legal entities for this purpose. A “benefit corporation” can have a broadly defined purpose to create “general public benefit," whereas a “social purpose corporation” must specify a particular social mission in its bylaws. These\xa0businesses have new\xa0<a href="http://www.law.cornell.edu/wex/fiduciary_duty">fiduciary\xa0</a><a href="http://www.law.cornell.edu/wex/fiduciary_duty">duties</a>\xa0to their shareholders\xa0requiring them to balance profit maximization with a social purpose like alleviating poverty, protecting the environment, or increasing access to healthcare.</p>\n<p dir="ltr">This movement to create a more socially-minded business environment was pioneered by\xa0<a href="http://www.bcorporation.net/">B Lab</a>, a nonprofit organization that has created a community of over 900 Certified Benefit Corporations. This certification signals a company\'s social purpose to consumers, allowing them to make more informed purchasing decisions. The two legal entities created by SB 654 will not necessarily be B Lab-certified, and will undergo an evaluation by the state. However, it is worth pointing out the origins of this movement were from outside the public sector. It started as\xa0a private effort to create higher standards of corporate purpose, accountability, transparency, and performance.</p>\n<p dir="ltr">The hope is that the benefit corporation law will make Florida a hub for social enterprise. Companies are already registering to take advantage of this status.\xa0<a href="http://www.sequil.com/">Sequil Systems Inc.</a>, a B Lab-certified architectural consultancy in Delray Beach that specializes in environmentally-conscious construction, would become the first benefit corporation in Florida. Sequil’s CEO Jef Conley has commented on the\xa0powerful signal that B Lab certification sends to consumers, saying B Lab certification,\xa0<a href="http://www.justmeans.com/blogs/florida-affirms-b-corp-status-as-sequil-systems-leads-the-way">“helps emphasize who we already are."</a></p>\n<p dir="ltr">Though most reports on the B-Corp legislation are glowingly positive, the bill does have its\xa0<a href="http://blogs.law.harvard.edu/corpgov/2012/05/13/benefit-corporations-vs-regular-corporations-a-harmful-dichotomy/">detractors</a>. Some think that a corporation’s legal responsibility to its shareholders ought not be excused, while others maintain altruism cannot be served within the for-profit sector. In future blogs on B-Corps, we will address these detractions and discuss the potential incentives the legislation creates.</p>\n\n</div>'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '91'), ('wp:post_date', '2014-09-23 15:32:00'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2014-09-23 15:32:00'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'b-corps-a-new-kind-of-company'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', [OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'b-corps'), ('#text', 'B Corps')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'b-lab'), ('#text', 'B Lab')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'benefit-corporations'), ('#text', 'Benefit Corporations')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'corporate-governance'), ('#text', 'Corporate governance')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'florida'), ('#text', 'Florida')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'nonprofits-and-social-entrepreneurship'), ('#text', 'Nonprofits and Social Entrepreneurship')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'rick-scott'), ('#text', 'Rick Scott')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'sayfie'), ('#text', 'Sayfie')])]), ('wp:postmeta', [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_publicize_pending'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_published'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_client_id'), ('wp:meta_value', '-1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_facebook'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_google_plus'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_twitter'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_linkedin'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_tumblr'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_path'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', 'Overbearing Licensing of Farm Labor Contractors'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2014/09/29/overbearing-licensing-of-farm-labor-contractors/'), ('pubDate', 'Mon, 29 Sep 2014 15:36:00 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=93')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', '<span class="submit">Original post date: September 25, 2014\nArticle by: Dan Davy</span>\n<div class="content">\n\nAccording to\xa0<a href="http://www.ij.org/licensetowork">a recent Institute for Justice study,\xa0</a>Florida has the fourth most burdensome occupational licensure laws in the nation. \xa0One of the many occupations Florida licenses is farm labor contracting.\xa0<a href="http://www.leg.state.fl.us/statutes/index.cfm?App_mode=Display_Statute&amp;Search_String=&amp;URL=0400-0499/0450/Sections/0450.28.html">A farm labor contractor is</a>\xa0anyone who employs other farm workers for a third party or furnishes employees to work under the supervision of a third party for a fee or other form of compensation.\n\nFlorida is one of nine states to require a license to operate as a farm labor contractor, and one of two states to require an exam to enter the profession. Florida also requires $160 in fees.\n\nFlorida has had issues with agriculture migrant worker conditions and labor trafficking. According to a 2013 report by Polaris, a non-profit focused on human trafficking, Florida has<a href="http://www.polarisproject.org/media-center/news-and-press/press-releases/915-report-spotlights-human-trafficking-trends-in-the-us">\xa0the 3rd highest number of human trafficking cases in the nation.</a>\xa0\xa0<a href="http://www.cahr.fsu.edu/sub_category/currenttrends.pdf">\xa0Some have argued</a>\xa0for \xa0using licensing of farm labor contractors to address this issue. Indeed, labor trafficking may call for some level of accountability through licensing.\n\nFlorida’s Department of Business and Professional Regulation (DBPR)\xa0<a href="http://www.leg.state.fl.us/Statutes/index.cfm?App_mode=Display_Statute&amp;URL=0400-0499/0450/0450.html">is responsible for licensing \xa0and regulating the occupation</a>. While 48 states see no need to conduct competency testing for farm labor contractors,\xa0<a href="http://www.leg.state.fl.us/statutes/index.cfm?App_mode=Display_Statute&amp;Search_String=&amp;URL=0400-0499/0450/Sections/0450.30.html">Florida tasks \xa0DBPR</a>\xa0with providing “a program of education and examination” for these workers. Ostensibly the examination ensures the contractor “is knowledgeable concerning the duties and responsibilities of a farm labor contractor.”\n\nHowever, it seems unclear that the absence of government competency exams in the 48 other states has caused public health and safety concerns, nor quality problems. In the case of labor trafficking, it is unclear how our licensure-testing requirement eliminates the bad actors who willfully operate outside of the law and exploit labor. Such overreach in licensing requirements is a poor substitute for the broader enforcement and immigration reforms needed to prevent the exploitation of migrant workers. The private market seems to effectively self-regulate farm labor contractors’ level of service nationwide.\n\nFlorida’s farm labor contractors do benefit from their permitting and testing requirements, even if the public benefits are unclear or tenuous. Economists\xa0<a href="http://www.nber.org/papers/w14308.pdf">Morris Kleiner and Alan Krueger found</a>\xa0that on average licensing boosts wages for workers by 15%. Since competition from other potential contractors is deterred by the licensing and testing requirement, higher prices are passed on to consumers increasing contractor incomes. Further, Kleiner and Krueger found that individuals in licensed professions receive a psychological boost because they tend to perceive themselves as more competent.\n\nDo Florida’s entrenched farm labor contractors benefit from their licensing laws? Yes. Do they result in higher prices? Yes. Do they make it more difficult to enter the profession? Yes. Do they promote public health and food safety? Unlikely.\n\nIt is time to reexamine and reform Florida’s farm labor licensing and ensure a clear nexus with public health and safety. Florida should start by joining the 48 other states and eliminate the requirement for contractors to pass an examination in order to legally compete in the agriculture industry.\n\n</div>'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '93'), ('wp:post_date', '2014-09-29 15:36:00'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2014-09-29 15:36:00'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'overbearing-licensing-of-farm-labor-contractors'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', [OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'agriculture'), ('#text', 'agriculture')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'dbpr'), ('#text', 'DBPR')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'farm-labor'), ('#text', 'farm labor')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'human-trafficking'), ('#text', 'human trafficking')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'labor'), ('#text', 'labor')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'licensing'), ('#text', 'licensing')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'migrant-workers'), ('#text', 'migrant workers')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'overreach'), ('#text', 'overreach')]), ('wp:postmeta', [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_publicize_pending'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_published'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('title', 'Taxi Regulation Reduces Driver Opportunity'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2014/09/30/taxi-regulation-reduces-driver-opportunity/'), ('pubDate', 'Tue, 30 Sep 2014 15:39:00 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=95')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', '<span class="submit">Original post date: September 30, 2014\nArticle by: Ben Douglas</span>\n<div class="content">\n\nFor decades, state and local governments have imposed dramatic entry controls on the taxi industry across the United States. These regulatory hurdles benefit established companies at the expense of drivers. Many cities issue "medallions," a permit that grants its owner the legal right the right to operate a taxicab. These cost over <a href="http://ij.org/taxi-medallions-in-chicago-will-cost-at-least-360-000" target="_blank">$360,000 in Chicago</a> and <a href="http://www.nyc.gov/html/tlc/html/about/average_medallion_price.shtml">$1 million in New York</a>. Twenty-one of the 50 biggest cities maintain ordinances or fall under statutes strictly limiting the number of cab permits which may be issued.\n\nMany states and localities classify the taxi industry as a “public utility.” For example, taxis fall under the regulatory authority of the Public Utilities Commission in <a href="http://tornado.state.co.us/gov_dir/leg_dir/olls/2013TitlePrintouts/CRS%20Title%2040%20%282013%29.pdf">Colorado</a> and <a href="http://www.puc.state.pa.us/consumer_info/transportation/motor_carrier/limos_taxis_movers.aspx">Pennsylvania </a>(<a href="http://www.phillymag.com/articles/feature-hell-called-it-wants-its-cabs-back/2/">outside of Philadelphia</a>).\xa0 A startup taxi company in 19 of the 50 biggest cities must prove the need for its business before receiving permission to operate\xa0 in the form of a certificate of public convenience and necessity. These certificates are a highly restrictive type of company permit used to closely regulate the availability, quality, financial practices, and mergers of firms providing services to the public, such as cable tv, electricity, natural gas, or water services. Opposing parties—such as existing taxi companies—often protest the “public necessity” and therefore legality of these startup competitors. Entrenched companies argue they would provide the service if demand existed and shift the burden of proof that a market exists to the potential competitor. Sometimes, applicants must prove to the regulatory authority that the existing service is inadequate to meet public demand before being issued a permit. Understandably, this has made it very difficult to compete with established companies in most areas, shifting the balance of power between driver and company in favor of the latter.\n\nThese regulations make permits for companies and cabs very valuable and costly to obtain. Unfortunately, these costs are often passed on to struggling drivers in the form of exorbitant fees to lease licenses or operate a franchised vehicle. The more draconian the regulatory scheme, the higher the fees. This is quite an onus to place on an already struggling sector of the workforce. Moreover, it is regressive. Taxi drivers’ median annual income (including tips) in the 50 biggest cities is<a href="http://www.bls.gov/oes/current/oes533041.htm"> just $22,693, </a>despite providing an invaluable service that provides numerous benefits, such aspreventing drunk driving and providing transportation to those without vehicles. This translates to $11.09/hour—gross.\n\n<a href="http://coss.fsu.edu/d6/dmc/content/restrictive-taxi-licensing-hurts-economic-opportunity">In Miami-Dade County</a>, the privilege of operating a cab for a day costs nearly $100. Between licensing fees, gas, maintenance, and driver permitting fees, drivers actually make below minimum wage. This is not unique. Portland, Oregon drivers average a <a href="https://www.portlandoregon.gov/revenue/57849">net hourly income of $6.22</a>. San Diego drivers earn <a href="http://d3n8a8pro7vhmx.cloudfront.net/onlinecpi/pages/329/attachments/original/1399851534/CPISDSU_TaxiReport_FINAL1.pdf?1399851534">less than $5</a>—due in part to the county’s practice of capping the number of firms allowed to provide taxi services. Our estimates peg Jacksonville driver incomes at less than half the state’s minimum wage after leasing and gas costs are taken into account.\n\nThe harsh reality of life as a cab driver is that regulation works for entrenched companies. Our preliminary regression analysis has shown a significant negative relationship between the practice of permitting companies (a policy strongly supported by the companies themselves) and driver wages. Particularly stringent company permitting requirements lower wages even further. Concentrated markets, i.e., markets in which a large number of permits are owned by a relatively few number of firms, also see lower driver wages relative to less concentrated markets.\n\nEliminating draconian taxi regulation, such as public convenience and necessity requirements, will go a long way to increasing taxi driver wages and opportunities. Taxi drivers should be allowed to own their own businesses just like rideshare drivers are currently allowed to around the world. Given the clout of established taxi interests, phasing out monopoly privilege and its faulty economic rationale may be politically difficult for policymakers, but it is the efficient and equitable solution in the long run.\n\n</div>'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '95'), ('wp:post_date', '2014-09-30 15:39:00'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2014-09-30 15:39:00'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'taxi-regulation-reduces-driver-opportunity'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', [OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'cabs'), ('#text', 'cabs')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'medallions'), ('#text', 'medallions')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'monopoly'), ('#text', 'monopoly')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'public-utilities'), ('#text', 'public utilities')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'regulation'), ('#text', 'regulation')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'taxi'), ('#text', 'taxi')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'taxi-licensing'), ('#text', 'Taxi licensing')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'taxis'), 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2014/10/02/government-protects-consumers-from-bad-haircuts/'), ('pubDate', 'Thu, 02 Oct 2014 15:41:00 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=97')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', '<span class="submit">Original post date: October 02, 2014\nArticle by: Dan Davy</span>\n<div class="content">\n\nFlorida protects its hairy public from rogue barbers by requiring prospective barbers to pay fees and complete extensive education requirements and exams before granting permission to legally operate. \xa0These requirements are one part of what makes Florida’s licensing the fourth most burdensome in the country according to <a href="http://coss.fsu.edu/d6/dmc/content/Licensetowork.ij.org/6">a recent study by the Institute for Justice.\xa0</a>\n\nProspective barbers must pay costs of $250 for the license and exam fees. These fees nearly double the national average of $130 according to the study.\n\nHowever, Florida barbers’ most burdensome entry requirement is 1,200 hours—roughly 280 days—of training at a licensed barber school. This amounts to over <a href="http://www.tallahassee.com/story/opinion/columnists/2014/09/09/daniel-davy-scale-back-licensing-laws/15358497/">8 times as much required education</a> as Emergency Medical Technicians. \xa0For reference, <a href="http://www.floridabarberacademy.edu/programs/">the Florida Barber Academy charges</a> $14,550 including all tuition and fees for its certified 1200 hour program and certification. This education requirement, however, is duplicative as all licensees must pass an exam demonstrating complete mastery over the skill set and the profession’s health and safety issues.\n\nThese licensing requirements are a significant and burdensome barrier to entry into a low-income occupation. <a href="http://www.bls.gov/oes/current/oes_fl.htm">The Bureau of Labor Statistics</a> reports barbers earn a modest median wage of $10.38 per hour in Florida.\n\nIt wasn’t always so difficult to become a barber. Until 1978 and the passage of Florida’s “Barbers’ Act,” the iconic American tradecraft was not subject to licensing requirements in Florida. <a href="http://www.leg.state.fl.us/Statutes/index.cfm?App_mode=Display_Statute&amp;URL=0400-0499/0476/0476.html">The Act claimed licensing was</a> “necessary in the interest of public health, safety, and welfare to regulate the practice of barbering in this state.”\n\n<a href="http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1996-02-22/news/9602210895_1_barber-cosmetologists-florida">Support for licensing was growing </a>in large part because of concerns over the usage of potentially harmful chemicals and the transmission of diseases by barbers untrained in sanitation and cleanliness. \xa0However, Florida’s licensing laws go far beyond health and safety education by requiring nearly 9 months of technical training, largely in styling and technique.\n\nFlorida should eliminate its duplicative barber education requirements. To the extent the public interest is served at all by licensing, the state’s interest should be limited to protecting public health and safety. All individuals who demonstrate a mastery over the basic barber skill set on the state-level exam deserve a chance to compete in the marketplace regardless of their completion of costly, redundant training requirements.\n\n</div>'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '97'), ('wp:post_date', '2014-10-02 15:41:00'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2014-10-02 15:41:00'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'government-protects-consumers-from-bad-haircuts'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', [OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'barber-licensing'), ('#text', 'barber licensing')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'barbers'), ('#text', 'barbers')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'barriers-to-entry'), ('#text', 'barriers to entry')]), 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2014/10/10/the-changing-landscape-of-urban-transportation/'), ('pubDate', 'Fri, 10 Oct 2014 15:43:00 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=99')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', '<span class="submit">Original post date: October 10, 2014\nArticle by: Ben Douglas</span>\n<div class="content">\n\nUber CEO Travis Kalanick recently released his vision for the future, touting “<a href="http://blog.uber.com/city-future">a million fewer cars on the road</a>,” along with reduced congestion, emissions, and DUIs. If this vision is realized, in combination with <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/30/sunday-review/the-end-of-car-culture.html?_r=3&amp;">an aging driving demographic</a> and the rise of <a href="http://daily.bhaskar.com/news/HW-tesla-ceo-elon-musk-to-make-a-driverless-car-google-sure-have-reasons-to-worry-4767137-NOR.html">driverless cars</a>, it would transform urban planning, transportation, and America’s automobile industry.\n\nUrban development is currently constrained by available parking and street congestion. <a href="http://www.autolife.umd.umich.edu/Environment/E_Casestudy/E_casestudy2.htm">As much as half</a> of the modern American city’s land area is dedicated to the automobile and related infrastructure. Municipal codes require\xa0 specific levels of parking space for all\xa0 new development. This <a href="http://shoup.bol.ucla.edu/People,Parking,CitiesJUPD.pdf">creates an asymmetry</a> that exacerbates congestion by reducing the land available for streets and driving. Widespread adoption of\xa0<a href="http://blog.uber.com/uberpool">UberPool</a>, <a href="http://blog.uber.com/tag/uberx/">UberX</a>, and other ridesharing services may reduce the need for parking spaces and personal automobiles, thus mitigating this asymmetry and the associated congestion.\n\nThis technology may prove harmful to the auto industry, particularly if governments (federal, state, and local) get on board. Precedent indicates this is unlikely, however. Minimum parking requirements\xa0<a href="http://shoup.bol.ucla.edu/People,Parking,CitiesJUPD.pdf">inadvertently subsidize</a> private car ownership. The 2009 “cash for clunkers” scheme <a href="http://www.marketplace.org/topics/business/auto-industry-subsidies-are-piling">had a similar effect</a>. Most importantly, the Treasury’s <a href="http://www.treasury.gov/initiatives/financial-stability/TARP-Programs/automotive-programs/Pages/default.aspx">$80 billion bailout</a> of the industry strongly indicates the US government’s unwillingness to tolerate threats to it.\n\nDriverless cars will further decrease the need for the private vehicle commute as the technology becomes safer and more affordable. As of April, Google’s driverless cars had passed <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/extreme/181508-googles-self-driving-car-passes-700000-accident-free-miles-can-now-avoid-cyclists-stop-for-trains">700,000 accident-free miles</a>. To this day, they have had no at-fault accidents. Uber <a href="http://techcrunch.com/2013/08/25/uberauto/">has already committed to purchase</a> 2,500 of the vehicles from Google and <a href="http://www.theverge.com/2014/5/28/5758734/uber-will-eventually-replace-all-its-drivers-with-self-driving-cars">Kalnick indicated</a> he considers them the way of the future: "When there\'s no other dude in the car, the cost of taking an Uber anywhere becomes cheaper than owning a vehicle. So the magic there is, you basically bring the cost below the cost of ownership for everybody, and then car ownership goes away."\n\nAccording to the <a href="https://enotrans.r.worldssl.net/wp-content/uploads/wpsc/downloadables/AV-paper.pdf">Eno Center for Transportation</a>, driverless cars “may be available on the mass market by 2022 or 2025.” Nissan and Volvo are already trying to make the technology commercially viable. If successful, driverless cars will transform the future far beyond urban planning and the auto industry. New highway safety and liability laws must be made and <a href="http://www.economist.com/news/special-report/21576224-one-day-every-car-may-come-invisible-chauffeur-look-no-hands">decades of road-safety legislation </a>must be overturned to make way for this new innovation.\n\nWhile the technology is currently<a href="http://online.wsj.com/articles/laser-eyes-pose-price-hurdle-for-driverless-cars-1405969441"> too expensive for most consumers</a>, swift improvements and cost reductions are likely. The automobile itself was initially a plaything of the uber-rich until Henry Ford’s assembly line brought it to the masses. The <a href="http://www.pcworld.com/article/127104/article.html">first hard drive</a> held only 5 MB of data, cost $50,000, and was the size of two refrigerators.\n\nIt is also important to remember there are significant costs to human driving, lest we commit the <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nirvana_fallacy">nirvana fallacy</a>. An estimated <a href="http://www.alertdriving.com/home/fleet-alert-magazine/international/human-error-accounts-90-road-accidents">90% of accidents</a> are due to human error and cost <a href="http://mashable.com/2014/07/07/driverless-cars-tipping-point/">$450 billion annually</a>. In order to be economically viable, driverless cars need not be perfect and cost-free, only safer and less expensive than human-operated vehicles.\n\nThe private sector may be picking up the slack in creating a viable, efficient, economically-friendly alternative to the personal automobile commute <a href="http://coss.fsu.edu/dmc/content/go-green-dont-expand-transit">where public transit has failed</a>. If this proves to be the case, companies like Uber and Google will fundamentally change city life as we know it.\n\n</div>'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '99'), ('wp:post_date', '2014-10-10 15:43:00'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2014-10-10 15:43:00'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'the-changing-landscape-of-urban-transportation'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', [OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'driverless-cars'), ('#text', 'driverless cars')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'public-transit'), ('#text', 'public transit')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'transit'), ('#text', 'transit')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'transit-reform'), ('#text', 'transit reform')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'transportation'), ('#text', 'Transportation')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'uber'), ('#text', 'uber')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'urban-development-2'), ('#text', 'urban development')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'urban-planning'), ('#text', 'urban planning')])]), ('wp:postmeta', [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_publicize_pending'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_published'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_client_id'), ('wp:meta_value', '-1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_facebook'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_google_plus'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_twitter'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_linkedin'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_tumblr'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_path'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', 'Reevaluating Benefit Corporations'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2014/10/13/reevaluating-benefit-corporations/'), ('pubDate', 'Mon, 13 Oct 2014 15:46:00 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=101')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', '<span class="submit">Original post date: October 13, 2014\nArticle by: Dan Davy</span>\n<div class="content">\n\n<a href="http://coss.fsu.edu/dmc/content/b-corps-new-kind-company">A previous blog</a> discussed the potential for Florida’s recently passed Benefit Corporation (B-Corp) legislation to encourage social enterprise. Some consider the B Corp movement a <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4djAObGZnmI">“seismic sea change in the world of corporations.”</a> However, whether this legal innovation will make a significant impact on social entrepreneurs is unclear.\n\nB-Corp laws address the problem of shareholder activists. Shareholder activists use their ownership—typically a stake of 10% or more of the total shares—to launch campaigns to change company plans. Activists can push for either financial profit maximization goals or non-financial, sometimes socially beneficial goals.\n\nShareholder activists often pursue short-term personal profits at the expense of product quality, labor standards, and environmental impacts. Carl Icahn used this tactic to lead the once iconic TWA into bankruptcy after selling vital assets while pursuing short-term profit maximization. The B-Corp laws protect management from such shareholder pressure to sacrifice social benefit in order to promote the corporation’s interests by <a href="http://www.leg.state.fl.us/statutes/index.cfm?App_mode=Display_Statute&amp;Search_String=&amp;URL=0600-0699/0607/Sections/0607.606.html">stating that</a> “the creation of general social benefit… is deemed to be in the best interest of the benefit corporation.” \xa0 For example, B-Corp management may sell company assets to someone other than the highest bidder if they demonstrate reasons of social benefit.\n\nIn contrast, some activist shareholders have made environmental sustainability a key issue in their <a href="http://www.ceres.org/press/press-releases/2011-proxy-season-report-fracking-water-scarcity-other-issues-show-shareholders-resolute-on-climate-sustainability-resolutions">law suits and corporate resolutions</a>. The new B-Corp laws will empower this kind of social activism by expanding management’s responsibility beyond traditional profit seeking to consider general social benefit in each business action. Management is required to report yearly on its social impact. Meanwhile shareholders are given the right to action against management through an enforcement proceeding, which can provide injunctive relief.\n\nNonetheless B-Corp laws have received some negative reviews.\n\nAdding new protection for managers could incentivize moral hazard and undermine traditional shareholders’ ability to make returns. <a href="http://www.amazon.com/Conscious-Capitalism-Liberating-Heroic-Business/dp/1422144208">Whole Foods CEO John Mackay points out</a> that shareholders are actually the last people in a business to be paid, only after employees’, suppliers’, and lenders’ accounts are settled. He maintains that “such owner control makes sense because, of all the stakeholders in a business, the owners are most vulnerable to [the exploitation of] both managers and other stakeholders.”\n\nOthers, including writers at the Harvard Law Blog, <a href="http://blogs.law.harvard.edu/corpgov/2012/05/13/benefit-corporations-vs-regular-corporations-a-harmful-dichotomy/">question the need</a> for protecting management since “there is no legal restriction on directors’ ability to consider the interests of other stakeholders, including the groups listed in the B-Corp statutes.” Florida law, for example, already <a href="http://www.leg.state.fl.us/statutes/index.cfm?App_mode=Display_Statute&amp;Search_String=&amp;URL=0600-0699/0607/Sections/0607.0830.html">expressly permits</a>\xa0traditional management to consider stakeholders other than the corporation and shareholders. These laws are not empowering management to do anything they are not already allowed to do.\n\nUndoubtedly, shareholder activism can create chaos for a company’s management, and the law provides some protection for entrepreneurs seeking growth capital. However, such disruptions do not often affect social entrepreneurs who rarely have shareholders at all, much less lead publically traded firms.\n\nWhile these laws may provide an air of legitimacy to the burgeoning social enterprise movement and ensure the “social” stays in social enterprise, it fails to address the obstacles most of Florida’s entrepreneurs face on a daily basis. The B-Corp laws are a step in the right direction, but making Florida competitive for entrepreneurs will require more substantive reforms. \xa0For instance, <a href="http://www.tallahassee.com/story/opinion/columnists/2014/09/09/daniel-davy-scale-back-licensing-laws/15358497/">removing Florida’s byzantine regulatory obstacles</a> such as occupational licensing would do more than crafting B-Corp protections to empower our state’s social entrepreneurs. Reforms like that could be good for all businesses, social or otherwise.\n\n</div>'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '101'), ('wp:post_date', '2014-10-13 15:46:00'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2014-10-13 15:46:00'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'reevaluating-benefit-corporations'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', [OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'b-corps'), ('#text', 'B Corps')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'benefit-corporations'), ('#text', 'Benefit Corporations')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'entrepreneurship-2'), ('#text', 'entrepreneurship')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'florida'), ('#text', 'Florida')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'john-mackey'), ('#text', 'john mackey')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'moral-hazard'), ('#text', 'moral hazard')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'nonprofits-and-social-entrepreneurship'), ('#text', 'Nonprofits and Social Entrepreneurship')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'social-enterprise'), ('#text', 'social enterprise')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'social-entrepreneurship'), ('#text', 'social entrepreneurship')])]), ('wp:postmeta', [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_publicize_pending'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_published'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_client_id'), ('wp:meta_value', '-1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_facebook'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_google_plus'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_twitter'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_linkedin'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_tumblr'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_path'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', 'Entrepreneurship and Civil Rights: Then and Now'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2014/11/07/entrepreneurship-and-civil-rights-then-and-now/'), ('pubDate', 'Fri, 07 Nov 2014 15:48:00 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=103')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', '<span class="submit">Original post date: November 07, 2014\nArticle by: Matt Kelly</span>\n<div class="content">\n\nFlorida State University recently hosted distinguished <a href="http://drdavidhjackson.com/" target="_blank">Florida A&amp;M University professor David Jackson</a> for a lecture on the role of business in the Civil Rights Movement. Using his research on <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Booker_T._Washington" target="_blank">Booker T. Washington</a> as a basis, Dr. Jackson introduced his audience to notable 20th century African-American entrepreneurs in Jacksonville, Florida. Many of his examples can be thought of as the social entrepreneurs of their time. Success in business was a quiet form of resistance under Jim Crow era segregation, according to Jackson.\n\nSocial entrepreneurs create market-based solutions to social problems, and a focus on social mission deeply informs their business decisions. With a similar mindset, black business people throughout the South offered alternatives to their marginalized customers, strengthening communities as well as making money. Black entrepreneurs like <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln_Lewis" target="_blank">A.L. Lewis</a> of the <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Afro-American_Life_Insurance_Company" target="_blank">Afro-American Life Insurance Company</a>, and <a href="http://www.metrojacksonville.com/forum/index.php?topic=13243.0" target="_blank">Douglas Anderson</a>, who ran Jacksonville’s first black-friendly bus company, were motivated to solve the social ills of their day and used business as a means to do so.\n\nEntrepreneurship is still a source of empowerment for minorities, and social entrepreneurs recognize that markets are needed for communities to flourish. Today, there is no shortage of creative and successful African-American business people, and the framework of social entrepreneurship continues to play prominently.\n\n<a href="http://www.nuekie.com/pages/about-our-founder" target="_blank">Eunice Cofie</a>, an applicant to the Diehl Family Social Enterprise Competition, managed by the DeVoe Moore Center at Florida State University, is one such inheritor of this tradition. Codie founded <a href="http://www.nuekie.com/" target="_blank">Nuekie</a>, a health and beauty company that offers dermatological and cosmetic products to people of color. Health and beauty products have existed for millennia, yet African-Americans still have limited options for their unique skincare needs.\xa0Most dermatological companies have a one-size-fits-all approach that focuses on treating\xa0white skin, and neglects ethnic skin types.\xa0Cofie saw this market inefficiency as a social problem that could be solved through entrepreneurship, and took the opportunity to create value for an underserved population.\n\nCofie told us in an interview that Nuekie’s, “mission is to change the way people of color feel about the science and medical industry by offering them products suited to their needs.” Cofie went on to say, “People of color have a contentious history with the medical industry, and have often been exploited by it. We want to be the place where tradition and science heal.” Cofie uses her knowledge of chemistry, gained from an education at FAMU, to craft innovative dermatological solutions. Many <a href="http://www.nuekie.com/pages/about-our-founder" target="_blank">Nuekie products</a> incorporate modern science with herbal remedies used in Ghana, where her parents were born. In 2013, The Tallahassee Chamber of Commerce named Nuekie<a href="http://nuekie.blogspot.com/2013/05/nuekie-named-start-up-business-of-year.html" target="_blank">Tallahassee\'s Startup Business of the Year</a>.\n\nDr. Jackson’s lecture on the role of business in the Civil Rights Movement highlighted Booker T. Washington’s founding of the <a href="http://www.pbs.org/wnet/jimcrow/stories_org_business.html" target="_blank">National Negro Business League</a> in 1900 as a seminal moment of change. This emphasis casts new light on the struggle for racial equality. Social entrepreneurs like Eunice Cofie have taken to heart these historical insights in order to solve the social problems of our own time, utilizing business as a powerful engine of social progress.\n\n</div>'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '103'), ('wp:post_date', '2014-11-07 15:48:00'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2014-11-07 15:48:00'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'),
