OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wp_attachment_context'), ('wp:meta_value', 'custom-header')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wp_attachment_metadata'), ('wp:meta_value', 'a:5:{s:5:"width";i:1500;s:6:"height";i:937;s:4:"file";s:94:"/home/wpcom/public_html/wp-content/blogs.dir/848/80998613/files/2014/12/cropped-fsupicture.jpg";s:5:"sizes";a:0:{}s:10:"image_meta";a:11:{s:8:"aperture";i:0;s:6:"credit";s:0:"";s:6:"camera";s:0:"";s:7:"caption";s:0:"";s:17:"created_timestamp";i:0;s:9:"copyright";s:0:"";s:12:"focal_length";i:0;s:3:"iso";i:0;s:13:"shutter_speed";i:0;s:5:"title";s:0:"";s:11:"orientation";i:0;}}')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wp_attachment_custom_header_last_used_pub/illustratr'), ('wp:meta_value', '1422388753')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wp_attachment_is_custom_header'), ('wp:meta_value', 'pub/illustratr')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', 'Normalizing Relations with Cuba: A Step Forward'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2014/12/23/normalizing-relations-with-cuba-a-step-forward/'), ('pubDate', 'Tue, 23 Dec 2014 17:41:00 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=112')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', '<span class="submit">Original post date: December 23, 2014\nArticle by: Matt Kelly</span>\n<div class="content">\n<p class="p1">In <a href="http://www.whitehouse.gov/issues/foreign-policy/cuba">a recent statemen</a>t, President Obama suggested Congress lift the 54 year long trade embargo on Cuba and announced concrete steps he and the communist nation’s president Raul Castro would take to normalize relations. The controversial statement elicited mixed responses from <a href="http://www.npr.org/blogs/thetwo-way/2014/12/21/372283625/gop-sens-rubio-paul-square-off-over-cuba-policy-shift">legislators</a>, <a href="http://dailycaller.com/2014/12/22/cuba-rammed-sunk-refugee-boat-one-day-before-obamas-decision-to-ease-sanctions/">news media</a>, and the <a href="http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/the-fix/wp/2014/12/23/poll-support-increases-for-lifting-cuba-embargo-travel-restrictions/">public</a>. But economic analysis suggests normalization could be a step forward for both countries. More often than not, trade sanctions harm both parties involved, and <a href="http://www.mitpressjournals.org/doi/abs/10.1162/isec.22.2.90?journalCode=isec#.VJRjisABA">ultimately fail</a> to topple unfriendly regimes. Opening up trade relations with the Caribbean island could be in the United States’ best interest, especially Florida’s.<!--more--></p>\n<p class="p1"><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_embargo_against_Cuba">The embargo</a>, which has existed in one form or another since October 1960, prohibits trade between Cuba and the United States. Occasional revisions to the law have altered the list of prohibited products. Since 1999 foreign subsidiaries of U.S. companies have also been barred from trading with Cuba. It is <a href="http://www.fas.org/sgp/crs/row/RL31139.pdf">extremely difficult for Cuban immigrants to visit family members</a>, since paying airfare taxes to Cuban airports violates the Cuban Assets Control Regulations. Under these regulations, U.S. citizens must obtain a license from the U.S. Treasury Department’s Office of Foreign Assets Control to make any transactions in Cuba, otherwise risking prosecution and fines. The Obama administration relaxed some of these policies in 2009, easing the travel ban and removing limits on remittances to family members in Cuba.</p>\n<p class="p1">The <a href="http://waysandmeans.house.gov/media/pdf/111/2010apr29_brilliant_testimony.pdf">U.S. Chamber of Commerce estimates</a> the cost of the embargo at $1.2 billion in foregone business annually to the U.S., while Cuba loses only $685 million annually. These figures suggest the U.S. has much to gain from ending the embargo, Florida perhaps most of all. Before its revolution, <a href="http://www.tampabay.com/news/business/economicdevelopment/restored-relations-with-cuba-could-have-major-impact-on-tampa-bay/2210541">Cuba was Tampa’s biggest trading partner</a>, and Florida’s other ports could receive a boost if trade were to resume.</p>\n<p class="p1">Moreover, compared to the overall inefficiency of its socialist economy, the embargo poses only a minor handicap. Cuba’s government has kept its people in <a href="http://www.heritage.org/index/country/cuba">abject poverty</a>, depriving them of necessities and consumer products alike. Troubling too is Cubans’ <a href="http://www.hrw.org/americas/cuba">lack of political freedom</a>. The country’s internet is among the most tightly controlled in the world.</p>\n<p class="p1">However, <em>el bloqueo</em> (as Cuba’s government calls the embargo) does not address Cuba’s political and economic oppression. In fact, <a href="http://democracyinamericas.org/pdfs/Dissident_Letter_to_Congress.pdf">a letter from the Cuban Civil Society</a>, a humanitarian activist group that opposes the Castro regime, states that “the isolation of the people of Cuba benefits the most inflexible interests of its government, while any opening serves to inform and empower the Cuban people and helps to further strengthen our civil society.” Soft power could be much more effective if U.S. tourists and products could travel freely to Cuba.</p>\n<p class="p1">We have yet to see if Raul Castro’s government will <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/dec/23/cuba-assata-shakur-americas-most-wanted-woman-will-not-be-extradited">fully cooperate</a>, though the recent release of USAID worker Alan Gross, who has had been in prison on the island since December 2009, is encouraging. Regardless, if the U.S. wishes to share the free-market ideals that have made it a success, it might consider practicing free trade in its own backyard.</p>\n\n</div>\n<!--more-->\n\n<!--more-->\n\n<!--more-->'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '112'), ('wp:post_date', '2014-12-23 17:41:00'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2014-12-23 17:41:00'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'normalizing-relations-with-cuba-a-step-forward'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', [OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'castro'), ('#text', 'Castro')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'communism'), ('#text', 'Communism')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'cuba'), ('#text', 'Cuba')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'embargo'), ('#text', 'embargo')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'florida'), ('#text', 'Florida')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'foreign-policy'), ('#text', 'Foreign Policy')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'foreign-policy-2'), ('#text', 'foreign policy')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'obama'), ('#text', 'Obama')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'politics-2'), ('#text', 'Politics')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'trade'), ('#text', 'trade')])]), ('wp:postmeta', [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_twitter'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_linkedin'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_tumblr'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_path'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_google_plus'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_facebook'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_published'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_client_id'), ('wp:meta_value', '-1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_publicize_pending'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_edit_last'), ('wp:meta_value', '77167941')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', 'geo_public'), ('wp:meta_value', '0')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', "Rubio's Opposition to Normalization with Cuba Not Without Merit"), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2015/01/06/rubios-opposition-to-normalization-with-cuba-not-without-merit/'), ('pubDate', 'Tue, 06 Jan 2015 18:58:20 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=115')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', '<p class="p1">By Matt Kelly</p>\n<p class="p1">Florida Senator Marco Rubio has been an outspoken critic of President Obama’s call to end the trade embargo on Cuba, characterizing the policy shift as <a href="http://www.wsj.com/articles/marco-rubio-the-turning-point-in-relations-with-cuba-1418862936">“a victory for oppressive governments the world over.”</a>The grandson of Cuban immigrants, Rubio represents the interests of <a href="http://www.fas.org/sgp/crs/row/R40566.pdf">“old school” emigres</a>. This group, which immigrated following the 1959 revolution, has significantly influenced American foreign policy on Cuba. \xa0Normalization will likely be positive for both countries, but the misgivings of these first-generation Cuban-Americans should not be ignored.</p>\n<p class="p1"><!--more-->Many in the first generation of post-revolution immigrants were landed property owners and beneficiaries of the former <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fulgencio_Batista">Batista regime</a>. Their businesses and belongings were confiscated when Castro took power in 1959. In today’s dollars, an estimated <a href="http://www.bostonglobe.com/ideas/2014/04/18/cuba-you-owe-billion/jHAufRfQJ9Bx24TuzQyBNO/story.html">$7 billion in Cuban property was taken</a>. Sugar and tobacco fields, banks, factories, land, and personal property were all seized from tens of thousands of Cubans. These political dissidents fled north to the U.S., and now represent a vocal constituency urging U.S. officials to use everything from economic sanctions to military force to topple Castro’s regime.</p>\n<p class="p1">Though Rubio is of a younger generation <a href="https://cri.fiu.edu/research/cuba-poll/2014-fiu-cuba-poll.pdf">that supports normalization</a>, his political beliefs are strongly informed by his grandfather’s experiences under Castro. Rubio has cultivated firm support within this aging but staunchly anti-communist community, and their votes propelled him to serve as the first Cuban-American Speaker of The Florida House before being elected to the U.S. Senate in 2010.</p>\n<p class="p1">Cuba’s government threatened the lives as well as livelihoods of their people. Such behavior isn’t something the U.S. should ignore or condone. Though the <a href="http://www.cato.org/publications/speeches/four-decades-failure-us-embargo-against-cuba">embargo on Cuba has been ineffectual</a>, its intended purpose to discourage the theft of private property and authoritarian oppression is a worthy one.</p>\n<p class="p1">The first generation of post-revolution Cuban immigrants will continue to influence this Cuban-American relations, pressuring the Castros to respect private property rights and political freedoms. Such pressure is needed. Property rights are an integral part of human rights, and this emphasis highlights the economic injustices present in Cuba.</p>\n<p class="p1">President Obama’s compromise may displease some Cuban-Americans, but strengthening links between the Cuban and American economies could potentially open the door to a broader conversation about democratic principles.</p>\n<p class="p1">Under the <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helms%E2%80%93Burton_Act">Helms-Burton Act of 1996</a>, any official end to the embargo will require an act of Congress. With his position in the Senate, Marco Rubio, and by extension, first-generation Cuban-Americans, will continue to play an important role in this debate.</p>\n<p class="p2">A key issue going forward will be the question of compensation for claim holders of seized land in Cuba. A future blog post will discuss possible means of reaching a consensus on this issue, which could potentially ease resistance to normalization and pave the way for a new and friendlier relationship between the Cuba and the United States.</p>'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '115'), ('wp:post_date', '2015-01-06 18:58:20'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2015-01-06 18:58:20'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'rubios-opposition-to-normalization-with-cuba-not-without-merit'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', [OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'batista'), ('#text', OrderedDict([('title', 'The Current State of Pensions in Florida'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2015/01/13/the-current-state-of-pensions-in-florida/'), ('pubDate', 'Tue, 13 Jan 2015 19:07:50 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=119')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', '<p class="p1">By Matt Kelly</p>\n<p class="p1">With their swampy humidity and world famous theme parks, Florida’s cities seem a world away from the frigid cold and automotive factories of Detroit, Michigan. Yet the two states have at least one commonality: underfunded pension liabilities. Such liabilities can potentially put a state or municipality into budgetary crisis, even bankruptcy. <a href="https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/tag/public-pensions/">Reforming Florida’s state and municipal pension systems from ones with defined benefit plans to defined contribution plans could help avoid such pitfalls.</a></p>\n<p class="p1"><!--more-->To understand why <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Defined_benefit_pension_plan">defined benefit plans</a> are vulnerable to underfunding, consider how benefits are calculated. They are based, in part, on projected rates of return on investments. Governments contribute to employees’ pension accounts on a regular basis, but promising a reliable return thirty years into the future is difficult, if not impossible. Even if the best economic forecasters failed to predict the 2008-09 recession, the most severe downturn since the Great Depression.</p>\n<p class="p1">Defined benefit plans guarantee that the amount promised to retirees be paid regardless of actual returns. If asset values are lower than expected, governments are obligated to make up the difference with taxpayers’ money.</p>\n<p class="p1">On the other hand, <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Defined_contribution_plan">defined contribution plans</a> merely stipulate that employers contribute a certain amount into retirement accounts every year. Rather than promise a future benefit now for some distant date, employees receive employer contributions plus returns. This would operate as in any investment account. While this exposes employees to investment risks, taxpayers are protected from having to cover potentially large liabilities in the event of an economic downturn.</p>\n<p class="p1"><a href="http://www.jamesmadison.org/issues/2014-policy-brief-florida-retirement-system-why-now.html">DeVoe Moore Center Professor of Economics Randall Holcombe has pointed out </a>that incentives of unions and lawmakers align to guarantee sizeable pensions for government employees now and push the present cost of government into the future. However, if a fund underperforms, it’s taxpayers who foot the bill.</p>\n<p class="p1">The Florida Retirement System, which serves state workers, has a $22 billion unfunded liability, with assets equal to about 86% of overall liabilities. Compared to the national average of about 72%, this is really quite good. However,<a href="http://www.ncpa.org/pdfs/st329.pdf"> a study by the National Center for Policy Analysis</a> argues that every state underestimates its unfunded pension liability because they project unrealistically high rates of return.</p>\n<p class="p1">This only scratches the surface of Florida’s pension liabilities. Florida cities fare worse. Some see Florida municipalities like Hollywood or Cooper City, where pensions are only 30% to 50% funded, as canaries in the coal mine; warnings of future calamities. <a href="http://etf.wi.gov/news/morningstar-report2013.pdf%20">Around 30% of municipalities in Florida are under 70% funded</a>, the threshold that investment management firm Morningstar Fund defines as solvent. This underfunding could foretell future statewide problems. In 2013, the state of Florida spent $500 million to bolster the underfunded Florida Retirement System, the program for state workers.</p>\nEnacting reforms that shift public employees into defined contribution programs and away from defined benefit plans would ensure Florida avoids future budgetary crises during economic downturns and protect the long term solvency of the state pensions system. Past bills have proposed to allow municipalities to shift future hires and current employees into defined contribution plans. <a href="http://politics.heraldtribune.com/2014/11/19/florida-pension-reform-looms-large/">Already about 25% of the newly hired state workers opt for defined contribution plans.</a>\xa0A future blog will discuss possible policy changes that could help ensure the health of Florida\'s state and municipal pensions.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '119'), ('wp:post_date', '2015-01-13 19:07:50'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2015-01-13 19:07:50'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'the-current-state-of-pensions-in-florida'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', [OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'detroit'), ('#text', 'Detroit')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'fiscal-policy'), ('#text', 'Fiscal Policy')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'florida'), ('#text', 'Florida')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'florida-retirement-system'), ('#text', 'Florida Retirement System')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'frs'), ('#text', 'FRS')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'government-spending'), ('#text', 'Government Spending')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'pensions'), ('#text', 'pensions')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'public-pensions'), ('#text', 'public pensions')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'public-policy'), ('#text', 'public policy')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'state-budget'), ('#text', 'State Budget')])]), ('wp:postmeta', [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_publicize_pending'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_published'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_client_id'), ('wp:meta_value', '-1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_edit_last'), ('wp:meta_value', '77167941')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', 'geo_public'), ('wp:meta_value', '0')])]), ('wp:comment', OrderedDict([('wp:comment_id', '3'), ('wp:comment_author', 'Florida&#8217;s Pensions Could Be Reformed Locally | The DeVoe L. Moore Center Blog'), ('wp:comment_author_email', None), ('wp:comment_author_url', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/2015/02/26/floridas-pensions-could-be-reformed-locally/'), ('wp:comment_author_IP', '192.0.100.182'), ('wp:comment_date', '2015-02-27 21:31:16'), ('wp:comment_date_gmt', '2015-02-27 21:31:16'), ('wp:comment_content', '[&#8230;] Management Services informing them that reforms are needed to address their unfunded liabilities. A previous blog pointed out that while Florida’s state’s employee pension fund is 86% funded (better [&#8230;]'), ('wp:comment_approved', '1'), ('wp:comment_type', 'pingback'), ('wp:comment_parent', '0'), ('wp:comment_user_id', '0'), ('wp:commentmeta', [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', 'akismet_result'), ('wp:meta_value', 'false')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', 'akismet_history'), ('wp:meta_value', 'a:4:{s:4:"time";d:1425072678.0182321071624755859375;s:7:"message";s:28:"Akismet cleared this comment";s:5:"event";s:9:"check-ham";s:4:"user";s:0:"";}')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', 'akismet_history'), ('wp:meta_value', 'a:4:{s:4:"time";d:1425076666.4990708827972412109375;s:7:"message";s:43:"Akismet re-checked and cleared this comment";s:5:"event";s:9:"check-ham";s:4:"user";s:0:"";}')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', 'jabber_published'), ('wp:meta_value', '1425666375')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', 'akismet_history'), ('wp:meta_value', 'a:4:{s:4:"time";d:1425666376.5809810161590576171875;s:7:"message";s:55:"devoemoorecenter changed the comment status to approved";s:5:"event";s:15:"status-approved";s:4:"user";s:16:"devoemoorecenter";}')])])]))]), OrderedDict([('title', 'New Study Tests the Merits of Surge Pricing'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2015/01/15/new-study-tests-the-merits-of-surge-pricing/'), ('pubDate', 'Thu, 15 Jan 2015 16:23:47 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=121')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', '<p class="p1">By Matt Kelly</p>\n<p class="p1">As Uber, Lyft and other “ridesharing” services continue to revolutionize the urban transportation landscape, <a href="http://www.businessinsider.com/new-york-city-considers-uber-surge-pricing-cap-2015-1">more complaints are surfacing</a> questioning the efficiency and fairness of the innovative services they provide. One of the more recent is “surge pricing,” the idea that services provided during peak periods carry a higher charge or fee.</p>\n<p class="p1"><!--more-->A new study by Princeton economist Dr. Henry Farber, titled <a href="http://www.nber.org/papers/w20604">“Why You Can’t Find a Taxi in The Rain,”</a> could have an important impact on the this debate. Farber’s study could help policy-makers and the general public more fully understand the economic behavior of taxi drivers.</p>\n<p class="p1">Past research suggested that taxi drivers target a certain level of earnings and then adjust their hours accordingly. If a taxi driver wanted to earn $250 in a 12 hour shift, for example, she would work until she reached the target and then take the rest of the shift off even if they could earn more money by working longer hours and making more trips. This is what economists call “reference dependence” and reflects a “negative wage <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elasticity_%28economics%29">elasticity</a> of labor supply”--it would seem taxi drivers paradoxically work fewer hours even as wages increase.</p>\n<p class="p1">In some ways, this makes sense. Why work after 12PM when I’ve already earned the amount of money I expected to make by 6PM? However, reference dependence contradicts established economic theory, which generally predicts workers will work more if wages increase. A small academic literature has emerged that supports the idea of reference dependence and negative elasticity for drivers’ labor supply. (See <a href="https://www.aeaweb.org/articles.php?doi=10.1257/aer.97.4.1047">here</a>, and<a href="http://qje.oxfordjournals.org/content/112/2/407.short">here</a>)</p>\n<p class="p1">Farber’s study challenges these claims. By using a much larger data set than previous studies and introducing a number of variables that help detect and account for other factors affecting drivers’ behavior, Farber estimates more reliable, detailed results. He finds no evidence of negative wage elasticity of labor supply and instead finds a positive elasticity; suggesting taxi driver behavior is consistent with a traditional economic theory: they work more as wages rise.</p>\n<p class="p1">How does this study relate to the Uber and ridesharing debate?</p>\n<p class="p1">Surge pricing is intended to increase wages to attract more drivers to an area with high demand. Reference dependent drivers would then reach their target earnings much faster and thus end their shifts prematurely. This could reduce supply and drive the fare price even higher!</p>\n<p class="p1">Farber’s results, however, suggest that taxi drivers will work more when surge pricing is used, and thus more taxi service will be available at periods of peak demand. This is good news for Uber’s drivers and customers. Surge pricing won’t reduce supply, but rather will attract more drivers to an area with high demand, helping them find better-paying customers while customers enjoy quicker pick-ups.</p>\nSurge pricing will likely remain controversial, but policy makers should note its merits in connecting supply with demand more efficiently. Market pricing for taxis and other transportation services could greatly improve efficiency in a 21st century transit system, helping taxi passengers to stay dry and out of the rain.'), 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2015/01/27/new-study-sheds-light-on-property-taxes-in-florida/'), ('pubDate', 'Tue, 27 Jan 2015 19:51:07 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=123')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', '<p class="p1">By Matt Kelly</p>\n<p class="p1"><a href="http://econpapers.repec.org/article/eeeregeco/v_3a46_3ay_3a2014_3ai_3ac_3ap_3a167-176.htm">A new study</a> by <a href="https://ideas.repec.org/e/pih2.html">DeVoe Moore Eminent Scholar Keith Ihlanfeldt</a> and economist Kevin Willardsen explores property taxes in Florida. The authors challenge the conventional wisdom that governments only consider the “public interest” when writing their budgets and setting tax rates. With property taxes accounting for 31% of Florida’s total revenues, understanding how rates are determined is vital to policy makers, voters, and <a href="http://www.stateofflorida.com/Portal/DesktopDefault.aspx?tabid=29">taxpayers</a>.</p>\n<p class="p1"><!--more-->The property tax rate, or “<a href="http://www.investopedia.com/terms/m/millagerate.asp">millage rate,</a>” Ihlanfeldt and Willardsen write, can be thought of as a “strategic policy tool in the competition among local governments for mobile capital.” However, as with business monopolies, governments with “monopoly power” can charge higher prices to their customers (i.e. higher taxes for residents).</p>\n<p class="p1">The city of Miami, for example, has a particularly large footprint on beachfront property in southeast Florida. Residents and businesses may be reluctant to abandon the city’s beach access or other natural resources, even if millage was significantly increased. This monopoly power insulates the city from the competition of neighboring jurisdictions with lower tax rates.</p>\n<p class="p1">Ihlanfeldt and Willardsen seek to examine this <a href="http://www.jstor.org/stable/30024173?seq=1#page_scan_tab_contents">monopoly power</a> in Florida’s local governments by estimating what economists call the “elasticity of the tax rate with respect to the tax base.” In other words, they measure how changes in a community’s tax base have effected changes in tax rates. The authors break down local governments into four categories: rural townships, townships in metropolitan areas, counties, and principal cities of metropolitan areas. Notably, the study goes beyond previous research by examining the property tax rate’s responsiveness to both <em>upward </em>and <em>downward</em> changes in property value. Communities with more monopoly power, like Miami or other principal cities, are expected to raise taxes more when the tax base declines, and lower rates less when the tax base increases. This implies higher spending and tax rates because of the reluctance of its residents and businesses to move.</p>\n<p class="p1">Their results show principal cities behave just so, especially when compared to communities in rural areas or other towns in a metropolitan area. The authors see these observed differences in tax rates as evidence of greater monopoly power in the local governments of principal cities.</p>\n<p class="p1">These results challenge the notion that governments always act in the “public interest”. In their review of past research, the authors note, “one of the alleged virtues of the property tax is that it produces relatively stable revenues regardless of movements in real estate markets.” In principle, governments can lower rates when property values increase and raise rates when values fall, a practice called “offsetting”. Indeed, they find Florida’s local governments increased millage rates in response to the decline in property values during the 2007-2009 recession. But these adjustments varied from place to place. Ihlanfeldt and Willardsen find this “offset mechanism” is weaker than previous research suggested, and will vary depending on a government’s “monopoly power.”</p>\n<p class="p1">Florida residents and businesses choose to locate in a given area for numerous reasons. The local tax structure may be one such consideration. Ihlanfeldt and Willardsen’s study refines the conventional wisdom on property taxes, explaining how rates are determined in political systems and how they <a href="http://www.bostonglobe.com/metro/regionals/north/2013/01/27/values-fall-recession-but-homeowners-stuck-with-higher-tax-bills/EM4kjnktq1fCtMOAkTgHWN/story.html">change in response to economic shocks</a>. These are valuable insights for Florida’s taxpayers.</p>'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '123'), ('wp:post_date', '2015-01-27 19:51:07'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2015-01-27 19:51:07'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'new-study-sheds-light-on-property-taxes-in-florida'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', [OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'florida'), ('#text', 'Florida')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'ihlanfeldt'), ('#text', 'Ihlanfeldt')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'local-government'), ('#text', 'local government')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'millage'), ('#text', 'millage')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'monopoly-power'), ('#text', 'monopoly power')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'property-taxes'), ('#text', 'property taxes')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'public-policy'), ('#text', 'public policy')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'tax-policy-2'), ('#text', 'Tax Policy')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'taxes'), ('#text', 'taxes')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'willardsen'), ('#text', 'Willardsen')])]), ('wp:postmeta', [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_publicize_pending'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_published'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_client_id'), ('wp:meta_value', '-1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_facebook'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_google_plus'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_twitter'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_linkedin'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_tumblr'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_path'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_edit_last'), ('wp:meta_value', '77167941')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', 'geo_public'), ('wp:meta_value', '0')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', 'Reforms are Brewing in Florida'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2015/02/03/reforms-are-brewing-in-florida/'), ('pubDate', 'Tue, 03 Feb 2015 16:43:50 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=126')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'By Matt Kelly\n\nFloridians are brandishing their growlers as the state’s legislature considers reforms that would finally <a href="http://brewerslaw.com/index.php/dear-64-oz-growler-florida-doesnt-intentionally-hate-you/" target="_blank">legalize the popular 64 oz. alcoholic beverage container</a>. Florida is the only state in the nation to prohibit the growler, a legal idiosyncrasy that craft brewers say stifles their growth. An exemption to allow small brewers to self-distribute their beer is also on the table. These proposals have brought the inefficiencies of Florida’s beer regulation to the fore as legislators debate the fate of beer.\n\n<!--more-->Beer regulation in the United States is cumbersome by design. When the 18th Amendment was repealed in 1933, ending Prohibition, policy makers endeavored to keep alcohol prices high and raise barriers to entry into the market. Even after the death of the speakeasy, puritanical sensibilities persisted. The regulation of alcoholic beverages was left to the states, some of which established public monopolies while others constructed byzantine regulations for private companies.\n\nThe key provision of post-Prohibition alcohol regulation has been a requirement that producers not sell directly to retailers, but rather contract with distributors who do business with bars and liquor stores. These regulations have come to be known as <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three-tier_%28alcohol_distribution%29" target="_blank">the three-tier system</a>. Although state laws vary significantly, most divide the three tiers (production, distribution, and retail) into separate interests that cannot intermingle.\n\nAdditional laws that restrict breweries’ right to contract with distributors also limit the industry’s growth. These “franchise laws” lock brewers into long-term contracts with only a single distributor, exposing them to supply chain risk \xa0and limiting their flexibility.\n\nHowever, with the impressive growth of craft breweries many states have created exemptions that allow small breweries producing less than a certain amount of barrels a year to self-distribute. As of yet, Florida has created no such exemptions, but does allow sale on a brewery’s premises in so-called “taprooms.”\n\nSelf-distribution allows craft manufacturers to compete in a business dominated by a few large firms. MillerCoors and Anheuser-Busch Inbev, together control about 80% of the beer market nationally. Distributors tend to favor these massive companies, which make up the bulk of their sales. Allowing small firms to self-distribute could help level the playing field.\n\nCraft brewers constitute an increasingly vibrant segment of the Florida beer market. <a href="http://www.fred.ifas.ufl.edu/economic-impact-analysis/pdf/Craft_Brewing_FL_2014.pdf" target="_blank">A study from The University of Florida</a> counts 90 craft brewers in the Sunshine State, employing 4,000 people, but the potential for growth is far larger. This fledgling industry is projected to reach a capacity of 550 breweries and create over 40,000 jobs.\n\nThe three-tier system was intended to raise prices and stifle growth in the alcoholic beverage industry. Indeed, it has accomplished these goals. However, if the state wishes to create jobs and allow business to prosper, it should not only end the growler ban, but also create a self-distribution exemption as 36 other states have done already.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '126'), ('wp:post_date', '2015-02-03 16:43:50'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2015-02-03 16:43:50'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'reforms-are-brewing-in-florida'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', [OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'alcohol'), ('#text', 'alcohol')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'beer'), ('#text', 'beer')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'brewers'), ('#text', 'brewers')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'craft-beers'), ('#text', 'craft beers')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'crafts-breweries'), ('#text', 'crafts breweries')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'distribution'), ('#text', 'distribution')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'entrepreneurship'), ('#text', 'Entrepreneurship')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'florida'), ('#text', 'Florida')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'growler'), ('#text', 'growler')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'growlers'), ('#text', 'growlers')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'politics-2'), ('#text', 'Politics')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'prohibition'), ('#text', 'prohibition')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'regulation'), ('#text', 'regulation')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'regulation-2'), ('#text', 'Regulation')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'taprooms'), ('#text', 'taprooms')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'three-tier-system'), ('#text', 'three-tier system')])]), ('wp:postmeta', [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_publicize_pending'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_published'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_client_id'), ('wp:meta_value', '-1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_facebook'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_google_plus'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_twitter'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_linkedin'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_tumblr'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_path'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_edit_last'), ('wp:meta_value', '77167941')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', 'geo_public'), ('wp:meta_value', '0')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', 'Sports Stadiums Not Worth Public Subsidies'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2015/02/05/sports-stadiums-not-worth-public-subsidies/'), ('pubDate', 'Thu, 05 Feb 2015 17:04:48 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=131')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'By Logan Shewmaker\n\nNext time you attend a ballgame, consider for a moment the monumental effort necessary to build a sports stadium. Surely, stadiums are among the most impressive structures ever built. Tourists continue to marvel at the architectural wonder of Rome’s Coliseum. But does that justify public subsidies? Three-fourths of stadiums in the U.S. are owned by local city and/or county governments (and hence publicly funded). Understanding the economic impacts are important to the public discussion about decisions to subsidize them. A host of academic studies call into question the alleged economic benefits of today’s sports stadiums.\n\n<a href="http://www.miamidolphins.com/multimedia/photo-gallery/DOLPHINS-DARKROOM-Sun-Life-Stadium-Renovation-Renderings/8f3f20f6-b067-433d-b01b-f274f53f830a" target="_blank"><!--more-->The Miami Dolphins recently released information</a> about the planned renovations of Sun Life Stadium. The revamp will include seating reductions and rearrangements, an updated concourse, and a canopy to cover 92% of seats from the south Florida sun. The renovations are estimated to cost between $350 and $400 million, and are to be completed before the 2016 NFL season.\n\nWhile most of the construction is privately funded by stadium owner <a href="http://www.forbes.com/profile/stephen-ross/" target="_blank">Steve Ross,</a> Miami-Dade County has agreed to contribute up to $5 million per year for 20 years from local hotel taxes to fund the project. County Mayor Carlos Gimenez stressed the stadium is not eligible for other public revenues beyond these tourism-related taxes.\n\nWhy are <a href="http://www.travelandleisure.com/articles/understanding-hotel-taxes" target="_blank">local hotel taxes</a> important? Hotel taxes are politically popular because they supposedly relieve locals of the tax burden. With tourists paying for sports stadiums, what’s not to like?\n\nBut how much do sports stadiums really improve the local economy? And do the effects justify public subsidies?\n\nOne 2012 <a href="http://www.scribd.com/doc/92368114/Stadium-Bonds" target="_blank">study by financial services company UBS</a> found little to no effect on local economies from the construction of sports stadiums. UBS attributes this to the “<a href="http://news.illinois.edu/news/04/1117stadiums.html" target="_blank">substitution effect.</a>” That is, people generally spend the same amount on entertainment in a given time, so adding a new entertainment venue simply draws money away from existing businesses.\n\nAnother <a href="http://edr.state.fl.us/Content/returnoninvestment/SportsGrantsandPrograms.pdf" target="_blank">study by Florida’s Office of Economic and Demographic Research</a> (OEDR) makes clear that sports stadiums are a bad investment, whether it’s tourists or locals who pay for them. Sports stadiums generate a return on investment (ROI) consistently under 1.0, meaning these investments are a net drain on public coffers.\n\nThe OEDR blames this poor performance on the fact that sports stadiums are long-term commitments. “This is problematic, because the long-term economic impacts of these sport teams... are far from clear when the initial evaluation is made.” The OEDR recommends state and local governments focus on shorter-term programs, like the Florida Sports Foundation (FSF) grants that fund only single sporting events that will occur in the near future. The FSF program enjoys a much higher ROI of 5.6, according to their analysis.\n\nIf taxpayers aren’t receiving a return on their investments in sports stadiums, it may be better to leave construction and renovation projects in the hands of stadium and team owners. DeVoe Moore Center Professor of Economics <a href="http://jse.sagepub.com/content/6/3/237.abstract" target="_blank">Chris Clapp’s research on sports stadiums</a> shows that sports franchise owners reap most of the benefits from construction subsidies. If it’s the Dolphins franchise and stadium owners who will receive the profits from the Sun Life renovations, it may be better that owners bear the costs as well.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), 'https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2015/02/cropped-fsu_logo_footer.jpg'), ('wp:postmeta', [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wp_attached_file'), ('wp:meta_value', '/home/wpcom/public_html/wp-content/blogs.dir/848/80998613/files/2015/02/cropped-fsu_logo_footer.jpg')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wp_attachment_context'), ('wp:meta_value', 'custom-header')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wp_attachment_metadata'), ('wp:meta_value', 'a:5:{s:5:"width";i:100;s:6:"height";i:100;s:4:"file";s:99:"/home/wpcom/public_html/wp-content/blogs.dir/848/80998613/files/2015/02/cropped-fsu_logo_footer.jpg";s:5:"sizes";a:0:{}s:10:"image_meta";a:11:{s:8:"aperture";i:0;s:6:"credit";s:0:"";s:6:"camera";s:0:"";s:7:"caption";s:0:"";s:17:"created_timestamp";i:0;s:9:"copyright";s:0:"";s:12:"focal_length";i:0;s:3:"iso";i:0;s:13:"shutter_speed";i:0;s:5:"title";s:0:"";s:11:"orientation";i:0;}}')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wp_attachment_custom_header_last_used_pub/sorbet'), ('wp:meta_value', '1423777928')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wp_attachment_is_custom_header'), ('wp:meta_value', 'pub/sorbet')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', "Florida's Franchise Laws are Holding Back Craft Beer"), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2015/02/10/floridas-franchise-laws-are-holding-back-craft-beer/'), ('pubDate', 'Tue, 10 Feb 2015 16:38:15 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=141')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', '<p class="p1">By Matt Kelly</p>\n<p class="p1">While legislators and beer enthusiasts across Florida attempt to <a href="http://floridanewsflash.com/article.php/beer-ldquogrowlerrdquo-bill-on-hold-21047#" target="_blank">lift a 50-year-old ban on growlers</a> (64 oz. containers of beer), many are ignoring a key aspect of this controversial policy issue: franchise termination laws. <a href="http://www.brewersassociation.org/government-affairs/laws/franchise-laws/" target="_blank">Franchise law</a> regulates contracts between beer manufacturers--breweries--(the franchisors) and distributors (the franchisees). Florida’s franchise laws, however, currently give distributors an unfair advantage over suppliers and legislators should consider reforming them to level the playing field.</p>\n<p class="p1"><!--more-->As mentioned in a previous blog, breweries in Florida must sell their entire product to distributors. In turn retailers are required to buy beer from licensed distributors. This requirement aids distributors by limiting competition, but Florida’s franchise laws go further by <a href="http://komlossylaw.com/franchise/" target="_blank">making it difficult for brewers to terminate their contracts</a>. Economist Douglas Glen Whitman from the Independent Institute writes, “The predictable result of impeding such terminations is inflated markups by wholesalers.”</p>\n<p class="p1">To terminate a contract, brewers must prove that there’s “good cause,” which is narrowly defined as fraud or bankruptcy on the part of distributors. This is an unreasonably high standard not seen in most industries. According to a <a href="https://cei.org/sites/default/files/Angela%20Logomasini%20-%20A%20CARE-less%20Rush%20to%20Regulate.pdf" target="_blank">2011 report by The Competitive Enterprise Institute</a>, “Failure for a wholesaler to find markets for a product is usually not considered adequate reason for termination...” in the beer distribution market. Suppliers are stuck with their distributor whether it’s good for business or not. This handicap ultimately limits consumers’ choices and keeps prices high.</p>\n<p class="p1">In his book <a href="http://www.independent.org/store/book.asp?id=25" target="_blank">Strange Brew</a>, Whitman points out the “double markup problem,” in which the use of a distributor raises prices while profits fall, since they are divided between two companies. To avoid this problem, beer producers can “impose contractual obligations on wholesalers” in contract negotiations, requiring them to sell at a certain price or specifying a minimum sales quota. Problems like shirking and opportunism by brewers or distributors could be anticipated and addressed privately. Disputes could, and should be settled via traditional contract remedies as in most other businesses.</p>\n<p class="p1">However, Florida’s franchise laws make such private agreements unenforceable. The difficulty in terminating an agreement creates a moral hazard, since distributors have no incentive to improve services when suppliers are locked into contracts indefinitely.</p>\n<p class="p1">Franchise laws hurt small brewers most. Since the most profitable beers are established favorites like Budweiser and Miller Lite, distributors have little incentive to promote new beers that few customers have heard of. Allowing small breweries to switch distributors with greater ease could make them more flexible. As microbreweries grow, their distribution needs will change. <a href="http://www.brewersassociation.org/statistics/economic-impact-data/" target="_blank">Craft beer is leading growth in this industry,</a> but tying craft brewers indefinitely to a single distributor greatly limits their profitability.</p>\n<p class="p1">Distributors nevertheless perform an integral role in the beer business. As small breweries grow, they will likely need to contract with distributors who can deliver their product efficiently. However, without the option to exit, contracts can quickly become a ball-and-chain for start-up manufacturers.</p>\n<p class="p1">Legalizing the 64 oz. growler and creating exemptions for small brewers to self-distribute would be worthwhile improvements to Florida’s beer regulations. However, franchise laws will continue to limit brewers’ choices as they grow. Growlers and self-distribution would add some hops into Florida’s craft beer industry, but any package that avoids reforming franchise law is likely to have a flat impact.</p>'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '141'), ('wp:post_date', '2015-02-10 16:38:15'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2015-02-10 16:38:15'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'floridas-franchise-laws-are-holding-back-craft-beer'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', [OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'beer'), ('#text', 'beer')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'beer-growler'), ('#text', 'beer growler')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'beer-regulation'), ('#text', 'beer regulation')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'contracts'), ('#text', 'contracts')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'craft-beer'), ('#text', 'craft beer')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'entrepreneurship'), ('#text', 'Entrepreneurship')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'florida'), ('#text', 'Florida')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'franchise-law'), ('#text', 'franchise law')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'growlers'), ('#text', 'growlers')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'regulation'), ('#text', 'three-tier system')])]), ('wp:postmeta', [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_publicize_pending'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_published'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_client_id'), ('wp:meta_value', '-1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_facebook'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_google_plus'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_twitter'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_linkedin'), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_edit_last'), ('wp:meta_value', '77167941')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', 'geo_public'), ('wp:meta_value', '0')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', 'The Foundations of Political Capitalism'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2015/02/12/the-foundations-of-political-capitalism/'), ('pubDate', 'Thu, 12 Feb 2015 16:15:14 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=145')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'By Matt Kelly\n\nThomas Piketty’s <a href="http://www.amazon.com/Capital-Twenty-First-Century-Thomas-Piketty/dp/1491534656" target="_blank"><i>Capital in the Twenty-First Century</i> </a>raised quite a stir last year among economists. Piketty identifies rising wealth inequality as inherent in capitalism, and recommends a worldwide wealth tax to temper its effects. Many have taken issue with Piketty’s data and analysis, and the idea that inequality is rising at all is controversial, but most agree that Piketty’s tome is a rigorous work of scholarship. But according to <a href="http://randallholcombe.com/" target="_blank">DeVoe Moore Center professor Randall Holcombe</a>, the author may beignoring political constraints that would contribute to such an accumulation of wealth and power.\n\n<!--more-->In a <a href="http://object.cato.org/sites/cato.org/files/serials/files/cato-journal/2015/2/cj-v35n1-2.pdf" target="_blank">recent paper published by The Cato Institute</a>, Holcombe makes this argument on “political capitalism,” defined as a system in which “the economic and political elite cooperate for their mutual benefit.”’ Business and government collude to perpetuate their power and interests, enriching themselves at the expense of the poor and middle class. Professor Holcombe explores the history and intellectual foundations of this idea, and suggests that the political left and right are surprisingly united in their disdain for it.\n\nThe idea of <a href="http://www.politicalcapitalism.org/what/" target="_blank">political capitalism</a> will be familiar to most readers, but social commentators typically portray this collusion as an infiltration of socialism into capitalism, or visa versa. Holcombe suggests that, instead, political capitalism ought to be recognized as a distinct economic system. The inequality Piketty highlights may actually be a product of political capitalism, not some inherent feature of the free market.\n\nHolcombe traces the origin of this idea to sociologist <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Max_Weber" target="_blank">Max Weber’s</a> description of Ancient Rome, and even suggests <a href="https://www.marxists.org/archive/marx/" target="_blank">Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels</a> had political capitalism in mind when they noted, “Each step in the development of the bourgeoisie (wealthy class) was accompanied by a corresponding political advance of that class.”\n\n<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_choice" target="_blank">Public Choice</a> economists such as James Buchanan and Gordon Tullock applied economic methods to analyze the political process, and Holcombe sees their contributions as a foundation for understanding political capitalism. Their work explains why wealthy special interests can more easily obtain favors from government legislators, a practice called “<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rent-seeking" target="_blank">rent-seeking.</a>” A few well-connected business people can better negotiate to pass legislation than a large number of diffuse voters who are difficult to organize.\n\nMore recent work by <a href="http://whynationsfail.com/" target="_blank">Acemoglu and Robinson (2012)</a> describes the corruption in many developing countries as similar to political capitalism. A much-cited <a href="http://scholar.princeton.edu/sites/default/files/mgilens/files/gilens_and_page_2014_-testing_theories_of_american_politics.doc.pdf" target="_blank">study by Gilens and Page (2014)</a> also finds public policies most often align with elites’ preferences.\n\nHolcombe argues that economists need to study political capitalism on its own terms if they hope to identify solutions to this problem. While the left criticizes inherent problems with capitalism, and the right blames political dysfunction on government interventions, both assessments describe the features of political capitalism. Public intellectuals with opposing political views like <a href="http://www.josephstiglitz.com/" target="_blank">Joseph Stiglitz</a> (left) and <a href="http://davidstockmanscontracorner.com/" target="_blank">David Stockman</a> (right), both recently published books that attack political capitalism. Political activist <a href="https://nader.org/" target="_blank">Ralph Nader</a> has even argued this common disdain for political capitalism can unite both the left and right to work together.\n\nHolcombe’s work on political capitalism offers an alternative explanation for what Piketty’s sees as worsening inequality and advocates that economists examine political capitalism rather than continue to fruitlessly compare capitalism and socialism. After recognizing political capitalism as a distinct system, opposing sides of this debate may find themselves in agreement.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '145'), ('wp:post_date', '2015-02-12 16:15:14'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2015-02-12 16:15:14'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'the-foundations-of-political-capitalism'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', [OrderedDict([('@domain', ('description', None), ('content:encoded', '<p style="text-align:left;">This blog is maintained by the DeVoe Moore Center, an applied policy research center in the College of Social Sciences and Public Policy at Florida State University (<a href="http://www.coss.fsu.edu/dmc">www.coss.fsu.edu/dmc</a>). The blog is considered an outreach component of the DeVoe Moore Center’s programs and activities and not a core academic research activity. All posts are written by faculty, staff, interns or researchers directly affiliated with the Center, and content is supervised by senior staff and subject to a multi-stage editorial process (including review by a staff editor).</p>\nBlogs are journalistic endeavors and reflect the perspectives and interpretations of the authors. Posts do not necessarily reflect the official views of the DeVoe Moore Center, the College of Social Sciences and Public Policy, Florida State University, or FSU’s Board of Trustees. Any concerns about content should be sent to Matthew Kelly, blog content editor at <a href="mailto:mlk12b@my.fsu.edu">mlk12b@my.fsu.edu</a> or Sam Staley, Director of the DeVoe Moore Center, at <a href="mailto:sstaley@fsu.edu">sstaley@fsu.edu</a>.\n\n&nbsp;\n\n&nbsp;\n\n<strong>Brief bios and taglines for the authors are provided on the blog here: <a href="https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/authors/">https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/authors/</a>\n</strong>'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '167'), ('wp:post_date', '2015-02-12 17:49:23'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2015-02-12 17:49:23'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'editorial-process'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'page'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('wp:postmeta', [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_edit_last'), ('wp:meta_value', '77167941')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wp_page_template'), ('wp:meta_value', 'default')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_publicize_pending'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', 'geo_public'), ('wp:meta_value', '0')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', 'Authors'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/authors/'), ('pubDate', 'Thu, 12 Feb 2015 21:55:08 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?page_id=185')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', '<span style="color:#333333;"><img class="alignnone  wp-image-535" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2015/02/mattkelly1.png" alt="MattKelly" width="209" height="227" /></span>\n\n<span style="color:#333333;"><b>Matt Kelly</b> is the lead policy analyst and blog content manager for the DeVoe Moore Center. He works in collaboration with research assistants that he manages to produce meaningful policy commentary and policy briefs under the Policy Lab Group. His areas of research focus on social entrepreneurship, regulation, and the disruptive effects of the sharing economy. He earned his degree in economics from Florida State University.</span>\n\n<span style="color:#333333;"><img class="alignnone  wp-image-532" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2015/02/2e076e820899c5bda6b7ef9678da5b44-th.jpg" alt="2e076e820899c5bda6b7ef9678da5b44.th" width="170" height="253" /></span>\n\n<span style="color:#333333;"><b>Sam Staley</b> is Director of the DeVoe Moore Center and on the full-time faculty of the College of Social Sciences and Public Policy. He teaches in the departments of economics and urban planning, with academic specialties in regulation, economic development, housing and land, growth management, transportation, and urban policy.\xa0He also is a research fellow at the Reason Foundation and a senior fellow at both the Indiana Policy Review Foundation and the Buckeye Institute for Public Policy Solutions.\xa0Staley received his B.A. in Economics and Public Policy from Colby College, M.S. in Social and Applied Economics from Wright State University, and Ph.D. in Public Administration, with concentrations in urban planning and public finance from Ohio State University.</span>\n\n<span style="color:#333333;"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-533" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2015/02/holcombe.jpeg" alt="holcombe" width="207" height="270" /></span>\n\n<span style="color:#333333;"><strong>Randall G. Holcombe </strong>is DeVoe Moore Professor of Economics at Florida State University. He received his Ph.D. in economics from Virginia Tech, and taught at Texas A&amp;M University and at Auburn University prior to coming to Florida State in 1988. Dr. Holcombe is also Senior Fellow at the James Madison Institute, a Tallahassee-based think tank that specializes in issues facing state governments. He served on Florida Governor Jeb Bush’s Council of Economic Advisors from 2000 to 2006, and is past president of the Public Choice Society and the Society for the Development of Austrian Economics. Dr. Holcombe is the author of fifteen books and more than 150 articles published in academic and professional journals. His books include From Liberty to Democracy: The Transformation of American Government (2002), and Producing Prosperity (2013). His primary areas of research are public finance and the economic analysis of public policy issues.</span>\n\n<span style="color:#333333;"><img class="alignnone  wp-image-536" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2015/02/kevingom.png" alt="kevingom" width="229" height="274" /></span>\n\n<span style="color:#333333;"><strong><b>Kevin Gomez</b> </strong>is the Outreach Director for the DeVoe Moore Center. He is President of the Economics Club at Florida State University and the National Association for Business Economics FSU Chapter. He is the Florida State Fellow and blogger for <a style="color:#333333;" href="http://www.genfkd.com/author/kevin-gomez">GenFKD</a>.<strong>\n</strong></span>\n\n<span style="color:#333333;"><img class="alignnone  wp-image-531" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2015/02/2ca88a1.jpg" alt="2ca88a1" width="220" height="220" /></span>\n\n<span style="color:#333333;"><b>Tyler Worthington\xa0</b>is the Lead Analyst of the Data Analytics Group in the DeVoe Moore Center which produces data driven commentary from the DMC-managed <a style="color:#333333;" href="http://www.flopengov.org">FLOpenGov</a> database. He is currently in the Applied Master\'s in Economics program at Florida State University.</span>\n\n<span style="color:#333333;"><img class="alignnone  wp-image-545" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2015/02/aaeaaqaaaaaaaarsaaaajde3zmm5n2zmltuzytitndnmzc1hmwuwlwjkzjnlowy2mjcxng.jpg" alt="AAEAAQAAAAAAAARsAAAAJDE3ZmM5N2ZmLTUzYTItNDNmZC1hMWUwLWJkZjNlOWY2MjcxNg" width="195" height="195" /></span>\n\n<span style="color:#333333;"><strong>Nadia James</strong>\xa0is a data analyst within the Data Analytics Group or the DeVoe Moore Center. She is currently in the Applied Master\'s in Economics program at Florida State University.</span>\n\n<span style="color:#333333;"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-546" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2015/02/aaeaaqaaaaaaaauaaaaajduwodbknwe1lwvkmdgtngi3mc1hnjjmltk2owrlm2nmmtzlnq.jpg" alt="AAEAAQAAAAAAAAUAAAAAJDUwODBkNWE1LWVkMDgtNGI3MC1hNjJmLTk2OWRlM2NmMTZlNQ" width="200" height="200" /></span>\n\n<span style="color:#333333;"><strong>Nick Hyder</strong>\xa0is a data analyst within the Data Analytics Group or the DeVoe Moore Center. He is currently in the Applied Master\'s in Economics program at Florida State University.</span>\n\n<span style="color:#333333;"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-544" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2015/02/aaeaaqaaaaaaaacgaaaajdhkzjqzntmzlwrimtctngzkmy1induxlthjmjfkzjkxntq2zq.jpg" alt="AAEAAQAAAAAAAAcGAAAAJDhkZjQzNTMzLWRiMTctNGZkMy1iNDUxLThjMjFkZjkxNTQ2ZQ" width="200" height="200" /></span>\n\n<span style="color:#333333;"><strong>Tian Ma</strong>\xa0is a data analyst within the Data Analytics Group or the DeVoe Moore Center. He is currently in the Applied Master\'s in Economics program at Florida State University.</span>'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '185'), ('wp:post_date', '2015-02-12 21:55:08'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2015-02-12 21:55:08'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'authors'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'page'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('wp:postmeta', [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_edit_last'), ('wp:meta_value', '77167941')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wp_page_template'), ('wp:meta_value', 'default')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_publicize_pending'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', 'geo_public'), ('wp:meta_value', '0')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', "Florida's Dysfunctional Property Insurance System"), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2015/02/17/187/'), ('pubDate', 'Tue, 17 Feb 2015 17:03:13 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=187')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'By Matt Kelly Many readers will remember the hurricane season of 2004 as <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2004_Atlantic_hurricane_season" target="_blank">a chaotic time to be a Florida resident.</a> The Sunshine State received four torrential storms that year, causing $45 billion in losses. School was cancelled, streets were covered with debris, and 37 lives were lost. Since 2005, Florida has experienced a nine-year reprieve from major hurricanes, but the state’s largest property insurance company has only recently recovered from the financial losses incurred in 2004 and 2005. <a href="http://www.jamesmadison.org/press-room/release-florida-report-outlines-lasting-property-insurance-market-reform-recommendations.html" target="_blank">A new report by senior fellow of the R Street Institute R.J. Lehmann, from the James Madison Institute</a> makes clear that the next big storm could also devastate public coffers unless reforms are made.<!--more--> Florida and Louisiana are the only two U.S. states that have government established property insurance companies. Florida’s <a href="https://www.citizensfla.com/" target="_blank">Citizens Property Insurance Company</a> was established in 2002 to “offer coverage to Floridians who legitimately could not obtain it from the private market,” serving as an insurer of last resort. Lehmann’s report notes, “In 2007, Citizens’ role was greatly expanded to offer insurance policies to any homeowner who receives a quote for coverage from a private insurer more than 15 percent greater than Citizens’ rates.” Since then, Citizens has ballooned. As of June 30, 2014, it covered as much as 22% of Florida’s property insurance market, with 912,731 policies in force and over $295 billion in exposure. Citizens has reached these proportions through its advantage as a public entity, creating a dysfunctional insurance system along the way. Unlike private insurance companies, Citizens has the authority to impose charges, called <a href="https://www.citizensfla.com/about/CitizensAssessments.cfm" target="_blank">“emergency assessments,”</a> on almost all other insurance policyholders in the state. These assessments would increase premiums for policyholders statewide in order to cover Citizens\' deficits arising from a severe storm or storms. These assessments can extend to nearly every form of insurance and last for multiple years. This advantage allows Citizens to charge artificially low premiums to its policyholders, many of whom can already afford the market rate. The company’s coverage remains significantly below market price and has only recently returned to an actuarially sound level. Though with 22% of the property insurance policies in Florida currently, Citizens was much larger just a few years ago. In 2012 it had a 42% market share. Thanks in part to steps taken by lawmakers and Citizens’ management, the company’s exposure has been significantly reduced, from a peak of $510 billion to $295 billion today. Governor Scott made an important step forward in moving Citizens to a more actuarially sound footing when <a href="http://www.politifact.com/florida/promises/scott-o-meter/promise/624/reform-citizens-insurance-to-consistently-operate/" target="_blank">he advocated for, and secured, the lifting of a 10% cap on premium increases for sinkhole coverage.</a> In 2014, 185,405 of its policies were transferred to the private market, and Citizens has now accumulated a surplus of $7.9 billion. Yet this surplus is mostly due to the extremely rare nine-year stretch without a major hurricane. A one-in-one-hundred year storm would far outstrip Citizens’ modest savings. <a href="http://edr.state.fl.us/Content/returnoninvestment/BeachReport.pdf" target="_blank">The Office of Economic and Demographic Research estimates</a> that such a storm could cause between $183.22 billion and $198.99 billion in damages, with $90.86 billion in insured residential and commercial property losses. Not only would Citizens’ current surplus not cover such damages, but nearly everyone with a private insurance policy would be effectively taxed in order to pay for Citizens’ deficits. There’s no avoiding the next catastrophic storm, but Lehmann’s report suggests several reforms that could minimize the impact on Florida’s taxpayers. Future blogs will discuss potential solutions to Florida’s dysfunctional insurance system. With $2.9 trillion in coastal property values, such reforms are vital to Florida’s future and the fiscal solvency of the state.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '187'), ('wp:post_date', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2015/02/cropped-westcott-building.jpg')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'http://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2015/02/cropped-westcott-building.jpg'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '192'), ('wp:post_date', '2015-02-17 21:29:29'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2015-02-17 21:29:29'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'cropped-westcott-building-jpg'), ('wp:status', 'inherit'), ('wp:post_parent', 'custom-header')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wp_attachment_metadata'), ('wp:meta_value', 'a:5:{s:5:"width";i:713;s:6:"height";i:261;s:4:"file";s:101:"/home/wpcom/public_html/wp-content/blogs.dir/848/80998613/files/2015/02/cropped-westcott-building.jpg";s:5:"sizes";a:0:{}s:10:"image_meta";a:11:{s:8:"aperture";i:0;s:6:"credit";s:0:"";s:6:"camera";s:0:"";s:7:"caption";s:0:"";s:17:"created_timestamp";i:0;s:9:"copyright";s:0:"";s:12:"focal_length";i:0;s:3:"iso";i:0;s:13:"shutter_speed";i:0;s:5:"title";s:0:"";s:11:"orientation";i:0;}}')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wp_attachment_custom_header_last_used_pub/sorbet'), ('wp:meta_value', '1424212012')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wp_attachment_is_custom_header'), ('wp:meta_value', 'pub/sorbet')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', "Orlando's Soccer Stadium Not Worth Public Investment"), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2015/02/19/orlandos-soccer-stadium-not-worth-public-investment/'), ('pubDate', 'Thu, 19 Feb 2015 17:26:15 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=194')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'By Logan Shewmaker\n\nU.S. Major League Soccer (MLS) is pushing to expand into Florida. Between 2008 and 2013, the average MLS franchise’s market capitaliztion <a href="http://www.forbes.com/sites/chrissmith/2013/11/20/major-league-soccers-most-valuable-teams/">grew 175 percent</a>. The average attendance for MLS games exceeds<a href="http://www.forbes.com/sites/chrissmith/2013/11/20/major-league-soccers-most-valuable-teams/"> 18,000</a>, higher than the NBA. <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Beautiful_Game">“The beautiful game”</a> is growing in the United States, but does MLS growth justify public subsidies?\n\n<!--more-->In 2013, Orlando City Soccer Club joined the MLS as an<a href="http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2013-11-19/sports/os-mls-orlando-city-1120-20131119_1_orlando-magic-mls-commissioner-don-garber-mls-franchise"> expansion team</a>. The club will hold matches beginning in the 2015 season and compete as the Orlando City Lions. To become a franchise, the MLS prefers teams play in soccer-specific stadiums. Construction costs are significant. Orlando City is currently<a href="http://www.cityoforlando.net/venues/mls-soccer-stadium/">\xa0designing a new stadium</a> in downtown Orlando that is expected to cost $110 million in total.\n\nBut who’s going to pay for it? The franchise itself will contribute $30 million, plus an additional $675,000 annually for 25 years. Twenty million dollars would be subsidized by taxpayers from the tourist development tax fund, along with another $20 million directly from the City of Orlando. The Lions have also requested<a href="http://www.orlandosentinel.com/news/politics/political-pulse/os-orlando-city-soccer-stadium-money-nears-goal-line-but-state-squabbling-persists-20150211-post.html"> $2 million dollars in subsidies from the State of Florida, and the proposal is pending before the state legislature.</a>\n\nDespite these large outlays, the return to taxpayers is minimal. According to <a href="http://edr.state.fl.us/Content/returnoninvestment/SportsGrantsandPrograms.pdf">a study from the Office of Economic and Demographic Research</a> (ODR), sports stadiums typically have a return on investment (ROI) of just 0.30, well below 1, meaning that for every $1 invested only $0.30 is gained in added revenue. <a href="http://49ers.savesantaclara.org/pdf/TheEdificeComplex.pdf">Research conducted by Assistant Professor of Economics at FSU Chris Clapp</a> concluded that team owners ultimately receive the profits from these subsidies. As a <a href="http://www.tallahassee.com/story/opinion/2015/02/17/sam-staley-sports-stadium-subsidies-drain-economy/23545799/">recent op-ed by DeVoe Moore Center Director Samuel Staley</a> points out, sports stadiums may be profitable to stadium owners, but they are a net loss in terms of public investment.\n\nThis begs the question: Is a new stadium in Orlando necessary?\n\nA study published in the<a href="http://sc.edu/study/colleges_schools/hrsm/research/research_journals_and_publications/jvem_pdfs/vol4_no2/investigation_of_major_league_soccer_attendance.pdf"> Journal of Venue and Event Management</a> found that soccer-specific stadiums usually increase attendance, but that proximity to downtown and a good marketing plan are crucial to success. For instance, the Seattle Sounders are by far the most financially successful MLS team, yet they play in an NFL stadium. The Sounders’ “March to the Match” parades on game days have also proved an energizing part of their marketing plan.\n\nThe Orlando City Lions have already sold<a href="http://www.orlandocitysc.com/post/2015/02/02/orlando-city-surpasses-11000-season-tickets-inaugural-season"> 11,000 season tickets</a> for the first season, which will be played in the Citrus Bowl. The Citrus Bowl has undergone countless renovations, most recently in 2014. Since this shared arrangement is working well, the case for another taxpayer subsidized MLS stadium seems weak based on team performance alone.\n\nConstruction on the new MLS stadium has already begun, but a new venue may not be necessary for the Lions soccer team. Orlando City Soccer’s “<a href="http://www.mlssoccer.com/news/article/2015/02/05/orlando-city-sc-launch-plan-draw-65000-fans-inaugural-mls-match-citrus-bowl">Fill the Bowl</a>” marketing campaign is intended to pack 65,000 fans into the Citrus Bowl for the season’s first game, and given the advanced ticket sales and publicity surrounding it, they may be successful.\n\nMLS is growing, but Florida’s taxpayers should not have to foot the bill for their new stadiums, especially when evidence shows such projects have a low return on investment. When the time for expansion is right, willing private investors will be better suited to fund stadium construction. Tax dollars would be better spent on education, infrastructure, or a host of other projects and services before sports stadiums.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '194'), ('wp:post_date', '2015-02-19 17:26:15'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2015-02-19 17:26:15'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'orlandos-soccer-stadium-not-worth-public-investment'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', [OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'citrus-bowl'), ('#text', 'Citrus Bowl')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'economics'), ('#text', 'economics')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'fiscal-policy'), ('#text', 'Fiscal Policy')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'lions'), ('#text', 'Lions')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'mls'), ('#text', 'MLS')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'orlando'), ('#text', 'Orlando')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'orlando-city-lions'), ('#text', 'Orlando City Lions')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'orlando-city-soccer'), ('#text', 'Orlando City Soccer')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'tax-policy-2'), ('#text', 'Tax Policy')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'taxes'), ('#text', 'taxes')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'tourism'), ('#text', 'tourism')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'urban-development'), ('#text', 'Urban Development')])]), ('wp:postmeta', [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_publicize_pending'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_published'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_client_id'), ('wp:meta_value', '-1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wpas_skip_facebook'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key',
