OrderedDict([('title', 'FSU Westcott aerial w DMC'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/fsu-westcott-aerial-w-dmc/'), ('pubDate', 'Tue, 24 Feb 2015 21:57:43 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2015/02/fsu-westcott-aerial-w-dmc.jpg')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', None), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '199'), ('wp:post_date', '2015-02-24 21:57:43'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2015-02-24 21:57:43'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:meta_value', 'pub/twentyten')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', "New Book Documents Tourist's Adventures in Cuba"), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2015/02/25/new-book-documents-tourists-adventures-in-cuba/'), ('pubDate', 'Wed, 25 Feb 2015 16:21:13 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=223')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'By Matt Kelly\n\nA new book by <a href="http://www.seu.edu/academics/faculty/jrold/">Jason R. Old</a>, professor of Spanish and Latin American Culture at Southeastern University in Lakeland, Florida, sheds light on the people of Cuba, a timely topic given recent decisions to open up trade with this island nation. “I invite you to enjoy my <i>anthrotouristic</i> journey through Cuba, as I seek to understand Cuba’s system, their culture, and their overall way of life,” begins <a href="http://www.amazon.com/Cuba-Embargo-Jason-R-Old/dp/1499333390"><i>Cuba: Behind the Embargo</i>.</a> Old is a self-described scholar of Che Guevara steeped in the Marxist-Leninist literary tradition, yet his views shift somewhat throughout his travels. Though he sets out thinking socialism is well suited to the island’s people, he returns home feeling “more confused than when I left.”<!--more-->\n\n<i>Behind the Embargo</i> is most enjoyable when describing the natural environment and the warmth and generosity of Cuba’s people. Readers can easily imagine Old taking in the scenery from a taxi car window, bumping along a dirt road lined with royal palms, fanning himself as the sun beats down on the Soviet era <i>lada</i> (car), the driver cracking a joke now and again. He relays the easy-going attitude of local guides who show him the countryside: its winding trails, majestic waterfalls, and damp secret caves. Moments like these, enjoying serenity in the humid jungle, are <i>Behind the Embargo</i>’s best. “The most important things that I took away from this adventure were the beautiful places that I had the privilege to see and all of the amazing people that I met,” Old writes.\n\nAs Old converses with fast-made friends, however, the realities of their daily lives are slowly revealed. At first, though, he is either unwilling or unable to see the desperation that later becomes apparent. He reflects later in the book that early chapters may seem naive to readers.\n\nOne particularly ironic scene occurs as a well-educated woman named Miriam recounts the illustrious history of her neighborhood, all taking place in front of the ruins of her demolished home, the last wooden structure in the community. Government officials felt \xa0it should be “updated,” and so destroyed the history that Miriam worked to document. The irony appears lost on Old, who admires Miriam’s willingness to see this demolition as a “learning opportunity.”\n\nAs a tourist, Old chooses to stay in government-approved housing called <i>casa particulars</i>, which are typically run by families with favorable views of the Castro regime. <i>Casa particulars </i>are privately operated and usually located in nicer areas with better infrastructure.\n\nAs his journey continues, Old is able to remain in impoverished areas for longer periods of time, getting a view of Cuba that most tourists are not privy to. Though he praises the Cuban government’s achievements (free health care, education, food, etc.), he also begins to notice shortages of medical and school supplies.\n\nOld eventually criticizes Cuba’s lack of freedom of speech, its low state-imposed wages, and what he calls the “brain drain,” whereby an absence of economic opportunity incentivizes people to earn income illegally, work in tourism, or leave the island altogether. One daughter of a family he stays with says that she doesn’t “see the point in studying when she can make more money working as a maid” in her grandmother’s <i>casa particular</i>. Though the author ultimately thinks the American embargo is this “brain drain”’s most likely cause, he points to several internal problems as well.\n\nOld’s most pointed complaints are directed at the government’s tourism policies, which he says are keeping Cuba locked in the past. Tourists are prohibited from going to certain parts of the island, ostensibly for safety. This prevents visitors and locals from truly enjoying a cultural exchange. Through these laws, as well as Internet censorship policies that prevent hotel and tourism businesses from promoting themselves online, Cuba is refusing to enter the twenty-first century.\n\nDespite Cuba’s ideological differences with the United States, there are many similarities. Old humorously observes that in both places, billboards bombard citizens with messages of one kind or another. “I am not entirely sure which style of billboard I prefer: the provocative sexual innuendoes of the capitalist marketing in the United States ... or the overtly socialist propaganda, revolutionary rhetoric and quotes that permeate just about every Cuban street corner.”\n\nReaders will enjoy Old’s description of the Cuban countryside, cuisine, and people, but what makes Jason Old’s <i>anthrotouristic</i> account interesting is his changing worldview. Seeing his opinions shift as the book progresses is a lesson to American readers on both ends of the political spectrum. Open-mindedness is a virtue.\n\nThough Old is perhaps too kind in his final analysis of Castro’s regime, <i>Cuba: Behind the Embargo</i> serves as an educational glimpse into the lives of everyday Cubans. Hopefully, as America eases the embargo, more first-hand accounts like this will be told.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '223'), ('wp:post_date', '2015-02-25 16:21:13'), ('wp:meta_value', 'pub/twentyten')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', "Florida's Pensions Could Be Reformed Locally"), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2015/02/26/floridas-pensions-could-be-reformed-locally/'), ('pubDate', 'Thu, 26 Feb 2015 19:24:47 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=232')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'By Matt Kelly\n\n<a href="http://pension360.org/florida-to-19-local-pension-plans-fix-funding-issues-now/" target="_blank">On January 27th, the managers of 19 Florida pension funds received a “call to action” letter from the Florida Department of Management Services </a>informing them that reforms are needed to address their unfunded liabilities. <a href="https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/2015/01/13/the-current-state-of-pensions-in-florida/" target="_blank">A previous blog</a> pointed out that while Florida’s state’s employee pension fund is 86% funded (better provisioned than 41 other U.S. states), some municipal pensions are less than 50% funded, posing a budgetary risk. Reforms are certainly needed, but what exact shape reforms should take might best be decided locally.<!--more-->\n\n<a href="https://www.myfrs.com/" target="_blank">The Florida Retirement System (FRS)</a> administers benefits for the state, counties, and 302 cities, among other entities. In 2013, the Florida Legislature <a href="http://politics.heraldtribune.com/2014/11/19/florida-pension-reform-looms-large/" target="_blank">appropriated an extra $500 million to bolster the FRS</a> and cover liabilities of some underfunded cities, and will need to appropriate that much for about 20 years in order to cover unfunded liabilities.\n\nThe state itself shares blame for shortfalls. <a href="http://www.floridaleagueofcities.com/Assets/Files/IB-Municipal_Pension_Reform_013014.pdf" target="_blank">A 1999 law mandates cities pay a minimum annual level of benefits to pensioners and devote any additional property taxes collected to additional benefits rather than servicing liabilities.</a> This requirement makes it difficult for cities to cover existing liabilities, and thus makes underfunding more likely. Correcting this system’s flaws would help Florida avoid budgetary crises as pension liabilities increasingly outpace revenues.\n\nTransitioning from defined benefit plans to defined contribution plans is the most effective solution. However, unfunded liabilities vary from city to city. Removing the state’s 1999 law’s requirements could allow cities needed flexibility. Local governments could then make the changes in retirement age, eligibility for vesting, and contribution requirements that are necessary to fund their liabilities.\n\nPublic employees were made a promise in good faith about their pension benefits and have based their retirement decisions around these assumptions. Going back on this promise has eroded confidence in government, as pensioners and taxpayers think twice about the state’s ability to meet other commitments. However, the financial realities of the pension system demand attention, and reforms are needed to avoid future budgetary crises.\n\nSome maintain that future reforms should consider every public employee as a candidate for transition to defined contribution plans. Such changes would immediately stop governments from increasing their unfunded pension liabilities, but suddenly moving all 623,011 active members into defined contribution plans may be politically impossible and perhaps unnecessary.\n\nA gradual approach, allowing current retirees and long-vested employees to keep their benefits, shifting recently vested employees into defined contribution plans, and requiring new employees to do the same, is the most practical policy reform in the short term. A less bold but hands-off solution, though, would remove existing laws that encourage underfunding for municipal pensions, like the requirement that cities use additional property tax revenue to fund additional benefits.\n\nMunicipal public pensions might be fixed locally once onerous state requirements are removed.<a href="http://archive.flsenate.gov/data/session/2010/Senate/bills/billtext/pdf/s1902.pdf" target="_blank"> SB 1902,</a> which was proposed (but not passed) in 2010, would have reversed the 1999 law and allowed Florida’s municipalities to switch employees to defined contribution plans as they see fit. Removing state demands on municipal governments is a needed reform, since they force cities to guarantee benefits not all can afford to pay.\n\nLocal pension plans will need to change, but many reforms can best be decided at the local level. Removing the State of Florida’s unrealistic requirements on local governments would allow municipalities the flexibility to do so.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '232'), ('wp:post_date', '2015-02-26 19:24:47'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2015-02-26 19:24:47'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'floridas-pensions-could-be-reformed-locally'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', [OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'defined-benefit-plans'), ('#text', 'defined benefit plans')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'defined-contribution-plans'), ('#text', 'defined contribution plans')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'department-of-management-services'), ('#text', 'Department of Management Services')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'fiscal-policy'), ('#text', 'Fiscal Policy')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'florida'), ('#text', 'Florida')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'florida-retirement-system'), ('#text', 'Florida Retirement System')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'frs'), ('#text', 'FRS')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'municipal-pensions'), ('#text', 'municipal pensions')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'pensions'), ('#text', 'pensions')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'politics-2'), ('#text', 'Politics')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'public-pensions'), ('#text', 'public pensions')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'public-spending'), ('#text', 'public spending')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'reform'), ('#text', 'reform')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'tax-policy'), ('#text', 'tax policy')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'tax-policy-2'), ('#text', 'Tax Policy')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'unfunded-pension-liabilities'), ('#text', 'unfunded pension liabilities')])]), ('wp:postmeta', [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_publicize_pending'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_published'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_client_id'), ('wp:meta_value', '-1')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', 'Depopulation of Citizens Property Insurance Should Continue'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2015/03/05/depopulation-of-citizens-property-insurance-should-continue/'), ('pubDate', 'Thu, 05 Mar 2015 05:00:00 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=242')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', '<p class="p1">By Matt Kelly</p>\n<p class="p1"><a href="http://www.myafchome.org/state-capital-briefs--wednesday--february-18--2015" target="_blank">On February 17th, 2015, Florida state Senator Anitere Flores filed SB 1006</a>, which would place restrictions on shifting insurance policies from state-backed <a href="https://www.citizensfla.com/" target="_blank">Citizens Property Insurance Corporation</a> to private sector insurers. Citizens’ policyholders would be notified before being transferred to private insurers, who would be barred from increasing premiums more than 10% annually for three years. Most importantly, <a href="http://www.flsenate.gov/Session/Bill/2015/1006/BillText/Filed/HTML" target="_blank">SB 1006</a> would require written consent from policyholders before their policies could be transferred. Though intended to protect Citizens\' customers, legislators will ultimately need to decide the best course for the state as a whole. This policy change could delay productive reform and expose Floridians to undue risk.<!--more--></p>\n<p class="p1"><a href="https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/2015/02/17/187/" target="_blank">Citizens Property Insurance Corporation has the advantage of being able to exact assessments from insurance companies of nearly every kind throughout Florida.</a> Yet Citizens was actuarially unsound until only recently, requiring policyholders across the state to cover its deficits. Even with the company’s current surplus of $7.5 billion, a one-in-one-hundred year storm could deplete this reserve and require an additional $1.69 billion in emergency assessments to cover losses.</p>\n<p class="p1">Citizens functions to shift the risk of natural disasters from private property owners to the general public. Such socialization of risk is problematic for several reasons. Foisting higher premiums on low-risk customers in order to make up for the artificially low premiums of high-risk customers creates what economists call an <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adverse_selection" target="_blank">“adverse selection” problem</a>: higher risk customers will opt into the system in order to transfer financial risk to the low-risk policyholders \xa0The imbalance among policyholders’ risk levels then leads low-risk policyholders to exit the market and go uninsured, while attracting ever more high-risk customers.</p>\n<p class="p1"><a href="http://opim.wharton.upenn.edu/risk/library/WRCib2013a_Insurance+BehavioralEconomics.pdf" target="_blank">A 2013 policy brief from the University of Pennsylvania</a> makes clear that even without adverse selection problems, behavioral biases plague the hurricane and flood insurance industry. Consumers often underestimate the impact of low-probability, high-impact events, such as one-in-one hundred year hurricanes, making it difficult for insurance companies to price policies.</p>\n<p class="p1">By failing to reflect a property’s true risk level, Citizens sends misleading market signals to policyholders. <a href="http://www.independent.org/pdf/tir/tir_13_02_2_pompe.pdf" target="_blank">Policy analysts Jeffrey Pompe and James Rinehart from the Independent Institute have pointed out that failing to reflect true risks in insurance policies also creates a moral hazard.</a> “Government involvement in property insurance has encouraged coastal development in hazardous areas, which is responsible, in part, for increased damage costs from storms.”</p>\n<p class="p1"><a href="http://www.insurancejournal.com/magazines/features/2015/01/12/353223.htm" target="_blank">Lawmakers and company managers have done much to improve this situation by reducing Citizens’ portfolio from 1.5 million policyholders in November 2007 to its current level of 727,000, lowering the risk to Florida taxpayers.</a> This has brought Citizens’ loss exposure down from $511 billion to $229 billion. State regulators recently announced they will soon allow private insurers to assume another 132,440 policies.</p>\n<p class="p1"><a href="http://www.consumeraffairs.com/insurance/citizens_property_insurance_corp.html" target="_blank">Citizens has received criticism from former customers in the process</a>, many of whom say they were saddled with expensive premiums without warning. These complaints are understandable: Given Citizens’ artificially low rates, who would want to cancel their insurance policy with them? But these artificially low rates encourage risky behavior and are supported at the expense of other lower risk policyholders in the state.</p>\n<p class="p3">Giving notice to customers is fair, but allowing Citizens’ policyholders to remain with the state-run insurer and retain these artificially low premiums would be unfair to the other policyholders in Florida who effectively subsidize them. A better policy strategy would be to allow Citizens to charge actuarially fair premiums that reflect a policyholder’s true risk, ultimately balancing the property market through more transparent pricing.</p>'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '242'), ('wp:post_date', '2015-03-05 05:00:00'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2015-03-05 05:00:00'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), Legislators Seek To Clarify Ridesharing Regulations'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2015/03/24/florida-legislators-seek-to-clarify-ridesharing-regulations/'), ('pubDate', 'Tue, 24 Mar 2015 11:00:00 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=249')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'By Matt Kelly\n\nThe ridesharing technology company Uber has created quite a controversy overthe past year for its unprecedented disruption of the traditional taxi industry. Users praise the California-based company for shorter wait times and cheap fares, along with features like its driver rating system. Given the mobile app’s popularity with customers, many are now questioning the merits of local and state regulations, which continue to inhibit existing taxi companies. <a href="http://tbo.com/news/politics/uber-lyft-and-other-car-services-may-get-help-from-lawmakers-20150308/">Florida is currently considering reforms</a> to address commercial insurance mandates and automobile safety standards while easing fare regulations and permitting.<!--more-->\n\nFlorida state Sen. Jeff Brandes recently filed <a href="http://www.flsenate.gov/Session/Bill/2015/1326">SB 1326</a>, which would regulate Uber and Lyft not as taxis or limousines but as newly classified Technology Network Companies (TNCs). TNC drivers would need to purchase commercial automobile liability insurance to operate, and be barred from accepting street hails. Another bill, <a href="http://flhouse.gov/Sections/Bills/billsdetail.aspx?BillId=53919">HB 817</a>, filed by Rep. Matt Gaetz, goes further and would transfer regulatory authority from county and local governments to the state. The state would then decide how best to streamline the permitting process.\n\nBut as lawmakers ponder ways to police safety, <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/01/31/technology/companies-are-rating-customers.html">Uber itself has already devised a mechanism to the same effect: ratings</a>. After using Uber, passengers signal the quality of their experience to future users by giving their driver a 1-5 score. Drivers likewise rate passengers with a score that other drivers can consider before picking them up in the future. In most areas, Uber does not allow drivers with an average rating below 4.6 to work for them. These rating systems give both parties an avenue for feedback, improving service and safety.\n\nGiven Uber’s success in the absence of strict safety laws, the case for regulation of the taxi industry looks weaker now than in past years. However, automobile insurance requirements continue to gain political traction and are provided in both SB 1326 and HB 817.\n\nThe bills differ as to what level of insurance coverage should be required. <a href="http://www.mypalmbeachpost.com/news/news/ubers-florida-fight-whose-insurance-pays-and-when/nkWSg/#83c5c3ea.2631545.735681">Should coverage extend to times when drivers haven’t picked anyone up, or apply only when passengers are present?</a> While Sen. Brandes’ bill would require commercial insurance policies to cover accidents occurring anytime a driver is logged into the Uber mobile application, Rep. Gaetz’s bill would mandate coverage only when drivers have accepted passengers. Insurance costs will impact fares as well as driver wages, and are thus relevant to both drivers and customers.\n\nA number of other regulations besides pricing and safety requirements also impact taxis, and could be streamlined. For instance, research conducted at the DeVoe Moore Center suggests that having a company permitting process increases market concentration in an area’s taxi industry. Higher market concentration tends to limit supply, often resulting in longer wait times and higher fares where fares aren’t fixed by regulators. Rep. Gaetz\'s bill, which would turn over local and county permitting authority to the state, could potentially simplify this process and allow ridesharing services to better meet demand.\n\nRegardless of what regulatory regime eventually emerges from this debate, the hostility among taxi companies, drivers, regulators, and market disruptors like Uber can\'t continue for long. Officials in Broward County have ticketed over 250 Uber drivers for operating illegally, while traditional taxi companies’ drivers have staged occasional protests in Miami and Ft. Lauderdale. Yet Uber has created over 10,000 new jobs in South Florida alone. Every stakeholder in this issue needs a legislative solution to provide clarity in order to ease these tensions.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '249'), ('wp:post_date', '2015-03-24 11:00:00'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2015-03-24 11:00:00'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'florida-legislators-seek-to-clarify-ridesharing-regulations'), Learn about Emerging Sharing Economy'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2015/04/08/fsu-students-learn-about-emerging-sharing-economy/'), ('pubDate', 'Wed, 08 Apr 2015 17:56:24 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=256')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'By Katie Dawson\n\nLast month, the <a href="http://coss.fsu.edu/dmc/" target="_blank">DeVoe L. Moore Center</a> had the opportunity to \xa0co-sponsor a one-day conference with the <a href="http://fee.org/" target="_blank">Foundation for Economic Education (FEE)</a> at Florida State University. FEE is an organization dedicated to educating individuals on free-markets and economics in a way that is both easily digestible and interesting. On February 28, their staff took the stage to present on, “How the Sharing Economy is Changing the World.”<!--more-->\n\nThe day started off with a presentation from FEE distinguished fellow <a href="http://www.jeffreytucker.me/" target="_blank">Jeffrey Tucker</a>, an insightful beginning. Tucker spoke about how the rising peer-to-peer economy is quickly becoming a staple in our everyday lives. <a href="http://www.its.caltech.edu/~nsulliva/personal.html" target="_blank">Nikki Sullivan</a> followed Tucker with a captivating talk on how neuroscience and economics intertwine to help explain human behavior. \xa0Sullivan explained that the way humans behave and react to their environment has a lot to do with the emergence of markets in mankind’s early history.\n\nFollowing a lunch break, <a href="https://www.fee.org/people/detail/lawrence-w-reed" target="_blank">Lawrence Reed</a>, President of FEE, gave students some insight on why <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Free_trade" target="_blank">free trade</a> is the optimal way to both improve relationships with other countries and to improve the domestic economy. He also discussed how free trade’s outcomes differ from protectionism and results in higher welfare for both producers and consumers in the long run.\n\nStudents then had the chance to participate in a group activity meant to improve their entrepreneurial skills. Attendees broke into teams to discuss business ideas, and after some time, the best ideas were chosen and presented to a panel of entrepreneurs. The simulation was in the style of the television show, <a href="http://www.cnbcprime.com/shark-tank/" target="_blank">“Shark Tank,”</a> where budding entrepreneurs present their business plans with the hopes of receiving funding from distinguished professionals. This gave students the opportunity to work on their business “pitches” in a fun and challenging way.\n\nThe conference came to a conclusion with <a href="http://fee.org/people/detail/max-borders" target="_blank">Max Borders</a> and his presentation on the power of \xa0entrepreneurship to create value in a world of growing uncertainty. His message was empowering. He spurred the young individuals in the audience to take advantage of the sharing economy as an entrepreneurial tool. He stated that this would better both themselves and \xa0the world at large.\n\nOver 120 students attended the conference, and with engaging speakers and a wealth of encouragement, it was a huge success for those present. It was hard not to feel optimistic about the future as speakers and attendees passionately discussed the potential benefits of the sharing economy.\n\nA social took place after the lectures, where attendees had the opportunity to engage with the speakers and share their thoughts about the day. Students were able to convey their opinions and ideas to some of the brightest intellectuals that free-market economics has to offer. The overall sentiment was very positive, and \xa0members of FEE shared their enthusiasm about future events at Florida State.\n\nThe DeVoe Moore Center was delighted to have been a part of the conference’s success and hopes to see more educational experiences like this taking place for FSU’s students. Entrepreneurship and peer-to-peer technology \xa0continues to \xa0empower Millennials, and with the technological progress that has occurred in just the past few years, it seems the best is yet to come!'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '256'), ('wp:post_date', '2015-04-08 17:56:24'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2015-04-08 17:56:24'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2015/04/21/growlers-ban-likely-to-end/'), ('pubDate', 'Tue, 21 Apr 2015 16:41:45 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=258')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'By Matt Kelly\n\nThis legislative session, Florida lawmakers are considering <a href="https://www.flsenate.gov/Session/Bill/2015/0186" target="_blank">reforms that would revamp many of the state’s regulations on alcohol</a>. A measure to legalize a popular beer container size, the 64 oz. <a href="http://growler-station.com/growler/" target="_blank">growler</a>, has sparked a debate over the larger issue of the three-tier beer regulation system. Powerful special interests have complicated every step in the process, with distributors and craft brewers battling it out to secure an advantage. As the leading sector of the beer industry, craft beer should be allowed to prosper without regulatory restrictions. Recent developments in the legislature indicate that craft beer is indeed winning the battle.<!--more-->\n\n<a href="http://www.brewersassociation.org/statistics/economic-impact-data/" target="_blank">Specialty breweries have revitalized the beer industry </a>and provided customers with far greater choice. While overall beer sales fell 1.9% nationally last year, craft beer sales grew 17.2%. Apparently, customers like the variety that craft beer affords, and are voting with their wallets.\n\n<a href="http://www.brewersassociation.org/statistics/by-state/" target="_blank">The overall economic impact of Florida’s craft beer industry is still small compared to that of Oregon, Colorado, and California</a>, where hundreds of craft brewers produce millions of barrels annually. Yet recent growth has been significant. <a href="http://www.fred.ifas.ufl.edu/economic-impact-analysis/pdf/Craft_Brewing_FL_2014.pdf" target="_blank">A 2014 study by economist Timothy Taylor and his colleagues at the University of Florida</a> found that the number of craft breweries in Florida expanded from just six to more than 50 between 2007 and 2013. The authors say the industry’s potential is still greater. They project a statewide capacity of 550 microbreweries in coming years, generating $2.5 billion in sales revenue and as many as 40,000 jobs.\n\nAn important catalyst to the national rise of craft beer has been the relaxation of the three-tier regulatory system of beer regulation. Many states have established a self-distribution exemption for small brewers who produce less than a certain volume annually. Rep. Greg Steube, R-Sarasota has said that Florida’s uncompetitive regulations are largely responsible for the lag in economic impact.\n\nAmbiguities with the state’s allowance for breweries to sell their beer on their premises in <a href="http://brewerlong.com/license-your-brews/" target="_blank">“taprooms”</a> instigated a lawsuit earlier this year. <a href="http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/10/29/us-usa-florida-beer-idUSKBN0II2IV20141029" target="_blank">Distributors and retailers intended to shut down these brewery-operated taprooms, but the case was later dropped.</a>\n\nFlorida’s ban on the growler, however, has been the chief hindrance to craft beer’s growth. <a href="http://www.leg.state.fl.us/Statutes/index.cfm?App_mode=Display_Statute&amp;Search_String=&amp;URL=0500-0599/0563/Sections/0563.06.html" target="_blank">Any alcoholic beverage container size up to 32 ounces and more than 128 ounces is permissible, but increments in between are strictly outlawed.</a> Sellers can be slapped with a second-degree misdemeanor for violating this requirement.\n\nBut why is the growler so important to craft beer? Bottling and canning can be prohibitively expensive for small brewers, so the use of refillable 64 oz. growlers has allowed them to avoid this added marginal cost. <a href="http://www.brewersassociation.org/author/bart-watson/" target="_blank">Bart Watson</a>, an economist with the Brewers Association, has said <a href="http://www.tampabay.com/news/politics/stateroundup/floridas-craft-beer-industry-poised-to-win-long-sought-changes/2219434" target="_blank">the cost-effective container has been essential to craft beer’s explosion in popularity.</a>\n\nOutlawing this popular container size in Florida has hindered a fledgling industry that’s flourishing across the country. However, the Florida legislature could soon change that. Senator Latvala’s (R- Clearwater) bill, SB 186, which would legalize growlers and clarify the rules on taprooms in the state, has passed the Senate and awaits a vote in the House.\n\nIf Florida wants to be a business-friendly state, it should have policies that make it easier for entrepreneurs to innovate and serve their customers. Ending the growler ban would do just that, paving the way for further economic growth in craft beer.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '258'), ('wp:post_date', '2015-04-21 16:41:45'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2015-04-21 16:41:45'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'growlers-ban-likely-to-end'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', distributors')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'beer-regulation'), ('#text', 'beer regulation')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'craft-beer'), ('#text', 'Florida')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'growler-ban'), ('#text', 'growler ban')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'growlers'), ('#text', 'growlers')]), 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2015/05/04/business-incubator-helps-spur-student-entrepreneurs/'), ('pubDate', 'Mon, 04 May 2015 17:20:24 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=268')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', '<a href="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2015/05/domi-get-together.jpeg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-269" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2015/05/domi-get-together.jpeg?w=300" alt="domi get together" width="300" height="199" /></a><a href="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2015/05/domi_logo.png"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-270" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2015/05/domi_logo.png" alt="Domi_logo" width="253" height="199" /></a>\n\nBy Joanna Douglas\n\nFlorida State University students with a passion for social change are benefiting from partnerships beyond the campus to inspire their ideas for start-ups that address pressing social issues. The Tallahassee-based business incubator <a href="http://www.domistation.com/" target="_blank">Domi Station</a> continued its support of the university’s <a href="http://socent.fsu.edu/" target="_blank">Social Entrepreneurship and Innovation Initiative</a> with a special opportunity for students to practice their pitch skills during a simulated “shark-tank” style event at the company’s headquarters.<!--more-->\n\nStudents in the Social Entrepreneurship and Economic Development course at FSU’s <a href="http://coss.fsu.edu/dmc/" target="_blank">DeVoe L. Moore Center</a>toured Domi Station, April 24, 2015. Three budding entrepreneurs were chosen by their classmates to pitch their ideas for viable social enterprises that would help solve critical problems through sustainable revenue streams.\n\nDaniel Boyle, a senior in economics and literature, pitched Fluid, a proposed corporation to raise awareness of Florida’s water depletion crisis by offering unique and trendy apparel with creative designs inspired by cave system maps and aquifer level charts. Profits would be directed towards such existing projects as the city of Clearwater’s efforts in groundwater replenishment. Boyle said his enterprise would partner with the city, relevant nonprofits, and Florida-based designers to develop Fluid.\n\nGabriela Fulginiti, a junior in international affairs and art with an entrepreneurship minor, pitched Kitabé for Kids, which will create an online platform for private donors to purchase books online for direct shipment to schools in India with diminished resources. Fulginiti plans to partner with the Amazon Affiliates program to generate revenue from all purchases made through the Kitabé portal. She plans to begin developing a pilot project this summer during her third trip to India.\n\nKamila Toska, a junior in economics, pitched Social Cue, a business-to-nonprofit marketing consulting and design company. Marketing consultants would use the innovative Social Cue database to identify potential mutually beneficial partnerships, such as those between the clothing company Patagonia and its many nonprofit partners or Pilot Pen and Keep America Beautiful. Toska described her potential market as nonprofits looking to scale outreach and impact, as well as businesses looking to add corporate social responsibility to their overall business model.\n\nThe students made their pitches to Domi Station Co-founder-Partner David Lawson, Incubator Manager Christine Urban, and Community Manager Lucas Lindsay, a recent graduate of FSU’s Department of Urban and Regional Planning. The Domi reps gave the three students vital feedback on their development ideas with an eye to creating sustainable business plans.\n\nSince its grand opening last year, Domi Station has co-sponsored student events such as <a href="http://hackfsu.com/" target="_blank">Hackathon</a>, which brings together software and hardware engineers, designers, and students to create team projects from scratch, and <a href="http://digitech.fsu.edu/2015/" target="_blank">Digitech</a>, an FSU event featuring innovative student exhibits and tech start-up presentations. Domi also hosts the weekly <a href="http://www.1millioncups.com/" target="_blank">1 Million Cups</a> meeting of Tallahassee entrepreneurs, which welcomes FSU student pitches, and maintains work space in their headquarters specifically for FSU students.\n\nThe Social Entrepreneurship and Economic Development course is designed for upperclassmen to think critically about social issues and develop business plans for viable social enterprises. DeVoe Moore Center Director Sam Staley and Project Manager Joanna Douglas co-instruct the class through group dialogues, interactive workshops, guest speakers, and site visits. The class fulfills an elective requirement for the <a target="_blank">social entrepreneurship and innovation specialization</a> within the interdisciplinary social sciences (ISS) program in the College of Social Sciences and Public Policy.\n\nIn fall 2014, Eddie Sepe used the course to pursue his passion for starting an urban farm that supports community development projects. Since graduating, Sepe has teamed up with Tallahassee Aquaponics and is currently assisting the development of educational programs for local schools in Leon County.\n\n“I can\'t stress enough how much I appreciate the insightful advice about a whole new way to do business,” Sepe said about the course. “Sam Staley definitely kept me motivated and inspired to do my best this semester. It means a lot having so much support from genuine and caring teachers who I feel are truly making a huge difference at Florida State.”\n\nThanks to innovative classroom instruction and partnerships with ventures such as Domi Station, Florida State students are becoming part of the rapidly growing social entrepreneurship and innovation ecosystem around campus and across the globe.'), None), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '270'), ('wp:post_date', '2015-05-04 17:20:17'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2015-05-04 17:20:17'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'a:5:{s:5:"width";i:253;s:6:"height";i:199;s:4:"file";s:85:"/home/wpcom/public_html/wp-content/blogs.dir/848/80998613/files/2015/05/domi_logo.png";s:5:"sizes";a:0:{}s:10:"image_meta";a:11:{s:8:"aperture";i:0;s:6:"credit";s:0:"";s:6:"camera";s:0:"";s:7:"caption";s:0:"";s:17:"created_timestamp";i:0;s:9:"copyright";s:0:"";s:12:"focal_length";i:0;s:3:"iso";i:0;s:13:"shutter_speed";i:0;s:5:"title";s:0:"";s:11:"orientation";i:0;}}')]), All Aboard for Intercity Railroads?'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2015/05/07/is-florida-all-aboard-for-intercity-railroads/'), ('pubDate', 'Thu, 07 May 2015 17:43:01 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=272')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'By Matt Kelly\n\nA battle over railroads is underway in the Sunshine State. Activists in Florida have stridently protested<a href="http://www.allaboardflorida.com/"> All Aboard Florida (AAF)</a>, which will launch the United State’s first privately funded and operated intercity rail service in over 50 years. AAF’s opponents strongly doubts the enterprise’s financial viability.<a href="http://object.cato.org/sites/cato.org/files/pubs/pdf/pa663.pdf"> Generally, rail services across the country do often have a negative return on investment and most around the world struggle to break even</a>. However, there is reason to think that a private firm could operate more efficiently.<!--more-->\n\nFlorida TaxWatch, a policy research center based in Tallahassee, has noted that Florida is growing much faster than the rest of the country,<a href="http://floridataxwatch.org/resources/pdf/May14ECFINAL.pdf"> putting stress on existing infrastructure</a>. Alternative forms of transportation are being pursued to reduce congestion and improve amenities.\n\nAll Aboard Florida is owned by Florida East Coast Industries, which was founded in 1892 by railroad entrepreneur<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_Flagler"> Henry Flagler</a>. By 1896, Flagler’s East Coast Railway connected Miami with the northeast United States. Since then, passenger trains have become less profitable, and today most are government sponsored enterprises or public-private partnerships. However, Florida East Coast Industries has bet billions of dollars that an intercity rail service between Miami and Orlando could be profitable for years to come.\n\n<a href="http://www.floridanotallaboard.net/">An organization called CARE FL has been AAF’s most vocal opponent</a>, arguing the project will bring noise and traffic to communities along its path. Some of these worries are unfounded. Chugging along at 90 mph, AAF’s light train cars can clear railroad crossings much faster and quieter than the freight trains that currently traverse the same route.\n\nAAF’s financial sustainability remains a more legitimate concern. A study commissioned by CARE FL and written by Dr. John Friedman of Brown University, concludes, “Miami and Orlando are not cities with characteristics in which passenger trains can thrive.” Friedman predicts that AAF will lose over $100 million annually and fail to pay back its creditors.\n\nHowever, some question the study’s conclusions and methodology.<a href="http://reason.org/news/show/surface-transportation-news-137#c"> The Reason Foundation has challenged Friedman’s revenue estimates</a>, since they are based on overly pessimistic assumptions concerning ridership. By contrast, AAF’s own analysis “reflects a far more detailed assessment of demand...” Since it’s AAF’s money on the line, it makes sense that its analysis would be more rigorous\n\nFriedman also claims “AAF will receive $50 to $73 million of subsidies annually.” However, that conclusion depends on one’s definition of “subsidy.” Florida’s taxpayers are indeed providing a loan to be paid back with interest, but not a direct subsidy as Friedman suggests. He also says the $1.75 billion in tax-exempt bonds that AAF may issue are a subsidy, yet such financing is the norm for transportation investments, public and private, and amounts to foregone tax revenue rather than actual spending.\n\nFlorida East Coast rail enterprise may indeed be unprofitable as Friedman suggests. Only time will tell. Unlike the many publicly operated railways around the U.S., however, AAF’s losses would be limited to its shareholders. Public transportation enterprises can afford to incur financial losses, since taxpayers cover any gaps between revenues and expenses. With skin in the game, All Aboard Florida is more likely to be financially sustainable than its publicly run counterparts, and Florida’s taxpayers need not worry about absorbing potential losses of this privately funded company.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '272'), ('wp:post_date', '2015-05-07 17:43:01'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2015-05-07 17:43:01'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'is-florida-all-aboard-for-intercity-railroads'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'uncategorized'), ('#text', 'Uncategorized')])), ('wp:postmeta', [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_publicize_pending'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_published'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_client_id'), ('wp:meta_value', '-1')])]), ('wp:comment', OrderedDict([('wp:comment_id', '12'), ('wp:comment_author', 'Longhammer'), ('wp:comment_author_email', 'Mattkelly9@cfl.rr.com'), ('wp:comment_author_url', None), ('wp:comment_author_IP', '166.172.186.114'), ('wp:comment_date', '2015-05-09 17:17:06'), ('wp:comment_date_gmt', '2015-05-09 17:17:06'), ('wp:comment_content', "California's high speed rail Project puts taxpayers at risk. AAF does not. While there are certainly public accommodations being made for AAF, The main driver is a private enterprise that's serving a consumer need, creating jobs and making a profit. Sounds like a good idea!"), ('wp:comment_approved', '1'), ('wp:comment_type', None), ('wp:comment_parent', '0'), ('wp:comment_user_id', '0'), ('wp:commentmeta', [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', 'email_notification_notqueued'), ('wp:meta_value', '1431637770')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', 'jabber_published'), ('wp:meta_value', '1431637770')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', 'akismet_history'), ('wp:meta_value', 'a:2:{s:4:"time";d:1431196854.0882470607757568359375;s:5:"event";s:9:"check-ham";}')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', 'akismet_history'), ('wp:meta_value', 'a:3:{s:4:"time";d:1431637771.0341370105743408203125;s:5:"event";s:15:"status-approved";s:4:"user";s:16:"devoemoorecenter";}')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', 'akismet_result'), ('wp:meta_value', 'false')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', 'akismet_history'), ('wp:meta_value', 'a:2:{s:4:"time";d:1431191826.7160129547119140625;s:5:"event";s:9:"check-ham";}')])])]))]), OrderedDict([('title', 'Pricing Water in Florida'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2015/05/12/pricing-water-in-florida/'), ('pubDate', 'Tue, 12 May 2015 18:34:07 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=276')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'By Tyler Worthington\n\nAs Florida’s population grows it will have to address a multitude of new problems, including stress on water supplies. States like California have experienced severe water shortages in recent years, and mismanagement has exacerbated this problem. Because California does not accurately price water, it has been misallocated. In Florida, The Turkey Point Nuclear Power Plant is another case study in how the lack of a pricing mechanism can deplete and misallocate resources.<!--more-->\n\nThe Turkey Point Power Plant consists of two nuclear reactors, and is managed by Florida Power and Light (FPL). Unlike most nuclear power plants in the United States, Turkey Point does not have cooling towers. Instead it utilizes the <a href="https://www.fpl.com/clean-energy/nuclear/turkey-point-faq.html">Cooling Canal System (CCS)</a>, a 168 mile network of 36 canals used to cool the water for plant operations.\n\n<a href="http://www.miamiherald.com/news/local/community/miami-dade/article7053941.html">Last Summer</a>, this system had trouble maintaining the federally mandated canal temperatures. FPL filed an emergency request to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to allow the cooling system to exceed the 100 degree limit. In order to cool down the canals, <a href="http://www.miamiherald.com/news/local/environment/article10655732.html">FPL filed another emergency request to the South Florida Water Management District (SFWMD) to draw 100 million gallons of additional water from nearby sources.</a>\n\nHowever, Turkey Point Nuclear Power Plant is not the only large user of water in Florida. <a href="http://www.miamiherald.com/news/local/environment/article9924155.html">Attempts to revive the Biscayne Bay in Miami and restore the Everglades National Park also require many million gallons of water</a>. There is simply not enough to accomplish all three tasks.\n\nBut who decides how to allocate water among these projects? Currently, 5 water management districts throughout the state control Florida’s water supply. To draw large amounts of water, <a href="http://www.sfwmd.gov/portal/page/portal/xweb%20-%20release%202/water%20use%20permits">users must purchase a permit to use water as a public good</a>. After the permit is granted there is no per unit price of the water.\n\nThis lack of a proper pricing mechanism can make resources prone to depletion. Florida Agriculture Commissioner Adam Putnam has said that property rights and pricing are key to getting water policy right. The more that water is treated like a social good, the more problems arise, and <a href="http://proprights.com/archives/1182">“privately owned land is always better managed and more productive than publicly owned land.”</a>\n\n<a href="http://voices.nationalgeographic.com/2012/08/29/the-high-costs-of-free-water/">An article </a>by Brian Ritcher, Chief Scientist for the Global Water Program of The Nature Conservancy, explains the consequences of cheap water. “The costs of cheap water are far too high. It has allowed for severe dewatering of the planet’s <a href="http://environment.nationalgeographic.com/environment/freshwater/">freshwater</a> sources and caused <a href="http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2012/05/120531-groundwater-depletion-may-accelerate-sea-level-rise/?utm_source=feedburner&amp;utm_medium=feed&amp;utm_campaign=Feed%253A+ng%252FNews%252FNews_Water+%2528National+Geographic+News+-+News+Water%2529">sea level rise to accelerate</a>...Water shortages have pushed millions of hectares of <a href="http://www.unep.org/dewa/giwa/publications/finalreport/freshwater_shortage.pdf">farms out of production</a>.” These hidden costs are not factored into the permit price for large users like FPL.\n\nCharging a per unit price for water could ensure that water is efficiently allocated and not depleted. If water is accurately priced, then the price will rise as it becomes more scarce. As prices rise, consumers are incentivized to conserve supply and replenish the resource. A National Bureau of Economic Research paper by Sheila M. Olmstead and Robert N. Stavins notes that \xa0“<a href="http://www.nber.org/papers/w14147">Using prices to manage water demand is more cost-effective than implementing non-price conservation programs.”</a>\n\nWithout water pricing Floridians risk experiencing the shortages and rationing seen in California, but establishing a price system for water would ensure abundance for years to come.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '276'), ('wp:post_date', '2015-05-12 18:34:07'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2015-05-12 18:34:07'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'pricing-water-in-florida'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', [OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'adam-putnam'), ('#text', 'Adam Putnam')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'biscayne-bay'), ('#text', 'Biscayne Bay')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'climate-change'), ('#text', 'climate change')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'energy'), ('#text', 'Energy')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'everglades'), ('#text', 'Everglades')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'land-use'), ('#text', 'Land Use')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'miami'), ('#text', 'Miami')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'nuclear-power'), ('#text', 'nuclear power')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'private-property'), ('#text', 'private property')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'regulation-2'), ('#text', 'Regulation')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'south-florida-water-management-district'), ('#text', 'South Florida Water Management District')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'turkey-point'), ('#text', 'turkey point')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'turkey-point-nuclear-power-plant'), ('#text', 'turkey point nuclear power plant')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'urban-development'), ('#text', 'Urban Development')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'utilities'), ('#text', 'utilities')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'water'), ('#text', 'water')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'water-pricing'), ('#text', 'water pricing')])]), ('wp:postmeta', [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_publicize_pending'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_published'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_client_id'), ('wp:meta_value', '-1')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', 'Florida Risks Government Shutdown'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2015/05/21/florida-risks-government-shutdown/'), ('pubDate', 'Thu, 21 May 2015 18:44:36 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=278')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'Florida’s legislature failed to pass a budget in this years legislative session. The House and Senate are opposed on major issues related to health care policy and medicaid expansion. <a href="http://blog.independent.org/2015/05/05/floridas-financial-health-care-follies-and-a-problem-with-a-part-time-legislature/">Interested readers will want to visit the Beacon, the blog at The Independent Institute’s website, where DeVoe Moore Scholar Dr. Randall Holcombe posted a blog on the ongoing budgetary crisis.</a> Florida’s legislature is set to reconvene for a special three-week session beginning June 1st. Also on the agenda is a discussion on how to spend money apportioned for the maintenance and preservation water and environmentally important land set aside for preservation under the voter-approved Amendment 1. However, if legislators fail to pass a budget, that could mean a <a href="http://www.tampabay.com/news/politics/stateroundup/florida-senate-and-house-agree-to-scope-of-special-session/2229886">state “government shutdown”.</a>'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '278'), ('wp:post_date', '2015-05-21 18:44:36'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2015-05-21 18:44:36'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'florida-risks-government-shutdown'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'uncategorized'), ('#text', 'Uncategorized')])), ('wp:postmeta', [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_publicize_pending'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_published'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_client_id'), ('wp:meta_value', '-1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_publicize_job_id'), ('wp:meta_value', '10861385546')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', "New Study Sheds Light on Ridesharing's Labor Market"), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2015/05/27/new-study-sheds-light-on-ridesharings-labor-market/'), ('pubDate', 'Wed, 27 May 2015 17:29:32 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=280')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'By Matt Kelly\n\nFew economic issues have been more talked about this year than the<a href="http://www.miamiherald.com/news/business/article21599697.html"> disruptive forays into the taxi market</a> by ridesharing technology companies like Uber and Lyft. It seems reasonable to assume ridesharing drivers are of the same ilk as traditional taxi drivers, yet little academic research has been done...until now.<a href="https://s3.amazonaws.com/uber-static/comms/PDF/Uber_Driver-Partners_Hall_Kreuger_2015.pdf"> A recent analysis comparing taxi and Uber drivers by Uber’s head of policy research Jonathan Hall and Princeton University professor Alan Krueger sheds light on these differences and the future of work in the “sharing economy.”</a><!--more-->\n\nThe December 2014 survey of Uber drivers had 601 respondents. The results were compared with<a href="http://www.bls.gov/ooh/transportation-and-material-moving/taxi-drivers-and-chauffeurs.htm"> separate survey data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics on taxi and chauffeur drivers.</a> The authors found that, compared to taxi drivers, Uber’s driver-partners are typically younger (half are under 40 years old versus 28% of taxi drivers) and have more education (37% have college degrees while the figure is 15% for taxi drivers). While both Uber and the broader taxi industry employ women at levels below the labor market average of 47%, Uber’s driver-partners are more likely to be women than are taxi drivers. Uber drivers are mostly non-white, but less so than traditional taxi drivers. Uber’s driver-partners are also slightly more likely to have children at home, be attending school, and be military veterans. About half of Uber’s driver-partners worked in transportation services previously.\n\nA key reason that drivers partnered with Uber was the greater flexibility it affords. Eighty-five percent reported their main reason for partnering with Uber was “to have more flexibility in my schedule and balance my work with my life and family.” Most driver-partners work as independent contractors, a labor category that has long valued the ability to work when they want to.\n\nEighty percent of Uber driver-partners had full- or part-time jobs before joining, and only 8% said they had been unemployed just prior to joining, suggesting Uber serves in large part to supplement income and to ease the transition between jobs. Yet many drive full time with Uber, with 38% of respondents saying it is their only job. Thirty-six percent of driver-partners weren’t actively looking for a job before partnering, which the authors say “suggests that Uber provided a new alternative that enticed a large number of people to engage in work activity that was not previously available.”\n\nThe study also points out that Uber attracts higher quality drivers who seek to earn more income based on the reputation they can build through Uber’s rating system.\n\nMany commentators, such as former economic advisor to Presidents Clinton and Obama<a href="https://www.americanprogress.org/issues/economy/report/2015/01/15/104266/report-of-the-commission-on-inclusive-prosperity/"> Larry Summers, have hypothesized that the sharing economy is linked with economic inequality.</a> However, Hall and Krueger contend, “...an objective look at the data reveals little evidence that a rise in contingent or alternative work arrangements has played an important role in driving these momentous labor market shifts.”\n\nUber’s exponential growth is worth noting. Florida cities like Miami and Orlando are among Uber’s highest growth areas. Flexibility is key for these workers, and Uber has opened up alternatives not found in the traditional job market. Overall, Hall and Krueger suggest Uber’s driver-partners, and the emerging sharing economy in general, are less revolutionary than popularly thought, but they represent definite gains in welfare for workers and consumers.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '280'), ('wp:post_date', '2015-05-27 17:29:32'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2015-05-27 17:29:32'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', [OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'bls'), ('#text', 'BLS')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'bureau-of-labor-statistics'), ('#text', 'Bureau of Labor Statistics')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'business'), ('#text', 'business')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'economics'), ('#text', 'economics')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'flexibility'), ('#text', 'flexibility')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'income'), ('#text', 'income')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'inequality'), ('#text', 'inequality')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'job-market'), ('#text', 'job market')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'labor'), ('#text', 'labor')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'labor-economics'), ('#text', 'Labor Economics')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'labor-market'), ('#text', 'labor market')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'lyft'), ('#text', 'lyft')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'regulation'), ('#text', 'regulation')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'ridesharing'), ('#text', 'ridesharing')]), '11069273092')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', 'Solar Farm Proposed In Tallahassee'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2015/06/02/solar-farm-proposed-in-tallahassee/'), ('pubDate', 'Tue, 02 Jun 2015 14:38:01 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=284')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'By Logan Shewmaker\n\n<a href="http://www.tallahassee.com/story/news/local/2015/03/23/tallahassee-prepares-add-solar-power-portfolio/70338948/">City of Tallahassee Utilities officials recently received proposals from solar contractors to build a solar farm</a>, which could produce up to 10 megawatts of electricity (1% of Tallahassee’s energy needs). The project is expected to occupy 100 acres of land, and cost roughly $30 million. David Byrne, manager of electric system integrated planning for the city, has said the solar farm’s purposes would be to diversify fuel use for long-term cost stability, and forward the city’s “effort toward environmental stewardship.” There are numerous benefits to solar power, but the costs greatly outweigh the benefits for now.<!--more-->\n\nThe proposal would create a purchasing agreement with a third-party company. The city would pay for the generated electricity, and the company would build and manage the solar farm. Customers would continue to direct their utility bills to the city.\n\nCity officials also hope a federal tax credit will incentivize a third-party company to join the project. Taxable entities (such as solar companies) are eligible for a 30 percent credit for solar farm construction, but this credit decreases after December 2016.\n\nThe city expects prices in the purchasing agreement to be competitive with Tallahassee’s current electrical costs since the cost of producing solar energy has decreased expeditiously. According to the Solar Energy Industries Association, the cost of installing a photovoltaic (PV) solar power system has decreased<a href="http://www.seia.org/policy/solar-technology/photovoltaic-solar-electric"> 33%</a> since 2011.\n\nThis decrease can be attributed to the decreasing cost of manufacturing. As the solar energy market has grown, so has manufacturing of solar materials, and <a href="http://www.quora.com/Why-have-solar-panel-prices-decreased-so-dramatically-Will-this-trend-continue-and-should-end-users-wait-for-prices-to-drop-further">solar manufacturing companies have been able to achieve economies of scale</a> and reduce costs somewhat. Solar panels themselves have also become more efficient. Currently, the average PV system produces at <a href="http://www.forbes.com/sites/peterdetwiler/2013/07/16/as-solar-panel-efficiencies-keep-improving-its-time-to-adopt-some-new-metrics/">15% efficiency</a>, up from 11% in 2000. This efficiency is <a href="http://unews.utah.edu/news_releases/boosting-solar-cell-efficiency/">expected to continue increasing</a>.\n\nHowever, electricity from solar power is still much pricier than natural gas (Tallahassee’s primary fuel source). According to the Energy Information Administration’s (EIA) 2014 Annual Energy Outlook, the<a href="http://www.eia.gov/forecasts/aeo/pdf/electricity_generation.pdf"> the average levelized cost of electricity</a> (LCOE) for solar PV in 2019 is projected to be $118.6 per megawatt hour (a megawatt hour is <a href="http://www.cleanenergyauthority.com/solar-energy-resources/what-is-a-megawatt-and-a-megawatt-hour/">the amount needed to run 10 automobile engines continuously for one hour</a>). <a href="http://www.solar-estimate.org/showfaq.php?id=261">LCOE measures</a> the average yearly cost of an energy source over time, and is used to reflect the fact that the a solar panel’s high installation costs can be paid off over its lifetime. By comparison, the average LCOE for conventional natural gas is almost half the cost of Solar PV at $66.3/MWh.\n\nAnother measure the EIA recommends that energy consumer and producers consider is the levelized avoided cost of electricity (LACE)--the cost to the grid required to produce the electricity displaced by a new power source. Subtracting LCOE from LACE gives us the “net economic value”. A negative remainder indicates that the cost of the new power source exceeds the benefit. A positive number indicates the opposite. The EIA summary projects the average difference between LCOE and LACE for solar PV to be -$45.2 per MWh by 2019, compared to -$3.4 per MWh for natural gas.\n\nSwitching to solar power may currently be too costly for Tallahassee. Despite recent gains in efficiency, solar PV remains significantly more expensive than natural gas. However, solar PV’s future appears promising. The same EIA report mentioned above projects the average difference between LCOE and LACE in 2040 to be -$11.9 per MWh for solar PV, a vast improvement. Solar PV will likely continue to decrease in cost, but may take decades to be competitive with other energy sources.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '284'), ('wp:post_date', '2015-06-02 14:38:01'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2015-06-02 14:38:01'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'solar-farm-proposed-in-tallahassee'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), 'city-of-tallahassee-utilities'), ('#text', 'City of Tallahassee Utilities')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'energy'), ('#text', 'Energy')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'energy-policy'), ('#text', 'energy policy')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'fiscal-policy'), ('#text', 'Fiscal Policy')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'green'), ('#text', 'green')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'lace'), ('#text', 'LACE')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'lcoe'), ('#text', 'LCOE')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'local'), ('#text', 'local')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'natural-gas'), ('#text', 'natural
