('wp:postmeta', [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_published'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_client_id'), ('wp:meta_value', '-1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_publicize_job_id'), ('wp:meta_value', '11261613991')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', 'Taxis and Ridesourcing Companies Serve Different Customers'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2015/07/09/taxis-and-ridesourcing-companies-serve-different-customers/'), ('pubDate', 'Thu, 09 Jul 2015 14:23:55 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=286')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'By Matt Kelly\n\nUber, Lyft, Sidecar, and other “ridesourcing” services have been the subject of a near continuous stream of popular<a href="http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-33313145"> news stories</a>,<a href="http://www.theverge.com/2015/6/17/8797021/uber-california-lawsuit-labor-employee-contractor"> lawsuits</a>,<a href="http://www.miamiherald.com/news/local/community/miami-dade/article25827388.html"> protests</a>, and even<a href="http://tbo.com/news/politics/uber-lyft-and-other-car-services-may-get-help-from-lawmakers-20150308/"> regulatory reforms</a> across the world. The reporting has often bordered on sensationalism, but a handful of recent economic studies have tried to objectively examine the effects of “ridesourcing” on drivers and customers. Ridesourcing is the term used when referring to companies such as Uber and Lyft that use technology rather than traditional taxi company models to connect users with transportation suppliers. Their results suggest that these companies are meeting a demand that traditional taxis have failed to satisfy, while potentially yielding environmental gains.<!--more-->\n\n<a href="http://tsrc.berkeley.edu/node/796">A study from the University of California, Berkeley</a> surveyed 380 ridesourcing users in San Francisco, California. Respondents were asked about when, how, and why they used these services. The authors then compared their results with data from a 2012 Community Survey on taxi customers to see if the two clienteles behaved differently.\n\nA charge frequently levelled at ridesourcing companies is that they are essentially the same as taxi companies, and derive most of their added value from flouting regulations. If survey data of customers proved that ridesourcing companies and taxis are serving a similar customer base, then such charges might be justified.\n\nHowever, the Berkeley study instead finds substantial differences in the two groups. “The findings indicate ridesourcing serves a previously unmet demand for convenient, point-to-point urban travel. Although taxis and ridesourcing share similarities, the findings show differences in users and the user experience.”\n\n“Ridesourcing wait times are markedly shorter and more consistent than those of taxis.” Almost no respondents said they waited more than 15 minutes, while nearly a third of taxi customers did. There was also far less variability in wait time for ridesourcing trips. “Ridesourcing users tend to be younger, own fewer vehicles and more frequently travel with companions.” The Berkeley data also show that ridesharing apps serve customers at times and locations that taxis and other forms of public transit are unable or unwilling to.\n\nThe authors also stress that the taxi industry has historically suffered from a lack of information about customers and drivers, but suggest that “<a href="http://www.businessinsider.com/leaked-charts-show-how-ubers-driver-rating-system-works-2015-2">rating systems</a> might resolve the lack-of-information problem. These advances bring into question how the need for regulation may have changed.”\n\n<a href="http://www.smart2020.org/_assets/files/Smart2020UnitedStatesReportAddendum.pdf">Another report from 2008</a>, though not specifically mentioning ridesourcing apps, points out the environmental benefits that technological advancements in transportation portend. The Global e-Sustainability Initiative estimatesd that using information and communications technology (ICT) to optimize logistics of individual road transport could reduce annual carbon dioxide emissions in the U.S. by 70 to 190 million metric tons by 2020.<a href="http://www.ericsson.com/res/docs/2014/ict-and-the-future-of-transport.pdf"> A 2014 report from the Ericsson</a>, a technology company, also touts the benefits of technological integration in an emerging future where customer satisfaction and environmental sustainability intersect. This comports well with data from the Berkeley study. Forty percent of survey respondents said they drive less since using ridesourcing apps.\nIf companies like Uber, Lyft, and Sidecar are using information technology to better connect supply and demand, serve customers that traditional public transit doesn’t, and even reduce our environmental footprint, it may be worth reconsidering the sensational news reports and chaotic protests that surround these technologies. A clear-headed appraisal of the costs and benefits is necessary to make a judgement on ridesourcing’s effect. The Berkeley study suggests its emergence is a net gain for users, as well as society as a whole.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '286'), ('wp:post_date', '2015-07-09 14:23:55'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2015-07-09 14:23:55'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'taxis-and-ridesourcing-companies-serve-different-customers'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', [OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'environment'), ('#text', 'environment')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'lyft'), ('#text', 'lyft')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'regulation-2'), ('#text', 'Regulation')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'ridesharing'), ('#text', 'ridesharing')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'ridesourcing'), ('#text', 'ridesourcing')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'sharing-economy'), ('#text', 'sharing economy')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'sidecar'), ('#text', 'sidecar')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'transit'), ('#text', 'transit')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'transportation'), ('#text', 'Transportation')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'uber'), ('#text', 'uber')])]), ('wp:postmeta', [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_published'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_client_id'), ('wp:meta_value', '-1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_publicize_job_id'), ('wp:meta_value', '12563201875')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', 'Off The Grid: The Future of Solar Power'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2015/07/16/off-the-grid-the-future-of-solar-power/'), ('pubDate', 'Thu, 16 Jul 2015 17:35:53 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=289')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'By Logan Shewmaker\n\nAccording to the Solar Energy Industries Association (SEIA),<a href="http://www.seia.org/state-solar-policy/florida"> Florida ranks 3rd</a> in the United States for rooftop solar energy potential. But Florida only ranks 13th in “cumulative solar capacity installed.” <a href="http://www.wctv.tv/home/headlines/Sunshine-State-or-Not-Florida-Badly-Behind-on-Solar-Power-304276541.html">Some experts</a> think that this lack of solar energy installation stems from poor policy. James Fenton, director of the Solar Energy Center at the University of Central Florida, has said, "The rules are set up so there isn\'t competition right now.” One way to encourage competition would be for Florida to legalize third-party <a href="http://www.seia.org/policy/finance-tax/third-party-financing">Power Purchase Agreements (PPA)</a>.<!--more-->\n\nA PPA is an agreement through which a developer installs a solar photovoltaic (PV) system on a customer’s property and sells the electricity generated on-site exclusively to that customer. Rather than buy electricity from a utility company, energy users can pay for solar energy produced on their own property. <a href="http://www.epa.gov/greenpower/buygp/solarpower.htm">With a PPA</a>, the customer’s payments are based on the actual electricity produced, rather than a fixed rate as with a solar panel leasing agreement.\n\n<a href="http://ncsolarcen-prod.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/3rd-Party-PPA_0302015.pdf">PPAs are explicitly legal in 24 states,</a> but are illegal in Florida. To sell electricity in the Sunshine State, a company must be a public utility regulated by the Florida Public Service Commission\n\nGroups like <a href="http://www.flsolarchoice.org/">Floridians for Solar Choice</a> are concerned that current rules restrict customer choice. They say solar companies should have the ability to sell electricity directly to customers. Floridians for Solar Choice is promoting a <a href="http://www.miamiherald.com/news/politics-government/state-politics/article26819602.html">state constitutional ballot initiative </a>for 2016 that would allow customers to purchase from sources other than a franchised traditional electric utility company.\n\nHowever, <a href="http://www.cnbc.com/id/102075665">utility companies worry PPAs could hurt revenue</a> and compromise the reliability of the electrical grid (which the companies maintain). In order to recoup lost revenue, utility companies might have to raise their prices.\n\nUtility companies are also concerned that increasing electricity produced by residential solar panels could expand “net metering.” With <a href="http://www.seia.org/policy/distributed-solar/net-metering">net metering</a>, a household’s solar PV systems are connected to the electrical utility grid. PV systems often produce more electricity than households use. Households often sell their excess electricity to their utility companies via the grid, and receive a credit on their utility bill. This can be an appealing option for solar energy users, but it may reduce utility companies’ revenues.\n\n<a href="http://emp.lbl.gov/sites/all/files/LBNL%20PV%20Business%20Models%20Report_no%20report%20number%20(Sept%2025%20revision).pdf">A study by the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory</a> (LBL) suggested the financial impacts of solar PV and net metering are minimal. Berkeley found that if solar PV rose from its current level of 0.2% of retail electricity sales to 2.5%, average retail electricity rates would only increase 0.1% to 0.2%. Utility shareholders would be only slightly more impacted. At 2.5% of total retail electricity sales, solar PV is expected to decrease shareholder earnings by 0.3% to 4.7% over 10 years. The LBL study found that the effect of net metering on electricity rates would likely be “modest,” though the effects on shareholder earnings appeared larger and more variable.\n\nOverall, the LBL study concludes that PPA would not increase electricity rates to an unreasonable level to users. Furthermore, the gains to solar energy users and the environment could be substantial. PPAs offer a market-based solution to diversifying Florida’s energy sources, allowing consumers a greater choice in the marketplace.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '289'), ('wp:post_date', '2015-07-16 17:35:53'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2015-07-16 17:35:53'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'off-the-grid-the-future-of-solar-power'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', [OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'energy'), ('#text', 'Energy')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'energy-2'), ('#text', 'energy')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'florida'), ('#text', 'Florida')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'green'), ('#text', 'green')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', As of late 2012, seven U.S cities have running heritage streetcars. The Tampa Electric Company (TECO) Line Streetcar System is one example. <a href="http://www.tampabay.com/news/transportation/masstransit/fdot-to-kick-in-1-million-to-help-plan-tampa-streetcar-expansion/2226549">The Florida Department of Transportation (FDOT) recently committed 1 million dollars</a> to assess the feasibility of expanding and renovating Tampa’s streetcars. Studies indicate that tourists are the TECO’s most frequent riders, but the line hasn’t performed successfully for several years. In order to be profitable, the TECO Line Streetcar System will need to serve more daily commuters, as well as tourists interested in Tampa’s history.<!--more-->\n\nTampa’s first streetcar lines were<a href="http://www.tecolinestreetcar.org/news/inventing_the_future.pdf"> built in 1892</a>, and swiftly became an important part of daily transportation.<a href="http://floridahistory.org/ybor2.htm"> Cigar factories dominated the economy in Tampa in the early 1900s</a> and workers depended on streetcars in order to get to work. Tampa’s streetcars reached their peak of popularity in 1926, serving 26 million passengers that year, but all had ceased operating by 1946. Numerous attempts were made to bring them back into operation, and the streetcars were eventually revived in 2003.\n\nThe FDOT study will evaluate <a href="http://www.bizjournals.com/tampabay/news/2015/04/22/tampas-historic-streetcar-gets-1m-boost-from-fdot.html">“potential ridership, environmental impacts and economic development opportunities as well as refine capital and operational costs”</a>. The study’s results will determine whether providing federal and state funds for the TECO Line Streetcar is a sound investment.\n\n<a href="https://mlsvc01-prod.s3.amazonaws.com/2c3658b4001/e2409905-a6bf-48e4-b457-8df224ed9727.pdf">A study conducted by HDR and published by the Hillsborough Regional Area Transit Authority (HART)</a> outlined four possible scenarios for expansion, with estimated costs ranging from 37 million dollars to approximately 60 million dollars. Yet there are concerns about the TECO line’s feasibility in its current state. According to HART’s <a href="http://www.gohart.org/transparency/finance/annual_reports/fy2014.pdf">financial report for 2014</a>, streetcar ridership declined 6.12% from 2013 to 2014. TECO incurred a deficit of $662,000 that same year. Ridership is projected to continue declining in the near future.\n\nAnother study by <a href="http://transweb.sjsu.edu/PDFs/research/1201-streetcar-transit-in-modern-US-cities.pdf">The Mineta Transportation Institute (MTI)</a> examined the purpose, function and performance of streetcar transit in five major cities: Little Rock, Memphis, Portland, Seattle, and Tampa. The study identifies tourism as a key factor in the performance of streetcars within its case study of Tampa. Tourism accounted for 57% of the TECO streetcar system’s total ridership. Between 2003 and 2008, TECO’s revenue and ridership increased each year, but have declined since the 2008 recession. MTI concludes their case study of TECO by saying that streetcar performance within Tampa may be too dependent on the tourism industry and should diversify its customer base.\n\nMany analysts believe that taxpayers ought to receive a<a href="http://www.inc.com/encyclopedia/return-on-investment-roi.html"> return on public investments</a> that is greater than 1 (meaning that every tax dollar spent spurs more than a dollar in additional revenue) in order for a project to be justified on cost effectiveness. TECO’s shortcomings warrant concern from Tampa residents and taxpayers.<a href="http://www.miaminewtimes.com/news/record-breaking-973-million-tourists-visited-florida-last-year-6565278"> 2014 was a record breaking year for Florida’s tourism industry</a>, but the TECO line still lost ridership and revenues, suggesting it can’t count on future tourism growth to sustain it financially. Changes must be made to the TECO line to make it a profitable enterprise. It must better serve Tampa’s local commuters, as well as tourists, or run the risk of becoming a one dimensional tourist attraction.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '291'), [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_published'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_client_id'), ('wp:meta_value', '-1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_publicize_job_id'), ('wp:meta_value', '13176389058')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', 'Price Regulations Complicate Net Metering and Solar Energy'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2015/08/05/price-regulations-complicate-net-metering-and-solar-energy/'), ('pubDate', 'Wed, 05 Aug 2015 15:46:56 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=293')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'By Logan Shewmaker\n\n<a href="http://ncsolarcen-prod.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/3rd-Party-PPA_0302015.pdf">As in four other states,</a> all electricity for residential use in Florida must be purchased from franchised utility companies. However, solar energy advocates are trying to change this by allowing private purchase agreements between residents and solar companies in order to expand rooftop solar power production in the Sunshine State. Crucial to this initiative is a policy called "net metering". Expanding consumer choice is commendable, but because of numerous subsidies and price regulations at play in this market, such a policy could also have a negative impact on non-solar energy users.<!--more-->\n\nSolar photovoltaic (PV) energy systems have become more affordable thanks to changing consumer preferences, but costs to consumers have also fallen because of government subsidies. These subsidies\xa0are making residents more likely to install solar power than they otherwise would be. A common government incentive for rooftop solar is a process called "net energy metering" (NEM). At midday, rooftop PV systems often produce more electricity than households use. This excess electricity is sent back into the electrical grid. NEM customers get a billing credit based on the amount of excess electricity they produced.\n\nBut what price should utility companies pay households for this customer-produced solar energy? Rather than allow market forces to determine prices based on supply and demand, the Florida Public Service Commission (FPSC) currently regulates prices. According to <a href="https://www.flrules.org/gateway/ChapterHome.asp?Chapter=25-17">Rules chapter 25-17,</a> utility companies must pay retail prices for solar power their users produce. The problem is that retail rates include the cost of transportation and distribution, but those are services that the utility provides, not the consumer. Utility companies are concerned about the potential impacts on the electricity transmission network, or “the grid,” and warn that encouraging solar energy production may come at the expense of non-solar customers. Prices for non-NEM customers may rise to make up for lower revenues.\n\nSeveral economic studies analyze the potential effects of NEM on consumers and utilities, but their results vary widely. <a href="http://publicservice.vermont.gov/sites/psd/files/Topics/Renewable_Energy/Net_Metering/Act%2099%20NM%20Study%20Revised%20v1.pdf">A study by the Vermont Public Service Department</a> found that aggregate net costs to non-NEM customers over twenty years would be “close to zero.” In contrast, <a href="http://www.cpuc.ca.gov/NR/rdonlyres/C311FE8F-C262-45EE-9CD1-020556C41457/0/NEMReportWithAppendices.pdf">a study by the California Public Utilities Commission</a> predicted that non-NEM customers would have to pay an additional 20 cents for every kWh produced by NEM customers (based on systems installed in 2012), because of the price regulations that require utilities to buy NEM customers’ power at retail rates.\n\nThe economic research on this topic is not in complete agreement, but some evidence confirms utility companies’ claims, suggesting that NEM customers will benefit at the expense of non-NEM customers and the grid’s long-term maintenance provided by legacy utilities. Those who can’t afford to install solar panels could be left with a higher utility bill. Changes in price regulations are necessary to prevent this cross-subsidization. Utilities organizations, such as the Edison Electric Institute, would like to see customer-generated electricity sold to utilities <a href="http://www.eei.org/issuesandpolicy/generation/NetMetering/Documents/Straight%20Talk%20About%20Net%20Metering.pdf">at wholesale prices, rather than retai</a>l.\n\nThe Florida Public Service Commission \xa0should consider modifying its price regulations regarding net metering since current practices may result in unfair cost sharing and skewed economic incentives. The environmental goals of net metering proponents may be laudable, but the policy’s potential effect on residents who can’t afford to install solar merits consideration.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), 'price-regulations-complicate-net-metering-and-solar-energy'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', [OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'energy'), ('#text', 'Energy')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'energy-2'), ('#text', 'energy')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'environment'), ('#text', 'environment')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'net-metering'), ('#text', 'net metering')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'price-regulation'), ('#text', 'price regulation')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'pv'), ('#text', 'PV')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'solar'), ('#text', 'solar')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'solar-energy'), ('#text', 'solar energy')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'subsidies'), ('#text', 'subsidies')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'utilities'), ('#text', 'utilities')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'utility-companies'), ('#text', 'utility companies')])]), ('wp:postmeta', [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_published'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_client_id'), ('wp:meta_value', '-1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_publicize_job_id'), ('wp:meta_value', '13432689371')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', 'Measuring Liberty: The Economic Freedom of the World Index'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2015/08/11/measuring-liberty-the-economic-freedom-of-the-world-index/'), ('pubDate', 'Tue, 11 Aug 2015 15:17:01 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=296')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'By Matt Kelly\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Defining freedom can be a difficult endeavor, yet the ability to compare relative economic and social liberties among countries is of significant importance for economic research. With that aim in mind,</span><a href="http://coss.fsu.edu/economics/node/31"> <span style="font-weight:400;">Florida State University professor and DeVoe Moore scholar James Gwartney</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> and</span><a href="https://www.smu.edu/News/2014/robert-lawson-10jan2013"> <span style="font-weight:400;">Robert Lawson of Southern Methodist University</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">, have compiled the</span><a href="http://www.freetheworld.com/"> <span style="font-weight:400;">Economic Freedom of the World Index</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> since 1996. The authors admit that quantifying an abstract idea like freedom has its limitations, but the index has greatly enhanced academic understanding of the relationship between liberty and economic performance.</span>\n\n<!--more-->\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">The Economic Freedom of the World (EFW) Index is made up of 42 distinct variables, which can be grouped into 5 basic categories: (1) size of government in terms of expenditures, taxes, and enterprises, (2) legal structure and security of property rights, (3) access to sound money, (4) freedom to trade internationally, and (5) regulation of credit, labor, and business. Variables include the length of time needed to start a business, restrictions on international trade, government spending levels, military interference in economic and civil matters, inflation, and a host of other factors. These values are added up to compute a country’s ranking on the EFW index.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Hong Kong and Singapore are tied for the top 2012 ranking, while the United States has lagged behind in recent years (and is currently ranked 12th). </span><a href="http://www.freetheworld.com/2014/EFW2014-POST.pdf"><span style="font-weight:400;">The 2014 report</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> attributes the relatively poor performance by the U.S. to “the increased use of eminent domain to transfer property to powerful political interests, the ramifications of the wars on terrorism and drugs, and the violation of the property rights of bondholders in the auto-bailout case have weakened the tradition of strong adherence to the rule of law in United States.” These are worrying trends for the U.S., the overall growth in economic freedom across the globe is also something to celebrate. Measured on a 10-point scale, the overall average has risen from 5.32 in 1980 to 6.84 in 2012.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">A higher EFW ranking is associated with greater social well-being. For instance, the average income for a country’s poorest 10% of its population reached $11,610 for countries in the top quartile of the EFW. In contrast, the bottom quartile (25%) in the least free countries earned an average of $1,358 (dollar figures are calculated using</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity"><span style="font-weight:400;"> purchasing power parity</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> and in constant 2011 US$). Perhaps most strikingly, life expectancy is 79.9 years in the top quartile of the EFW compared to 63.2 years in the bottom quartile.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Numerous academic studies \xa0have used EFW data to explain how economic performance is affected by government institutions.</span><a href="http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1467-6435.2006.00327.x/abstract"> <span style="font-weight:400;">A 2006 paper by Gwartney, Holcombe, and Lawson</span></a> <span style="font-weight:400;">indicates that a one-point decline in the EFW rating is associated with a reduction in the long-term GDP growth of between 1.0 and 1.5 percentage points annually. </span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Others have used it to explain the relative successes of reform and revolutionary movements throughout the world, as with</span><a href="http://www.fraserinstitute.org/uploadedFiles/fraser-ca/Content/research-news/research/publications/institutions-and-economic-political-and-civil-liberty-in-the-arab-world.pdf"> <span style="font-weight:400;">a more recent paper by Fred McMahon on the Arab Spring</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">. Although a period of “phony reform” during the late 20th century nocently discredited the idea of free markets for many in the Middle East, the region’s average EFW rating ticked upward slightly in 2012. Though many cards are stacked against them (violence, clientelist governments, sectarianism), the higher EFW is a positive sign.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Gwartney and Lawson maintain that their EFW index doesn’t encompass everything there is to know about</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_growth"> <span style="font-weight:400;">economic growth</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">, which is also influenced by demographics, innovation, and access to natural resources among other factors. Yet, their index and the research inspired by it suggests government institutions matter tremendously. The index provides valuable insight into the nature and characteristics of market-oriented economies and those dominated by government regulation and planning.</span>'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '296'), ('wp:post_date', '2015-08-11 15:17:01'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2015-08-11 15:17:01'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'measuring-liberty-the-economic-freedom-of-the-world-index'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', [OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'arab-spring'), ('#text', 'arab spring')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'data'), ('#text', 'data')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'devoe-moore-center'), ('#text', 'DeVoe Moore Center')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'economics'), ('#text', 'economics')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'efw'), ('#text', 'EFW')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'freedom'), ('#text', 'freedom')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'james-gwartney'), ('#text', 'James Gwartney')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'liberty'), ('#text', 'liberty')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'politics'), ('#text', 'politics')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'regulation-2'), ('#text', 'Regulation')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'research'), ('#text', 'research')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'robert-lawson'), ('#text', 'Robert Lawson')])]), ('wp:postmeta', [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_published'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_client_id'), ('wp:meta_value', '-1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_publicize_job_id'), ('wp:meta_value', '13623951015')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', 'Measuring Success and Failure in Public Transportation: The Case of Sunrail'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2015/08/27/measuring-success-and-failure-in-public-transportation-the-case-of-sunrail/'), ('pubDate', 'Thu, 27 Aug 2015 15:19:38 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=300')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', '<a href="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2015/08/sunrail.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-305" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2015/08/sunrail.jpg?w=300" alt="sunrail" width="300" height="220" /></a>\n\nBy Santiago Arango\n\nIn May, SunRail, Orlando’s commuter rail system, celebrated its first year of operation and was<a href="http://www.orlandosentinel.com/news/traffic/os-sunrail-federal-money-20150504-story.html"> awarded a $93 million federal grant</a>.<a href="http://www.fta.dot.gov/documents/FL_Orlando_SunRail_Phase_II_South_Profile_FY15.pdf"> Phase II of SunRail’s construction</a> will add four more stations and 17.2 miles of rail into neighboring Osceola County within two years.<a href="http://www.forbes.com/pictures/edgl45emig/no-4-orlando-fl/"> Orlando is the 4th fastest growing city in the U.S.</a>, meaning SunRail has a growing market and an opportunity to sustain itself. Yet concerns remain. SunRail averages 3,700 riders daily, 15% shy of its goal of 4,300. It has accrued a $27.2 million deficit so far. Economists disagree on how best to measure the success of projects like SunRail, but it should be accountable to measurable objectives.<!--more-->\n\nA lackluster first year for SunRail has not shaken the confidence of its supporters.<a href="http://www.orlandosentinel.com/news/sunrail/os-sunrail-fares-low-20150510-story.html"> Orlando Mayor Buddy Dyer calls the performance “good for a first year”</a> and expects revenue and ridership to increase. FDOT is likewise optimistic,<a href="http://www.dot.state.fl.us/planning/trends/tc-report/economy.pdf"> anticipating savings</a> associated with decreased highway traffic congestion created by public rail transit alternatives.\n\nWhile privately owned and operated railroad systems, such as <a href="http://www.allaboardflorida.com/">All Aboard Florida</a>, must cover its costs with revenues or cease operation, publicly funded transportation projects like SunRail have the luxury of access to state, local, and federal money, and can thus operate as long as public money is available. There is little economic incentive to be profitable with this backing.\n\nBut does ridership and profitability tell us everything we need to know about SunRail’s performance? Some economists maintain that positive externalities should be included in analyses of rail transit.<a href="http://www.economicsonline.co.uk/Market_failures/Positive_externalities.html"> Positive externalities</a> are indirect benefits from the production of some good or service, experienced by a third party but not accounted for by producers and consumers. Unlike private benefits (like profits, savings, or utility from consumption), positive externalities benefit people who don’t necessarily buy or use the service (e.g., less secondhand smoke when a smoker decides to quit, less pollution when a driver walks to work, decreased highway congestion resulting from a rail transit as an alternative to automobiles).\n\n<a href="http://vtpi.org/railcrit.pdf">A study published by the Victoria Transport Policy Institute (VTPI)</a> suggests ways to measure the positive externalities of public transit. The study quantified their impact by comparing congestion costs in areas with rail systems and those without. On average, commuters in areas with rail systems experienced 46 fewer hours of travel delay annually. VTPI called for other researchers to use a “broader scope of analysis” in assessing rail’s success.\n\nHowever, SunRail’s financial losses may outweigh the positive externalities associated with it. A<a href="http://object.cato.org/sites/cato.org/files/pubs/pdf/pa663.pdf"> study conducted by the Cato Institute</a> questioned economists’ ability to accurately measure positive externalities and other non-monetary benefits. The authors observe that even when accounting for reduced congestion and other positive externalities, few public rail systems are successful. Still, the success of rail service, and public investments in general, ought to be measured by tangible and quantifiable standards that can allow comparisons among projects so that taxpayers can determine the best use of public spending.\n\nAfter an underwhelming first year of operation, SunRail needs to meet its objectives, whether in terms of profitability and ridership or the positive externality of decreased congestion. Orlando is the<a href="https://www.tomtom.com/en_gb/trafficindex/#/"> 96th most congested city in the world by some measures.</a> Rail transit might provide an alternative to alleviate that congestion although private enterprise has more incentive to do so successfully. Reaching more congested areas where demand for transit alternatives is highest, as it will in <a href="http://www.clickorlando.com/news/sunrail-to-expand-to-orlando-international-airport/33382282">Phase III of construction</a>, has the potential to improve SunRail’s performance, but Orlando’s public rail line will need to demonstrate its worthiness to taxpayers by meeting measurable objectives.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '300'), ('wp:post_date', '2015-08-27 15:19:38'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2015-08-27 15:19:38'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'measuring-success-and-failure-in-public-transportation-the-case-of-sunrail'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '305'), ('wp:post_date', '2015-08-27 18:16:32'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2015-08-27 18:16:32'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'closed'), '/home/wpcom/public_html/wp-content/blogs.dir/848/80998613/files/2015/08/sunrail.jpg')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wp_attachment_metadata'), ('wp:meta_value', 'a:5:{s:5:"width";i:3237;s:6:"height";i:2376;s:4:"file";s:83:"/home/wpcom/public_html/wp-content/blogs.dir/848/80998613/files/2015/08/sunrail.jpg";s:5:"sizes";a:0:{}s:10:"image_meta";a:11:{s:8:"aperture";i:0;s:6:"credit";s:0:"";s:6:"camera";s:0:"";s:7:"caption";s:0:"";s:17:"created_timestamp";i:0;s:9:"copyright";s:0:"";s:12:"focal_length";i:0;s:3:"iso";i:0;s:13:"shutter_speed";i:0;s:5:"title";s:0:"";s:11:"orientation";i:0;}}')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', 'Regulations mislead, unfairly question safety of small food producers'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2015/09/11/florida-regulation-limits-economic-opportunities-for-small-food-processors/'), ('pubDate', 'Fri, 11 Sep 2015 17:20:31 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=307')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'By Samuel R. Staley, Ph.D.*\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Fresh food markets are experiencing rapid growth across the nation as more and more residents look for local food options. In Tallahassee, popular local markets are patronized at the Downtown Marketplace and Lake Ella, and a new market is being encouraged as part of the revitalization efforts in Frenchtown. Public policy and regulation, however, often discourage the growth of these markets and so-called “cottage- industry” food products, sometimes in subtle but powerful ways.<a href="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2015/09/lemonloafboughtatdowntownmarkeplace.jpg"><img class="size-medium wp-image-308 alignright" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2015/09/lemonloafboughtatdowntownmarkeplace.jpg?w=225" alt="LemonLoafBoughtatDowntownMarkeplace" width="225" height="300" /></a></span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">For example, a fresh baked lemon loaf recently purchased at Tallahassee’s Downtown Marketplace carried a label proclaiming “Made in a cottage food operation that is not subject to Florida’s food safety regulations.” This label, </span><a href="http://www.freshfromflorida.com/content/download/10223/137606/CottageFoodAdvisoryChanges_Feb_2014_withFormNumber.pdf"><span style="font-weight:400;">required by state law</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">, may seem benign--a simple warning to potential consumers--but the wording along with its placement misleads the public and undermines small food-processing companies.</span><!--more-->\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">First, the label implies that the food product is unsafe. Pointing out the fact that food is produced outside the state’s regulatory framework suggests the food is less safe than food regulated by the state. This is odd because the Florida Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services </span><a href="http://www.freshfromflorida.com/content/download/10223/137606/CottageFoodAdvisoryChanges_Feb_2014_withFormNumber.pdf"><span style="font-weight:400;">defines a cottage food product</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> as “food that is not </span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Potentially_Hazardous_Food"><span style="font-weight:400;">a potentially hazardous food</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">.” Subjecting it to food safety regulations would accomplish little, and the label does nothing more than implant the presumption that the product is unsafe.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Second, the label is at best misleading because the suggestion behind the wording is that foods that are subject to Florida’s food safety regulations are in fact more safe. This research does not appear to exist. A search of the academic literature revealed no studies that demonstrated a higher risk of food-born diseases among cottage-industry food producers compared to commercial producers. Several studies, on the other hand, have examined how these regulations create undue burdens on small producers. </span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Moreover, licensing, inspections and certification requirements don’t guarantee food safety, the implied default suggested by the label. The </span><a href="http://www.fda.gov/Food/RecallsOutbreaksEmergencies/Outbreaks/ucm438104.htm"><span style="font-weight:400;">recent outbreak of listeria</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> in ice cream produced by large-scale, commercial producer Blue Bell Creameries is a case in point. </span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blue_Bell_Creameries#2015_recalls"><span style="font-weight:400;">Hundreds of employees were laid off, </span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">and massive recalls threatened the very existence of the company, as plants were shut down and consumers refused to buy their products after Listeria led to the deaths of three to five people. </span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Regardless of whether food is produced by large-scale commercial operations or small-scale cottage business, food safety cannot be guaranteed. The procedures used to test for contamination require sampling of products, not testing every product that is produced. Facilities are not inspected daily (nor is this necessary), and not every production run of a food product is evaluated (or could be evaluated) for safety and quality. Indeed, inspections are often reactive, not proactive, initiated from reports by consumers or competitors.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Some groups are organizing to challenge the value of these regulations. The Institute for Justice, a libertarian public-interest law firm based in Washington, D.C., for example, has established a </span><a href="http://www.ij.org/FoodFreedom"><span style="font-weight:400;">Food Freedom Initiative</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> to challenge unnecessary regulations that keep small food processors and food entrepreneurs from starting and expanding their businesses. Its report, </span><i><span style="font-weight:400;">The Attack on Food Freedom </span></i><span style="font-weight:400;">by Baylen Linnekin and Michael Bachmann, can be found </span><a href="http://ij.org/images/pdf_folder/economic_liberty/perspectives-food-freedom.pdf"><span style="font-weight:400;">here</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">. The organization has also initiated litigation challenging Florida’s misleading labeling required for </span><a href="http://ij.org/florida-skim-milk"><span style="font-weight:400;">selling skim milk</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> and a law in Miami Gardens </span><a href="http://www.ij.org/FlVeggies"><span style="font-weight:400;">prohibiting front-yard vegetable gardens</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> (while allowing trees and fruits). Hopefully, this litigation will result in regulatory reform that is more evidence-based than current labeling requirements that seem tailored to scare consumers rather than inform them.</span>\n\n<em>*Samuel R. Staley, Ph.D., is director of the DeVoe L. Moore Center at Florida State University.</em>'), ('excerpt:encoded', 'State regulations often impose unnecessary burdens on small businesses, including the cottage-food industry'), ('wp:post_id', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2015/09/figure-1.png')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', None), ('excerpt:encoded', "Leon County's Fee Revenue nearly tripled after 2009. Data from www.Floridaopengov.org"), ('wp:post_id', '311'), ('wp:post_date', '2015-09-18 14:54:18'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2015-09-18 14:54:18'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'closed'), ('wp:post_name', 'figure-1'), ('wp:status', 'inherit'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'attachment'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('wp:attachment_url', 'https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2015/09/figure-1.png'), ('wp:postmeta', [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wp_attached_file'), ('wp:meta_value', '/home/wpcom/public_html/wp-content/blogs.dir/848/80998613/files/2015/09/figure-1.png')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wp_attachment_metadata'), ('wp:meta_value', 'a:5:{s:5:"width";i:816;s:6:"height";i:480;s:4:"file";s:84:"/home/wpcom/public_html/wp-content/blogs.dir/848/80998613/files/2015/09/figure-1.png";s:5:"sizes";a:0:{}s:10:"image_meta";a:11:{s:8:"aperture";i:0;s:6:"credit";s:0:"";s:6:"camera";s:0:"";s:7:"caption";s:0:"";s:17:"created_timestamp";i:0;s:9:"copyright";s:0:"";s:12:"focal_length";i:0;s:3:"iso";i:0;s:13:"shutter_speed";i:0;s:5:"title";s:0:"";s:11:"orientation";i:0;}}')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', 'FIGURE 2'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/figure-2/'), ('pubDate', 'Fri, 18 Sep 2015 14:54:35 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2015/09/figure-2.png')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', None), ('excerpt:encoded', 'New business startups are critical to economic growth. (GSP data from The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis; New business starts data from The Bureau of Economic Analysis.)'), ('wp:post_id', '312'), ('wp:post_date', '2015-09-18 14:54:35'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2015-09-18 14:54:35'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'closed'), ('wp:post_name', 'figure-2'), ('wp:status', 'inherit'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'attachment'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('wp:attachment_url', 'https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2015/09/figure-2.png'), ('wp:postmeta', [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wp_attached_file'), ('wp:meta_value', '/home/wpcom/public_html/wp-content/blogs.dir/848/80998613/files/2015/09/figure-2.png')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wp_attachment_metadata'), ('wp:meta_value', 'a:5:{s:5:"width";i:952;s:6:"height";i:560;s:4:"file";s:84:"/home/wpcom/public_html/wp-content/blogs.dir/848/80998613/files/2015/09/figure-2.png";s:5:"sizes";a:0:{}s:10:"image_meta";a:11:{s:8:"aperture";i:0;s:6:"credit";s:0:"";s:6:"camera";s:0:"";s:7:"caption";s:0:"";s:17:"created_timestamp";i:0;s:9:"copyright";s:0:"";s:12:"focal_length";i:0;s:3:"iso";i:0;s:13:"shutter_speed";i:0;s:5:"title";s:0:"";s:11:"orientation";i:0;}}')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', 'Property-tax hike in Tallahassee reveals broken budget process'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2015/09/21/zero-based-budgeting-would-identify-government-spending-cuts-and-savings/'), ('pubDate', 'Mon, 21 Sep 2015 19:43:31 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=315')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'By Samuel R. Staley, Ph.D.\n\n<a href="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2015/09/citizensgroup14points.jpg"><img class=" wp-image-316 alignright" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2015/09/citizensgroup14points.jpg?w=300" alt="Citizensgroup,14points" width="317" height="313" /></a>Local Tallahassee activists have<a href="http://www.tallahassee.com/story/news/2015/09/15/group-pitches-million-budget-cuts/72346956/"> proposed $9.5 million in budget cuts and savings </a>after city commissioners agreed to consider a 23% increase in property taxes <a href="https://talgov.com/Uploads/Public/Documents/dma/pdf/2016proposedfaq.pdf">justified to fund additional police officers</a>. Last week, <a href="http://www.tallahassee.com/story/news/2015/09/20/property-tax-debate-challenges-budget-process/72508128/">commissioners reduced the increase to 13%</a>, but many, including the <a href="http://www.tallahassee.com/story/opinion/editorials/2015/09/19/opinion-better/72423600/">editors of the <i>Tallahassee Democrat</i></a>, are not convinced that even this modest increase is necessary. The details of the 14-point plan along with <a href="http://tallahasseereports.com/2015/09/15/citizens-group-details-path-to-no-property-tax-increase-proposes-9-5-million-in-adjustments/">full coverage of the proposal can be found at <i>Tallahassee Reports</i></a>, a newspaper that serves as a local government watchdog.<!--more-->\n\nCitizens for Responsible Spending, the architect of the spending and savings plan, is an umbrella group formerly known as the Budget Hawks. The new group attempts to do what city staff have been reluctant to: find modest savings in other parts of the city budget to stave off a property tax increase. <a href="http://www.floridataxwatch.org/">Florida TaxWatch CEO </a>Dominic Calabro argued at a press conference announcing the proposal that a 23% increase in property tax simply isn’t justified when inflation is increasing at 1% per year and the city’s population isn’t growing significantly.\n\nWhile $9.5 million might seem like a lot \xa0of money to cut or shift around, the proposed savings are modest in the context of a <a href="http://www.boarddocs.com/fla/talgov/Board.nsf/files/9XJU5W62591D/$file/D%20-%20Operating%20Budget%20Appropriations%20and%20Financial%20Summary.pdf">$685.8 million (proposed) annual operating budget</a>. As Calabro said: “This is easy.” In fact, I learned as budget analyst and executive in several think tanks that finding savings in some areas to boost more important initiatives comes with the job. As a rule of thumb I realized that as a practical matter almost <a href="http://reason.org/blog/show/the-ten-percent-rule">any cut of up to 10% could be managed</a> without realigning strategic priorities. The savings proposed by Citizens for Responsible Spending amount to less than 1.5% of the city’s operating budget. The fact city staff are balking at 1.5% is an indicator that they haven’t thoroughly examined their own priorities and spending patterns.\n\nThe city is justifying higher property taxes on the <a href="https://talgov.com/Uploads/Public/Documents/dma/pdf/2016proposedfaq.pdf">addition of 18 new police positions</a>. This presumes that nothing else in the budget can be rearranged, priorities shifted, or lower valued programs and initiatives cut. However, the citizens group, which consists of lay people (non-experts), suggested <a href="http://tallahasseereports.com/2015/09/15/citizens-group-details-path-to-no-property-tax-increase-proposes-9-5-million-in-adjustments/">cutting four unfilled full-time equivalent staff</a> in non-essential departments that could provide budgetary savings $400,000. Better management to reduce overtime, they said, could save another $484,000.\n\nThese types of savings could be identified by city staff if they used zero-based budgeting, a process that ensures programs, initiatives, and spending are held accountable to the city’s mission and produces measurable results and outcomes. In the most pure form, this process has staff start with no allocation--a zero base--and build their budget based on performance, mission appropriateness, and value added.\n\nThe idea that 100% of Tallahassee’s current budget is performing at levels where 1.4% can’t be reallocated to fund new police officers does not pass the common sense test, and is certainly inconsistent with what most budget analysts experience. If the city budget truly is this tight, zero-based budgeting would provide the evidence that the increase is justified based on productivity and impact. It would also give citizens the confidence they need to know city officials are taking their concerns seriously.\n\nThe proposals put forth by Citizens for Responsible Spending are very modest, even inconsequential from a budgetary perspective. In presenting their proposal, however, concerned citizens have helped uncover systemic flaws in the City of Tallahassee budgets for spending and programs. The task for the city is to use this public flap to begin the more earnest task of reforming the budget process.'), ('excerpt:encoded', 'Proposed tax increase in Tallahassee shows broken budget process. Zero-based budgeting would help.'), ('wp:post_id', '315'), ('wp:post_date', '2015-09-21 19:43:31'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2015-09-21 19:43:31'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', OrderedDict([('title', 'Citizens Property Insurance Corporation is Regressive and Risky'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2015/09/28/citizens-property-insurance-corporation-is-regressive-and-risky/'), ('pubDate', 'Mon, 28 Sep 2015 21:08:42 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=320')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'By Matt Kelly\n\nCitizens Property Insurance Corporation was formed by the Florida Legislature in 2002 for the purpose of serving Florida’s residual property insurance market. Its creation was justified by the argument that middle-income residents have a tough time purchasing insurance in a hurricane-prone state like Florida, and public subsidies were needed to even the playing field for these struggling families. Recent economic research, however, has shown that Citizens is actually a regressive program that disproportionately benefits the wealthy.\n\n[caption id="attachment_322" align="alignright" width="300"]<a href="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2015/09/logue-and-ben-shahir-map.png"><img class="wp-image-322 size-medium" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2015/09/logue-and-ben-shahir-map.png?w=300" alt="Logue and Ben-Shahir map" width="300" height="277" /></a> FIGURE 1: Dark green areas are the most subsidized. From Logue and Ben-Shahir (2015).[/caption]\n\n<a href="http://repository.law.umich.edu/law_econ_current/111/">In a 2015 paper</a>,<a href="https://www.law.umich.edu/FacultyBio/Pages/FacultyBio.aspx?FacID=klogue"> Kyle D. Logue</a> of The University of Michigan and<a href="http://www.law.uchicago.edu/faculty/ben-shahar"> Omri Ben-Shahar</a> of the University of Chicago show that the amount of subsidy a household receives from Citizens increases with wealth. Insurance premiums for more expensive beachside properties are actually the most subsidized, turning the political justification for Citizens’ existence on its head. Figure 1 shows this wealth redistribution with a map from Logue and Ben-Shahir’s paper. The darker shades of green correspond to more subsidized customers. In fact, lower-risk inland regions often pay higher premiums in order to fund these generous subsidies to affluent coastal homeowners.<!--more-->\n\n<a href="http://www.floir.com/">Florida’s Office of Insurance Regulation</a> (OIR) is ultimately responsible for setting Citizens’ rates, and their policy of favoring affluent coastal homeowners may get even worse. Citizens recently asked the OIR that they be allowed to increase rates, in part to cover water-loss claims in South Florida. Contrary to Citizens’ own recommendations,<a href="http://www.floir.com/siteDocuments/Citizens176885-15-O.pdf"> the OIR ordered that rates should increase slightly more for low-risk areas, and slightly less for high-risk coastal areas.</a> This rate change may redistribute even more wealth from Florida’s taxpayers and insurance policyholders to Citizens’ wealthy and high-risk customers.\n\nLogue and Ben-Shahir also point out that “the subsidies induce excessive development (and redevelopment) of storm-stricken and erosion-prone areas.” Citizens-subsidized premiums make high-risk properties appear cheaper than a free market would allow, encouraging development where storms pose the biggest threat. This also leaves every taxpayer and insurance policyholder in Florida on the hook to cover damages in the event of a catastrophic storm. As a publicly funded company, Citizens can tap into state funds and extract assessments from other insurance policyholders throughout the state, an advantage not enjoyed by private companies that must operate within their means.\n\nThough efforts to reduce Citizens’ exposure have brought the number of its policies-in-force down from a peak of 1.5 million to fewer than 600,000, it remains Florida’s largest property insurer by customer count.\n\n[caption id="attachment_325" align="alignright" width="400"]<a href="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2015/09/citizens-graph.png"><img class="wp-image-325" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2015/09/citizens-graph.png?w=300" alt="Citizens graph" width="400" height="220" /></a> FIGURE 2: The private market has picked up the slack as Citizens depopulates. Data from Florida\'s Office of Insurance Regulation.[/caption]\n<p style="text-align:left;">There is reason to believe Florida would be better off without Citizens. The private market has increased the number of properties it insures as Citizens has reduced its own (see Figure 2), indicating that private insurers are able and willing to serve the residual market. Growth in the private market means property insurance premiums in Florida will more accurately reflect the risk associated with the property. Lawmakers should continue to depopulate Citizens in order to halt its regressive subsidies and allow private insurance companies to encourage safer and less risky development.</p>'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '320'), ('wp:post_date', '2015-09-28 21:08:42'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2015-09-28 21:08:42'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), OrderedDict([('title', 'Privatize the Florida Retirement System'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2015/10/02/privatize-the-florida-retirement-system/'), ('pubDate', 'Fri, 02 Oct 2015 15:07:28 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=327')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'By Randall G. Holcombe, Ph.D.\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;"><a href="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2015/10/pension-379671.jpg"><img class="size-medium wp-image-328 alignright" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2015/10/pension-379671.jpg?w=300" alt="pension-379671" width="300" height="178" /></a>Over the past few years both Governor Scott and several members of the Florida legislature have been pushing the idea of transforming the <a href="https://www.myfrs.com/" target="_blank">Florida Retirement System </a>(FRS), which pays pensions to retired state workers, from a defined benefit system into a defined contribution system. \xa0<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Defined_benefit_pension_plan" target="_blank">A defined benefit system</a>, which covers most state workers today, pays a specific monthly benefit determined by the number of years worked and the worker’s salary leading up to retirement. \xa0<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Defined_contribution_plan" target="_blank">A defined contribution system</a> pays a certain amount every year into an account owned by the employee, and the pension amount is determined by how much money the retiree’s account has accumulated in contributions and earnings on those contributions.</span><!--more-->\n\nDefined benefit plans face the problem that governments can make promises to pay future pensions without setting aside the money to fund them. \xa0Eventually, the plans run out of money and can’t pay the promised pensions. \xa0Then, either the government must come up with more funding, or pensions must be cut, or some combination of the two. \xa0Defined contribution plans avoid this problem because the future pension is determined by the amount of money going in. \xa0That money is the property of the employee, and future government financial problems can’t erode retiree pensions. \xa0Defined contribution plans offer advantages to both employers and employees.\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">I agree that the state should shift FRS to defined contribution pensions, but really, the proposals from Governor Scott and reform-minded legislators do not go far enough. \xa0Many private investment firms are in the business of operating defined contribution pension plans. \xa0We should not only shift to defined contribution plans, but privatize those plans for new workers. \xa0The state does not need to operate a pension system because there are private sector firms who specialize in doing just that. \xa0Get the state out of the pension business altogether.</span>'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '327'), ('wp:post_date', '2015-10-02 15:07:28'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2015-10-02 15:07:28'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'privatize-the-florida-retirement-system'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', [OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'defined-benefit'), ('#text', 'defined benefit')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', spiral toward insolvency. Here is Dr. Holcombe with a viable solution for Florida\'s pension system.'), ('wp:comment_approved', '1'), ('wp:comment_type', None), ('wp:comment_parent', '0'), ('wp:comment_user_id', '73351328'), OrderedDict([('title', 'Thaw in Cuban Economic Sanctions May Heat Up  Florida’s Economy'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2015/10/05/thaw-in-cuban-economic-sanctions-may-heat-up-floridas-economy/'), ('pubDate', 'Mon, 05 Oct 2015 20:46:19 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=334')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', '<p dir="ltr">By: Roberto Cordovez*</p>\n\n\n[caption id="attachment_335" align="aligncenter" width="419"]<a href="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2015/10/150414_cuba_obama_castro_gty_1160_1160x629.jpg"><img class=" wp-image-335" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2015/10/150414_cuba_obama_castro_gty_1160_1160x629.jpg?w=300" alt="Cuba\'s President Raul Castro (L) speaks during a meeting with US President Barack Obama on the sidelines of the Summit of the Americas at the ATLAPA Convention center on April 11, 2015 in Panama City. AFP PHOTO/MANDEL NGAN (Photo credit should read MANDEL NGAN/AFP/Getty Images)" width="419" height="228" /></a> Cuba\'s President Raul Castro (L) speaks during a meeting with US President Barack Obama on the sidelines of the Summit of the Americas at the ATLAPA Convention center on April 11, 2015 in Panama City. AFP PHOTO/MANDEL NGAN (Photo credit should read MANDEL NGAN/AFP/Getty Images)[/caption]\n<p dir="ltr">Pope Francis’ trip to Havana has put Cuba back in the spotlight as America continues journey toward normalizing relations between the two nations. While most believe normalization will be a boon for Cuba’s economy, few have explored the implications for Florida’s economy.<!--more--></p>\n<p dir="ltr">A 2014 poll conducted by Florida International University professors Guillermo J. Grenier and Hugh Gladwin found that 68% of Cubans living in Miami favored improved diplomatic relations with Cuba while more than two thirds favored unrestricted travel by all Americans to Cuba.</p>\n<p dir="ltr">These attitudes are consistent with research that questions the benefits of economic sanctions. The Peterson Institute for International Economics found that in 116 cases of economic sanctions spanning the years 1914 through 1990, the overall success rate in meeting their goals, including regime change or changing target country economic policies, was 34 percent (or 39 cases). The study also found that the rate of success dropped to 26 percent, or around 20 cases, for the more recent years 1970 through 1989. Interestingly, the years that the success rate fell coincided with the years of the Cold war where tensions between US and the Soviet Union, and by proxy Cuba, were a primary driver of policies involving sanctions.</p>\n<p dir="ltr">As a research assistant working at the DeVoe Moore Center at Florida State University, I examined the potential effects of sanctions imposed on Cuba on 19 of Florida metropolitan area economies. I found mixed evidence on the effects of certain sanctions imposed on Cuba at the regional level (by the Organization of American States) and at the transcontinental level (European Union). Using a “gravity model”, a technique that estimates economic impacts by identifying economic “pulls” or attractions, I found a slight drop in exports by Florida metropolitan areas when the European Union sanctions were in place between 2003 and 2008. This may have been the result of the lower incentives for European businesses to invest in Cuba and its surrounding areas which include Florida.</p>\n<p dir="ltr">My analysis also found that while the Organization of American States had a ban exports to Cuba, Florida’s metropolitan areas experienced a slight increase in their number of exports. This may be attributed to Florida absorbing a portion of Cuba’s export market thanks to the geographical similarities between the neighboring countries.</p>\n<p dir="ltr">Despite these sanctions, Florida remained a central hub for economic activity for travelers, families and businesses invested in Cuba. Florida hosts the two largest U.S. gateways to Cuba: Miami and Tampa. \xa0Since 2011, more than 164,000 passengers have flown into and out of Tampa on trips leading to Cuba. This traffic volume is likely to increase as direct flights to Havana become more frequent.</p>\n<p dir="ltr">Rising tourism and increased cruise ship activity are other benefits to Florida as a result of thawed economic relations. Carnival Cruise Line reports that they are preparing to start trips to Cuba as early as May 2016 as part of cultural exchange trips through a program called Fathom. Given Florida’s position as a cruise line capital, with some of the world’s most active ports at Cape Canaveral, Port Everglades in Fort Lauderdale, and Port Miami, cruise volume is likely to increase significantly.</p>\n<p dir="ltr">In sum, lifting economic sanctions and normalizing trade between the two countries will allow Florida’s economy to grow and take advantage of natural synergies between the two economies. This will foster friendly competition between the regional players and, in the long run, will help create a more stable foundation for the regional economy of the gulf. The process of normalization can bring Florida many opportunities for tourism as well as other sectors of the economy.</p>\n<p dir="ltr"><em>*Roberto Cordovez is an econo</em><em>mics graduate of Florida State University and research assistant in the DeVoe L. Moore Center in the College of Social Sciences and Public Policy. He is currently involved with business investments in India and Africa.</em></p>'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '334'), ('wp:post_date', '2015-10-05 20:46:19'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2015-10-05 20:46:19'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'thaw-in-cuban-economic-sanctions-may-heat-up-floridas-economy'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), This rule marks a continuation of one of the largest and most controversial disputes over governmental jurisdiction in water policy history. Recently, the U.S. Sixth District Court of Appeals</span><a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/volokh-conspiracy/wp/2015/10/09/sixth-circuit-puts-controversial-waters-of-the-united-states-wotus-rule-on-hold/"><span style="font-weight:400;"> issued a stay against the EPA and Army Corps</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> preventing the rule from being implemented. This is probably good news for Florida. </span><!--more-->\n\nUnder the new rule, tributaries, “adjacent water bodies,” land within the 100-year floodplain, and, in some cases, water within 4,000 feet of a tributary or other covered water, are now under The Corps’ and EPA’s direct regulatory authority.\n\n<a href="http://www.jamesmadison.org/wp-content/uploads/Waters-of-the-U.S.-2015.pdf" target="_blank"><span style="font-weight:400;">In a recent policy report</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"><a href="http://www.jamesmadison.org/wp-content/uploads/Waters-of-the-U.S.-2015.pdf" target="_blank">\xa0from the James Madison Institute</a>, M.Reed Hopper and Mark Miller, attorneys at Pacific Legal Foundation, claim “its [W.O.T.U.S. rule] \xa0implementation puts </span><span style="font-weight:400;">virtually all waters and much of the land in Florida under the control of the Army Corps of Engineers and the EPA”.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Under the provisions of the new rule,</span><a href="http://www.usace.army.mil/Portals/2/docs/civilworks/regulatory/news/final_CWR_eco_analysis.pdf"> <span style="font-weight:400;">34.5 percent \xa0of “other waters” are now under EPA jurisdiction</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">, adding between 2.84 and 4.65 percent of total waters to EPA regulatory authority.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">The </span><span style="font-weight:400;">EPA itself estimates this change in the Clean Water Act’s scope will cost Americans</span><a href="http://www.gao.gov/assets/680/671628.pdf"> <span style="font-weight:400;">$158 million-$465 million</span></a> <span style="font-weight:400;">a year. The land and livelihoods of many Floridians could be threatened by the high costs of these federal regulations. </span><span style="font-weight:400;">Most Floridians with land under the EPA’s jurisdiction would be required to obtain a federal permit to alter or use their property.</span><a href="http://are.berkeley.edu/~sunding/Economcs%20of%20Environmental%20Regulation.pdf"> <span style="font-weight:400;">The historical cost of federal individual permits average more than $270,000 (and rang from $7,000 to $1,530,000)</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Now, property developers must obtain permits to fill any water or wetlands on the property. They are also required to make payments to a</span><a href="http://www.floridamitigationbanking.org/mitigationbanks/"> <span style="font-weight:400;">mitigation bank</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> for those filled wetlands—payments that range between</span><a href="http://www.usace.army.mil/Portals/2/docs/civilworks/regulatory/news/final_CWR_eco_analysis.pdf"> <span style="font-weight:400;">$34,000 to $217,800 per acre</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">. According to</span><a href="http://www.law360.com/articles/682313/fla-will-go-with-the-flow-on-epa-waters-of-the-us-rule"> <span style="font-weight:400;">Gregory Munson</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">, former Florida Deputy Secretary of Water Policy and Ecosystem Restoration, “the new rule likely means that more waters, especially wetlands, on their [property owner’s] property will be categorized as ‘waters of the United States,’ and thereby subject them [property developers] to permitting and mitigation requirements under federal law more often.” Additional steps in the regulatory process mean a more lengthy approval process that could stall economic development in the state’s rural areas.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">This new rule could also </span><a href="http://www.jamesmadison.org/wp-content/uploads/Waters-of-the-U.S.-2015.pdf"><span style="font-weight:400;">hinder local governments’</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> ability to build and maintain infrastructure such as new road construction, ditch management, water treatment facilities and stormwater systems because they will also have to apply for and receive \xa0federal permits for new projects and alterations.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">While the EPA claims that the benefits of this regulation outweigh the costs, Dr. David Sunding, a professor of economics at the University of California, Berkeley, </span><a href="http://www.brattle.com/system/publications/pdfs/000/005/014/original/WOTUS-Economic-Report_Sunding_WAC_0514.pdf?1401975706"><span style="font-weight:400;">argues</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> that the EPA underestimates the acreage that the proposed rule will regulate and does accurately consider the costs and increased number of required permitting actions.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Everyone wants to protect our nation’s waters but it’s important to consider whether that’s worth this rule’s cost to Floridians, especially if we are unsure of the exact cost. The U.S. Court of Appeals decision halting the implementation of this new rule is probably a good one for Florida property owners.</span>'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '339'), ('wp:post_date', '2015-10-09 23:10:58'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2015-10-09 23:10:58'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'epas-w-o-t-u-s-rule-would-affect-much-of-florida'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', [OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'army-corps-of-engineers'), ('#text', 'Army Corps of Engineers')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'environment'), ('#text', 'environment')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'environmental-protection-agency'), ('#text', 'Environmental Protection Agency')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'epa'), ('#text', 'EPA')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'floodplains'), ('#text', 'Floodplains')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'florida'), ('#text', 'Florida')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'land-use'), ('#text', 'Land Use')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'politics-2'), ('#text', 'Politics')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'regulation'), ('#text', 'regulation')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'regulation-2'), ('#text', 'Regulation')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'water-policy'), ('#text', 'Water Policy')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'waters-of-the-united-states'), ('#text', 'Waters of the United States')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'wotus'), ('#text', 'WOTUS')])]), ('wp:postmeta', [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_published'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_client_id'), ('wp:meta_value', '-1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2015/10/wakulla-springs-edward-ball-state-park.jpg')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', None), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '340'), ('wp:post_date', '2015-10-09 23:10:27'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2015-10-09 23:10:27'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'closed'), ('wp:post_name', 'wakulla-springs-edward-ball-state-park'), ('wp:status', 'inherit'), ('wp:post_parent', '339'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'attachment'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('wp:attachment_url', 'https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2015/10/wakulla-springs-edward-ball-state-park.jpg'), ('wp:postmeta', [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wp_attached_file'), ('wp:meta_value', '/home/wpcom/public_html/wp-content/blogs.dir/848/80998613/files/2015/10/wakulla-springs-edward-ball-state-park.jpg')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wp_attachment_metadata'), ('wp:meta_value', 'a:5:{s:5:"width";i:1609;s:6:"height";i:1119;s:4:"file";s:114:"/home/wpcom/public_html/wp-content/blogs.dir/848/80998613/files/2015/10/wakulla-springs-edward-ball-state-park.jpg";s:5:"sizes";a:0:{}s:10:"image_meta";a:11:{s:8:"aperture";d:8;s:6:"credit";s:0:"";s:6:"camera";s:11:"NIKON
