OrderedDict([('title', 'FDA Rules May Vaporize The E-cigarette Industry'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2015/11/02/fda-rules-may-vaporize-the-e-cigarette-industry/'), ('pubDate', 'Mon, 02 Nov 2015 19:23:07 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=342')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', '<a href="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2015/11/vape.jpg"><img class="wp-image-343 alignright" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2015/11/vape.jpg?w=300" alt="vape" width="354" height="215" /></a>By Kevin Gomez\n\nIn the last three years, the electronic-cigarette business has exploded. According to Wells Fargo Securities, the “vaping” industry has gone from estimated revenue of $1 billion in 2012 to <a href="http://www.miamiherald.com/news/local/article28764616.html">$3.5 billion </a>in 2015. Although much more research is needed to assess e-cigarettes health effects, <a href="https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/457102/Ecigarettes_an_evidence_update_A_report_commissioned_by_Public_Health_England_FINAL.pdf">some medical professionals say it is at least healthier than smoking</a>. <a href="https://www.congress.gov/bill/114th-congress/house-bill/2058/text">New rules</a> that expand the Food and Drug Administration’s (FDA) authority to regulate vaping, however, will likely halt growth and favor large companies over smaller ones.<!--more-->\n\nE-cigarettes, or “vapes,” have a small heater that vaporizes a mixture of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glycerol">glycerine</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Propylene_glycol">propylene glycol</a> infused with nicotine and flavorings, commonly called “e-juice.” This chemical reaction creates a breathable smoke-like mist for users to inhale. E-cigarettes come in many different styles. Customization vapes, called “mods,” have a digital component which controls \xa0nicotine levels and the voltage/wattage of the heater.\n\n<a href="http://ntr.oxfordjournals.org/content/15/9/1623.short">A study by the Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)</a> shows that electronic-cigarette users are mostly cigarette smokers, and <a href="http://ntr.oxfordjournals.org/content/17/2/245.short">another study from Emory University</a> shows most users are attracted to their purportedly less harmful effects. \xa0However, the American Lung Association, American Heart Association, and other medical groups are concerned that e-cigarettes could <a href="http://heartinsight.heart.org/August-2014/Can-E-cigarettes-Help-You-Quit-Smoking/">pose a serious health risk to children and adults. </a>Although some <a href="http://www.jwatch.org/fw109119/2014/07/31/e-cigarettes-safer-alternative-regular-cigarettes?query=pfw">studies</a> support e-cigarettes relative health benefits, <a href="http://www.addiction.com/6300/e-cigarette-laws/">scientists are not in complete agreement</a>.\n\nCurrently, close to 7,000 vape stores exist in the US, UK, and Canada according to an <a href="https://www.vapeabout.com/datadownload/index.php">online vape shop database</a>, and over 210 stores in Florida.\n\nThe current vape market is relatively unregulated. Under the FDA’s proposed rules, however, e-juice makers would have to <a href="http://www.fda.gov/downloads/TobaccoProducts/NewsEvents/UCM397724.pdf">register products with the FDA</a>, undergo a review process, and publicly report ingredient listings. Regulatory consultants at SciLucent LLC claim the costs of introducing an e-juice flavor under the new rules would amount to <a href="http://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10130211234592774869404581088451777513530?alg=y&amp;cb=logged0.5364477611146867">between $2 million to $10 million</a> per product. Stores will also no longer allow customers to sample e-juice flavors on premises before purchasing them. This would be a significant blow to boutique e-juice makers, whose more exotic flavors would not only be more expensive, but also aren’t likely to be purchased without consumers trying them first.\n\nVapes purportedly offer relative health benefits to smokers at a lower price than cigarettes. According to the CDC, cigarette smoking in the United States has declined from 273 billion cigarettes sold in 2013 to <a href="http://www.cdc.gov/tobacco/data_statistics/fact_sheets/economics/econ_facts/index.htm#spending">264 billion</a> in 2014. While <a href="https://www.heartland.org/policy-documents/research-commentary-west-virginia-sin-taxes-and-vaping">sin taxes</a> on cigarettes, which make the unhealthy habit more expensive for smokers, have contributed to this fall, <a href="http://www.michiganjb.org/issues/2/article4.pdf">a study from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology</a>, contends that “widespread and readily available information about the severe side effects of cigarette smoking” has had the greatest impact.\n\nIn an attempt to curb declining cigarette sales, big tobacco companies have entered the e-cigarette market, but are pushing for the new rules that will likely eliminate their competition. <a href="http://quotes.wsj.com/RAI">Reynolds</a>, the second largest tobacco company in the US, has created its own e-cig, the “Vuse,” and has <a href="http://www.fda.gov/downloads/advisorycommittees/committeesmeetingmaterials/tobaccoproductsscientificadvisorycommittee/ucm441429.pdf">strongly supported FDA intervention into smokeless tobacco products</a>. The added regulatory costs of new FDA rules can be easily absorbed by large tobacco companies, but will be more difficult for smaller companies.\n\nIronically, a heavy-handed approach to regulating vapes may actually tip the scales in favor of traditional big tobacco. With increased momentum in favor of regulation, the FDA’s proposed rules could halt growth in an emerging industry and reduce access to a smoking alternative.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), 19:21:56 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2015/11/vape.jpg')])), ('description', 'a:5:{s:5:"width";i:768;s:6:"height";i:467;s:4:"file";s:80:"/home/wpcom/public_html/wp-content/blogs.dir/848/80998613/files/2015/11/vape.jpg";s:5:"sizes";a:0:{}s:10:"image_meta";a:11:{s:8:"aperture";i:0;s:6:"credit";s:0:"";s:6:"camera";s:0:"";s:7:"caption";s:0:"";s:17:"created_timestamp";i:0;s:9:"copyright";s:0:"";s:12:"focal_length";i:0;s:3:"iso";i:0;s:13:"shutter_speed";i:0;s:5:"title";s:0:"";s:11:"orientation";i:1;}}')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', 'Fix the FRS Before It Breaks'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2015/11/12/fix-the-frs-before-it-breaks/'), ('pubDate', 'Thu, 12 Nov 2015 18:33:06 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=348')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', '<span style="font-weight:400;"><img class="alignright" src="http://www.michigancapitolconfidential.com/media/images/2012/pension-reform.jpg" alt="" width="345" height="259" /></span>\n\nBy Randall G. Holcombe, Ph.D.\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">In a recent blog post I argued in favor of shifting the </span><a href="http://www.myfrs.com/index.htm"><span style="font-weight:400;">Florida Retirement System (FRS)</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> that provides pensions for retired state workers to a defined contribution system, and privatizing the system. Governor Scott and many legislators favor the shift to a defined contribution system, and because many private companies provide these systems for employers, there is no reason for the state to be involved at all. Let private companies handle the pension system for state workers. Let’s look at two arguments against this, to see why they don’t hold up.</span>\n\n<!--more-->\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">First, critics of privatization note that FRS is running well as it is, and argue “If it ain’t broke, don’t fix it.” The problem with this argument is that the time to fix it is before it breaks, not after. FRS is, at the moment, </span><a href="http://www.pewtrusts.org/en/multimedia/data-visualizations/2015/the-fiscal-health-of-state-pension-plans"><span style="font-weight:400;">about 80% funded</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">, or maybe less, depending on who’s doing the calculations, but nobody calculates that it is fully funded. That’s already a problem, but not as big a problem as in some other states like Illinois and California that face substantial unfunded liabilities. </span><a href="http://jacksonville.com/news/metro/2015-01-27/story/florida-warns-pension-plans-fix-your-sinking-ships"><span style="font-weight:400;">Many of Florida’s local governments do also</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">. FRS “ain’t broke” only in comparison to many other government pension plans that are in much worse shape, but it still has unfunded liabilities. The main counter argument isn’t that the system is broken now, however, but that the time for reform is before FRS runs into the same problems that dog so many government pension plans.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">A second argument is that the current </span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Defined_benefit_pension_plan"><span style="font-weight:400;">defined benefit plan</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> is better for workers and retirees, but that’s not true either. For one thing, with a privatized </span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Defined_contribution_plan"><span style="font-weight:400;">defined contribution system</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">, money is deposited into the employee’s account and belongs to the employee. A defined benefit plan depends on FRS remaining solvent as long as the employee lives. Current employees’ benefits depend on the system being in good shape after they retire, which may not be true even if it is in good shape now. A defined contribution plan avoids this problem. Second, while retirees in a defined contribution plan can annuitize their retirement benefit to get a guaranteed amount every month, they don’t have to. For employees with substantial assets, they can just withdraw money when they need it, and leave the amount in their accounts when they die to their heirs. This option is not available with a defined benefit plan. Third, while some argue that the retirement benefits are greater with a defined benefit plan, this isn’t necessarily true. It depends on how much the state kicks in during the employee’s period of employment. A fourth benefit is that employees are immediately vested in a defined contribution plan. Short-term employees in a defined benefit plan may not work long enough to get vested.</span>\n\nShifting FRS to defined contribution plans and privatizing it offers benefits to the state, to taxpayers, to employees, and to retirees.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '348'), ('wp:post_date', '2015-11-12 18:33:06'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2015-11-12 18:33:06'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'fix-the-frs-before-it-breaks'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', [OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'defined-benefit'), ('#text', 'defined benefit')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'devoe-moore-center'), ('#text', 'DeVoe Moore Center')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'fiscal-policy'), ('#text', 'Fiscal Policy')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'florida-retirement-system'), ('#text', 'Florida Retirement System')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'pension-reform'), ('#text', 'pension reform')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'public-pensions'), ('#text', 'public pensions')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'rick-scott'), ('#text', 'Rick Scott')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'taxpayers'), ('#text', 'taxpayers')])]), ('wp:postmeta', [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_published'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_client_id'), ('wp:meta_value', '-1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_publicize_job_id'), ('wp:meta_value', '16793571541')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', "Florida's Tourism Development Tax"), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2015/11/23/floridas-tourism-development-taxes/'), ('pubDate', 'Mon, 23 Nov 2015 19:08:16 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=350')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'By Erick Winterkamp\n\n[gallery ids="355,356" type="rectangular"]\n\nPolicymakers experience conflicting pressure concerning taxation. Corporations want taxation on competing products and industries, government officials often need more taxation to cover rising expenses, and the public would rather taxes be levied on anyone but themselves. Balancing these opposing factors, along with elected officials’ desire for reelection, results in a myriad of taxation policies. To appease conflicting interests in crafting tax policy, economists often recommend using the<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ramsey_problem"> Ramsey rule</a>, which aims to minimize the distortions caused by taxation. While this goal of optimizing taxation is laudable, the Ramsey rule has limitations.<!--more-->\n\nThe Ramsey rule recommends taxes be levied on goods with <a href="http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/inelastic-demand">inelastic demand,</a> products where \xa0demand is less responsive to changes in price. For instance, if the price of gasoline rises $5 per gallon, the amount consumed won’t substantially change in the short run because there is no good alternative. On the other hand, if the price of Oreo cookies increases by $5 per package, the quantity demanded will likely drop since consumers can opt for an equivalent product, or forgo Oreos altogether.\n\nThe goal of the Ramsey rule is to reduce what economists call “<a href="http://www.investopedia.com/terms/d/deadweightloss.asp?adtest=term_page_v14_v2">deadweight loss</a>.” Deadweight loss is the negative effect of an inefficient allocation of resources due to a tax or other government intervention. Since consumers are less likely to decrease the quantity demanded of goods with inelastic demand when prices increase due to a tax, the Ramsey rule suggests taxes be applied to such goods. In the hypothetical example above, the rule suggests policymakers tax gasoline, not Oreos.\n\nThere are some limitations to this, however, as explained by DeVoe Moore scholar Randall Holcombe in<a href="http://pfr.sagepub.com/content/30/6/562.abstract"> a paper titled, “The Ramsey Rule Reconsidered.”</a> Policymakers in charge of tax policies can’t observe every price point along a demand curve, and thus cannot say how much the quantity sold will drop in response to an increase in price. Demand elasticities also change with consumer preferences, so once efficient tax policies can become inefficient over time. As new innovators enter the market, tax regimes may be slow to adapt. Politics are also important. Businesses have incentives to sponsor research claiming their competitors’ products are more resilient to taxation than their own. In a perfect world, the Ramsey rule might work just fine, but lack of information, dynamic changes in the economy over time, and special interests can affect the implementation process to create a less than optimal tax system.\n\nAn example of the Ramsey rule is the<a href="http://www.occompt.com/finance/tourist-development-tax/"> Tourist Development Tax (TDT)</a> levied by some counties in Florida. TDT is levied exclusively on short-term lodging (property rented &amp; property rentals), like hotel rooms and other accommodations rented for fewer than six months. Tourists are said to have a relatively inelastic demand for hotel lodging, since a few hundred extra dollars in lodging costs isn’t likely to deter them from a vacation they’ve saved for all year. Counties, such as Orange and Miami-Dade, with significant tourism activity are allowed to levy higher tax rates, given the more inelastic demand presumed for their attractions. Revenues from TDT fund tourism-related projects like convention centers and arenas, along with related advertising (in accordance with<a href="http://www.leg.state.fl.us/statutes/index.cfm?App_mode=Display_Statute&amp;URL=0100-0199/0125/Sections/0125.0104.html"> F.S. 125.014</a>), to support the tourism industry in Florida.\n\nMarket disruptors in the hotel business like <a href="https://www.airbnb.com/">Airbnb</a> may make TDT less viable over time as <a href="http://priceonomics.com/hotels/">brick and mortar hotels must compete</a>. New innovators are <a href="http://www.wtsp.com/story/news/local/2015/05/14/is-airbnb-costing-tampa-bay/27343827/">more difficult to tax</a> and change the demand for existing hotels. If consumer preferences change in response to such innovations, TDT may create more distortions and increased deadweight loss.\n\nThe statutory restrictions placed on the allocation of TDT funds are supported by the tourism lobby and sometimes prevent local governments from spending the funds in ways they believe might be more productive. As<a href="http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2013-04-23/business/os-bed-tax-for-lifeguards-20130422_1_hotel-taxes-tourism-industry-beach-patrol"> reported by the <i>Orlando Sentinel</i></a><i>,</i> Okaloosa County diverted $2.5 million in TDT funds to beach patrol and lifeguard salaries and away from items like tourism advertising. The thinking was lifeguards increase safety, which draws more tourists. The county faced open opposition from the<a href="http://www.fadmo.org"> Florida Association of Destination Marketing Organizations</a> and the<a href="https://www.frla.org/"> Florida Restaurant and Lodging Association</a>, despite backing from the President of the Florida Senate,<a href="http://www.flsenate.gov/Senators/s1"> Don Gaetz</a> [R].\n\nLimited information, changes over time, and political pressures make applying the Ramsey rule in the real world problematic. Taxes like the TDT, however well designed, cannot eliminate deadweight losses and are still vulnerable to inefficiencies and manipulation.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '350'), OrderedDict([('title', "Occupational Licensing For Florida's Barbers Does More Harm Than Good"), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2015/12/08/occupational-licensing-floridas-barbers-does-more-harm-than-good/'), ('pubDate', 'Tue, 08 Dec 2015 16:22:54 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=363')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'By Jamaal Gill\n\n<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-369" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2015/12/baltimore-barbershop-barber-haircut-dsc_0069.jpg" alt="Baltimore-Barbershop-Barber-Haircut-DSC_0069" width="6016" height="4000" />\n\nThe rise of occupational licensing has become a major concern to Florida’s businesses. <a href="http://www.leg.state.fl.us/Statutes/index.cfm?App_mode=Display_Statute&amp;URL=0400-0499/0476/0476.html">These regulations</a> affect everyone from doctors to restauranteurs; barbers to financial advisors. The main justifications for occupational licensing are the promotion of consumer welfare, public health, and a higher quality service. However, in many professions, occupational licensing keeps barriers to entry high while providing little benefit to public health and safety.<!--more-->\n\nAn occupational license is a statewide certification that one must acquire in order to conduct business in the state legally. Consider the effect of occupational licensing on barbers. In order to<a href="http://www.myfloridalicense.com/dbpr/pro/barb/documents/barbers_faq.pdf"> become a licensed barber in Florida</a>, one must first enroll in an accredited barber school. After completing 1200 hours of training to graduate, one can apply for a <a href="https://www.myfloridalicense.com/CheckListDetail.asp?SID=&amp;xactCode=1010&amp;clientCode=0301&amp;XACT_DEFN_ID=5060">barber’s license</a>. As of December 1, 2015, the application fee was <a href="http://www.myfloridalicense.com/dbpr/pro/forms/feepops/0301_1010.html">$178</a>. The application must be approved by the <a href="http://www.myfloridalicense.com/dbpr/">Department of Business and Professional Regulation</a>. Once approved, the applicant waits for contact from <a href="http://home.pearsonvue.com/">a designated testing service</a> in order to complete a three and a half hour long exam. On average, the cost of completing the schooling, application and permit fees is around <a href="http://www.beautyschoolsdirectory.com/faq/barber_schools.php#cost-of-barber-school">$10,000</a> from a public institution. If training is received at a private institution, the average cost of schooling increases to around $20,000.\n\nOne way to evaluate Florida’s licensing system is to compare it with other states. In <a href="http://learn.org/articles/Which_Schools_Offer_Training_to_Become_a_Barber_in_New_York_City.html">New York</a>, barbers are required to complete only 288 educational hours and an apprenticeship in order to be licensed. Florida’s licensing requirements exceed this by 912 hours.\n\nAnother way to evaluate Florida’s occupational licensing system is to measure the cost of obtaining a license as a proportion of annual income. A barber working 40 hours a week and making the state’s <a href="http://www.bls.gov/oes/current/oes395011.htm">average hourly wage of $12.93</a> can expect to make $28,430 a year. With an average cost of obtaining a license of $10,000 or $20,000, these regulatory costs make up roughly 35% to 77%, respectively, of a barber’s annual salary; a substantial burden.\n\n<a href="http://fee.org/freeman/does-occupational-licensing-protect-consumers/">The suitability of tests needed to obtain occupational licenses is another criterion for evaluation.</a> According to interviews with local Tallahassee barbers, the skills and techniques learned in barber school were not applicable for use in their profession. Practical skills needed to perform popular haircuts like <a href="https://s-media-cache-ak0.pinimg.com/736x/9e/4d/2d/9e4d2d0ea165554dcbfba97d3924841c.jpg">fades</a> weren’t taught unless students personally sought out such training on their own time. According to Lionel Skinner at Tallahassee’s Renegade Barber Shop, “The amount of time spent in class doing nothing could be better spent building the skills that are needed to become a qualified and efficient barber. Overall, the process leads to less quality barbers.”\n\nLicensing requirements are costly (in both money and time) to would-be workers and may not even provide the skills they need to do their jobs. Higher wages mean <a href="https://www.whitehouse.gov/sites/default/files/docs/licensing_report_final_nonembargo.pdf">higher prices for consumers</a>, but public health and safety are not necessarily protected.\n\n<a href="http://www.kauffman.org/what-we-do/resources/entrepreneurship-policy-digest/occupational-licensing-a-barrier-to-entrepreneurship">States have increased the number of occupations that must be licensed</a>, as well as the requirements to obtain licenses. According to a report released by the President’s Council of Economic Advisors, <a href="https://www.whitehouse.gov/sites/default/files/docs/licensing_report_final_nonembargo.pdf">over twenty-five percent of American workers must have an occupational license in their field.</a> As <a href="http://www.forbes.com/sites/elainepofeldt/2013/05/27/u-s-entrepreneurship-hits-record-high/">self-employment</a> trends upward, there is increasing pressure to reduce the <a href="http://www.econlib.org/library/Enc1/OccupationalLicensing.html">barriers to entry </a>for new entrepreneurs. The current limitations in place to become a barber or other licensed professional are too onerous in the state of Florida, preventing future entrepreneurs from entering the industries they wish to work in.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '363'), ('wp:post_date', '2015-12-08 16:22:54'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2015-12-08 16:22:54'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'occupational-licensing-floridas-barbers-does-more-harm-than-good'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', [OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'barber-licensing'), ('#text', 'barber licensing')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', OrderedDict([('title', 'Regulation of Uber, Lyft Should Be Local, Not Statewide'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2016/01/04/regulation-of-uber-lyft-should-be-local-not-statewide/'), ('pubDate', 'Mon, 04 Jan 2016 14:48:29 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=377')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', '&nbsp;\n\n[gallery ids="387,386" type="rectangular"]\n\nBy Matt Kelly\n\nIt seems that everywhere Uber, Lyft, and other transportation network companies (TNCs) set up shop, trouble with local regulators follows. The situation in<a href="http://www.govtech.com/fs/transportation/Florida-Is-Caught-in-the-Middle-of-Uber-Taxi-War.html"> Florida has been no different</a>. The Uber vs. taxi debate has been so heated that state lawmakers have proposed \xa0legislation (HB 509) to simply regulate all vehicles for hire at the state level. While statewide reforms would ease regulations in some locations, they would tighten restrictions elsewhere. It may be better to allow local government regulators to adapt at their own pace.<!--more-->\n\n<a href="http://www.fl-counties.com/docs/default-source/legal-documents-links/bertha-henry-presentation---tnc.pdf?sfvrsn=2">Consider Uber’s experience in Broward County</a>. After launching operations there in November 2014, Uber drivers were issued<a href="http://www.bizjournals.com/southflorida/blog/morning-edition/2015/01/uber-drivers-fined-35k-in-broward.html"> 250 citations by January 2015</a>. In April, county commissioners passed new regulations on TNCs, which dictated insurance requirements, background checks, and vehicle maintenance standards that TNCs claimed favored taxis. In response, Uber ceased operations in Broward altogether. In October, TNCs and<a href="http://www.broward.org/commission/Pages/default.aspx"> Broward County commissioners</a> reached a<a href="https://webapps.broward.org/newsrelease/AdminDisplayMessages.aspx?intMessageId=7385"> deal</a> that would ease<a href="http://www.broward.org/PermittingAndLicensing/TransportationNetworkCos/Pages/LegalResources.aspx"> restrictions on TNCs</a>. TNCs soon resumed operations. In the face of a changing transportation industry, Broward County initially resisted the challenge to its regulatory structure, but eventually accepted the wishes of its businesses and constituents. Similar stories abound through the state.\n\nIn some locations, concessionary deregulation of TNCs has been even more striking. Lawmakers in<a href="http://www.floridatoday.com/story/news/2015/11/12/melbourne-levels-playing-field-uber-taxis-limos/75582478/"> Melbourne</a> and<a href="http://www.heraldtribune.com/article/20151005/ARTICLE/151009802?p=2&amp;tc=pg&amp;tc=ar"> Sarasota</a> voted to eliminate taxi regulations altogether, putting TNCs and taxis on equal footing while deregulating both.\n\nLicensing and safety regulations aren’t easy to discard. Florida’s counties raised an annual average of<a href="http://floridaopengov.org/county-revenue-and-expenses/"> $17.7 million from licensing fees between 2009-2013</a>, providing a clear incentive to preserve the status quo. It’s understandable then that local governments are slow to change. However, the benefits of TNCs innovations appear too great to ignore. Sometimes quickly and sometimes slowly, local regulators are adapting for the better of businesses and consumers.\n\n<a href="http://www.sayfiereview.com/page/Uber%20transportation%20bill%20starts%20rolling%20in%20House">But state legislators may usurp local governments\' authority altogether</a>. Legislators failed to pass a bill earlier this year to regulate common-carrier vehicles for hire at the state level. A new bill to the same effect, HB 509, recently passed a hurdle in the House Highway and Water Safety Subcommittee and may be voted on in the spring legislative session. While standardizing rules across localities, statewide reforms would have different effects in different places.\n\nTo be sure, a patchwork of regulations across Florida’s counties and municipalities is emerging, and such complexity creates costs for entrepreneurs wishing to operate in multiple jurisdictions. But statewide reforms would not uniformly decrease the cost of business. Although TNCs could be regulated less strictly in Broward County under statewide rules, they may experience more onerous regulation in places like Sarasota.\n\nThe market disruptions TNCs introduce are instructive on multiple levels. Surge pricing, driver and user rating features,<a href="http://qz.com/566021/uber-just-notched-a-win-in-florida/"> employing drivers as independent contractors</a>, and other TNC business practices have done much to show private enterprise can effectively self-regulate and flexibly allocate resources in an advanced economy. Government responses to these innovations have also shown much about the political economy of entrepreneurship and regulation. The myriad of reforms occurring in Florida and across the world to accommodate (or crush) TNCs reflect competition for business among local governments. Who is to say at this early stage which regulatory regime will prove most economically beneficial and fair?\n\nRather than a statewide solution, it may be better to allow local governments to adapt at their own pace. Closer to their constituents, local governments are arguably more responsive to local needs than the state legislature. It would be a shame if state lawmakers preempt a healthy democratic change at work.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '377'), ('wp:post_date', '2016-01-04 14:48:29'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', OrderedDict([('title', "Duval county tops spending per person, followed by some of Florida's smallest counties"), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2016/01/15/duval-county-tops-spending-per-person-followed-by-some-of-floridas-smallest-counties/'), ('pubDate', 'Fri, 15 Jan 2016 20:45:25 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=399')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'By: Nick Hyder, Tian Ma, Igor Lukashevich, and Nadia James\n<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-417" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2016/01/12575875_1064336550277370_163496356_n.jpg" alt="12575875_1064336550277370_163496356_n" width="733" height="507" />\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Out of the 67 counties in the state of Florida, Duval County spends the most per capita. Duval County is home to Florida’s most populous city, Jacksonville, which has a population over twice as large as Miami, Florida’s second most populous city. In 2014, Duval County spent roughly 43% of its total expenses on the physical environment, which mainly consists of utilities (electric, gas, water, and sewage). Comparatively, the average Florida County allots only 10% of its expenses to this.</span><!--more-->\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Monroe County is second on the list of counties spending per capita. Located in the Southwest tip of the state, the county also includes the Florida Keys, including Key West. Monroe County spent the largest portion of its budget in 2014 on public safety at 27%, but this is still lower than the average Florida County with spends close to 30% on public safety. Monroe spent close to 8% of its budget on economic environment in 2014. Economic environment expenses consist of employment, industry, and housing development. \xa0Home to part of the Everglades, Monroe County receives numerous Federal grants for the purpose of preserving its environment, so it is able to spend more money on environmental preservation than other counties. </span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Florida’s most populous county, Miami-Dade, ranks number three on spending per capita. However, Miami-Dade spent the most money in 2014: over $9 billion. Miami-Dade spent the largest portion of its budget in 2014 on human services at just under 19%, which included health and developmental disability services. This is more than four times larger than the average Florida County which spends only about 4% on human services.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Some of Florida’s least populated counties are spending a significant amount per person. Walton and Franklin County are both home to less than 65,000 citizens yet they both rank in the top ten for spending per person. Walton County, \xa0located in Florida’s panhandle on the Gulf Coast, spent close to half of its total expenditures in 2014 on transportation/core infrastructure and public safety. Franklin County, also located in Florida’s panhandle on the Gulf Coast, spent $8.5 million out of its $33 million of expenditures in 2014, or 26%, on general court administration. The average county in Florida spends roughly 4% of its expenditures on all court related expenditures.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">The top ten Florida Counties in spending per capita is a diverse group. Large counties such as Duval and Monroe make the list, but so do smaller counties such as Walton and Franklin. Duval County spends over $500 more per person than the next closest County, Monroe, and spends almost double per person that the fourth highest spending county (Franklin) does. Monroe and Miami-Dade, the two southernmost Counties in Florida, come in at number two and three, respectively. It is to be seen if these county spending trends continue into 2015 as Florida Counties continue to recover from the Great Recession.</span>\n\n&nbsp;\n\n<b>Data and References</b>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">All Data can be found at the links below:</span>\n\n<a href="http://www.floridaopengov.org"><span style="font-weight:400;">www.Floridaopengov.org</span></a>\n\n<a href="http://www.myfloridacfo.com/transparency/"><span style="font-weight:400;">http://www.myfloridacfo.com/transparency/</span></a>\n\n<a href="http://www.fl-counties.com/advocacy/fac-research-data/county-revenues-and-expenses---fy-2013"><span style="font-weight:400;">http://www.fl-counties.com/advocacy/fac-research-data/county-revenues-and-expenses---fy-2013</span></a>'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '399'), ('wp:post_date', OrderedDict([('title', "Florida's Frugal Government"), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2016/01/22/floridas-frugal-government/'), ('pubDate', 'Fri, 22 Jan 2016 20:03:30 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=422')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'By Randall G. Holcombe, Ph.D.\n\n<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-425" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2016/01/m-florida-state-capital-11.jpg" alt="M-florida-state-capital-1" width="340" height="231" />\n\nLiving in Tallahassee, I often hear people complain about Florida’s frugal state government. \xa0It is true that Florida is among the most frugal states. According to<a href="http://kff.org/other/state-indicator/per-capita-state-spending/"> this article</a> Florida is second from the bottom among states in per capita state government expenditures, and<a href="http://blogs.wsj.com/numbers/what-states-have-the-most-government-workers-1654/"> this article</a> says Florida is also second from the bottom in government employees per capita. \xa0Nevada is the only state lower than Florida in both categories.<!--more-->\n\nThe message of those who complain about Florida’s low ranking is almost always that the state government should spend more, using as evidence how far Florida is below the national average. \xa0But there is no virtue in being average. \xa0If state government spending is a good thing, we’d want to be at the top of the list; if it is a bad thing, we deserve credit for being at the bottom.\n\nSometimes I’ll see people claim that if our government spent more, we could accomplish various things with the money, but that’s hypothetical. \xa0Would we really accomplish anything more if we spent more?\n\nPeople who claim we spend too little should compare the government goods and services people in high-expenditure states get that Floridians don’t. \xa0State governments spend more than twice as much per person in Arkansas, Connecticut, and Massachusetts as we do in Florida. \xa0Do they have better roads than we do, or better parks? \xa0What are they getting for their money?\n\nNormally, we think that if we spend less for something, that’s a good thing, so I take any evidence that Florida ranks low in state government spending or government employment as something positive. \xa0People who want to complain about Florida’s frugal state government shouldn’t be telling us how little it costs. \xa0That should be a positive thing. \xa0They should be telling us what people in other states, where state governments are bigger, are getting that we Floridians are not. \xa0As a longtime Florida resident, I don’t see the evidence that we are being shortchanged.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '422'), ('wp:post_date', '2016-01-22 20:03:30'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2016-01-22 20:03:30'), OrderedDict([('title', 'The Top 10 Highest Earning Counties in Florida'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2016/01/26/the-top-10-highest-earning-counties-in-florida/'), ('pubDate', 'Tue, 26 Jan 2016 22:32:57 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=429')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', '<span style="font-weight:400;">By: Igor Lukashevich and Nadia James</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">The top six Florida counties for revenue intake per capita are as follows: Duval, Monroe, Miami-Dade, Franklin, Charlotte, and Collier. Total revenues for counties follow very closely with total expenditures, as the same six counties also </span><a href="https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/2016/01/15/duval-county-tops-spending-per-person-followed-by-some-of-floridas-smallest-counties/"><span style="font-weight:400;">topped the list</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> for expenditures per capita. This relationship makes sense because the more that a county takes in, the more it can spend.</span>\n\n<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-432" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2016/01/revenue-graph.jpg" alt="Revenue Graph" width="717" height="410" /><!--more-->\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Duval County obtains roughly 46 percent of its revenue from charges for various government services. Since Jacksonville is the largest city in Florida, accounting for nearly 95 percent of the county’s population, Duval is able to collect more revenue from services like transportation, utilities, and public safety than most other Florida counties. \xa0Interestingly, however, Duval County obtains a very small portion of its revenues from property taxes. Property taxes account for only about 9 percent of Duval’s total revenues, the lowest percentage in Florida. Miami-Dade County follows a similar pattern, with 41 percent of its revenue coming from charges for services and only 13 percent of its revenue coming from property taxes(65</span><span style="font-weight:400;">th</span><span style="font-weight:400;"> lowest out of 67 counties). \xa0</span><span style="font-weight:400;">\n</span><span style="font-weight:400;">\n</span> <span style="font-weight:400;">Franklin County, located in the Panhandle along the Gulf Coast,obtains nearly a third of its revenue from property taxes, with another sizeable chunk coming from charges for government services. Despite having a population of only about 11,000 people, </span><span style="font-weight:400;">Franklin is home to several large preserved areas and rivers, and large commercial timber and commercial fishing industries</span><span style="font-weight:400;">. These industries utilize considerable energy and space for production purposes, translating into property and service tax revenue for the county. The businesses are also eligible to receive subsidies, explaining why Franklin County receives a significant portion of its revenue from state grants.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;"> Monroe and Collier counties are some of the richest in Florida based on median household income. They also receive more revenue per capita than many of the other less populous counties. Property taxes account for 27.84 percent of Collier’s and 20.71 percent of Monroe’s revenue, with charges for services accounting for a significant portion as well (28.76 percent for Collier and 19.55 percent for Monroe). Monroe County also contains part of Everglades National Park, Big Cypress National Preserve and Key West, which all receive substantial federal grants. In fact</span> <span style="font-weight:400;">7.2 percent of its budget, $</span><span style="font-weight:400;">27,239,977</span><span style="font-weight:400;">, is made up of federal grants compared to 3.6 percent for the average county.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">The \xa0counties that accumulate the most revenue are not necessarily the most populous. Some counties, such as Collier, Monroe, and Franklin, enjoy a large tax base simply by virtue of having many high value homes and capital intensive businesses \xa0inside their territories. And so, the top counties’ revenues are not based solely upon the number of people who reside there to pay taxes, but also on income received from the use of their natural resources and profitable industries. </span>\n\n&nbsp;\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Sources:</span><span style="font-weight:400;">\n</span><span style="font-weight:400;">\n</span><a href="http://www.fl-counties.com/advocacy/fac-research-data/county-revenues-and-expenses---fy-2013"><span style="font-weight:400;">http://www.fl-counties.com/advocacy/fac-research-data/county-revenues-and-expenses---fy-2013</span></a>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">http://www.indexmundi.com/facts/united-states/quick-facts/florida/median-household-income#map</span><span style="font-weight:400;">\n</span>'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), OrderedDict([('title', 'Health Care and Education Departments Spend the Most of Florida’s State Budget'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2016/01/30/health-care-and-education-departments-spend-the-most-of-floridas-state-budget/'), ('pubDate', 'Sat, 30 Jan 2016 21:51:56 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=435')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', '<span style="font-weight:400;">By: Nick Hyder and Tian Ma</span>\n\nWith 2015 behind us, it’s worthwhile to take stock of last year’s spending by state government. A state’s spending says a lot about its priorities, and accountability to taxpayers is an important component of a democracy. The Agency for Health Care Administration tops the list of spending by state agencies, followed by the departments of Education, Management Services, Revenue, and Transportation.\n\n<img class=" size-full wp-image-438 aligncenter" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2016/01/agencyspendingfinal.png" alt="AgencySpendingFinal" width="977" height="590" /><!--more--><span style="font-weight:400;">The </span><a href="http://ahca.myflorida.com/"><span style="font-weight:400;">Agency for Health Care Administration</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> (AHCA) had the largest budget of any executive agency in Florida in 2015 with expenditures just shy of $24 billion. Of this, $23 billion was spent on Medicaid, a federal and state funded medical assistance program that offers access to health care for low-income families and individuals, the elderly, and persons with disabilities. Nearly $10 billion of Florida’s Medicaid spending came from state funds, with the remaining $13.5 billion provided to the state by the federal government. An August 2015 forecast by AHCA projects that spending on Medicaid will increase by about </span><a href="https://ahca.myflorida.com/medicaid/recent_presentations/Florida_Medicaid_to_Senate_HHS_Appropriations_2015-10-20.pdf"><span style="font-weight:400;">$1.9 billion by fiscal year 2016-2017.</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> But this is likely to increase if the Florida Legislature passes Medicaid expansion efforts currently being considered in the legislature </span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">The </span><a href="http://www.fldoe.org/"><span style="font-weight:400;">Florida Department of Education</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> spent about $20 billion in 2015, ranking the second highest amount by a state agency. About 91% of this spending went to county school boards. Big counties such as Miami-Dade, Broward and Hillsborough received the largest levels of assistance, averaging about $1.25 billion each.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">The </span><a href="http://www.dms.myflorida.com"><span style="font-weight:400;">Department of Management Services</span> </a><span style="font-weight:400;">(DMS) spent just over $7 billion in 2015, narrowly edging out the Department of Revenue ($6.9 billion) and the Department of Transportation ($6.906 billion) for third place in spending. The DMS is the business arm of Florida’s government serving “to support sister agencies as well as current and former state employees with workforce and business-related functions so that agencies can focus on their core missions as defined in law.”</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Responsible for facilitating child support payments as well as collecting a processing state taxes, the</span><a href="http://www.fldoe.org/"> <span style="font-weight:400;">Department of Revenue</span> </a><span style="font-weight:400;">(DOR) ranks fourth in total spending for 2015. In a given year, the DOR collects over $30 billion in taxes and fees while processing over 9 million tax filings. The DOR serves a number of other key roles, including assisting legislatures in analyzing the impact of proposed bills.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">The</span><a href="http://www.dot.state.fl.us/"> <span style="font-weight:400;">Florida Department of Transportation</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> (FDOT) spent about $6.9 billion last year, \xa0with Mat Concessionaire LLC and I-595 Express, LLC ranked as two highest spending vendors, accounted for 11% of the department spending. Both located in Miami/ Fort.Lauderdale metropolitan area, Mat Concessionaire is responsible for the design, construction, and financing of the Port Miami Tunnel project, and I-595 Express is responsible for operation and maintenance of the I-595 Expressway. The rest of the spending was dedicated mainly to infrastructure, and was dispersed to various construction companies for work on roads and bridges.</span>\n\nTotal state spending increased approximately 7% from $72 billion in 2014 to $77 billion in 2015. Out of 35 state agencies listed, the Agency for Health Care Administration and the Department of Education spent over half of the \xa0total budget, while the remaining 33 agencies spent about $33 billion combined. This distribution of spending might seem surprising, but Florida has seen similar spending trends for the previous six years. Agency spending will likely continue to be dominated by health care and education through 2016.\n\n&nbsp;\n\n<b>Data and References</b>\n\nAll data can be found at the links below:\n\n<a href="http://floridaopengov.org/vendor-payments/"><span style="font-weight:400;">http://floridaopengov.org/vendor-payments/</span></a>\n\n<a href="http://ccf.georgetown.edu/all/floridas-medicaid-budget-just-facts/"><span style="font-weight:400;">http://ccf.georgetown.edu/all/floridas-medicaid-budget-just-facts/</span></a>\n\n&nbsp;'), OrderedDict([('title', 'Top \xa02% of state employees see faster rise in income than bottom 98% since the Great Recession'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2016/02/05/top-2-of-state-employees-see-faster-rise-in-income-than-bottom-98-since-the-great-recession/'), ('pubDate', 'Fri, 05 Feb 2016 16:13:49 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=442')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', '<span style="font-weight:400;">By: Igor Lukashevich</span><span style="font-weight:400;">\n</span><span style="font-weight:400;">\n</span><span style="font-weight:400;">In 2014, the world was abuzz with talk of Thomas Piketty’s treatise on global economic inequality, </span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capital_in_the_Twenty-First_Century"><i><span style="font-weight:400;">Capital in the Twenty-First Century</span></i></a><span style="font-weight:400;">. The rising global disparity of income, the author argued, will inevitably result in social and economic instability across the world. It is interesting to note that income inequality also exists, and has grown widely, within the very institution that Piketty has tasked with fixing it: government. An analysis of the total compensation received by 147,458 Florida state employees reveals the income gap between the top earners and everyone else, and how it has changed since 2008. </span><span style="font-weight:400;">\n</span><span style="font-weight:400;"><!--more-->\n</span><span style="font-weight:400;">Since the Great Recession, employees making over $100,000 in total compensation have accounted for approximately 10% of all earners within Florida government. On average, this group has seen their incomes rise only slightly faster than other state employees. They have added approximately $600 more to their annual compensation than have the bottom 90%. \xa0</span><span style="font-weight:400;">\n</span><span style="font-weight:400;">\n</span><span style="font-weight:400;">However, increasing inequality is much more pronounced for employees making over $175,000. Comprising only 2% of all earners within the Florida government, these workers have averaged approximately $11,000 more in increased compensation during the past seven years than have those below them on the income ladder. As can be gathered from the table below, the bottom 98% of Florida government employees have experienced a modest 2% rise in income, while the top have seen their earnings increase by as much as 6.5%.</span>\n\n<img class="  wp-image-448 aligncenter" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2016/02/12650368_1074823842561974_335016493_n.jpg" alt="12650368_1074823842561974_335016493_n" width="570" height="224" />\n\n&nbsp;\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">What government agencies have seen the most increase in income? Figure 1 shows the distribution of the top 2% of public employees by department.</span>\n\n&nbsp;\n\n<img class=" size-full wp-image-449 aligncenter" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2016/02/12650760_1074823839228641_577624695_n.jpg" alt="12650760_1074823839228641_577624695_n" width="573" height="377" />\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">An overwhelming majority (75%) of these high-earning employees work in the Office of the State Courts Administrator, with another 8% in the Justice Administrative Commission and 5% in the Health Department. Professionals in the judicial branch have consistently dominated the income ladder, making up over 80% of top earners in Florida government since the 1990s.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">It seems income inequality exists in both the public and private sectors. Although the recent growth in the earnings gap has not been as severe in the public sector as in the </span><a href="http://eml.berkeley.edu//~saez/saez-UStopincomes-2012.pdf"><span style="font-weight:400;">country overall</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">, it is nevertheless significant and worth examining. </span>\n\n&nbsp;\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">All data can be found at:</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Florida Open Gov:</span><a href="http://floridaopengov.org/"><span style="font-weight:400;">http://floridaopengov.org/</span></a>\n\n&nbsp;'), 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', None), ('wp:status', 'draft'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'uncategorized'), ('#text', 'Uncategorized')]))]), OrderedDict([('title', 'Tourism tax may soon be used for public services'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2016/02/15/tourism-tax-may-soon-be-used-for-public-services/'), ('pubDate', 'Mon, 15 Feb 2016 19:49:09 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=464')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', '<a href="http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2013-04-23/business/os-bed-tax-for-lifeguards-20130422_1_hotel-taxes-tourism-industry-beach-patrol"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-467" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2016/02/pascua-florida.jpg" alt="pascua-florida" width="600" height="400" /></a>\n\nBy Erick Winterkamp\n\n<a href="http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2013-04-23/business/os-bed-tax-for-lifeguards-20130422_1_hotel-taxes-tourism-industry-beach-patrol">Officials in Okaloosa County recently</a> diverted $2.5 million of Tourism Development Tax (TDT) revenues to pay for beach patrol and lifeguards, a move that Florida’s powerful tourism lobby contested. Tourism industry interest groups like the<a href="http://www.fadmo.org/"> Florida Association of Destination Marketing Organizations</a> and the<a href="https://www.frla.org/"> Florida Restaurant and Lodging Association</a> claimed this was an improper use of TDT funds, which are reserved for tourism-related projects only. County officials argued the allocation was appropriate, since increasing security personnel would increase safety and encourage more visits. This incident and others like it raise the question of how counties should be allowed to spend TDT funds.<!--more-->\n\nThe rules for appropriation of TDT funds laid out in section 5 of<a href="http://www.leg.state.fl.us/statutes/index.cfm?App_mode=Display_Statute&amp;URL=0100-0199/0125/Sections/0125.0104.html"> Florida State Statute 125.0104</a> have been a source of contention for policymakers and interest groups. Overall, the law makes clear that TDT revenues should be used for projects meant to increase future tourism, primarily convention centers, stadiums, and advertising. Clause 5.5 states that counties may also use TDT to fund facilities, improvements, and “renourishment” as long as it pertains to the preservation of beaches or inland lakes, rivers, and streams. The language leaves some room for interpretation, and has led to conflict between tourism industry groups and county officials.\n\nMore recently, Jackson County applied for TDT funding for a “boat ramp and elevated platform used as an observation area for viewing birds and the natural landscape” on the Chipola River. The tourism lobby again raised its ire. Florida Attorney General Pam Bondi \xa0issued an<a href="http://www.myfloridalegal.com/ago.nsf/Opinions/24B0E28792D5C13985257ED0004AC494"> advisory legal opinion</a> in favor of the project but stressed that TDT funding must be “…primarily related to the advancement and promotion of tourism.”\n\nDifferences in a law’s interpretation are to be expected, but some challenge the very premise that TDT funds <i>should</i> be devoted to tourism-related projects. Former state Rep. Linda Stewart (D-Orlando) has said,<a href="http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2013-07-14/business/os-tourist-tax-lost-options-20130714_1_resort-tax-tourist-taxes-bed-tax"> “The general public feels strongly that there has to be other ways to better spend that tourist tax.”</a> Orlando Sentinel columnist Scott Maxwell<a href="http://www.orlandosentinel.com/opinion/os-florida-hotel-taxes-police-scott-maxwell-20151128-column.html"> doubts the need for additional tourism spending in a state already flush with theme parks and hotels</a>. Indeed, a large body of economic research finds that convention centers, stadiums, and other<a href="http://www.upenn.edu/pennpress/book/15221.html"> large public spending projects bring little economic benefit to their communities.</a> Rep. Brad Drake of Eucheeanna recently filed<a href="http://www.myfloridahouse.gov/Sections/Bills/billsdetail.aspx?BillId=56232"> a bill that would allow counties to spend up to 10% of TDT revenues on public services</a> unrelated to tourism. However, the bill only applies to counties with populations of less than 225,000, limiting it to Bay, Okaloosa, and Walton Counties.\n\nThe tourism industry argues it pays more than its fair share of taxes already. Richard Maladecki, president and CEO of the Central Florida Lodging Association, believes that TDT should remain devoted to promoting tourism.<a href="http://www.orlandoweekly.com/orlando/how-the-tourism-industry-and-politicians-keep-floridas-tax-money-from-being-spent-where-we-need-it-most/Content?oid=2244501"> “That’s why it’s called the tourist development tax, to have a tax specifically earmarked for tourism promotions.”</a> Hoteliers already pay ad valorem and sales taxes which go to fund road construction, public transit, and police/fire services. Reallocating TDT for general services would be in conflict with what economists call the<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benefit_principle"> principle of benefit taxation</a>, in which taxes to fund public goods are paid primarily by users. The potential problem with shifting the tax burden onto the tourism industry is that people may overuse publicly provided goods (transportation, law enforcement, infrastructure, etc.). Still, as it stands now the tourism industry has a great deal of control over how TDT funds are spent, potentially opening the door to cronyism.\n\nThe restrictions on Florida’s TDT were set over 35 years ago and in some cases leave too much room for interpretation, leading to conflict among differing interest groups. Changing these rules would have important implications for Florida’s economic growth. With growing public and legislative support for some liberation of TDT funds pitted against the interests of Florida’s tourism industry, intriguing political theatre is sure to follow.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '464'), ('wp:post_date', '2016-02-15 19:49:09'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2016-02-15 19:49:09'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'tourism-tax-may-soon-be-used-for-public-services'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', [OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'benefit-taxation'), ('#text', 'benefit taxation')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'economics'), ('#text', 'economics')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'fiscal-policy'), ('#text', 'Fiscal Policy')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'fiscal-policy-2'), ('#text', 'fiscal policy')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'florida'), ('#text', 'Florida')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'government-spending'), ('#text', 'Government Spending')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'okaloosa-county'), ('#text', 'Okaloosa County')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'politics-2'), ('#text', 'Politics')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'tax-policy-2'), ('#text', 'Tax Policy')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'taxes'), ('#text', 'taxes')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'tourism'), ('#text', 'tourism')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'tourism-development-tax'), ('#text', 'Tourism development tax')])]), ('wp:postmeta', [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_published'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', Growing food inside cities can be<a href="https://www.newdream.org/blog/2011-09-calculating-the-savings-in-growing-your-own-food"> cheap</a>, and can provide a new level of control over what \xa0we consume. Urban gardens can also strengthen communities by providing a healthy alternative to impoverished areas with limited access to fresh fruits and vegetables. Tallahassee, for example, is home to at least five urban gardens.<a href="http://seedstock.com/2014/05/27/10-american-cities-lead-the-way-with-urban-agriculture-ordinances/"> Detroit – one of the country’s leaders in urban agriculture – is home to over 1,300</a>. In Florida, the rise of urban gardening has challenged existing zoning regulation and prompted both county- and city-level changes.<!--more-->\n\n<a href="http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/zoning/">Zoning</a> refers to how land is divided up by government authorities for different uses, such as residential, commercial, and agricultural. It came into practice in the United States in 1916, when New York City enacted the<a href="https://www.dartmouth.edu/~wfischel/Papers/02-03.pdf"> country’s first comprehensive zoning code</a>. Municipal zoning codes have tended to prohibit agriculture in urban areas, driving agricultural development away from residential property in the interest of keeping home values high and reducing<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuisance"> “nuisance lawsuits.”</a> However, since 1979 Florida’s Right to Farm law has prevented local governments from regulating agricultural zoning more strictly than state level regulations. More recently, the<a href="http://www.floridabar.org/DIVCOM/JN/JNJournal01.nsf/Articles/A7B016F345C2060585257DB80053C972"> Community Planning Act</a> has allowed local governments greater control over their local growth management, but agricultural land continues to fall under the Right to Farm Act’s protection.\n\nStill, urban gardens face many local<a href="http://duval.ifas.ufl.edu/documents/CommunityGardensRegsFINAL3.28.13.pdf"> regulations</a> that threaten their existence. For example, they may be allowed inside cities, but only as additions to residential properties.<a href="http://www.leoncountyfl.gov/growth/Permits/siteplan/ORD09-03.pdf"> According to a Leon County ordinance passed in 2009</a>, small scale urban gardens – “small scale” meaning less than an acre – can exist without a permit, provided owners don’t sell their produce and agree to farm only during daytime hours. Urban gardens can’t take up more than half of a property’s area.\n\nCities can also effectively outlaw urban gardens by making compliance with zoning codes prohibitively expensive. In some parts of Florida,<a href="http://www.miamiherald.com/news/local/community/article1957613.html"> individually owned gardens are being shut down</a> because they don’t comply with city ordinances. One of the most restrictive regulations on urban gardens right now is that they can’t legally be for-profit ventures, preventing owners from deriving any monetary benefit from them.\n\nUrban gardens are growing faster than zoning regulations can keep up. The "buy local" movement and concerns about large industrial farming has made residents friendlier to farming in residential areas. Rather than change their rules to reflect changing preferences, cities often choose to ignore their zoning codes. For now, urban garden owners are given individual exemptions to or variances from the law, in order to avoid zoning conflicts. In most Florida cities, zoning exceptions, conditional use permits, and variances almost always require contacting the local growth management department, where developers and property owners pay fees to be heard at the next available development council meeting. Obtaining individual exemptions is time-consuming, and they ultimately offer little long-term security for urban gardeners. Moreover, planners resist giving exemptions because they become a form of “spot zoning,” a practice that violates the spirit and strategic planning intent that is a key justification comprehensive land-use planning.\n\nAwareness about the need for comprehensive changes to zoning regulations arose in Leon County when one of its largest urban gardens,<a href="http://www.wtxl.com/news/something-s-growing-in-leon-county-new-zoning-codes-are/article_9df5eb10-3ae0-11e5-801d-73f4b257c248.html"> Ripe City, decided to start selling its produce</a>. New zoning laws meant to explicitly accommodate urban gardening are expected to be completed by spring 2016. In the meantime, the City of Tallahassee has created a<a href="https://www.talgov.com/eper/eper-gardening.aspx"> step-by-step guide</a> on how to start a community garden.\n\nAs urban agriculture continues to grow in popularity, local and state government regulators will have to adapt their rules. Otherwise, this kind of business can’t hope to make a profit. There is certainly a history of conflict between agricultural and zoning policies, but residents near urban gardens appear to enjoy this intersection between farming and city life. Zoning ordinances have hindered this movement’s growth, but reforms in Tallahassee may prove fruitful.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '479'), ('wp:post_date', '2016-02-22 15:48:50'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2016-02-22 15:48:50'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'urban-gardens-face-zoning-restrictions'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', [OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', Berman";s:12:"focal_length";i:0;s:3:"iso";i:0;s:13:"shutter_speed";i:0;s:5:"title";s:13:"Urban Farming";s:11:"orientation";i:0;s:8:"keywords";a:36:{i:0;s:10:"FoodCycles";i:1;s:12:"Urban Farmer";i:2;s:11:"agriculture";i:3;s:9:"city farm";i:4;s:12:"city farmers";i:5;s:12:"city farming";i:6;s:8:"crop mob";i:7;s:4:"farm";i:8;s:7:"farming";i:9;s:4:"food";i:10;s:12:"food growing";i:11;s:6:"garden";i:12;s:11:"garden tool";i:13;s:8:"gardener";i:14;s:9:"gardeners";i:15;s:9:"gardening";i:16;s:3:"hoe";i:17;s:6:"hoeing";i:18;s:13:"market garden";i:19;s:6:"people";i:20;s:7:"produce";i:21;s:11:"sustainable";i:22;s:23:"sustainable agriculture";i:23;s:4:"tool";i:24;s:5:"tools";i:25;s:17:"urban agriculture";i:26;s:10:"urban farm";i:27;s:13:"urban farmers";i:28;s:13:"urban farming";i:29;s:11:"urban scene";i:30;s:9:"vegetable";i:31;s:16:"vegetable garden";i:32;s:10:"vegetables";i:33;s:7:"weeding";i:34;s:12:"wheel barrow";i:35;s:21:"working in the garden";}}}')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', 'A Penny Seized is a Penny Earned: Asset Forfeiture in Florida'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2016/03/04/a-penny-seized-is-a-penny-earned-asset-forfeiture-in-florida/'), ('pubDate', 'Fri, 04 Mar 2016 21:51:32 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=495')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'By Matt Kelly and Tyler Worthington\n\n[caption id="attachment_504" align="alignnone" width="963"]<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-504" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2016/03/sheet-12.png" alt="Sheet 1(2)" width="963" height="657" /> FIGURE 1- All figures reported in 2014 dollars. Data from www.floridaopengov.org[/caption]\n\n<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asset_forfeiture">Asset forfeiture</a> is a tool used by federal and local law enforcement to seize property from people they believe may have been involved in a crime. <a href="http://ij.org/case/long-island-forfeiture/">In some cases</a>, property has been seized and not returned to the accused even if charges were not filed or dropped. Local governments and law enforcement agencies raise revenue through the sale of these assets, presenting an incentive to infringe on private property rights. In Florida, asset forfeiture revenue has risen dramatically since 2009, a worrying trend if these seizures are not connected to criminal convictions.<!--more-->\n\nWhile<a href="http://www.expertlaw.com/library/criminal/forfeiture.html"> criminal forfeiture</a> requires police to obtain a criminal conviction, police can use<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civil_forfeiture_in_the_United_States"> civil forfeiture</a> to seize and sell property without meeting the same high standards of evidence. Criminal courts require proof “<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Legal_burden_of_proof#Beyond_reasonable_doubt">beyond a reasonable doubt</a>.” Civil courts, in contrast, allow, agencies to file claims for forfeiture based on a “<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Legal_burden_of_proof#Preponderance_of_the_evidence">preponderance of evidence</a>”. Though originally meant to<a href="http://ag.hawaii.gov/cjd/asset-forfeiture-unit/history-of-asset-forfeiture/"> thwart organized crime</a>, civil forfeiture is today used with greater frequency and for a<a href="http://www.huffingtonpost.com/brad-reid/civil-asset-forfeiture-ch_b_3745209.html"> far wider variety of cases</a>.\n\nThe<a href="http://ij.org/"> Institute for Justice</a>’s (IJ) Report<a href="http://ij.org/report/policing-for-profit/"> “Policing for Profit”</a> details the tremendous growth in the use of asset forfeiture by federal and state agencies. In 1986 the Department of Justice took in $93.7 million from federal forfeitures. This number grew to $4.5 billion in 2014. That’s<a href="https://www.armstrongeconomics.com/international-news/north_america/americas-current-economy/police-civil-asset-forfeitures-exceed-all-burglaries-in-2014/"> more money than was stolen by burglars</a> in 2014, and 87% came from civil forfeitures. The IJ report also highlights a lack of transparency across the country. Federal and state agencies using asset forfeiture often don’t keep track of revenues received or spent.\n\nFlorida received a grade of D+ in IJ’s report card. Florida first allowed civil asset forfeiture in 1974. The “<a href="http://www.flsenate.gov/Laws/Statutes/2011/932.701">Florida Contraband Forfeiture Act</a>”, states, “All rights to, interest in, and title to contraband articles used in violation of…[state and federal law]…shall immediately vest in the seizing law enforcement agency upon seizure.” While the law states that revenues gained through sale of these items may only be used for “supplemental funding for authorized purposes,” a<a href="http://www.oppaga.state.fl.us/MonitorDocs/Reports/pdf/1510rpt.pdf"> 2015 Florida legislative policy staff (OPPAGA) determined </a>\xa0that tracking these funds was not possible because the state lacks consistent reporting requirements. The Institute for Justice estimates that Florida seized roughly $117 million between 2009-2014 from civil forfeitures, although, as OPPAGA made clear, exact records are impossible to obtain.\n\nTo gauge the magnitude of civil asset forfeiture,<a href="http://www.oppaga.state.fl.us/"> OPPAGA</a> conducted a survey of 152 law enforcement agencies in Florida. The office estimated that between 2010 and 2014 almost 19,000 seizures were made. Twenty-five percent of seized assets were eventually returned to their owners. Vehicles and currency were the most commonly seized items. Real property was rarely seized since it requires a higher burden of proof for agencies to confiscate. Sixteen percent of responding agencies reported making seizures without making any arrests.\n\nIn response, the <a href="http://www.flsheriffs.org/">Florida Sheriffs Association</a> asserts that the state’s asset forfeiture laws are appropriate and points out that Florida is one of only six states that uses a “<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Legal_burden_of_proof#Clear_and_convincing_evidence">clear and convincing</a>” standard of proof for civil forfeitures, a higher standard than “preponderance of evidence” but lower than “beyond a reasonable doubt.” However, the increase in revenue from asset seizures since 2009 (see Figure 1), a period when<a href="http://www.sun-sentinel.com/news/interactive/sfl-florida-crime-stats-2015-htmlstory.html"> crime was already decreasing in absolute terms</a>, suggests that even this standard may not be strict enough. A bill recently filed by Senator Jeff Brandes (R-Pinellas) would <a href="https://www.flsenate.gov/Session/Bill/2016/1044">raise the standard to “beyond a reasonable doubt” and also establish reporting requirements. </a>\n\nFigure 1 also shows the revenue reported for the category “Assets Seized by Law Enforcement” found in <a href="http://floridaopengov.org/">city and county budgets</a>. This measure underestimates revenue gained through seizure since much of this revenue may be categorized as “miscellaneous” or “other fines and forfeits.” Still, this revenue category is the best barometer available in the absence of statewide reporting requirements. Figure 2 shows a ranking of local governments by revenue from seizures. The City of Sunrise leads the pack, seizing over $4.3 million between 2009 and 2014. Pinellas County, the city of Orlando, and Broward County follow with total seizures of around $1.5 million each.\n\n[caption id="attachment_505" align="alignnone" width="534"]<img class="alignnone  wp-image-505" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2016/03/sheet-3.png" alt="Sheet 3" width="534" height="532" /> FIGURE 2- Data from www.floridaopengov.org[/caption]\n\nThe increasingly common seizure of property by federal, state, and local law enforcement is a worrying development. Protecting property rights is essential to economic growth, especially for cash businesses like restaurants, bars, and small boutique shops. Although Florida’s stated policy is that “officers adhere to federal and state constitutional limitations regarding an individual’s right to be free from unreasonable searches and seizures,” the explosion in revenues from civil forfeiture and lack of transparency suggest that law enforcement agencies have an incentive to seize assets with little external scrutiny. Changes are needed to ensure the protection of property rights and the civil liberties of Florida citizens.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '495'), ('wp:post_date', '2016-03-04 21:51:32'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2016-03-04 21:51:32'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'a-penny-seized-is-a-penny-earned-asset-forfeiture-in-florida'), ('content:encoded', None), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '505'), ('wp:post_date', '2016-03-04 21:43:32'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2016-03-04 21:43:32'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'),
