'a:5:{s:5:"width";i:660;s:6:"height";i:657;s:4:"file";s:83:"/home/wpcom/public_html/wp-content/blogs.dir/848/80998613/files/2016/03/sheet-3.png";s:5:"sizes";a:0:{}s:10:"image_meta";a:12:{s:8:"aperture";i:0;s:6:"credit";s:0:"";s:6:"camera";s:0:"";s:7:"caption";s:0:"";s:17:"created_timestamp";i:0;s:9:"copyright";s:0:"";s:12:"focal_length";i:0;s:3:"iso";i:0;s:13:"shutter_speed";i:0;s:5:"title";s:0:"";s:11:"orientation";i:0;s:8:"keywords";a:0:{}}}')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', 'Florida Facing the Wrong Direction on Immigration Reform'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2016/03/07/florida-facing-the-wrong-direction-on-immigration-reform/'), ('pubDate', 'Mon, 07 Mar 2016 11:30:00 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=515')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'By Selene Capparelli\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">The US immigration system has been badly broken for many decades. \xa0Mass deportation, enhanced border security, and keeping undocumented workers in perpetual illegal status have been proven to be </span><a href="http:///h"><span style="font-weight:400;">very costly and ineffective methods</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> to handle the constant influx of new immigrants.These policies r</span><span style="font-weight:400;">esult in hundreds of </span><a href="http://www.gao.gov/new.items/d06770.pdf"><span style="font-weight:400;">border-crossing deaths</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> each year, </span><a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3708262/"><span style="font-weight:400;">abject working and living conditions</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> for those who successfully enter the country, and depressed wages for many </span><a href="http://cis.org/immigration-and-the-american-worker-review-academic-literature"><span style="font-weight:400;">low-skill domestic workers</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">. \xa0Undocumented immigrants, however, represent vast untapped potential for economic growth in the US. Bringing them into the legal labor market will boost entrepreneurship, grow the economy, create jobs, and increase spending power.<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-522" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2016/03/9677860897_f505b6254c_b-1024x683.jpg" alt="9677860897_f505b6254c_b-1024x683" width="1024" height="683" /></span><!--more-->\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Unauthorized workers already pay sales and property taxes, yet providing them with legal status would increase their tax contributions by an estimated </span><a href="http://www.itep.org/pdf/undocumentedtaxes2015.pdf"><span style="font-weight:400;">$2.2 billion per year</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">. Low-skilled workers would be able to fill the positions Americans do not want while earning a fair wage. Currently their illegal status subjects them to potential exploitation and abuse by unscrupulous employers. Meanwhile, highly skilled immigrants will bring </span><a href="http://www.immigrationpolicy.org/just-facts/us-economy-still-needs-highly-skilled-foreign-workers"><span style="font-weight:400;">much-needed scientific and technical help</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> to our industries while creating jobs. Bill Gates reported in 2008 that, on average, for every H1-B (visa for foreign professionals) worker Microsoft hired, </span><a href="http:///h"><span style="font-weight:400;">four jobs</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> were created in a supporting capacity.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Furthermore, immigrants are exceptionally entrepreneurial. Studies have </span><a href="http://www.publicagenda.org/pages/csg-immigration"><span style="font-weight:400;">shown</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> that they are 30 percent more likely to start a new business and three times more likely to file a patent than native-born Americans. </span><span style="font-weight:400;">Forty percent of the companies on the Fortune 500 list in 2010 had been </span><span style="font-weight:400;">founded by an immigrant or the child of an immigrant. </span><span style="font-weight:400;">The competition created by immigrants may also</span><span style="font-weight:400;"> incentivize natives to perform better. According to a </span><a href="http://nber.org/papers/w18047"><span style="font-weight:400;">study</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> conducted by the National Bureau of Economic Research, greater rates of immigration coincide with a higher percentage of American natives graduating high school.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Moreover, an </span><a href="http://bakerinstitute.org/files/2311/"><span style="font-weight:400;">economic analysis</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> published in 2014 has concluded that adopting comprehensive immigration reform would increase wages, raise tax revenues, increase consumption of consumer goods, and create jobs</span><span style="font-weight:400;">.</span> <span style="font-weight:400;">Granting legal status to unauthorized workers is expected to increase their wages as well as those of native-born Americans.</span><span style="font-weight:400;"> It would increase GDP by 0.84 percent annually, totaling $1.5 trillion in additional income over 10 years.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">The Florida House of Representatives </span><a href="http://immigrationimpact.com/2016/02/05/florida-house-punishes-sanctuary-cities-bill-authorizing-military-force-against-refugees-passes-committee/"><span style="font-weight:400;">passed a bill</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> earlier this month that would force local police and government employees to act in place of federal immigration agencies by identifying and detaining undocumented workers and students. Failing to do so would cause them to be penalized in the form of fines of up to $5,000 per day. \xa0It should not be the responsibility of our local public officials to implement federal immigration policy. This represents a breach in the trust between residents and public service professionals like teachers and police officers -- a trust which is an essential thread in the fiber of a free society. Crime rates may actually increase because people will be reluctant to report crimes for fear of being deported. This bill may well weaken cooperation between state officials and local communities and perpetuate a cycle that prevents immigrants from flourishing and contributing to our economy.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Continuing to adopt legislation that alienates and persecutes immigrants or current citizens suspected of being undocumented is misguided and reckless. These populations should be given the chance to contribute and assimilate into our communities using an efficient and reasonable legal framework. These measures will foster economic and social progress in a way that reflects American values.</span>'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '515'), ('wp:post_date', '2016-03-07 11:30:00'), OrderedDict([('title', 'Gender Wage Gap in Florida'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2016/04/02/gender-wage-gap-in-florida/'), ('pubDate', 'Sat, 02 Apr 2016 00:13:02 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=549')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'By Tyler Worthington, Tian Ma, and Igor Lukashevich\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">One of the hottest topics in the 2016 presidential race is income inequality. Income inequality between the genders has been of particular interest. According to the </span><a href="https://www.whitehouse.gov/sites/default/files/docs/equal_pay_issue_brief_final.pdf"><span style="font-weight:400;">White House</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">, full-time working women are paid 78 cents for every dollar earned by a man. However, the labor market in the United States is far more nuanced than the White House seems to suggest. To see if their claim holds any water, Census Bureau data on the labor market in Florida were examined. The analysis found, </span><a href="http://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2015/04/14/on-equal-pay-day-everything-you-need-to-know-about-the-gender-pay-gap/"><span style="font-weight:400;">as many other researchers have already</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">, that the gap varies by age, education and occupation.</span>\n<!--more-->\n\nThe gender wage gap in Florida is significantly narrower than the national median. Data from the 2015 Current Population Survey show that women in Florida are paid 87 cents for every dollar earned by their male counterparts.\n\nHowever, this gap varies significantly as we go from comparing men and women in the aggregate to comparing men and women within the same age groups, education levels, and occupations. It’s misleading to analyze the earnings gap between 50-year-old women with Ph.D.’s working in the pharmaceutical industry to 22-year-old men working in food service and extrapolating that to the population as a whole. As the analysis gets closer to “comparing apples with apples,” men and women with similar characteristics actually have more similar incomes.\n\n<a href="https://www.shrm.org/Advocacy/Issues/CivilRights/Documents/Gender%20Wage%20Gap%20Final%20Report.pdf"><span style="font-weight:400;">Research shows</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> that age, experience, family decisions, education, and occupation are some of the main factors accounting for the gender wage gap. One major problem in analyzing this issue is the fact that since women who choose to raise families will earn less, even as women in professional positions are earning the same as their male counterparts, the average income for females will be lower than men’s. Certainly, sexism and outdated cultural norms regarding women in the workplace have had an impact on wages, but a gap may persist even when opportunities and incomes for women are equivalent to men in the same positions because of this statistical artifact.</span>\n\n<b>Age</b>\n<table style="height:283px;" width="646">\n<tbody>\n<tr>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">Age Group</span></td>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">Median Hourly Wage Gap</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">(cents for every dollar a man makes)</span></td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">16-25</span></td>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">100</span></td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">25-35</span></td>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">93</span></td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">36-45</span></td>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">89</span></td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">46-55</span></td>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">85</span></td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">56-65</span></td>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">84</span></td>\n</tr>\n</tbody>\n</table>\n<span style="font-weight:400;">The gender wage gap differs largely by age group as well. There is a significant closing of the gap among younger wage earners, especially those categorized as Millennials. One possible explanation for this could be the cultural changes that have been taking place in the United States for the past several decades. </span><a href="http://pubs.aeaweb.org/doi/pdfplus/10.1257/000282806777212350"><span style="font-weight:400;">The decrease in emphasis</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> on females’ role as a homemaker could potentially have encouraged women to pursue careers similar to those chosen by men. However, it is also possible that as women and men grow older, they make different work decisions based on the needs of their families.</span>\n\n<b>Occupation</b>\n<table>\n<tbody>\n<tr>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">Occupation Category</span></td>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">Median Hourly Wage Gap</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">(cents for every dollar a man makes)</span></td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">Technicians</span></td>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">77</span></td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">Managers</span></td>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">90</span></td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">Professionals</span></td>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">91</span></td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">Protective Services </span></td>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">100.00</span></td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">Sales</span></td>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">69</span></td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">Production, Craft, and Repair</span></td>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">93</span></td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">Personal Care and Personal Services</span></td>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">90</span></td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">Office and Admin</span></td>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">105</span></td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">Operators, \xa0Fabricators \xa0and Laborers </span></td>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">83</span></td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">Agriculture</span></td>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">75</span></td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">Food Prep, Building and Grounds, And Cleaning</span></td>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">90</span></td>\n</tr>\n</tbody>\n</table>\n<span style="font-weight:400;">A comparison of \xa0occupations types finds the gap also substantially different. Economists </span><a href="http://www.jstor.org/stable/2524915?seq=1#/h"><span style="font-weight:400;">Fields and Wolff</span></a> <a href="http://www.jstor.org/stable/2524915?seq=1#/h"><span style="font-weight:400;">found</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> occupations that require more skilled labor tend to see a closing of the gender pay gap over time. With the exception of technicians, almost every higher-skill occupation category in this analysis followed that trend.</span>\n\n<b>Education</b>\n<table>\n<tbody>\n<tr>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">Education Level</span></td>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">Median Hourly Wage Gap</span></td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">High School</span></td>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">85</span></td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">Some College</span></td>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">86</span></td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">Associate\'s-Vocational</span></td>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">85</span></td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">Associates-Academic</span></td>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">76</span></td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">Bachelors</span></td>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">84</span></td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">Graduate School</span></td>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">89</span></td>\n</tr>\n</tbody>\n</table>\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Finally, the gender pay gap shrinks as education level rises. As of 2014, the percentage of women with at least a bachelor\'s degree was </span><a href="http://blogs.census.gov/2015/10/07/women-now-at-the-head-of-the-class-lead-men-in-college-attainment/?cid=RS23"><span style="font-weight:400;">30.2 percent</span><span style="font-weight:400;">,</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> marking the first year that </span><a href="http://blogs.census.gov/2015/10/07/women-now-at-the-head-of-the-class-lead-men-in-college-attainment/?cid=RS23"><span style="font-weight:400;">‘they surpassed men, at 29.9%, in this accomplishment’</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">. The larger pay gaps observed in older age groups may also be due to different education levels between men and women in past decades.</span>\n\n<a href="https://public.tableau.com/views/FloridaWagesbyGenderandProfession/Dashboard2?:embed=y&amp;:display_count=yes&amp;:showTabs=y"><span style="font-weight:400;">Data visualization using Tableau</span></a> <a href="https://public.tableau.com/views/FloridaWagesbyGenderandProfession/Dashboard2?:embed=y&amp;:display_count=yes&amp;:showTabs=y"><span style="font-weight:400;">allows readers to </span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">see comparisons between women and men of the same age, occupation, and education level, see how the gender pay gap shrinks yet further. Once again, comparisons in the aggregate can be misleading.</span>\n\nAlthough the data do not allow for bold claims about what causes gender income inequality, both because of an insufficient sample size in our data and because of the nuances of this issue, the causes of gender pay inequality are more complex than the White House suggests. Looking at the U.S. labor market in the aggregate yields misleading results. The gap varies dramatically depending on age, education, and occupation.\n\n<i><span style="font-weight:400;">The interactive chart \xa0shows how wages vary by gender, race, education, and age.</span></i>\n\n<i><span style="font-weight:400;">The data taken \xa0from the U.S. Census and uses a sample size of 1,517 males and 1,556 females in Florida. \xa0People over age 65 were excluded, since that is the usual retirement age, and people with less than a 12th grade education, as the majority of the workforce has earned at least graduated high school.</span></i>\n\nClick on the image below to experience all the interactive features of the graph.\n\n<a href="https://public.tableau.com/views/FloridaWagesbyGenderandProfession_0/Dashboard2?:embed=y&amp;:display_count=yes&amp;:showTabs=y"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-555" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2016/04/capture.png" alt="Capture" width="769" height="510" /></a>\n\n&nbsp;'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '549'), ('wp:post_date', '2016-04-02 00:13:02'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2016-04-02 00:13:02'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'gender-wage-gap-in-florida'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', [OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'devoe-moore-center'), ('#text', 'DeVoe Moore Center')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'education'), ('#text', 'Education')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'gender-wage-gap'), ('#text', 'gender wage gap')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'income-inequality'), ('#text', 'income inequality')]), 'Microfinancing: Good for the Poor?'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2016/04/08/microfinancing-good-for-the-poor/'), ('pubDate', 'Fri, 08 Apr 2016 18:25:37 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoemoorecenter.wordpress.com/?p=564')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', '<span style="font-weight:400;">By Logan Shewmaker</span><span style="font-weight:400;">\n</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Many businesses start on loans. Traditionally, </span><a href="https://www.sba.gov/blogs/6-step-guide-how-get-business-loan"><span style="font-weight:400;">the loan process</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> works by allowing a business owner or individual to approach a bank, receive the money upfront, and then pay back the amount loaned out over a period of time. Bank loans range anywhere from a few hundred dollars to millions. Eligibility criteria usually include a favorable credit score or some form of collateral asset to ensure the lender will be paid back. But what if you have no credit or collateral? What about the impoverished people around the world that have the drive to start a business but are starting from zero?<img class="  wp-image-567 alignright" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2016/04/featuredimage1.jpeg" alt="featuredimage1" width="430" height="272" /> </span><!--more-->\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">In recent decades, the rise of microfinancing in developing areas has offered an alternative to traditional lending practices for the extremely poor. </span><a href="http://www.businessnewsdaily.com/4286-microfinance.html"><span style="font-weight:400;">Microfinancing</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> is exactly what it sounds like: providing very small loans of no more than a few hundred dollars to people with very limited means. By fostering local business growth through small-scale loans, microfinance appears to offer a highly efficient way to break the cycle of poverty. However, research has shown mixed results when testing the effectiveness of this method to promote economic and social progress.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Enterprising Solutions Global Consulting </span><a href="http://web.undp.org/execbrd/pdf/Main%20Report.pdf"><span style="font-weight:400;">released a report</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> in 2003 on the United Nations Capital Development Fund (</span><a href="http://www.uncdf.org/en/content/mandate-and-focus"><span style="font-weight:400;">UNCDF</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">). Using impact assessment surveys, the researchers tested whether microlending provides “poor clients with capital for investments, extra liquidity to allow them to take advantage of economic opportunities as they arise, and the opportunity to accumulate assets and gain access to savings to help protect against shocks in times of need.” The researchers assessed UNCDF microlending in several Least Developed Countries (LDC), including Nigeria, Malawi, and Haiti. The study found positive associations between participation in MFIs (Micro Finance Institutions) and investment in land as a household asset, secondary education, and risk protection for financial emergencies (medical expenses, natural disasters, etc.) when comparing treatment and control groups. </span>\n\n<a href="https://www.givedirectly.org/pdf/DFID_microfinance_evidence_review.pdf"><span style="font-weight:400;">Other studies</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> have yielded less promising results. Researchers at the UK Department for International Development reviewed dozens of studies on MFIs from several databases and determined that many of the reviewed cases were at a high risk of various selection, reporting, and attrition biases. Many studies did not test the validity of the instruments used or were not deemed rigorous enough. \xa0The researchers synthesized data from the studies to determine the impacts of MFIs on economic and social well-being. Most of these data were statistically insignificant. Overall, the researchers found the data to be inconclusive.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Impact assessment may be particularly difficult for MFIs because much of the quantitative data is subject to the potential bias of self-reporting. While many micro financing firms point to positive correlations between MFI participation and social progress, further research by independent agencies is needed to back this claim.</span>'), 'http://spark.fsu.edu/Project/165/Social-Entrepreneurship-Evaluation-Site-Visits')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_menu_item_xfn'), ('wp:meta_value', None)]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', OrderedDict([('title', 'Sheet 3 (1)'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/sheet-3-1/'), ('pubDate', 'Fri, 06 May 2016 19:33:04 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2016/05/sheet-3-1.png')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', None), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '593'), ('wp:post_date', '2016-05-06 19:33:04'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2016-05-06 19:33:04'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'closed'), ('wp:post_name', 'sheet-3-1'), ('wp:status', 'inherit'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'attachment'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('wp:attachment_url', 'https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2016/05/sheet-3-1.png'), ('wp:postmeta', [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wp_attached_file'), ('wp:meta_value', '/home/wpcom/public_html/wp-content/blogs.dir/848/80998613/files/2016/05/sheet-3-1.png')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wp_attachment_metadata'), ('wp:meta_value', 'a:5:{s:5:"width";i:963;s:6:"height";i:657;s:4:"file";s:85:"/home/wpcom/public_html/wp-content/blogs.dir/848/80998613/files/2016/05/sheet-3-1.png";s:5:"sizes";a:0:{}s:10:"image_meta";a:12:{s:8:"aperture";s:1:"0";s:6:"credit";s:0:"";s:6:"camera";s:0:"";s:7:"caption";s:0:"";s:17:"created_timestamp";s:1:"0";s:9:"copyright";s:0:"";s:12:"focal_length";s:1:"0";s:3:"iso";s:1:"0";s:13:"shutter_speed";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:0:"";s:11:"orientation";s:1:"0";s:8:"keywords";a:0:{}}}')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', 'Special Districts in Florida'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2016/05/09/special-districts-in-florida/'), ('pubDate', 'Mon, 09 May 2016 15:09:06 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/?p=610')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', '<span style="font-weight:400;">By: Matt Kelly and Tyler Worthington</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Former Speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives </span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tip_O%27Neill"><span style="font-weight:400;">Tip O’Neil</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> once said, “all politics is local,” meaning that politicians must appeal to local constituents to succeed. Yet political economy is arguably most opaque and complex at local levels. Local governments have grown as numerous as they are multifaceted. Over</span><a href="https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&amp;lr=&amp;id=lKWD2qwHPOUC&amp;oi=fnd&amp;pg=PR9&amp;dq=Berry+(2009)+special+districts&amp;ots=wccdCgbhnG&amp;sig=2TtwvLMBOSr75cg0JjWpC6Dwt68#v=onepage&amp;q=Berry%20(2009)%20special%20districts&amp;f=false"><span style="font-weight:400;"> the last 50 years, a new local government was created somewhere in the U.S. roughly every 18 hours.</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> Florida claims 410 incorporated municipalities and 67 counties but another 1650 smaller governments exist </span><a href="https://cms.bsu.edu/-/media/WWW/DepartmentalContent/MillerCollegeofBusiness/BBR/Publications/SpecialDistricts2012.pdf"><span style="font-weight:400;">under the radar</span></a> <a href="https://cms.bsu.edu/-/media/WWW/DepartmentalContent/MillerCollegeofBusiness/BBR/Publications/SpecialDistricts2012.pdf"><span style="font-weight:400;">of many in the general public and among elected officials</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">. </span>\n\n<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special-purpose_district"><span style="font-weight:400;">Special purpose districts</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> are local jurisdictions created by state legislation or local ordinances to serve a narrow purpose within a specified geographic area. Though individually small, Florida’s special purpose districts spent $13.9</span><span style="font-weight:400;">\xa0billion in 2014 (see <a href="https://public.tableau.com/profile/devoe.l.moore.center#!/vizhome/SpecialDistrictSpending/Sheet1">Figure 3</a></span><span style="font-weight:400;">).</span>\n\n<b>Figure 1:<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-593" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2016/05/sheet-3-1.png" alt="Sheet 3 (1)" width="963" height="657" /></b><!--more-->\n<p style="text-align:right;"><em><span style="font-weight:400;">Source: Florida Department of Economic Opportunity (see interactive graph </span><a href="https://public.tableau.com/views/NumberofSpecialDistrictsInFlorida/Sheet3?:embed=y&amp;:display_count=yes&amp;:showTabs=y"><span style="font-weight:400;">here</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">) </span></em></p>\n<span style="font-weight:400;">While municipalities, counties, and other “</span><a href="https://www.census.gov/newsroom/cspan/govts/20120301_cspan_govts_def_3.pdf"><span style="font-weight:400;">general purpose</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">” governments are run by elected public officials, a special purpose district’s administrators are often appointed. Special districts can serve a variety of purposes, from </span><a href="http://www.swfwmd.state.fl.us/"><span style="font-weight:400;">water supply management</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> and </span><a href="https://www.aclib.us/"><span style="font-weight:400;">library system administration</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">, to </span><a href="http://www.ouc.com/"><span style="font-weight:400;">utility service provision</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> and </span><a href="http://www.midwayfire.com/"><span style="font-weight:400;">fire protection</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">. Special districts do not include county school districts according to Florida’s legal definition.</span>\n\n<a href="http://www.floridajobs.org/community-planning-and-development/special-districts/special-district-accountability-program"><span style="font-weight:400;">In Florida</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">, special purpose districts are classified as </span><a href="http://www.floridajobs.org/community-planning-and-development/special-districts/special-district-accountability-program/an-introduction-to-special-districts#top"><span style="font-weight:400;">dependent or independent</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">. “Dependent” special districts must be created by general purpose governments. But if residents feel they are inadequately served by their local government, they can form an independent special district to provide specific functions. The governing bodies of dependent special districts are appointed by, or consist of members of the governing body of the county or city that created them, and their budgets must be approved by them. In contrast, “Independent” special districts can be governed by whomever property owners in the district choose, and are fiscally autonomous. About 62% of Florida’s special districts are independent (see </span><a href="https://public.tableau.com/profile/devoe.l.moore.center#!/vizhome/SpecialDistrictsSummary/Dashboard1"><span style="font-weight:400;">Figure 2</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">). Both dependent and independent special districts must comply with transparency standards set forth in </span><a href="http://www.leg.state.fl.us/statutes/index.cfm?App_mode=Display_Statute&amp;URL=0100-0199/0189/0189ContentsIndex.html"><span style="font-weight:400;">Chapter 189 of the Florida Statutes.</span></a>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Special districts typically have substantial administrative and fiscal independence, allowing for greater specialization and, in some cases, improved efficiencies. </span><a href="http://www.jstor.org/stable/30023951?seq=1#page_scan_tab_contents"><span style="font-weight:400;">Some economic research finds that increasing the number of special districts lowers the overall cost of services</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> to residents and consumers. However, special districts are sometimes created to simply </span><a href="http://goldwaterinstitute.org/en/work/topics/constitutional-rights/federalism/out-of-sight-how-special-taxing-districts-circumve/"><span style="font-weight:400;">circumvent debt limits that constrain general purpose governments</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">, and states with higher general purpose government spending tend to have more special districts. For example, in his book “</span><a href="http://www.amazon.com/Imperfect-Union-Representation-Governments-Institutions/dp/0521758351"><span style="font-weight:400;">Imperfect Union: Representation and Taxation in Multilevel Governments</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">,” University of Chicago political scientist </span><a href="http://harris.uchicago.edu/directory/faculty/christopher_berry"><span style="font-weight:400;">Christopher Berry</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> criticizes special district governance, contending that “each government has an incentive to overexploit the shared tax base to provide benefits to its special-interest constituency.”</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">While special districts are partially financed by general revenue from other local governments, most can raise revenue by issuing tax-free bonds, entering into contracts, taxing, and levying special property assessments. However, executives of special districts are often unelected, </span><a href="http://www.biblio.com/book/shadow-government-hidden-world-public-authorities/d/582859090"><span style="font-weight:400;">insulating them from the consequences of unpopular decisions.</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> In short, special purpose districts have many of the same powers as municipal and county governments, but lower standards of fiscal and political accountability. Twenty-eight percent of Florida’s special districts have no elected leadership (see </span><a href="https://public.tableau.com/profile/devoe.l.moore.center#!/vizhome/SpecialDistrictsSummary/Dashboard1"><span style="font-weight:400;">Figure 2</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">).</span>\n\n<b>Figure 2:<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-591" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2016/05/dashboard-1.png" alt="Dashboard 1" width="634" height="657" /></b>\n<p style="text-align:right;"><em><span style="font-weight:400;">Source: Florida Department of Economic Opportunity (see interactive graph </span><a href="https://public.tableau.com/profile/devoe.l.moore.center#!/vizhome/SpecialDistrictsSummary/Dashboard1"><span style="font-weight:400;">here</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">)</span></em></p>\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Comparing \xa0special districts across the nation is difficult because state laws governing their responsibilities and purposes vary widely. </span><a href="https://www.census.gov/govs/go/sd.html"><span style="font-weight:400;">According to the U.S. Census Bureau</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">, special districts (adhering to a </span><a href="https://www.census.gov/govs/go/special_district_governments.html"><span style="font-weight:400;">broader definition</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">) have more than tripled between 1952 and 2012, from 12,319 to 37,203. Nationwide, special districts spent over $208 billion in 2013, or 12.3% of total local government expenditures (see Table 1).</span>\n\n<b>Table 1: </b>\n\n<b>Nationwide Local Government Spending</b>\n<table>\n<tbody>\n<tr>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">Government Type</span></td>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">Spending (in thousands)</span></td>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">Percent of Total</span></td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">Counties</span></td>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">$384,835,379</span></td>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">22.8%</span></td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">Municipalities</span></td>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">$542,803,473</span></td>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">32.2%</span></td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">Townships</span></td>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">$51,024,124</span></td>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">3.0%</span></td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">Special Districts</span></td>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">$208,251,052</span></td>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">12.3%</span></td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">School Districts</span></td>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">$499,333,934</span></td>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">29.6%</span></td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">Total</span></td>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">$1,686,247,962</span></td>\n<td><span style="font-weight:400;">100.0%</span></td>\n</tr>\n</tbody>\n</table>\n<p style="text-align:right;"><em><span style="font-weight:400;">Source: United States Census Bureau</span></em></p>\n<span style="font-weight:400;">The DeVoe Moore Center collects revenue and spending data on special districts according to Florida’s legal definition, available at </span><a href="http://www.floridaopengov.org"><span style="font-weight:400;">www.Floridaopengov.org</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">. Special districts have grown precipitously. The number of special districts has more than doubled since 1990, from 728 to 1650. Spending more than doubled between 1994 and 2014, from just under $6 billion to $13.9 billion (see <a href="https://public.tableau.com/profile/devoe.l.moore.center#!/vizhome/SpecialDistrictSpending/Sheet1">Figure 3</a></span><span style="font-weight:400;">). In comparison, counties spent $39 billion in 2014, while municipalities spent $28 billion.</span>\n\n<b>Figure 3:<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-620" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2016/05/sheet-1.png" alt="Sheet 1" width="1204" height="823" /></b>\n<p style="text-align:right;"><em><span style="font-weight:400;">Source: Florida Department of Financial Services and\xa0<a href="http://www.Floridaopengov.org">www.Floridaopengov.org</a> (see interactive graph <a href="https://public.tableau.com/profile/devoe.l.moore.center#!/vizhome/SpecialDistrictSpending/Sheet1">here</a></span><span style="font-weight:400;">) </span></em></p>\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Given the size and scope of special purpose districts,</span><a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3saU5racsGE"><span style="font-weight:400;"> they generate remarkably little press coverage.</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> While mayors and county commissions are often credited with local accomplishments (or scandals), many government functions are carried out less accountably by special purpose districts. Any efforts to reform local governments will likely be ineffectual if special districts are ignored. If it’s true that “all politics is local,” special purpose districts deserve more attention.</span>\n\n&nbsp;\n\n&nbsp;\n\n<em>*Due to a spreadsheet error, this blog post mistakenly reported that total special district spending in 2014 was $14.8 billion when was originally posted May 9, 2016. The correct figure is $13.9 billion. Last updated: June 2, 2016.</em>'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '610'), ('wp:post_date', '2016-05-09 15:09:06'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2016-05-09 15:09:06'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'special-districts-in-florida'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), Miller, Policy Chief, Local Government Affairs Subcommittee - 2016-05-09 19:16:38'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/?post_type=feedback&p=619'), ('pubDate', 'Mon, 09 May 2016 19:16:38 +0000'), ('dc:creator', None), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'https://devoelmoorecenter.com/?post_type=feedback&p=619')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'Mssrs. Kelly &amp; Worthington: I read with interest your post about Florida Special Districts, particularly the cumulative financial information for 2014. We are in the process of updating the "Local Government Formation Manual" for the Florida House. If possible, would you please send me a reprint of your article with the imbedded graphs? If you have any questions, my direct line is 850-717-5681. Thank you.\nEric H. Miller\n<!--more-->\nAUTHOR: Eric H. Miller, Policy Chief, Local Government Affairs Subcommittee\nAUTHOR EMAIL: eric.miller@myfloridahouse.gov\nAUTHOR URL: \nSUBJECT: [The DeVoe L. Moore Center Blog] Contact Us\nIP: 206.201.188.1\nArray\n(\n    [1_Name] =&gt; Eric H. Miller, Policy Chief, Local Government Affairs Subcommittee\n    [2_Email] =&gt; eric.miller@myfloridahouse.gov\n    [3_Website] =&gt; \n    [4_Comment] =&gt; Mssrs. Kelly &amp; Worthington: I read with interest your post about Florida Special Districts, particularly the cumulative financial information for 2014. 23:49:23 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2016/05/sheet-1.png')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', None), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '620'), ('wp:post_date', '2016-06-02 23:49:23'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2016-06-02 23:49:23'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'closed'), ('wp:post_name', 'sheet-1'), ('wp:status', 'inherit'), ('wp:post_parent', '610'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'attachment'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('wp:attachment_url', 'https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2016/05/sheet-1.png'), ('wp:postmeta', [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wp_attached_file'), ('wp:meta_value', '/home/wpcom/public_html/wp-content/blogs.dir/848/80998613/files/2016/05/sheet-1.png')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wp_attachment_metadata'), ('wp:meta_value', 'a:5:{s:5:"width";i:1204;s:6:"height";i:823;s:4:"file";s:83:"/home/wpcom/public_html/wp-content/blogs.dir/848/80998613/files/2016/05/sheet-1.png";s:5:"sizes";a:0:{}s:10:"image_meta";a:12:{s:8:"aperture";s:1:"0";s:6:"credit";s:0:"";s:6:"camera";s:0:"";s:7:"caption";s:0:"";s:17:"created_timestamp";s:1:"0";s:9:"copyright";s:0:"";s:12:"focal_length";s:1:"0";s:3:"iso";s:1:"0";s:13:"shutter_speed";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:0:"";s:11:"orientation";s:1:"0";s:8:"keywords";a:0:{}}}')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', 'Special District Spending Priorities and Political Entrepreneurship'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2016/06/10/special-district-spending-priorities-and-political-entrepreneurship/'), ('pubDate', 'Fri, 10 Jun 2016 20:01:48 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/?p=622')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'By Matt Kelly and Tyler Worthington\n\n<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special-purpose_district"><span style="font-weight:400;">Special districts</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> are small local governments created by state statute or local ordinance to fulfill a particular purpose in a specified geographic area. Some special districts control the mosquito population in an area, while others are in charge of things like fire protection, library administration, or utility services. Unlike public officials in county, municipal, and other “general purpose” governments, those serving in special districts are often unelected. </span><a href="http://floridaopengov.org/"><span style="font-weight:400;">The DeVoe Moore Center collects data on Florida government spending</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">, including special districts. Special districts are most concentrated in South Florida and along the west coast (see </span><a href="https://public.tableau.com/profile/devoe.l.moore.center#!/vizhome/shared/CDS6XQGY9"><span style="font-weight:400;">figure 1</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">). Of total special district spending, 40% was used for health-related purposes, 14% for community development and 9% for housing assistance (see </span><a href="https://public.tableau.com/profile/devoe.l.moore.center#!/vizhome/WhatareSpecialDistrictssetuptodo/Story2"><span style="font-weight:400;">figure 3</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">). Districts serving other purposes, like water management, transportation, and waste management spent relatively little.</span>\n\n<b>Figure 1:</b>\n\n<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-648" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2016/06/dashboard-1-21.png" alt="Dashboard 1 (2)" width="634" height="657" />\n<p style="text-align:right;">(Source: Florida Department of Revenue)</p>\n<p style="text-align:right;"><!--more--></p>\n<span style="font-weight:400;">The size, number, and functions of special districts may reflect the local population’s need for public services. However, </span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_entrepreneur"><span style="font-weight:400;">political entrepreneurship</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">, or competition among public officials and businesses for profit by gaming the political system, also plays a role in determining district creation and spending priorities. According to Loyola University economist Thomas Dilorenzo, in order to avoid institutional restraints like </span><a href="http://www.ncsl.org/research/fiscal-policy/state-constitutional-and-statutory-requirements-fo.aspx#fl"><span style="font-weight:400;">Florida’s balanced budget amendment</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">, local governments sometimes create </span><a href="https://mises.org/library/competition-and-political-entrepreneurship-austrian-insights-public-choice-theory"><span style="font-weight:400;">“off-budget enterprises”</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">. Separate entities “are created by state and local governments, which could issue bonds that are not subject to the legal restrictions on public debt or even to voter approval.” Special districts are one such kind of “off-budget enterprise”. </span><a href="http://prq.sagepub.com/content/57/2/189.refs"><span style="font-weight:400;">When voters resist general purpose government spending on particular services and projects, politicians may simply shift spending into special districts</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">. The </span><a href="https://devoelmoorecenter.com/2016/05/09/special-districts-in-florida/"><span style="font-weight:400;">dramatic growth in the number of special districts</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> is a testament to political entrepreneurs’ success.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Where has political entrepreneurship been most active? </span><a href="https://public.tableau.com/views/WheredoSpecialDistrictsOperateinFlorida/Dashboard1?:embed=y&amp;:display_count=yes&amp;:showTabs=y"><span style="font-weight:400;">Figure 1</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> maps special districts onto the counties where they operate. Darker shades indicate greater numbers of special districts. Some provide services across county boundaries, but for simplicity’s sake we only include districts serving a single county. Hillsborough, Miami-Dade, Broward, and Palm Beach counties lead in the number of special districts. </span><a href="https://public.tableau.com/views/SpecialDistrictSpendingbyCounty/Dashboard2?:embed=y&amp;:display_count=yes&amp;:showTabs=y"><span style="font-weight:400;">Figure 2</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> shows each county’s special district spending. The average number of special districts in each county was 25, while spending totals in each county averaged $185 million. The number of special districts in a county is positively correlated with special district spending, with a </span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pearson_product-moment_correlation_coefficient"><span style="font-weight:400;">Pearson correlation coefficient</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> of about 0.6. A notable outlier is Orange County, whose relatively modest 46 districts spent a sizable $790 million in 2014. By comparison, Miami-Dade County had more than 100 special districts but spent $663 million.</span>\n\n<b>Figure 2:</b>\n\n<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-647" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2016/06/dashboard-2-2.png" alt="Dashboard 2 (2)" width="634" height="657" />\n<p style="text-align:right;">(Source: Florida Department of Revenue)</p>\n<span style="font-weight:400;">What purposes do these districts serve? </span><a href="https://public.tableau.com/views/GrowthofSpecialDistricts/Dashboard1?:embed=y&amp;:display_count=yes&amp;:showTabs=y"><span style="font-weight:400;">Figure 3</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> shows the number of special districts performing each function over time. </span><a href="https://public.tableau.com/views/SpecialDistrictSpendingbyFunction/Sheet3?:embed=y&amp;:display_count=yes&amp;:showTabs=y"><span style="font-weight:400;">Figure 4</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> shows a breakdown of special districts by function in 2014 alone. Of Florida 1650 special districts, 79 are drainage and water control districts, 61 are fire and rescue districts, 58 are soil and conservation districts, and 29 are health facility districts. </span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Community_Development_District"><span style="font-weight:400;">Community development districts</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> (CDDs) are most numerous and grew dramatically in number during the mid-2000s housing bubble, from 144 in 2001 to 607 today.</span>\n\n<b>Figure 3:<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-627" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2016/06/dashboard-1-1.png" alt="Dashboard 1 (1)" width="634" height="657" /></b>\n<p style="text-align:right;">(Source: Florida Department of Revenue)</p>\n<b>Figure 4:<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-628" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2016/06/sheet-3-2.png" alt="Sheet 3 (2)" width="963" height="352" /></b>\n<p style="text-align:right;">(Source: Florida Department of Revenue)</p>\n<span style="font-weight:400;">CDDs finance the construction of large neighborhoods, as well as the provision of public services to them. </span><a href="http://www.floridacddreport.com/cdd_news.cfm"><span style="font-weight:400;">Numerous news articles</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> have highlighted cases of likely abuse and corruption in CDDs. Since CDD board members are elected by landowners in a “one acre one vote” system rather than a majority of residents, </span><a href="http://lawpublications.barry.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1001&amp;context=barrylrev"><span style="font-weight:400;">developers can pressure board members at an early stage of construction to buy land from them at inflated prices.</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> CDDs pay for these purchases by issuing tax-free bonds tied to future property taxes from residents. </span><a href="http://www.tampabay.com/news/growth/if-you-live-in-a-cdd-community-pay-attention/1128542"><span style="font-weight:400;">Developers thus stand to benefit greatly from setting up a CDD.</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> CDDs provide a way for political entrepreneurs to capitalize on growing demand for housing while shifting the burdens of potential losses to taxpayers. </span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">But the downside is greater risk and exposure to failed projects. </span><a href="http://collinsinstitute.fsu.edu/sites/collinsinstitute.fsu.edu/files/CDD%20report%20FINAL%20Revised-Reformatted%207%2003%2014.pdf"><span style="font-weight:400;">A 2014 report by the Leroy Collins Institute</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> found that a lack of transparency and accountability in CDDs likely contributed to their financial decline following the housing bubble. </span><a href="http://www.floridacddreport.com/"><span style="font-weight:400;">Many CDDs went into default</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> after 2008, leaving residents with higher tax bills to compensate bondholders. As </span><a href="http://edq.sagepub.com/content/26/4/361.refs"><span style="font-weight:400;">an example of political entrepreneurship</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">, CDDs show how special districts can be used to enrich a few at the public’s expense.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">While community development districts are most numerous, hospital districts spent the most in 2014 (see </span><a href="https://public.tableau.com/views/SpecialDistrictSpendingbyFunction_0/Sheet2?:embed=y&amp;:display_count=yes&amp;:showTabs=y"><span style="font-weight:400;">figure 5</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">), with expenditures totaling almost $3.9 billion. CDDs, health care districts, housing authorities, and airport authorities followed. Districts specializing in water management, transportation, and waste management spent relatively little, making up 6,%, 3%, and 0.3% of total expenditures, respectively. While these spending priorities may simply reflect the desires of special district residents, political entrepreneurship may also have an influence. </span><a href="https://public.tableau.com/views/SpecialDistrictSpendingbyFunctionOverTime/Dashboard1?:embed=y&amp;:display_count=yes&amp;:showTabs=y"><span style="font-weight:400;">Figure 6</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> presents special district spending by function over time, showing how these priorities have changed.</span>\n\n<b>Figure 5:<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-629" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2016/06/sheet-2-1.png" alt="Sheet 2 (1)" width="963" height="300" /></b>\n<p style="text-align:right;">(Source: Florida Department of Revenue)</p>\n<b>Figure 6:<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-630" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2016/06/dashboard-1-2.png" alt="Dashboard 1 (2)" width="634" height="657" /></b>\n<p style="text-align:right;">(Source: Florida Department of Revenue)</p>\n<p style="text-align:left;"><span style="font-weight:400;">These data show the character and concentration of special districts across Florida. If special districts merely reflect the needs of the local population, their functions and spending behaviors may be in line with what would prevail if all public functions were undertaken by the general purpose government that created them. However, if special districts are the result of political entrepreneurship, the data presented here can tell us which functions and jurisdictions are most profitable to political entrepreneurs.</span></p>'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '622'), ('wp:post_date', '2016-06-10 20:01:48'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2016-06-10 20:01:48'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:meta_value', None)]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_menu_item_url'), ('wp:meta_value', 'http://coss.fsu.edu/d6/dmc/content/academic-studies-and-papers')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', 'Community Redevelopment Agencies'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2016/07/28/community-redevelopment-agencies/'), ('pubDate', 'Thu, 28 Jul 2016 19:57:22 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/?p=665')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'By Casey Barr\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Local governments face the perennial dilemma of obtaining money to fund community redevelopment projects. Requesting state or federal funds can be an </span><a href="https://www.cbo.gov/sites/default/files/113th-congress-2013-2014/reports/03-05-13FederalGrants_onecol.pdf"><span style="font-weight:400;">arduous bureaucratic process</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">, and these funds are often awarded to</span><a href="http://www.governing.com/topics/finance/gov-how-rural-communities-can-compete-for-development-cash.html"> <span style="font-weight:400;">larger, more prominent cities</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">, ignoring smaller towns where need is arguably greater. Community Redevelopment Agencies (CRAs) allow local governments to fund public and private projects by setting up special districts. This community designation and the public financing tools it utilizes are increasingly important parts of municipal budgeting. CRAs are not without their critics, however, and several scandals have erupted over their transparency, spending priorities, and ineffectiveness.</span>\n\n<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-671" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2016/07/stevenadams_via_flickr.jpg" alt="stevenadams_via_flickr" width="2400" height="1800" /><!--more-->\n\n<a href="http://www.leg.state.fl.us/Statutes/index.cfm?App_mode=Display_Statute&amp;URL=0100-0199/0163/0163.html"><span style="font-weight:400;">The Community Redevelopment Act of 1969</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> was a body of state legislation that allowed for the formation of CRAs in Florida. A </span><a href="https://devoelmoorecenter.com/2016/06/10/special-district-spending-priorities-and-political-entrepreneurship/"><span style="font-weight:400;">special district government</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">, the CRA, manages specific areas of the city deemed fit for redevelopment. A maximum of 80 percent of a municipality can be deemed a CRA. CRAs allow for the financing of private and public development projects through revenue bonds. Revenue bonds are loans paid back with a percentage of revenue generated by the development projects that they fund.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">CRAs can also take advantage of an indirect government subsidy program called </span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tax_increment_financing"><span style="font-weight:400;">tax increment financing</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> (TIF), wherein future increases in property tax revenues are deferred for a time and instead invested into the community through a trust fund. The CRA appraises the existing properties within its boundaries in order to establish a cumulative property value which will serve as a fixed tax base. Ideally, the property values within the CRA district increase over time, and the taxable revenue generated from property tax growth above the base amount (called the increment) is deposited in the CRA trust fund. The local government still receives the baseline amount of revenue, while the increment can only be spent by the CRA on projects within the district. This money can be invested in numerous ways: subsidizing commercial projects, awarding business grants, or constructing infrastructure.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">In theory, TIF provides local governments with a way to eliminate blight, but critics say that TIF isn’t effective and can even be a </span><a href="http://reason.org/files/cronyism_community_development.pdf"><span style="font-weight:400;">vehicle for crony capitalism</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">. Crony capitalism describes an economy where success depends on personal relationships with government officials rather than consumer demand or productivity as in a free market. There have been instances where</span><a href="http://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/shadow-budget-tif/Content?oid=1251320&amp;showFullText=true"> <span style="font-weight:400;">TIF funds were given to developers who made campaign contributions to local politicians</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">. </span><a href="http://www.sun-sentinel.com/local/palm-beach/delray-beach/fl-delray-redevelopment-agency-20150911-story.html"><span style="font-weight:400;">Some towns in Florida have seen conflict between city, county, and CRA governments over spending priorities</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> and </span><a href="http://www.floridabulldog.org/category/issues/community-redevelopment-agency-cra/"><span style="font-weight:400;">mismanagement of funds</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">The effectiveness of TIF in eliminating blight is also questionable.</span><a href="http://americandreamcoalition-org.adcblog.org/landuse/TIFsinIllinois.pdf"> <span style="font-weight:400;">A study by University of Illinois economists Richard F. Dye and David F. Merriman</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> found that property values in cities which use TIF-districts in order to stimulate development grow at the same rate, if not slower, than cities which do not use TIF. Dye and Merriman found evidence that when higher growth does occur in TIF-districts, it comes at the expense of non-TIF districts and leads to a lower growth rate for the city as a whole. Cities may face a decision of whether to eschew overall municipal growth in favor of the redevelopment of blighted areas.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">The City of Tallahassee has made liberal use of its own CRA. Launched in 1998, the </span><a href="https://www.talgov.com/cra/CRAHome.aspx"><span style="font-weight:400;">Tallahassee CRA</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> currently oversees two CRA districts: the Greater Frenchtown Redevelopment Area and the Downtown District Redevelopment Area. In both areas, CRA funding has assisted numerous public and private projects. </span><a href="https://www.talgov.com/cra/ecd-economic-downtown-cra.aspx"><span style="font-weight:400;">Notable examples</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> include the Marriott Residence Inn on West Gaines Street, the Tish Byrd Community Garden in Frenchtown, and the Alliance Center in downtown Tallahassee, as well as popular student housing properties College Town, the Catalyst, Onyx, and Stadium Centre. In 2015, the CRA awarded grants totalling $65,000 to help support 15 different festivals and parades. It also awarded business grants to architectural firm Lewis &amp; Whitlock, communications and design company Sachs Media Group, and Urban Outfitters, a popular retail clothing store.</span>\n\n<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-670" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2016/07/ecd-cra-horizon.jpg" alt="ecd-cra-horizon" width="550" height="300" />\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">The effectiveness of Tallahassee’s CRA spending, which is likely different from how the city government might have directed the funds, remains to be seen. CRAs are somewhat more insulated from voter sentiment, a typical feature of </span><a href="https://devoelmoorecenter.com/2016/06/10/special-district-spending-priorities-and-political-entrepreneurship/"><span style="font-weight:400;">special district governments</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">. The fact that much of the CRA’s funding benefits private for-profit enterprises means that a high level of transparency in CRA decision making is important for ensuring accountability and securing public trust. </span><a href="http://reason.org/files/cronyism_community_development.pdf"><span style="font-weight:400;">CRAs in California were found ultimately to be a vehicle for politicians to fund pet projects and award well-connected cronies</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">, and such abuse should be avoided.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">CRAs can be useful to local government financing redevelopment projects. By keeping all of the financing local, the CRA avoids the complicated and time-consuming process of requesting state or federal funds. However, CRAs have also been criticized because of a lack of transparency, a lack of evidence supporting their effectiveness, and examples of outright corruption. Free markets and private enterprise are essential for sustainable community development. To the extent that CRAs redirect tax dollars and private investment toward less productive activities, CRAs may do more harm than good. More attention should be paid to Tallahassee’s CRA to ensure it supports sustainable community redevelopment and doesn’t become another example of a CRA gone wrong.</span>'), ('excerpt:encoded', 'a:5:{s:5:"width";i:2400;s:6:"height";i:1800;s:4:"file";s:98:"/home/wpcom/public_html/wp-content/blogs.dir/848/80998613/files/2016/07/stevenadams_via_flickr.jpg";s:5:"sizes";a:0:{}s:10:"image_meta";a:12:{s:8:"aperture";s:3:"6.3";s:6:"credit";s:13:"Steven OrderedDict([('title', "New Report Analyzes Tallahassee's Permitting Process"), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2016/08/01/new-report-analyzes-tallahassees-permitting-process/'), ('pubDate', 'Mon, 01 Aug 2016 18:46:40 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/?p=683')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'By Matt Kelly\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">An efficient regulatory process is essential to the business development strategies of cities like Tallahassee, Florida. Regulations that are too cumbersome or unnecessary increase the cost of doing business without serving the public interest. The growth and negative impact of regulatory accumulation at the </span><a href="http://regdata.org/"><span style="font-weight:400;">federal level has been well documented</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">, but local land use and permitting processes have received less attention. To elucidate the local permitting process and assess its performance, the DeVoe Moore Center has mapped the permitting process for specific development types from start to finish. </span><a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B_41BWY6M6oHRnBTUHBMaG9jMXM/view"><span style="font-weight:400;">A recent report by Florida State University professor and director of the DeVoe Moore Center Samuel Staley and policy analyst Matthew Kelly</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> analyzes the permitting process for telecommunications towers, and finds it to be excessively lengthy and variable. </span>\n\n<b>Figure 1. Average number of days for telecommunications tower projects in Tallahassee, Florida’s regulatory permitting process<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-688" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2016/08/telecoms-data-picture-2.jpg" alt="telecoms data picture 2" width="989" height="660" /></b><!--more-->\n<p style="text-align:right;"><i><span style="font-weight:400;">(Source: </span></i><span style="font-weight:400;">Calculated by authors from Tallahassee Growth Management Department public records. The beginning of the process is marked by the issuance of a Land Use Compliance Certificate, and the end is marked by the issuance of a building permit. Values are given in the year a project began the process. No new towers were permitted in 2007, 2009 or 2010.)</span></p>\n<span style="font-weight:400;">The telecommunications sector provides an integral service, connecting people across great distances in a manner similar to the railroads of the 19th century. </span><a href="http://www.econlib.org/library/Enc/Telecommunications.html"><span style="font-weight:400;">Increased connectivity improves economic productivity by reducing the cost of communication and allowing labor to better specialize.</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> Whether current telecoms regulations serve the public interest is of importance to local economies, many of which would not otherwise have as much access to outside markets.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">The purpose of regulations should be to correct so-called “</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Market_failure"><span style="font-weight:400;">market failures</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">.” Examples of market failures include </span><a href="http://www.investopedia.com/terms/m/monopoly.asp"><span style="font-weight:400;">monopolies</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">, </span><a href="http://www.investopedia.com/terms/a/asymmetricinformation.asp"><span style="font-weight:400;">information asymmetries</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">, </span><a href="http://www.investopedia.com/terms/t/transactioncosts.asp?ad=dirN&amp;qo=investopediaSiteSearch&amp;qsrc=0&amp;o=40186"><span style="font-weight:400;">high transaction costs</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">, and </span><a href="http://www.investopedia.com/terms/e/externality.asp?ad=dirN&amp;qo=investopediaSiteSearch&amp;qsrc=0&amp;o=40186"><span style="font-weight:400;">externalities</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">. When a market failure exists and the private sector cannot correct it, government regulation may improve economic outcomes. However, government regulations also produce “</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Government_failure"><span style="font-weight:400;">government failures</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">.” Crony capitalists can </span><a href="http://www.investopedia.com/terms/r/rentseeking.asp"><span style="font-weight:400;">game the regulatory system for their advantage</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">. </span><a href="http://www.econlib.org/library/Enc/PriceControls.html"><span style="font-weight:400;">Price controls</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> and </span><a href="http://www.investopedia.com/terms/b/barrierstoentry.asp"><span style="font-weight:400;">barriers to entry</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> can create shortages. Overregulation discourages investment in a community and reduces the employment opportunities and income of residents. Government failures of regulation must be weighed against the market failures they are meant to counteract.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Tallahassee’s own permitting process for new telecommunications towers is lengthy and variable. A review of 29 telecommunications tower permit applications in Tallahassee determined that the average time spent in the permitting process between 1997 and 2011 was 274 days, ranging from a minimum of 7 days to a maximum of 688 days. Average wait times by year are presented in Figure 1. Regulatory fees levied on permit applicants averaged $2,224, 3 percent of the average project value of $66,684. Developers undergo a 10-step process, in which they must prove the need for their services, conduct geological tests, inventory natural features on their construction site, and comply with sometimes unusual and often illogical requests from regulators.</span>\n\nThe report also presents a case study of one tower developer\'s experience in the permitting process. Beginning in 2010, Tallahassee businessman DeVoe Moore and information technology specialist Freddie Figgers spent 258 days obtaining necessary permits to build a telecoms tower. A log detailing 90 phone calls and 50 trips to government regulatory agencies was kept by Moore and Figgers, who described their experience as "procrastinated". Their\xa0experience appears to be typical of the process as a whole.\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">The length and variability of the permit times suggested that local regulators wield substantial discretion over the pace of approvals at different stages of the development process. This creates uncertainty in the regulatory process and, to the extent it fails to correct market failures or creates new government failures, discourages private investment and economic development.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Conversations with tower developers in Tallahassee and throughout Florida suggested that publicly owned towers experience fewer delays, while private developers face a more confusing process. Permitting is carried out by multiple government agencies, many of which fail to properly coordinate their duties. Though developers disagreed about the degree to which local regulators hinder tower construction, most said the process is needlessly lengthy and requests often have no rational purpose. </span><span style="font-weight:400;">Consumers ultimately pay for these delays and regulatory costs through higher prices, less access, or less service diversity.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Improving Tallahassee’s permitting process is of significant importance to its economic growth strategy. Some businesses that have prospered here for years have </span><a href="http://www.tallahassee.com/story/money/2016/05/06/longtime-business-relocates-due-quincys-favorable-business-climate/83990526/"><span style="font-weight:400;">moved elsewhere explicitly because of the burdensome red tape of regulations</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">. The telecoms tower construction boom has already subsided for the most part, but streamlining and simplifying the regulatory process as a whole can ensure that future innovations are not similarly stifled. Such reforms could be accomplished without sacrificing the safety of residents, since many delays analyzed in this report did not serve a public safety purpose anyway. To read more about potential policy changes that could improve Tallahassee’s regulatory environment, </span><a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B_41BWY6M6oHRnBTUHBMaG9jMXM/view"><span style="font-weight:400;">read the full policy report</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">. To attract investment and jobs, Tallahassee needs a regulatory system fit for the twenty-first century.</span>'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '683'), ('wp:post_date', '2016-08-01 18:46:40'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2016-08-01 18:46:40'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'new-report-analyzes-tallahassees-permitting-process'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('category', [OrderedDict([('@domain', 'category'), ('@nicename', 'devoe-moore-center'), ('#text', 'DeVoe Moore Center')]), OrderedDict([('@domain', 'post_tag'), ('@nicename', 'devoe-moore-center'), ('#text', 'DeVoe Moore Center')]),
