But how are spending and organizational decisions made in a CRA?</span>\n\n<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-711" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2016/08/cra_map.jpg" alt="cra_map" width="6000" height="8000" />\n<p style="text-align:right;">(Source: City of Tallahassee. Available at:\xa0https://www.talgov.com/cra/CRAHome.aspx)<!--more--></p>\n<span style="font-weight:400;">CRAs can only be established when two governmental units, such as the City of Tallahassee and Leon County, come together to construct an interlocal agreement. In order to declare that a particular part of the city is fit for redevelopment, the CRA must first survey the area in question and construct a</span><a href="http://www.leg.state.fl.us/Statutes/index.cfm?App_mode=Display_Statute&amp;Search_String=&amp;URL=0100-0199/0163/Sections/0163.335.html"><span style="font-weight:400;"> “</span><span style="font-weight:400;">finding of necessity</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">.” The finding of necessity documents all sources of “blight” or “slum” when surveying a prospective area for redevelopment. A slum can be thought of as of an area characterized by decrepit human conditions, while an area is blighted mostly due to the condition of its real estate. Ideally, the CRA\'s spending programs should reflect the needs cited in the finding of necessity. However, a <a href="http://coss.fsu.edu/d6/dmc/sites/default/files/policybrief32_0.pdf">2009 Policy report on CRAs in Florida by Heather Khan for the DeVoe Moore Center found</a> a "deep disconnect between the slum and blight conditions cited in the blight study [also called the "finding of necessity"] and the content of the redevelopment plan."</span><!--more-->\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">After the local governments establish a CRA, they draft a Community Redevelopment Plan and establish a </span><a href="https://www.talgov.com/Uploads/Public/Documents/cra/pdf/00-O-51.pdf"><span style="font-weight:400;">trust fund</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> for the CRA to spend as its board members see fit. A CRA board must be composed of 5 to 9 commissioners –</span><a href="https://www.talgov.com/cra/cra-board.aspx"> <span style="font-weight:400;">Tallahassee’s currently has 9</span></a> <span style="font-weight:400;">– all of whom are elected officials in county or city government. These positions are unpaid, though commissioners are reimbursed for any travel expenses related to the job. The CRA makes decisions on a wide array of issues, such as apportioning money for use as business grants, issuing revenue bonds for a particular redevelopment activity, and modifying the Community Redevelopment Plan.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Which redevelopment projects ultimately receive funding? The choosing, planning, and subsequent funding of redevelopment projects are solely the responsibility of the CRA board. In hopes of securing grants to assist with project funding, </span><a href="http://www.tallahassee.com/story/news/2015/12/04/arts-groups-pushing-big-plans-cultural-district/76576464/"><span style="font-weight:400;">business owners, community leaders, and developers deliver presentations</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> highlighting the number of jobs a particular business might bring or the amount of taxable revenue it is projected to generate. Each commissioner gets a single vote per project, cast at</span><a href="http://www.boarddocs.com/fla/talgov/Board.nsf/files/A8YKGE4D3906/$file/Attachment%203.pdf"> <span style="font-weight:400;">CRA board meetings</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> held in the City Commission chambers at City Hall. </span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">One project that found consensus with the Tallahassee CRA board was the sale of 715 West Gaines Street, which was sold by the CRA to developers </span><a href="http://www.naproperties.com/"><span style="font-weight:400;">North American Properties</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> for $788,000 ($18,000 more than the initial offer).The Tallahassee CRA originally obtained the property in a </span><a href="http://www.tallahassee.com/story/news/local/2014/04/25/land-swap/8136285/"><span style="font-weight:400;">land swap deal</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> with the Florida State University in 2014 in exchange for a 5-acre parcel of land that the university plans to use to construct a new building for the </span><a href="http://business.fsu.edu/legacy-hall/news/2014/11/12/florida-cabinet-approves-land-swap-to-benefit-college-of-business"><span style="font-weight:400;">College of Business</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">. North American Properties, however, </span><a href="http://www.naproperties.com/developer-opens-gaines-street-projects-plans-grocery/"><span style="font-weight:400;">plans to use their newly acquired land to build more student housing and retail space</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">, as well as potentially opening a grocery store. North American Properties will not request CRA funds to fund the development of the property, instead relying on private investment and financing.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Not every decision is met with unanimity, however. Commissioners disagreed on </span><a href="http://www.tallahassee.com/story/money/2016/06/23/cra-debate-turns-tense-over-south-city-district-discussion/86290280/"><span style="font-weight:400;">whether to add new areas to the CRA</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> earlier this year. In another case </span><a href="http://www.tallahassee.com/story/news/2015/03/24/cra-meeting-stirs-contentious-debate/70388540/"><span style="font-weight:400;">\xa0in March 2015</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">, board members voted 5-3 to keep discussion open on a business magnet program that would relocate existing businesses to areas within a CRA district. Moving businesses around, rather than stimulating the development of new self-sustaining growth, is a </span><a href="http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0094119099921496"><span style="font-weight:400;">common effect of CRA activity</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">. City Commissioner Scott Maddox opined that the business magnet program would create a winner-and-loser scenario. He noted that businesses would likely leave other areas in the city they currently occupy to go to areas in the Frenchtown CRA district, and therefore not contribute to overall growth.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">How are CRA decisions evaluated? In 2015, the Tallahassee CRA adopted</span><a href="https://www.talgov.com/Uploads/Public/Documents/cra/pdf/cra_performance_measures.pdf"> <span style="font-weight:400;">objective performance measures</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> to be reviewed each fiscal year. So far, the Tallahassee CRA has achieved 9 out of its 13 goals, with another partially met. For instance, post-development taxable value for properties funded by the CRA \xa0has increased 20 percent on average, and major redevelopment projects were started twice a year. An annual commitment of at least 85 percent of CRA small business grant funds to its targeted areas was partially achieved. Some objectives, such as “improving the quality of life in Tallahassee,” are evaluated by inputs (like the amount of grants to special events and promotions) rather than outcomes.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Knowing \xa0how decisions are made in the Tallahassee CRA is an important part of holding elected city and county officials accountable for how they spend taxpayer money. To find out more about the Tallahassee CRA’s activities, see their 2016 meeting schedule</span><a href="https://www.talgov.com/uploads/public/documents/cra/pdf/cra_board_2016.pdf"> <span style="font-weight:400;">here</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">, and access records of meeting agendas and minutes available</span><a href="http://www.boarddocs.com/fla/talgov/Board.nsf/goto?open&amp;id=A9LFNF3FECF5"> <span style="font-weight:400;">here</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">.</span>'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '701'), ('wp:post_date', '2016-08-31 20:41:18'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2016-08-31 20:41:18'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', OrderedDict([('title', "The Per Business Regulatory Burden: Ranking Florida's Local Governments"), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2016/09/08/the-per-business-regulatory-burden-ranking-floridas-local-governments/'), ('pubDate', 'Thu, 08 Sep 2016 20:10:42 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/?p=730')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'By Matt Kelly and Tyler Worthington\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">The </span><a href="http://www.usnews.com/opinion/blogs/peter-roff/2015/05/16/the-real-cost-of-regulation-is-keeping-america-down"><span style="font-weight:400;">dramatic increase in federal government regulation</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> has been well documented by economists and journalists, as has its </span><a href="http://mercatus.org/publication/cumulative-cost-regulations"><span style="font-weight:400;">detrimental effects on economic growth</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">. The DeVoe Moore Center has constructed assorted measures of state and local regulatory restrictiveness. This article focused on revenues collected per business on the local level as a measure of relative regulatory burden (see </span><a href="https://public.tableau.com/profile/devoe.l.moore.center#!/vizhome/TotalRegulatoryBurdenbyCounty/Dashboard1"><span style="font-weight:400;">figure 1</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">).</span>\n\n<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-734" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2016/09/dashboard-1-3.png" alt="dashboard-1-3" width="634" height="696" /><a href="https://public.tableau.com/views/TotalRegulatoryBurdenbyCounty/Dashboard1?:embed=y&amp;:display_count=yes"><b>Figure 1. Ranking Florida’s local governments: local regulatory fees and taxes</b></a><b>. (</b><b><i>Sources</i></b><b>: Data from the Florida Department of Revenue and the US Census Bureau.)</b><!--more-->\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Before opening a store or other establishment, businesses and individuals often must obtain permits from local governments. Obtaining a permit typically involves multiple steps and fees payable to one or more government agencies in charge of regulating the activity. For instance, </span><a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B_41BWY6M6oHRnBTUHBMaG9jMXM/view"><span style="font-weight:400;">a recent study by the DeVoe Moore Center maps ten steps necessary to obtain a building permit for telecommunications tower construction</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">. Fees for 29 towers permitted in Tallahassee between 1997 and 2011 averaged $2,224, 3 percent of the average project’s value. Developers and residents must also pay impact fees, occupational licensing fees, special assessments, and some companies also pay franchise fees. </span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Because the fees levied on businesses and individuals by local governments vary, we added the regulation-related fees and taxes collected by both municipal and county governments within a county’s boundaries and then divided by the number of business establishments. This measure is meant to approximate the average regulatory burden on business in the county, although we exclude some costs such as wait times, consultant fees, compliance costs, and other less tangible costs associated with the regulatory process .</span>\n\n<a href="https://public.tableau.com/profile/devoe.l.moore.center#!/vizhome/TotalRegulatoryBurdenbyCounty/Dashboard1"><span style="font-weight:400;">Figure 1</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> ranks Florida’s counties by per business revenues from regulation-related fees and taxes collected by county governments and municipal governments within each county\'s borders in 2014. This includes</span><a href="http://www.homeadvisor.com/cost/architects-and-engineers/get-a-building-permit/"><span style="font-weight:400;"> building permit fees</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> paid by businesses to legally undertake construction, </span><a href="http://coss.fsu.edu/dmc/sites/coss.fsu.edu.dmc/files/Ihlanfeldt_Shaughnessy.pdf"><span style="font-weight:400;">impact fees</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> paid by developers for the cost of providing public services to new developments, local </span><a href="http://www.flsenate.gov/Laws/Statutes/2012/Chapter205"><span style="font-weight:400;">business taxes</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> levied on professionals obtaining occupational licenses, </span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special_assessment_tax"><span style="font-weight:400;">special assessments</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> occasionally levied in order to pay for one-off government spending projects, </span><a href="http://fernandinaobserver.com/2012/08/23/what-the-heck-is-a-franchise-fee-anyway/"><span style="font-weight:400;">franchise fees</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> which utility companies pay local governments to use the public right-of-way, and other unspecified regulatory fees included in local government budgets. Spending trends for these government revenue categories and many others going back to 1994 can be explored </span><a href="http://floridaopengov.org/"><span style="font-weight:400;">here</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">. On average, local governments collect $5,264 in regulation-related revenue per business, with a median of $5,276.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Figures 2–6 rank Florida’s counties by the components of the total regulatory burden. Only the top 25 counties are shown in figures 2-6, but all of Florida’s 67 counties can be viewed in the links below each figure. The number of business establishments in a county is denoted by the shade of each bar, with darker shades indicating more businesses residing in that county.</span>\n\n<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-735" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2016/09/dashboard-3.png" alt="dashboard-3" width="634" height="696" /><a href="https://public.tableau.com/views/BusinessTaxPerBusiness/Dashboard3?:embed=y&amp;:display_count=yes"><b>Figure 2. Ranking Florida’s counties: business taxes</b></a><b>. (</b><b><i>Sources</i></b><b>: Data from the Florida Department of Revenue and the US Census Bureau.)</b>\n\n<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-736" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2016/09/dashboard-2-1.png" alt="dashboard-2-1" width="634" height="696" /><a href="https://public.tableau.com/profile/devoe.l.moore.center#!/vizhome/BuildingPermitFeesPerBusiness/Dashboard2">Figure 3. Ranking Florida’s counties: building permits</a><b>. (</b><b><i>Sources</i></b><b>: Data from the Florida Department of Revenue and the US Census Bureau.)</b>\n\n<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-737" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2016/09/dashboard-5.png" alt="dashboard-5" width="634" height="696" /><a href="https://public.tableau.com/views/FranchiseFeesPerBusiness/Dashboard5?:embed=y&amp;:display_count=yes"><b>Figure 4. Ranking Florida’s counties: franchise fees</b></a><b>. (</b><b><i>Sources</i></b><b>: Data from the Florida Department of Revenue and the US Census Bureau.)</b>\n\n<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-738" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2016/09/dashboard-4.png" alt="dashboard-4" width="634" height="696" /><a href="https://public.tableau.com/views/ImpactFeesPerBusiness/Dashboard4?:embed=y&amp;:display_count=yes"><b>Figure 5. Ranking Florida’s counties: impact fees</b></a><b>. (</b><b><i>Sources</i></b><b>: Data from the Florida Department of Revenue and the US Census Bureau.)</b>\n\n<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-739" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2016/09/dashboard-6.png" alt="dashboard-6" width="634" height="696" /><a href="https://public.tableau.com/views/SpecialAssessmentsPerBusiness/Dashboard6?:embed=y&amp;:display_count=yes"><b>Figure 6. Ranking Florida’s counties: special assessments</b></a><b>. (</b><b><i>Sources</i></b><b>: Data from the Florida Department of Revenue and the US Census Bureau.)</b>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">On average, local governments collect $192 per business for business taxes, but the median was only $97. This suggests local governments in a small number of counties collect much more business taxes per business than others. Building permit fees collected per business are higher but more evenly distributed, with an average of $697 and a median of $568. Per business revenues from impact fees averaged $540, with a median of $120, suggesting some counties have local governments collecting a lot more of these fees per business than others. Franchise fees were relatively evenly distributed, with an average of $1,130 per business and a median of $898 per business (franchise fees were relatively high, but these fees are levied only on certain businesses). Special assessments averaged $2,443 per business, a substantial sum, with a median of $1,394, again suggesting a small number of counties are levying sizable special assessments per business.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Regulation-related fees and taxes vary from place to place. </span><a href="https://ideas.repec.org/a/eee/regeco/v46y2014icp167-176.html"><span style="font-weight:400;">Some counties have cities of a size and economic importance to attract residents and businesses despite high taxes</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">. Others don’t. </span><a href="http://www.areadevelopment.com/Corporate-Consultants-Survey-Results/Q1-2015/annual-corporate-executive-business-expansion-survey-287775.shtml"><span style="font-weight:400;">Labor market conditions, public services, and access to markets are most important</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> in determining businesses’ location decisions, but </span><a href="https://rio.jrc.ec.europa.eu/en/file/9593/download?token=lCll8H3e"><span style="font-weight:400;">regulation and taxes remain important factor</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">. Holding all else constant, a higher regulatory burden makes a location less attractive to businesses.</span>'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '730'), ('wp:post_date', '2016-09-08 As of 2012 states spent an estimated </span><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2012/12/01/us/government-incentives.html"><span style="font-weight:400;">$80.4 billion annually on tax incentives for businesses</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">. Yet, </span><a href="http://www.jstor.org.proxy.lib.fsu.edu/stable/pdf/4355170.pdf"><span style="font-weight:400;">most economic research on the subject</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> finds that targeted tax incentives are ineffective at attracting businesses, creating jobs, or improving a state’s economic performance.</span><span style="font-weight:400;"> In 2014, </span><a href="http://www.stateincentives.org/media/2015/outcomes/Florida_State_Specific_Report_-_November_2015.pdf"><span style="font-weight:400;">Florida spent $367 million on economic development programs and forewent $1.2 billion in such tax expenditures.</span></a>\n\n<img class=" size-full wp-image-763 aligncenter" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2016/10/taxincentive_480_auto.jpg" alt="taxincentive_480_auto" width="480" height="270" /><!--more-->\n\n<a href="http://edq.sagepub.com/content/15/1/90.abstract"><span style="font-weight:400;">Tax incentives have been gaining popularity</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> since the unemployment crises of the 1970s and the recessions of the early 1980s, when states began competing with each other to lure businesses. </span><a href="http://greyhill.com/economic-development-incentive"><span style="font-weight:400;">Tax incentives come in many forms</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">, including corporate income tax credits, property tax abatements, sales tax exemptions, and payroll tax refunds. Some incentive packages include direct grants and special financing deals. States offer eligibility to firms and industries they consider most likely to spur employment and spending. For example, </span><a href="http://www.kauffman.org/~/media/kauffman_org/research%20reports%20and%20covers/2015/10/shortchanging_small_business.pdf"><span style="font-weight:400;">Florida’s Qualified Target Industry Tax Refund is offered to businesses in aviation and aerospace, life sciences, and manufacturing, among others.</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> In Florida, most tax incentive programs are administered by the public-private partnership </span><a href="https://www.enterpriseflorida.com/"><span style="font-weight:400;">Enterprise Florida</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">, the </span><a href="http://dor.myflorida.com/Pages/default.aspx"><span style="font-weight:400;">Department of Revenue</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">, and the </span><a href="http://www.floridajobs.org/"><span style="font-weight:400;">Department of Economic Opportunity</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">. </span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">State governments offer these benefits to specific industries, often courting particular companies from out-of-state. For instance, </span><a href="http://knowledgecenter.csg.org/kc/content/after-state-bidding-war-tesla-picks-nevada-new-factory-site"><span style="font-weight:400;">multiple states engaged in a bidding war for a Tesla factory</span><span style="font-weight:400;"> in 2014</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">. However, predicting winners and losers in a market economy is difficult for public officials and private investors alike. For instance, </span><a href="http://www.goodjobsfirst.org/sites/default/files/docs/pdf/shortchanging.pdf"><span style="font-weight:400;">state tax incentive programs are biased toward big businesses</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">, despite the fact that </span><a href="https://www.sba.gov/content/small-business-gdp-update-2002-2010%20"><span style="font-weight:400;">small businesses employ far more people and contribute more to GDP</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">. </span><span style="font-weight:400;">Businesses receiving incentives generally </span><a href="http://edr.state.fl.us/Content/returnoninvestment/ROI-SelectEconDevIncentives.pdf"><span style="font-weight:400;">employed fewer people and spent less than national and regional averages for their industries</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">. </span><a href="http://edr.state.fl.us/Content/returnoninvestment/EDR_ROI.pdf"><span style="font-weight:400;">A report</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> by Florida’s Office of Economic and Demographic Research found that </span><span style="font-weight:400;">only half the targeted number of jobs had been created by companies receiving incentives. </span><span style="font-weight:400;">From a national perspective, </span><a href="http://research.upjohn.org/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1064&amp;context=empl_research"><span style="font-weight:400;">tax incentives sometimes result in no net growth</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> as firms that would have resided in one state merely move to another.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Despite their ubiquity, state tax incentive programs are ineffective at increasing employment. Deciding which industries and businesses would be most beneficial is the main difficulty. Interventions of this kind risk a misallocation of resources from productive industries and into less productive ones. </span><a href="http://home.uchicago.edu/~vlima/courses/econ200/spring01/hayek.pdf"><span style="font-weight:400;">Information about the demand for and scarcity of resources is communicated to producers and consumers through prices</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">. Firms employ labor and capital equipment in different industries, in part, because of the profits they expect to make. </span><span style="font-weight:400;"><a href="http://mercatus.org/publication/political-economy-state-provided-targeted-benefits">When state governments favor one industry over others using the tax code, prices are distorted</a>, and p</span><span style="font-weight:400;">rofits do not reflect market costs. Industries that aren’t necessarily productive or efficient thus receive an advantage in the tax code. While the industries that are most valued and beneficial in terms of employment are constantly changing, </span><a href="http://mercatus.org/sites/default/files/Coyne_TargetedBenefits_v2.pdf"><span style="font-weight:400;">tax incentives can remain in place for years.</span></a>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">If a state is a good location for a firm, the firm will move there on their own accord because their incentives are aligned with long term profitability. When a company moves to a state because of tax benefits, they receive a competitive advantage because of lower production costs. Local </span><a href="https://www.mercatus.org/publication/political-economy-state-provided-targeted-benefits"><span style="font-weight:400;">companies not receiving incentives struggle in the face of increased competition, and sometimes fail, even if they are more productive than firms receiving incentives.</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> Allowing markets, rather than public officials, to determine where firms locate provides an even playing field at a lower cost to taxpayers. </span><a href="http://www.goodjobsfirst.org/levelfield"><span style="font-weight:400;">Small businesses themselves support a simpler tax code with few loopholes, low rates, and a broad base over targeted tax incentives</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Tax incentives have not been effective at promoting economic development. A simpler tax code with few loopholes, low rates, and a broad base would be more likely to attract business and provide a fair playing field for all firms.</span>'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2016/10/taxincentive_480_auto.jpg')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', None), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '763'), ('wp:post_date', '2016-10-04 16:52:38'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2016-10-04 16:52:38'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'closed'), ('wp:post_name', 'taxincentive_480_auto'), ('wp:status', 'inherit'), ('wp:post_parent', '754'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'attachment'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', '0'), ('wp:attachment_url', 'https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2016/10/taxincentive_480_auto.jpg'), ('wp:postmeta', [OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wp_attached_file'), ('wp:meta_value', '/home/wpcom/public_html/wp-content/blogs.dir/848/80998613/files/2016/10/taxincentive_480_auto.jpg')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wp_attachment_metadata'), ('wp:meta_value', 'a:6:{s:5:"width";i:480;s:6:"height";i:270;s:4:"file";s:97:"/home/wpcom/public_html/wp-content/blogs.dir/848/80998613/files/2016/10/taxincentive_480_auto.jpg";s:5:"sizes";a:0:{}s:10:"image_meta";a:12:{s:8:"aperture";s:1:"0";s:6:"credit";s:0:"";s:6:"camera";s:0:"";s:7:"caption";s:0:"";s:17:"created_timestamp";s:1:"0";s:9:"copyright";s:0:"";s:12:"focal_length";s:1:"0";s:3:"iso";s:1:"0";s:13:"shutter_speed";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:0:"";s:11:"orientation";s:1:"0";s:8:"keywords";a:0:{}}s:8:"filesize";i:65776;}')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', 'Anti-Price Gouging laws Hamper Storm Recovery'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2016/10/07/anti-price-gouging-laws-hamper-storm-recovery/'), ('pubDate', 'Fri, 07 Oct 2016 14:28:36 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/?p=767')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'By Chad Thomas\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Prices can tell us a lot. They communicate information about the value of resources in an economy and coordinate action among myriad buyers and sellers, many of whom have never met. The price system often comes into question </span><span style="font-weight:400;"><a href="http://www.wral.com/north-carolina-questioning-2-more-gas-station-s-prices/16037591/">in the aftermath of a natural disaster</a>\xa0like Hurricanes Hermine and <a href="https://www.wunderground.com/hurricane/atlantic/2016/Hurricane-Matthew">Matthew</a></span><span style="font-weight:400;">, </span><a href="http://www.wral.com/north-carolina-questioning-2-more-gas-station-s-prices/16037591/"><span style="font-weight:400;">as when companies raise</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> prices in response to spikes in demand for scarce resources. However, this business practice, commonly referred to as “price gouging,” may </span><a href="https://fee.org/articles/on-price-gouging/"><span style="font-weight:400;">actually aid in disaster recovery</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">.</span>\n\n<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-769" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2016/10/ap_16280630167264-0.jpg" alt="ap_16280630167264-0" width="1280" height="853" /><!--more-->\n\n<span>After a natural disaster, the availability and demand for goods and services abruptly changes. Roads may be blocked and electricity may be unavailable. </span><span>Batteries, flashlights, water, food, gasoline and other necessities become more valuable before, during, and after a storm. Many </span><span><a href="http://www.wtxl.com/news/attorney-general-s-office-investigating-price-hiking-complaints-after-hermine/article_1dd105ae-75f5-11e6-8a89-ff24a2ac9e6f.html">Tallahassee</a>\xa0</span><span>residents recently experienced this first hand with Hurricane Hermine.</span><span> Businesses are incentivized to increase prices under such circumstances. Inflated prices can signal what and where goods and services are needed most and encourage businesses, both within and outside the affected community, to move increased numbers of these goods into the area. No one likes to pay more for necessities after a storm, but </span><a href="http://www.econlib.org/library/Columns/y2007/Mungergouging.html"><span>allowing prices to fluctuate in response to demand and supply can aid in disaster recovery.</span></a>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">From the perspective of consumers, price increases during natural disasters can feel exploitative - and public officials apparently share this sentiment. Some states including </span><a href="http://myfloridalegal.com/pages.nsf/Main/351A2341C335428185257038005FB8AB"><span style="font-weight:400;">Florida</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">, </span><a href="http://legis.la.gov/Legis/Law.aspx?d=85680"><span style="font-weight:400;">Louisiana</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">, </span><a href="http://www.ag.ny.gov/price-gouging"><span style="font-weight:400;">New York</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">, and </span><a href="http://nj.gov/governor/news/news/552012/approved/20121027c.html"><span style="font-weight:400;">New Jersey</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> have laws against price gouging that go into effect after a hurricane strikes. These laws set a price ceiling for certain products. </span><a href="http://www.cnbc.com/id/49622944"><span style="font-weight:400;">New Jersey “considers price increases of more than 10 percent during a declared state of emergency to be excessive” and may impose fines on companies that implement them</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">. During Hurricane Hermine, Florida’s </span><span style="font-weight:400;"><a href="http://www.wesh.com/news/attorney-general-pam-bondi-activates-pricegouging-hotline-for-hermine/41472586">Attorney General Pam Bondi set up a price-gouging hotline that residents can call if they feel they have been unfairly “gouged”</a>.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">The question of fairness is an important one, but anti-price gouging laws aren’t necessarily more fair. </span><span style="font-weight:400;">Price gouging laws prevent information about scarce goods from reaching suppliers, slowing recovery for all. </span><span style="font-weight:400;">Setting a price ceiling can cause shortages, leaving many people without necessities. If prices are allowed to rise in response to such an increase in demand, sellers are likely to move goods to the disaster zone where they are most needed and profitable. Under either situation, there won’t be enough for everyone. </span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Perhaps not surprisingly, most economists oppose laws that prohibit price gouging. For instance, in </span><a href="http://www.igmchicago.org/igm-economic-experts-panel/poll-results?SurveyID=SV_cGhnqM71sWPaoHa"><span style="font-weight:400;">a 2012 poll </span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">of 40 economists at leading research universities in the US, a majority expressed disagreement with a proposed price gouging bill in Connecticut. Agreement is not unanimous, however. </span><a href="http://scholar.princeton.edu/deaton/home"><span style="font-weight:400;">Nobel prize winning economist Angus Deaton</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">, strongly agreed with the proposed anti-price gouging law.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">In the aftermath of a catastrophe, government officials do not immediately have all of the necessary information to help communities recover. Coordinating a recovery effort is inherently complex and difficult to plan for. </span><span style="font-weight:400;">When Hurricane Hermine hit Tallahassee three weeks ago,\xa0</span><a href="http://www.tallahassee.com/story/news/2016/09/01/856-pm-thousands-without-power-tallahassee/89746580/"><span style="font-weight:400;">public officials had to determine how many utility workers would be needed</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> to remove fallen trees from roads and repair downed power lines.</span><span style="font-weight:400;"> Some residents were without power in Tallahassee until a </span><a href="http://www.wctv.tv/content/news/Power-Outage-Information-392096431.html"><span style="font-weight:400;">week</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> after Hermine made landfall. Even in the aftermath of a major natural disaster, the price system (if allowed to function) can quickly send important signals to suppliers and consumers about what and where goods and services are needed most.</span>\n\n<a href="https://fee.org/articles/anti-price-gouging-legislation-endangers-floridians/"><span style="font-weight:400;">As Hurricane Matthew makes landfall, Florida’s price-gouging laws will only slow the return to normalcy</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">. Gas stations in South Florida expect\xa0</span><a href="http://www.tallahassee.com/story/news/2016/10/06/gas-shortages-expected-south-florida/91669430/"><span style="font-weight:400;">shortages</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">, and such shortages are unavoidable\xa0without allowing prices to rise. It’s estimated that </span><span style="font-weight:400;">nearly </span><span style="font-weight:400;"><a href="http://www.usatoday.com/story/money/2016/10/06/how-much-economic-damage-hurricane-matthew-unleash/91692736/">1.4 million residential properties with a reconstruction value of $287 billion are at risk</a>\xa0of damage</span><span style="font-weight:400;">.\xa0Reconstructing damaged property will take time, but would be aided by prices that reflect demand.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Natural disasters are not easy to recoup from, but prices can help spread information about necessary supplies to aid in recovery.</span>'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '767'), ('wp:post_date', '2016-10-07 14:28:36'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2016-10-07 14:28:36'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'anti-price-gouging-laws-hamper-storm-recovery'), ('wp:status', 'publish'), ('wp:post_parent', '0'), ('wp:menu_order', '0'), ('wp:post_type', 'post'), ('wp:post_password', None), ('wp:is_sticky', label='Comment' type='textarea' required='1'/][contact-field label='New Field' type='text'/]")]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_rest_api_published'), ('wp:meta_value', '1')]), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2016/10/ap_16280630167264-0.jpg')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', None), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '769'), ('wp:post_date', '2016-10-07 13:57:09'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2016-10-07 13:57:09'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:meta_value', '/home/wpcom/public_html/wp-content/blogs.dir/848/80998613/files/2016/10/ap_16280630167264-0.jpg')]), OrderedDict([('wp:meta_key', '_wp_attachment_metadata'), ('wp:meta_value', 'a:6:{s:5:"width";i:1280;s:6:"height";i:853;s:4:"file";s:95:"/home/wpcom/public_html/wp-content/blogs.dir/848/80998613/files/2016/10/ap_16280630167264-0.jpg";s:5:"sizes";a:0:{}s:10:"image_meta";a:12:{s:8:"aperture";s:1:"0";s:6:"credit";s:0:"";s:6:"camera";s:0:"";s:7:"caption";s:0:"";s:17:"created_timestamp";s:1:"0";s:9:"copyright";s:0:"";s:12:"focal_length";s:1:"0";s:3:"iso";s:1:"0";s:13:"shutter_speed";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:0:"";s:11:"orientation";s:1:"0";s:8:"keywords";a:0:{}}s:8:"filesize";i:157474;}')])])]), OrderedDict([('title', "Ranking States' Occupational Licensing Regulations"), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/?p=798'), ('pubDate', 'Thu, 13 Oct 2016 14:59:02 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/?p=798')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'By Matt Kelly and Tyler Worthington\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">Government regulation has exploded in recent years. </span><a href="http://regdata.org/the-high-correlation-between-agency-budgets-and-agency-regulations/"><span style="font-weight:400;">Research</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> by the Mercatus Center at George Mason University reveals that federal regulatory restrictions have increased about 150 percent since 1975. </span><a href="http://www.investors.com/politics/perspective/state-and-local-regulations-choke-economic-growth-too-chuck-devore-salim-furth/"><span style="font-weight:400;">State and local regulations have likewise expanded</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">. In Florida, </span><a href="http://licensetowork.ij.org/fl"><span style="font-weight:400;">occupational licensing regulations are particularly restrictive</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> and far reaching. To compare Florida’s occupational licensing laws with other states’, the DeVoe Moore Center created a measure of “regulatory intensity” based on information gathered from state statutes.</span><!--more-->\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">As </span><a href="https://www.mercatus.org/publication/regulatory-accumulation-and-its-costs"><span style="font-weight:400;">regulation accumulates</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">, it can </span><a href="http://www4.ncsu.edu/~jjseater/regulationandgrowth.pdf"><span style="font-weight:400;">diminish economic growth</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">, especially for </span><a href="https://www.entrepreneur.com/article/230727"><span style="font-weight:400;">small businesses</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">. Government regulations increase the cost of doing business, and firms may cut costs by reducing employment, scaling back production, or moving elsewhere to improve profitability. It’s been estimated that federal regulation resulted in a </span><a href="http://mercatus.org/publication/unintended-consequences-federal-regulatory-accumulation"><span style="font-weight:400;">$39 trillion reduction in US GDP between 1949 and 2005</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">. State-level regulations also play a significant role in\xa0</span><a href="http://research.upjohn.org/jrnlarticles/125/"><span style="font-weight:400;">businesses’ location decisions</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">, and can likewise diminish economic growth. </span><a href="https://kansaspolicy.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/kpi-paper-business-perceptions-of-the-economic-impact-of-state-and-local-govt-reg.pdf"><span style="font-weight:400;">A March 2015 study by the Kansas Policy Institute</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> revealed that business owners were most concerned about a lack of transparency and inconsistent enforcement of state and local regulations, a problem that can worsen as regulation accumulates and becomes more complex.</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">One important regulation affecting Florida is occupational licensing. Occupational licenses must be obtained by professionals in regulated occupations before opening shop in Florida. </span><a href="http://reason.org/files/occupational_licensing_florida.pdf"><span style="font-weight:400;">A recent report by the Reason Foundation and the DeVoe Moore Center</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">\xa0highlights the regressive nature of these regulations, which affect about 326 professions in at least 39 industries. Indeed, Florida’s state-level regulations, including occupational licensing laws, are more restrictive than most other states. According to the </span><a href="http://freedominthe50states.org/regulatory"><span style="font-weight:400;">“Freedom in the 50 States” index</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">, Florida ranks 32nd in overall regulation (50 being most restrictive), but ranks 47th in the category of </span><a href="http://freedominthe50states.org/occupational-licensing"><span style="font-weight:400;">occupational licensing regulation</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">. </span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">In order to compare Florida’s regulatory burden to other states, the DeVoe Moore Center constructed a measure of “regulatory intensity” borrowing a </span><a href="http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/rego.12107/abstract;jsessionid=227949C44E93701ACBC528D4C5331553.f01t01"><span style="font-weight:400;">methodology created by economists Patrick McLaughlin and Omar Al-Ubaydli</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> for their </span><a href="http://regdata.org/"><span style="font-weight:400;">Regdata database</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">. The measure is a tally of the number of times particular words (specifically “shall,” “must,” “may not,” “prohibited,” and “required”) appear in the business regulation chapters of a state’s statutes. This data was created using a technology called </span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_scraping"><span style="font-weight:400;">web scraping</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">. The state statutes of Colorado, Massachusetts, Michigan, Nebraska, New Jersey, Oklahoma, and Pennsylvania are organized differently than other states, and are excluded from the sample because consistency in organization is needed to apply web scraping technology. </span>\n\n<a href="https://public.tableau.com/views/StateRestrictionCount/Dashboard1?:embed=y&amp;:display_count=yes"><span style="font-weight:400;">Figure 1</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;"> shows a ranking of US states by this measure of regulatory intensity (with a rank of “1” being most restrictive and "44" the least restrictive). Washington D.C. is also included. Darker shades of red denote a higher count of these “restriction” words. California is a clear outlier, with almost 9,500 more restrictions than the next most restrictive state, Texas. Consistent with other measures, Florida’s occupational licensing regulations have a high degree of “regulatory intensity”, ranking fourth among the states. <a href="https://public.tableau.com/profile/devoe.l.moore.center#!/vizhome/Top25StatesbyOcupationalLicensingRestrictions/Sheet10">Figure 2</a> shows a breakdown of each restriction word for the 25 states where regulatory intensity is highest. The average state had 5996 restriction words in the business regulation chapters of its statutes, while the median state, Kentucky, had 5215.</span>\n\n<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-830" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2016/10/dashboard-1-51.png" alt="dashboard-1-5" width="634" height="648" />\n\n<a href="https://public.tableau.com/views/StateRestrictionCount/Dashboard1?:embed=y&amp;:display_count=yes"><b>Figure 1</b></a><b>: Intensity of Occupational Licensing Regulations by State </b>(Source: Collected\xa0from 43 U.S. state’s statutes relating to occupational licensing, and District of Columbia\'s Ordinances)\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">This measure is not without limitations. The words counted in table 1 carry the legal authority to require and disallow specific activities, but the words before and after them are crucial. For instance, telling professionals they “must” receive some hours of training to be licensed has a different regulatory impact (and likely impact on job growth) than, say, telling professionals they “may not” be employed in a given industry at all. This measure alone cannot convey the quality and kind of regulation, but it can tell us </span><i><span style="font-weight:400;">how much</span></i><span style="font-weight:400;"> regulation has accumulated in states\' statutes.</span>\n\n<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-831" src="https://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2016/10/sheet-10-1.png" alt="sheet-10-1" width="935" height="456" />\n\n<b><a href="https://public.tableau.com/profile/devoe.l.moore.center#!/vizhome/Top25StatesbyOcupationalLicensingRestrictions/Sheet10">Figure 2</a>:\xa0Top 25 States by Occupational Licensing Restrictions\xa0</b><span style="font-weight:400;">(Source: Collected from 43 U.S. state statutes relating to occupational licensing and the District of Columbia\'s Ordinances)</span>\n\n<span style="font-weight:400;">As regulations become more complex, they become more costly to administer and navigate. This can </span><a href="http://www.economist.com/node/21547789"><span style="font-weight:400;">decrease economic growth</span></a><span style="font-weight:400;">. The measures of regulatory intensity presented here help to put Florida’s occupational licensing laws in context with other states. Simplifying state-level regulations would likely stimulate economic growth in the Sunshine State.</span>'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '798'), ('wp:post_date', '2016-10-13 14:59:02'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2016-10-13 14:59:02'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name', 'ranking-states-occupational-licensing-regulations'), ('wp:status', 'draft'), OrderedDict([('title', 'sheet-10-1'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/?attachment_id=831'), ('pubDate', 'Thu, 13 Oct 2016 16:00:37 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoemoorecenter.files.wordpress.com/2016/10/sheet-10-1.png')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', None), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '831'), ('wp:post_date', '2016-10-13 16:00:37'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2016-10-13 16:00:37'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'closed'), ('wp:post_name', OrderedDict([('title', 'Foreclosed Properties Sold to Homeowners Stabilize Property Values'), ('link', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/2016/10/19/foreclosed-properties-sold-to-homeowners-stabilize-property-values/'), ('pubDate', 'Wed, 19 Oct 2016 21:50:19 +0000'), ('dc:creator', 'devoemoorecenter'), ('guid', OrderedDict([('@isPermaLink', 'false'), ('#text', 'http://devoelmoorecenter.com/?p=835')])), ('description', None), ('content:encoded', 'The collapse of the housing market led to an increase in the number of foreclosed residences, with ownership of many reverting to the banks. These are referred to as REO (real estate owned) properties. Recent research concludes the presence of REOs in a neighborhood can lower the property values of nearby homes, but these studies do not consider whether this effect lingers after the REOs are sold. DeVoe Moore Eminent Scholar Keith Ihlanfeldt and Tom Mayock, economist at the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency (and former DMC fellowship recipient), have explored this issue and report their findings in an article titled “The Impact of REO Sales on Neighborhoods and Their Residents.”<!--more-->\n\nThe poor maintenance and disrepair typical of REOs may account for their detrimental effect on the values of surrounding residences. Ihlanfeldt and Mayock hypothesized an REO property will continue to exert this effect even after it is sold if the buyer is an investor but not if the buyer will reside in the home. Their reasoning is that an investor is more likely to convert an REO to a rental unit than to “flip” or rehab and resell it, and an investor with a rental property is less motivated than an owner-occupant to provide for needed upkeep and repairs. However, the researchers also hypothesized the negative effect of an REO bought by an investor will lessen over time.\n\nTo test their hypotheses, Ihlanfeldt and Mayock examined data on the sales of single-family homes in ten Florida counties since the housing bust. They estimated the effects on housing price of an array of variables, including structural characteristics of the home and external factors such as changes in quality of neighborhood schools, employment trends and seasonality of the real estate market. Their variables of interest, though, were proximity to four types of housing: ex-REOs owned by investors, ex-REOs occupied by owners, current REOs, and single-family rentals not previously in REO status.\n\nResults were as expected. In general, owner-occupied ex-REOs appear not to influence property values of nearby residences. Investor-owned ex-REOs, current REOs, and non-REO rentals, on the other hand, lower the values of neighboring properties. Additionally, the effect of investor-owned REOs tends to decrease over time until it is no greater than the effect exhibited by non-REO rentals. Ihlanfeldt and Mayock suggest that investors may take longer than owner-occupants to catch up on the repairs needed for the REOs they purchase, but do eventually remedy the neglect. They also remark on another possible consequence of REO sales – opening up housing opportunities in better neighborhoods – as a topic for future study.\n\nFor a full discussion of the background to this research, the methodology used, and detailed results, the article can be found in the <em>Journal of Real Estate Finance and Economics</em> at <a href="http://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11146-014-9465-0">http://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11146-014-9465-0</a>. It is one of the papers presented at a 2013 DeVoe Moore Center Critical Issues Symposium on housing market issues.'), ('excerpt:encoded', None), ('wp:post_id', '835'), ('wp:post_date', '2016-10-19 21:50:19'), ('wp:post_date_gmt', '2016-10-19 21:50:19'), ('wp:comment_status', 'open'), ('wp:ping_status', 'open'), ('wp:post_name',
